title: Warren Fends Off Party Challenger in Massachusetts Race
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  In a display of political muscle, Elizabeth Warren overwhelmingly won the state Democratic Partys endorsement on Saturday for the United States Senate seat held by Scott P. Brown, a Republican. With the size of her victory, she avoided a party primary in September.

title: Pakistan Acquits Four Men in Times Square Bomb Plot
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court on Saturday acquitted four men accused of assisting Faisal Shahzad, the Taliban-trained militant who tried to explode a car bomb in Times Square two years ago, a lawyer and several relatives said.

title: Quakes Deal Irreparable Blow to an Italian Regions Cultural Heritage
description: MIRANDOLA, Italy  With every new quiver here, something crumbles or new cracks appear. The second of two major earthquakes last month compounded the emergency, and we had to start monitoring everything from scratch.

title: Court Rivals May Someday Vie on Distant Field

At the time, Kevin Garnett was an 8-year-old in South Carolina and LeBron James had not been born. But when the same two soccer clubs meet July 28 at Fenway Park as part of their United States summer tours, James and Garnett are likely to be there as minority owners, James for Liverpool and Garnett for Roma.

description: When I wrote my first short story, I used my cat Moses as a muse. I created a world where he was a wise old tabby barn cat wearing a leather collar with a brass nameplate who interacted with everyone at the track and bettered their lives. Imagine my surprise when I walked past Security Gate 5 at Churchill Downs the week before this years Kentucky Derby and was greeted by Bill, an old tabby cat wearing the same exact collar. I stopped to return his affection and the security guards proudly told me that he ran Churchill Downs, and in his day, probably fathered most of the kittens around.

Another smiled often, and preferred to talk about Buddhism rather than politics. A third man, a former monk, liked herding animals with nomads.

Lincoln, it was disclosed, had married a man (Take a look at a photo of Mary Todd Lincoln and youll be convinced) and given birth to six children. All this, however, is ho-hum compared with the revelations in the coming film Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, in which our 16th president is, basically, Buffy in a stovepipe hat.

Lincoln acquiesced, though not without pointing out that Schurz was giving up prestige, comfort, and a large salary for a position that paid little and would bring plenty of work, discomfort, and danger.

Tourtellott of San Diego and Judge John M. Thompson of Santee, Calif. Parcells of Lititz, Pa., and Steven J. Parcells of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Martin Padovani performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake.

description: Kelly Morgan Strauss and Jason Eric Geisler were married Saturday evening at the Pierre hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Matthew Reimer performed the ceremony.

title: Claudia Gabel and Benjamin Lindvall
description: Claudia Ann Gabel and Benjamin Lloyd Lindvall were married Saturday at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall, the bridegrooms father and the churchs head pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Dorian Batt, Amir Vardi
description: Dr. Dorian Samantha Batt and Amir Vardi were married Saturday by Rabbi Eric B. Wisnia at the Grounds for Sculpture, a park in Hamilton, N.J.

description: Dr. Alisse Katherine Hauspurg and Dr. Adam James Janicki were married Saturday at Saltwater Farm Vineyard in Stonington, Conn. The ceremony was led by Jim R. Moss, an uncle of the bridegroom, who became a Universal Life Minister for the event.

title: Beth Scott, Anthony Sebro Jr.
description: Beth Shawna Scott and Anthony Kenneth Sebro Jr. are to be married Sunday at Church of the Advent Hope in New York. The Rev. K. Todd Stout, a Seventh-day Adventist minister and the churchs pastor, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Tamar Glatt, James Rubin
description: Dr. Tamar Nina Glatt, a daughter of Dr. Lisa S. Waxman and Dr. Sander L. Glatt of Overland Park, Kan., is to be married Sunday to James Lawrence Rubin, a son of Alicia and Kenneth Rubin of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Corey M. Helfand is to officiate at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Debra Elias, Seth Grossman
description: Debra Jill Elias and Seth Sherman Grossman were married Saturday at the Crescent Beach Club in Bayville, N.Y. Judge Guido Calabresi of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk in 2006 and 2007, officiated.

title: How Horrible Wars Can Be
description: HONG KONG  Too hot! she was screaming. Too hot!

title: Another Good Night for Brodeur, but Only a Great One Would Do
description: NEWARK  Martin Brodeur tried planting his stick on the ice to stop Jeff Carters shot from the high slot, but Brodeur made his move a split-second too late. The Los Angeles Kings then swarmed Carter to celebrate as Brodeur skated off the ice, another good night undone.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Open magazine takes a look at Pakistans newly liberated media and reports that it is taking on India bashers.

title: Kings Doughty Rises to Potential, at Just the Right Time
description: NEWARK  The best defenseman on the top pairing on the hottest team in the N.H.L. logged the most ice time in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night, just as he did in the series opener. Drew Doughty of the Kings tallied Los Angeless first goal, and he gazed helplessly from five feet away when the Devils tied the score. He delivered several crushing hits, and he committed what could have been a critical penalty in the waning minutes of regulation.

title: David Wrights Contract Non-Situation
description: David Wright repeated on Saturday that he did not wish to negotiate a new contract during the season.

title: Vikram Gandhis Documentary Kumar
description: In his early 20s Vikram Gandhi, a fledgling Indian-American filmmaker from New Jersey, decided to make a documentary about the yoga industry in the United States, focusing on its offshoot, the guru,Kathryn Shattuck  writes in The New York Times.

title: A Quietly Mesmerizing Novel Set in the Himalayas
description: Late in this quietly mesmerizing novel, set in a Himalayan hill town in the north of India, Andrea Thompson writes  in The Sunday Book Review section of The New York Times, Anuradha Roy describes the crystalline beauty of the peaks in winter, viewed long after the haze of the summer months and the fog of the monsoon, held in secret for those who choose to brave the cold.

title: Common Goals Demand a United Front
description: It has been more than a year since I published my first, and last, book, Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy. The entire experience has been life-altering, including managing the Web site that provided daily updates on Barbaro; researching the book, which included a two-year stint working for the trainer Steve Asmussen; writing the book; and selling it.

title: Russias Stance on Syria Poses a Challenge for E.U.
description: BRUSSELS  European Union-Russia summit meetings havent changed much since the last time Vladimir V. Putin was president, which was five years ago. Then, as now, there were talks about energy and the economic and investment climate in Russia. Sore spots: visa rules and Russian bans on imports of certain European farm products.
Update below

title: Assad Condemns Houla Massacre, Blaming Terrorists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad denied Sunday that the Syrian government played a role in the massacre in the village of Houla, using his first speech in five months to reiterate his line that foreigners were fomenting the violence in Syria.

title: At the Spoleto Festival USA, Chamber Music Continues to Fly Under the Radar
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The big classical music draws at the Spoleto Festival USA are usually the operas: this year, Philip Glasss Kepler and Guo Wenjings Feng Yi Ting (which will make its way to the Lincoln Center Festival next month). But if comparatively few festivalgoers travel to Charleston specifically for the chamber music concerts, they have been a popular and consistent part of this 35-year-old festivals personality from the start.

title: Ashley Biden and Howard Krein
description: Ashley Blazer Biden, the daughter of Jill Jacobs Biden and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Howard David Krein, a son of Bunny Lipner Krein and Stanley Krein of Cherry Hill, N.J. The Rev. David F. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Church in Greenville, Del., with Rabbi Joseph Forman assisting.

title: Britain Celebrates Queens 60-Year Reign
description: LONDON  Braving a day of bone-chilling, rain-dampened weather, a crowd estimated by the police at more than a million people lined the banks of the Thames on Sunday to acclaim Queen Elizabeth II as she marked 60 years on the throne with a royal river pageant of a kind last seen 350 years ago.

title: Playing Too Well for Your Own Good
Swimming in Sync At a London Hotel
description: Women with a case of Olympic fever can try to ease it with a dip in the pool at The Berkeley hotel in London, where synchronized swimming classes are being offered this summer.

title: Charlotte Decker and Gabriel Morgan
description: Charlotte Wanita Decker and Gabriel Adam Morgan were married Saturday afternoon at Blackberry Farm, a resort in Walland, Tenn. The Rev. Celeste A. Schroeder, a minister of the Light of Christ Community Church, officiated.

title: A Sport That Inspires a Sharp Wit
description: For all the eloquent and evocative writing there has been about golf, some of the best contributions to the lore, appreciation and understanding of the game have been spoken. There have been funny and perceptive things uttered about other sports, but there just seem to be more memorable quotations about golf. Here are a few of my favorites.

title: Katherine Hynes and Thomas Scott
description: Katherine Vance Hynes, a daughter of Anne Marie and James Hynes of Riverside, Conn., was married Saturday in Greenwich, Conn., to Thomas Everett Scott, a son of Darby A. Scott and Daniel T. Scott of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Ciprian Bejan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel in the Convent of the Sacred Heart school, from which the bride graduated.

title: Alison Butterfass and John Zagat
description: Alison Lauren Butterfass, a daughter of Susan Morris Butterfass and Stephen Eliot Butterfass of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Dr. John Alexander Zagat, a son of Nina Zagat and Tim Zagat of New York, are to be married Sunday in New York. Cantor Steve Sher is to officiate at the Water Club.

title: Xbox Gives Microsoft a Head Start in the Battle for Every Screen
description: Given the relentless battles by tech companies to win new smartphone users, you would think that the tiny screen is the only one that matters.

title: Thames Flotilla Highlight of Diamond Jubilee Celebrations
description: Tens of thousands gathered in London to celebrate Queen Elizabeth IIs diamond jubilee with an extravagant river pageant.

title: Lawsuit Shakes Mans World of Tech
description: Are the men who invented the Internet trapped in the past even as they create the future? Thats the debate that has sprung up here since Ellen Pao, a junior partner in her early 40s at the distinguished venture capital firm of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, filed a sexual discrimination lawsuit against the company and her colleagues there, reports David Streitfeld in Sundays New York Times. Although the accusations have yet to be heard in court, even some of Ms. Paos critics concede that she is exposing an uncomfortable truth about Silicon Valley: starting tech companies in 2012 is still a male game, and so is funding them.

title: Adjustable Drivers Fix Some Problems While Posing Others
description: With the market flooded with adjustable drivers, I wondered if these new tools were affecting golf instruction. Are people no longer asking their pros to fix their driver swings because all their problems are fixable by opening or closing the face with a click of a wrench or by moving some weights in the club head?

title: Cooler Weather Brings Trouble for Top Players at French Open
description: PARIS  The weather changed at the French Open, and the top of the tennis pyramid shook.

title: Euro Zone Is Lurching to a Crossroad
description: LONDON  As Spains economic crisis deepens and uncertainty swirls over Greeces future in the euro zone, the guardians of the increasingly fragile European monetary union are near a moment of truth: can they muster the will and resources to keep the euro zone from breaking apart?

title: Warming Arctic Tundra Producing Pop-Up Forests
description: Even as insect infestations and other factors accompanying warming have led to the browning of some stretches of boreal forest between temperate regions and the Arctic tundra, the tundra appears to be greening in a big way, various studies have shown. The newest such work, focused on scrubby windswept regions along Russias northwest Arctic coast, has found a particularly noteworthy shift is under way.

title: Obeying Judges Order, Zimmerman Turns Himself In and Is Back in a Florida Jail
description: MIAMI  Six weeks after being released from jail on bond, George Zimmerman, who is facing second-degree murder charges in the death of Trayvon Martin, is back behind bars.

title: In the Disability, Stress the Ability
description: Push Girls, a reality show about five attractive women in wheelchairs, is likely to engender a number of reactions in viewers, not all of them helpful to the cause of illuminating the lives of people with disabilities. From the premiere, showing Monday night on the Sundance Channel, its not entirely clear which of those reactions the seriess creators are going for. But the intent seems to be good, and if they can find the elusive line between voyeuristic and didactic, the show could become something of a milestone for a lot of people who have felt invisible for a long time.

title: A Fairy-Tale Weekend for Snow White and the Huntsman
description: Kristen Stewart, some gnarly dwarfs and a bloody fairy tale prevailed, as Snow White and the Huntsman led the weekend box-office results at North American theaters with about $56.3 million in ticket sales for Universal Pictures. It was an impressive feat, because the film opened without a 3-D version and the accompanying higher-priced tickets, though it took some technology to squeeze the likes of Bob Hoskins and Ray Winstone into their diminutive roles.

title: A $1 Cigarette Tax Starts a $47 Million Brawl in California
description: LOS ANGELES  California has some of the toughest antismoking laws in the country  it is illegal, in some places, to smoke in your own apartment  and boasts the second-lowest per capita smoking rate in the 50 states. But for all the disdain toward smoking, it has been 14 years since California raised its cigarette tax, a tribute to the power of the tobacco industry here and the waning of this states antitobacco dominance.

title: Velazquez Teams With Union Rags for Impressive Work
description: ELKTON, Md.  John Velazquez made the journey from New York to Fair Hill Training Center in Maryland on Sunday morning to ride Union Rags for the first time. Union Rags was scheduled to put in his final work, ahead of Saturdays Belmont Stakes. Things could not have gone more perfectly.

title: Feel the Fraudulence
description: Apparently I said something harsh but true this morning.

title: A Daddy for Annie
description: The Broadway-bound Annie has found its Daddy. The Australian opera and musical-theater singer Anthony Warlow will make his Broadway debut as the billionaire industrialist Daddy Warbucks in the coming revival of the 1977 musical, the shows producers announced on Sunday. Mr. Warlow will star opposite the previously announced cast members Katie Finneran as Miss Hannigan and Lilla Crawford as Annie.

title: Granderson Calls for More Accountability for Umpires
description: DETROIT  Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson used Saturday nights ejections of the hitting coach Kevin Long and Manager Joe Girardi by the plate umpire Bob Davidson to call for greater accountability for umpires.

title: The Level of Government Spending
description: A quick note on what has happened to the level of government spending since the economic crisis began.

title: Philip Glass, at Spoleto USA as Speaker and Spectator, Also Performs
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Philip Glass was not at the first performances of Kepler, his opera about the German mathematician and astronomer that opened here at the Spoleto Festival USA on May 26. But he flew in for the closing performance of the run, on Saturday. And while he was in town, he sat for an hourlong public interview and an impromptu performance at the Dock Street Theater on Saturday afternoon, as part of the festivals Music in Time series.

title: Forces of Nature and Ecstasy
description: Since the conductor and composer Julian Wachner became the director of music and arts at Trinity Wall Street in September 2010 he has pursued at least two distinct agendas. He has increased the amount of contemporary music performed by the churchs admirable Trinity Choir, bolstering that move by inaugurating a new instrumental ensemble, Novus NY. He has also taken steps to make the choir more visible outside its native habitat of Lower Manhattan, like mounting one of its cherished annual performances of Handels Messiah at Alice Tully Hall last year.

title: A Line Dance Charged With Meaning
description: The dabke is a line dance of the Levant. At weddings in Jordan, Lebanon and Syria, people link up arm to shoulder or hand in hand and stomp out rhythms and patterns. Israelis, so often at odds with their neighbors, also have a version. Dances are easier to share than territory.

title: Tunes From Screwy Bally-Hooey Warner Brothers
description: Attention all ye would-be hosts, writers and performers aspiring to the venerable 92nd Street Y series Lyrics & Lyricists. The season finale, Its Magic: Nine Decades of Songs From Warner Brothers, is a master class on how to escape the pitfalls of stuffy nostalgic reverence and make show business history crackle. Solemnity is the enemy, enthusiasm the key and insiders gossip the secret ingredient. A sample: Kissing Ronald Reagan, Alexis Smith once confided to Rex Reed, the shows host and writer, was like licking an elbow. Theres a lot more where that came from.

title: A Sly Take on Creativity
description: When youre sitting before Rebecca Patek, you must be patient. Um, she said at the start of her performance, Real Eyes, at the Chocolate Factory on Thursday night. Hi. Um. Im Rebecca. Um.

title: Carmina Burana Specialists From Spain Enliven a Favorite
description: The veteran Spanish conductor Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos gave the New York Philharmonic audience everything it had come to Avery Fisher Hall for on Thursday evening, and more. (The concert was the first in a subscription series that ended on Saturday.)

title: Yawns to Laughs: Audiences Shape a Play
description: During rehearsals for his new Off Broadway play, Storefront Church, John Patrick Shanley rewrote the final scene 20 times before he was satisfied. But it wasnt until the productions first preview, on May 16, that he discovered other scenes needed revising too. The evidence came from audiences  the sort of patrons who pay to attend Off Broadway shows early on and have more power than they may realize to shape new plays, even one by a Pulitzer Prize winner like Mr. Shanley (Doubt).

title: With Eye on Qualifying, Michael Bradley Is Eager to Get Back to Work
description: With the United States national team set to take on Canada Sunday night at Torontos BMO Field, midfielder Michael Bradley is anxious to get back onto the field after Wednesdays 4-1 loss to Brazil.

title: Japan Arrests Fugitive Wanted in 1995 Gas Attack
description: TOKYO  The police on Sunday arrested one of the two remaining fugitive suspects from the doomsday cult behind the 1995 nerve-gas attack on the Tokyo subway, Japanese media reported.

title: Out of Dark, Onto Field
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  Bob Bradley stood at attention as a full military band played the anthem of his adoptive country. In front of him, Egypts national soccer team, which he began managing about nine months ago, was lined up on the field at the 80,000-capacity Borg el Arab military stadium, the players singing proudly.

title: A Jail Guards Tale of His Journey to Inmate
description: Gary Heyward stood on 125th Street in Harlem, not far from the Apollo Theater, wearing a jumpsuit that was half blue and half orange.

title: I.S.S. Backs Two Starboard Nominees for AOL Board
description: Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended that AOL investors vote for two of three board candidates named by Starboard Value, an activist hedge fund.

title: Contemporary Movement With a Foot (or a Leg) in Earlier Times
description: Contemporary dance in America is often described as experimental. One unfortunate result of such lazy contextualizing, often, is to obscure that these artists, however progressive-minded, are working within and influenced by very distinct movement traditions. Twenty-first-century choreographers arent breaking new ground, at least not in the old sense of the avant-garde  and that isnt a bad thing.

title: Yankees Solve Verlander, Ending Trip on High Note
description: DETROIT  Seventeen seasons of playing for the Yankees have conditioned Derek Jeter to expect scenes like this, and to make fun of them.

title: Loneliness of 7-Eleven for Indian Immigrant
description: Dhiraj, the Indian immigrant father in Mayank Keshaviahs unsatisfying play Rangoon, a Pan Asian Repertory production, is like a Tiger Dad mixed with a Jewish mother. He loves to guilt-trip his children and has such high expectations for them that when his son brings home an excellent report card, he still gets scolded: An A minus is not an A.

title: William Hanley, Playwright and TV Writer, Dies at 80
description: William Hanley, who received critical acclaim as a Broadway and Off Broadway playwright in the 1960s and who later won Emmys for television scripts, died on May 25 at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 80.

title: Philosophys Western Bias
description: There is much talk in academic philosophy about the need to open up the discipline to so-called non-Western traditions and perspectives, both through changes to the curriculum and also within the demographics of philosophy departments themselves. These two aspects are seen as connected: it is thought that greater representation of non-Western philosophy will help to bring about greater diversity among the women and men who make up the philosophical community.

title: Stick Episodes Aside, Kings Feeling Comfortable With 2-0 Series Lead
description: The feeling now is that the Kings will win the Stanley Cup, and that only the details (number of games, parade route) need to be worked out. Whether or not that bears out, the teams second consecutive 2-1 overtime victory against the Devils  after a circular tour of the Devils zone by Jeff Carter that was as mesmerizing as Anze Kopitars breakaway in Game 1  lifted a weight off of the organization that had been lingering for 19 years.

title: Richard Dawson, Host Who Kissed on Family Feud, Dies at 79
description: Richard Dawson, the British-born actor and comedian who played a larcenous prisoner of war on the comedy Hogans Heroes and became a star as the dapper and gregarious host of the game show Family Feud, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Winning Start for Bradleys Egypt, but Challenges Are Many
description: Bob Bradley on Friday coached his first World Cup qualifier since being hired as Egypts manager last year, but he did so in an empty stadium  a consequence of the violence that plagued the country in general and soccer games in particular in the wake of the overthrow of the former president Hosni Mubarak. James Montague was in Alexandria for the game, reporting on the hardships, the sadness, the challenges and the pride Bradley feels as he tries to lead the Pharoahs back to their customary place atop African soccer.

title: Metalheads of All Alloys, Swirling Into the Night
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At the end of a loud, slow and steadying set on Saturday night by the doom-metal band Saint Vitus, its singer Scott Weinrich, known as Wino, methodically distributed Pabst Blue Ribbon tall boys to members of the audience and sang an old song, Born Too Late, over big riffs, a restful tempo and a minor key. It was music with little anxiety.

title: Orbiting the Grid
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome back for another week of solving!

title: Talent Agency Adds Brand Strategy Unit
description: A TALENT agency whose clients bear names that are like brands in Hollywood  among them, Johnny Depp, Channing Tatum, Judd Apatow and Jennifer Lopez  is getting more deeply into the brand-building business.

title: When Defending Earth Cost 25 Cents
description: LACONIA, N.H.  You insert a token. With a joystick and a button you blast away at robots, spaceships and meteors advancing from all sides. Eventually your last man dies. Game over.

title: An Actor Finds a Role Too Real
description: Paris on the brink. World War II looming. A place of culinary, erotic, conversational, sartorial and so many other pleasures. A place of elegance and discretion. The aromas of a thousand years of rain dripping on stone, of rough black tobacco and garlic and drains. And now, the smell of fear too.

title: Lifting Off to Copland and Stucky
description: Clara Longstreth, the music director of the estimable New Amsterdam Singers, has a knack for putting together engaging programs with a thematic hook. But as she notes on the choruss Web site, a theme is only good if every piece is a winner, not included just because it serves a theme.

title: Tribute to Composer Revered for Her Iconoclastic Ways
description: Darmstadt Institute, an annual new-music festival founded in 2008 by the New York composers Nick Hallett and Zach Layton, has become one of the citys most reliable sources for concerts as entertaining as they are edifying. Equally important, the series is a crowbar meant to pry open a rigid canon and admit outliers whose work, however obscure, has proved significant and durable.

title: Playing the Blues While Inside Prison Walls
description: Filmed at the Louisiana State Penitentiary, Music From the Big House, Bruce McDonalds loosely built documentary, yields the cognitive dissonance of being entertained by performers convicted of rape, murder and other offenses. The Canadian blues singer Rita Chiarelli acts as our ambassador to a realm of life sentences and strained redemption as she and the inmates put on a concert within this notorious prison known as Angola, formerly the site of a slave plantation.

title: New Tabloid by Murdoch Losing Sales
description: LONDON  Rupert Murdoch has endured a litany of blows in the unending phone-hacking scandal at his British tabloids. But one setback isnt happening in Parliament, but on Britains newsstands.

title: Reisinger Knockout Teams in New York City
description: The 52-board final of the Reisinger Knockout Teams took place on Thursday and Friday evenings at the Manhattan Bridge Club. After three low-scoring quarters Margie Gwozdzinsky, Ira Herman, Pietro Campanile, Brian Glubok, Allen Kahn and Jeffrey Rothstein led by 21 international match points.

title: Pregame: Canada vs. U.S.
description: The United and Canada share a long soccer history that dates to 1925, the first official international, won by Canada in Montreal, 1-0, on June 27. The American team has a 13-8-9 overall record against Canada and is riding a 14-game unbeaten streak (8-0-6) since losing by 2-0 in Vancouver, British Columbia on April 2, 1985.

title: Valentino to Create Ballet Costumes
description: The Italian designer Valentino Garavani will create costumes for three works by the New York City Ballet, to be performed for one night at its annual fall gala, the company is to announce on Monday. The gala, to be held at Lincoln Center on Sept. 20, will feature a new ballet set to selections from Tchaikovskys Eugene Onegin and a performance of George Balanchines Rubies as a tribute to the signature use of red by the designer simply known as Valentino, above. There is so much beauty in the ballet, the grace, the fluidity, Valentino said in a news release. He said he was honored to have City Ballet celebrate my work in this way, and I am very passionate about the design of these very special costumes. Benefit-priced tickets for the gala are available at (212) 870-5585. Tickets to the performance only go on sale Aug. 6 through (212) 496-0600 or nycballet.com.

title: Carly Simon to Share Her Life Story in Book
description: Carly Simon is joining the pack of musicians who have gone from writing and performing for the stage to telling all in memoirs. Random House announced on Sunday that it would publish Ms. Simons autobiography  the story of her childhood, the discovery of her life-altering stammer, her meteoric rise and unparalleled career in music, and her loves, including her marriage to James Taylor. Ms. Simon, above, a daughter of Richard L. Simon, a founder of Simon & Schuster, said she had an early awareness of the publishing industry, writing in a diary even as a child. After years of keeping journals and writing lyrics for my tunes, I have developed a strong interest in seeing how my life might just string together in a longer form, she said in a statement. I know Ill be looking for a strong chorus, like a repeating dream or theme. Ms. Simon told Reuters in a recent interview that she was busy writing her book and planned to finish it by years end. Susan Kamil, the publisher of Random House, said in an e-mail that Ms. Simons prose on the page is powerful, evocative, narrative driven, and the stories she tells are riveting. title: Lindsay Lohans New Wave
description: In First Point, his new short film, the artist Richard Phillips combines two of his current obsessions: surfing and Lindsay Lohan. Phillips has worked with the actress and tabloid goddess before, on a 90-second video for Neville Wakefields Commercial Break, which had a very brief run during the 54th Venice Biennale. And his studio is lined with several larger-than-life paintings of Lohan that came directly out of that particular project. But dont call Lohan his muse. Lohan, Phillips insists, is his collaborator as much as anyone in the stellar cast of people who worked on the film, including the legendary surf filmmaker Taylor Steele; the professional surfer Kassia Meador, who performs mesmerizingly as Lohans body double; the editor Jay Rabinowitz; and Thomas Bangalter, one half of the electro duo Daft Punk, who composed the ominously swelling score. As the trailer implies, First Point is at once a surf film and a film noir, an exploration of the California dream and the Hollywood nightmare, worlds that Lohan doesnt have to pretend to straddle on screen. But no doubt the question on everyones lips when First Point has its premiere next week at Art Unlimited, the curated section of the Art Basel fair, will be: Is it art? And that is just fine by Phillips. Its just like in my paintings, he says. Because of the actor and the popular culture dimensions of the project, it will give people  especially people in the art world  a real sense of instability with regard to my intentions. Is it a film? Is it an art video? It refuses to announce itself as either.

She was talking about her resort collection, which will deliver to stores in November and stay there for almost four months, through the holidays and into the new year. Its about transition now, and livening up what you already have in your winter wardrobe, she said. Not everyone goes to the beach. Pointing to looks like this one  a draping viscose and wool skirt paired with a clean, black V-neck tank  Cornejo made references to cities like New York and Berlin (where one could quickly make use any of the collections leather pieces, too), and suggested Art Basel in Miami as a perfect place to wear the complete range, from swimwear to evening wear and every dorky sort of look with a white shirt buttoned up in between.

title: Tibet: Negotiators Resign
description: Two senior envoys of the Dalai Lama who negotiated with China in nine rounds of talks have resigned, according to the Tibetan government-in-exile in India. The envoys, Lodi Gyari and Kelsang Gyaltsen, said in a statement that they were resigning because of the deteriorating situation inside Tibet, which, since 2009, has prompted 38 Tibetans to set themselves on fire. The envoys expressed disappointment over Chinas rejection of a plan for genuine autonomy for Tibet put forward by the Dalai Lama in 2008, and they said current circumstances made substantive dialogue difficult. The last round of talks took place in 2010. The Tibetan exile government said a task force on talks would meet again in December, after China announces its new leadership in the fall, with the aim of renewing negotiations.

title: El Salvador: Canadian Lawsuit Over Mine Allowed to Proceed
description: A Canadian companys lawsuit against El Salvador for blocking a gold mine can proceed under the countrys investment law but not under the provisions of the Central America Free Trade Agreement, a World Bank panel ruled Friday. In a case closely watched by environmentalists and the mining industry, the panel, the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, will make a binding decision on whether El Salvador unfairly failed to license the mine proposed by the Pacific Rim Mining Corporation or had the sovereign right to reject it after the company already made investments. Environmentalists had hoped the panel would reject the case outright and slow the spread of mining in Central America.

title: Syria: Heavy Clashes Reported
description: A Syrian activist group reported that at least 80 soldiers were killed over the weekend in clashes with rebels, which would be one of the largest losses for government forces since the uprising began in March 2011. The report, by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, could not be independently confirmed. The group also told Reuters that rebels had overrun army checkpoints in the northern town of Ariha, and a photo, right, released by activists was said to show damaged army tanks in the town. The reports cast further doubt on the viability of a truce plan arranged by Kofi Annan, an envoy of the United Nations and the Arab League. He plans to brief the United Nations Security Council this week and will also meet with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has said President Bashar al-Assad of Syria must resign as part of any solution to the conflict.

title: Now Playing | Fifty Years of the CFDA
description: Last night the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA) Fashion Awards took place at Lincoln Centers Alice Tully Hall in New York. There, industry members gathered to commemorate the organizations 50th anniversary, to recognize the years most exciting contributions to fashion design and journalism, and to celebrate the lifetime achievements of some of the businesss biggest creative influences. Kicking off the evenings ceremony was this short film, 50 Years of the CFDA, directed by Zoe Cassavetes and inspired by Richard Avedons 1969 portraits of Andy Warhol and members of the Factory. I think it came out as half film, half art collage, noted Cassavetes about the project. Of her subjects she said: I was pretty blown away by the talent that came through the studio during those two days [we were shooting]. It was interesting to see which designers are inspired by others and why. Its not just about the clothes they make  its about the universe they create. title: Death Penalty Death Watch: Mississippi
description: There is really only one rationale for the death penalty: Vengeance. Supporters of capital punishment talk about deterrence, but theres scant evidence that the threat of dying at the hands of the state actually reduces violent crime. On the contrary, as Princetons Peter Singer wrote in October, murder rates in Europe and other Western industrialized nations are lower, often much lower, than those in the US. In the US itself, the 16 states that have abolished the death penalty generally have lower murder rates than those that retain it.

description: And though a recent federal appeals court ruling has provided some hope to gays and lesbians that their unions could potentially be recognized by the federal government, nothing has changed just yet. title: Going Nuts for Smoothies
description: When I make a smoothie I like to make a meal out of it, or at least make something substantial enough to get me through my morning swim. But I dont like to bulk up my smoothies with protein powders or brewers yeast, supplements I used to add when I was first a vegetarian years ago and we didnt know much about how to get protein and certain B vitamins from plant sources. Now protein powders, the stuff of many an athletes blended drink, seem too processed to me. And I dont like to add anything that doesnt improve the taste of a blended drink, which rules out brewers yeast.

The shoes  clunky sandals with big candy ball stones and awkward, cartoon-character loafers  looked a little too big on the models. Make no mistake, though. Jacobs wasnt just clowning around. He knows his customers and knows that their eyes will have adjusted to ballooning skirts and funny fitting jackets (see fall) by the time resort hits stores. Jacobs also knows very well how to design commercial successes and sprinkle them between his experiments. These calf-length shifts, their fronts covered with glossy sequin florals and topped with jesters bows at the neck, like so, will wow and wear effortlessly.

title: Through a Courtyard, Ambitious Pork
description: There is more than one way to put some pig in a sandwich. Ralf Kuettel (right), the chef and owner of Trestle on Tenth, channels Northern Europe instead of Tennessee or Italy in the sandwich hell be serving at his new shop, Rocket Pig, using seasonings like juniper, mustard and bay leaves to flavor hunks of pork neck and shoulder, which he brines, then smokes and roasts. The compact shop, which opens next week, is behind the restaurant, reachable through a rusted gate and a charming little brick courtyard. There are counters for eating, as well as access to the restaurants garden. Raw oysters, cheeses, cured meats, potato chips, cookies, brownies and wine and beer round out the menu. Other items, like salads, soups and sausages, may be added in coming months. Everything, except for the alcoholic beverages, can be packed to go. And with the High Line entrance a block away, why not?

title: The Best Summer Olympics Movies (With a Few Asterisks)

title: From a TV Chef, Bottoms Up in Baking Pans
description: The latest addition to the line of cookware and serving pieces from Curtis Stone, the chef and television personality, is a trio of baking pans that combine heavy-duty steel with silicone liners. The cake, loaf and muffin pans have built-in silicone bottoms that can be popped up, making it easier to release their contents. Mr. Stone said he developed many of the cookware items sold under his name after filming the reality series Take Home Chef, in which he randomly finds people in a supermarket and goes to their homes to help them cook a meal. I got real insight into what people go through in the kitchen and how inadequate their equipment often is, he said. My products are not just endorsements. I hope Im solving problems.

title: A Latino Basic Goes Vegetarian
description: Young women embarking on a new artisanal food venture has become a familiar story. Susana Columna and Gloribell Tavera, both of whom lost their jobs in television, now make sofrito, a base for Latino dishes that is as essential as roux in New Orleans or mirepoix in France. (Soffrito is the Italian version.) Though sofrito is often made with pork or pork fat, Chulitas Famous Sofrito, produced in Long Island City, Queens, is vegetarian. Unlike a mass-market sofrito, it has no added starches, thickeners or other additives. There are two varieties: a verde, with bell peppers, garlic, lemon juice, vinegar and herbs; and a spiced one that is ruddy, dense and less moist, with similar ingredients as well as a good dose of paprika and cumin. Use them to get that bean and pork stew, chicken casserole or paella going; they can also serve as salsa, garnish or embellishment for a bowl of soup.

title: Big Government, Small Families
description: Last week I had the pleasure of joining the Washington Posts E.J. Dionne on The Diane Rehm Show for a discussion of his engaging new book, Our Divided Political Heart, which is both a meditation on the individualistic and communitarian strands in American political thought and history, and (as you might expect, given the author) a lament that the contemporary Republican Party has tilted the contemporary balance dangerously toward a radical individualism. My main criticism of his thesis (also perhaps predictably) was to question Dionnes tendency to equate community with government, given the way expansions of state power tend to crowd out more personal and/or voluntary forms of common life (civic, religious, familial), replacing human-scale interactions with bureaucratic process and leaving society more atomized than before. To which he responded that while this can happen, it doesnt have to happen: Government can strengthen local communities as well as weaken them, partner with private groups as well pre-empt them, and fill in the gaps left by purely voluntary effort as well as take those efforts place. Conceding that reality, I nonetheless tried to press Dionne a bit more on whether given where we are now, with a large-scale and costly welfare state having become a permanent feature of our national life even as more local and personal forms of community have attenuated, the conservative-communitarian suspicion of state power might not be more relevant than the liberal-communitarian view of the state as an instrument of social solidarity.

title: Djokovic and Federer Survive to Set Up French Open Semifinal Clash

title: Darfur War Crimes Prosecutor Urges Tougher Action Against Sudan President

title: Gay Marriage Inches Towards the Supreme Court

Last Thursday, the First Circuit ruled against the Defense of Marriage Act, which prohibits granting federal benefits to same-sex couples. Today, the Ninth Circuit declined to review an earlier decision by a three-judge panel against Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in California.

title: Savoring Movers Over the Moves
description: If you are a balletomane, caring more about dancers than choreography, then the casting of John Crankos three-act ballet Onegin (1965) brings excitements. When I first watched it, in 1978, the Stuttgart Ballet fielded four casts in three days, including two of Crankos original cast (Marcia Hayde as Tatiana, Egon Madsen as Lensky); I applauded them all eagerly. In the 1980s, when Natalia Makarova danced Tatiana with the English National Ballet, I thought her more riveting and varied than any previous interpreter. When Lynn Seymour later stepped into the same role, her intensity and naturalism proved yet more astonishing.

title: Gowns for Belles of the Ball at the Victoria and Albert Museum

title: In Nigeria, Stunned Residents Recount Plane Crash

title: What the Locusts Ate
description: One of the most troubling features of todays global economic crisis is the lack of political leadership anywhere. No one has the courage to tell their people the truth. And the truth, alas, is that four of the pillars of todays global economy  Europe, America, China and the Arab world  have, each in their own way, squandered huge dividends they enjoyed in recent decades, and now they have to dig out of their respective holes with fewer resources, less time and, almost certainly, more pain. There is no easy way out. But, as confronting these hard truths becomes unavoidable, I think were likely to see some wild, angry and destabilizing politics that could make the economic recovery even more difficult. Deep holes and weak leaders are a bad combination.

title: Canada: More Body Parts Turn Up

They said they had contacted the Montreal police to see if the packages were related to the killing of Jun Lin, a Chinese student. On Monday, the police in Berlin arrested a suspect in the killing, Luka Rocco Magnotta, who left Montreal for Europe over a week ago. Mr. Magnotta has agreed not to contest his extradition to Canada. Parcels containing another hand and foot were sent to the offices of two Canadian political parties last week. Montreal police said earlier on Tuesday that the victims head as well as a foot and a hand were still missing.

title: Average Prison Stay Grew 36 Percent in Two Decades
description: For petty offenders and violent criminals alike, the length of a prison stay increased by more than a third over the past two decades, a period of time in which the prison population doubled, according to a report by the Pew Center on the States. Inmates released from prison in 2009 spent an average of 2.9 years  or 36 percent  longer behind bars than offenders released in 1990, the report found. The additional time cost taxpayers more than $10 billion. In Florida, the average time served rose by 166 percent; in New York, 2 percent. Eight states showed decreases in the length of prison terms, according to the report, which analyzed data from the federal governments National Corrections Reporting Program. Adam Gelb, director of the centers Public Safety Performance Project, noted that the variation among states followed no evident regional pattern, reinforcing the idea that state policy choices, often driven by particular crimes or circumstances in that state, drive the size and cost of the prison population, rather than data and research about whats most effective in reducing crime.

title: Louisiana: Two Scientists Surrender E-Mail to BP
description: Two prominent scientists involved in estimating the flow rate from a ruptured oil well during BPs 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have surrendered more than 3,000 of their private e-mails to the company in response to a subpoena by the United States District Court in New Orleans. BP sought the e-mails from the scientists, Chris Reddy and Richard Camilli of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, to help prepare its defense in a lawsuit brought by the federal government. In an op-ed article in The Boston Globe, the scientists said they had given the company more than 50,000 pages of documents and data before the company also demanded the e-mails. They said they worried that BP would use the e-mails to falsely cast doubt on their conclusions. Our concern is not simply invasion of privacy, but the erosion of the scientific deliberative process, the scientists wrote. BP said the subpoena was in no way an attack on science.

title: College Board Drops Plans for Summer SAT

Critics complained that the Aug. 3 test was unfair, because only students enrolled in the $4,500 course, held on the Amherst College campus, could take it. The next general SAT test date is in October. The College Board initially said the August test was a pilot for summer testing. But on Tuesday, it said that because the SAT was created to democratize access to education, any summer pilot would have to be better aligned with our mission.

From the stone wall that runs along Tibbett Avenue, you can see practically the whole school: Pforzheimer Hall, Mullady Hall, the auditorium, the gymnasium and, right in the center, the manicured green expanse of the baseball field, home of the Lions, pride of the school.

The deal would give the label and performer royalties for traditional radio play  something the music business has long fought for and never received. In return, the label agreed to accept a cut for online radio play (which does award royalties to performers and labels), giving Clear Channel at least some measure of predictability in online payments. Online play is a tiny part of Clear Channels business but the company saw an opportunity to preemptively control costs.

Whatever happens in any game, it becomes some sort of a reflection on the Heat and their drive for the mythical seven championships. The color palette, which the designers called acidic, include muted mint (on a winning crocodile print cotton sweater with a matching skirt) and coral (the star of a color-blocked shirtdress). title: Gambling Group Lobbied for Convention Center at Cuomo Fund-Raiser
description: ALBANY  After Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos State of State speech in January, the political world wondered where he got the idea for a huge, Malaysian-financed convention center.

title: Just One Look | Michael Kors
description: Michael Kors opened three stores in Istanbul recently, and its there that he went for inspiration for resort. Coats as look changers, legginess (women are really going for shorts, Kors said during the presentation) and opulence through fabric (gold ikat shantung, lacquered python, fox fur and cashmere) were the collections key points. Most looks were shown with embellished flat sandals  What makes it resort? Kors asked the editors in attendance; whats on your feet, he asserted  and small bags decorated with gemstones (built-in jewelry). Here, a most elegant panne velvet shift captures the groups glamorous and easy attitude best.

title: Happy Hour at Ugg
description: Around 5 p.m. on Tuesday, inside the expanded Ugg store on Madison Avenue and 58th Street, preparations were underway to introduce what the company, well known for its shearling footwear, was describing as its first freestanding store for men. Actually, its attached to the two-year-old womens store, but theres a separate entrance.

title: Recall of the Wild
description: Gail Collins: David Im really sad about the results from Wisconsin. I cant find a silver lining. You and I totally disagree about what this vote means, and my analysis is much more depressing.

title: HBO Says No, for Now, to Fans Who Want a Web-Only Option
description: HBO doesnt want your money, Web-only television viewers.

title: Suspect Sought in Queens Sex Attacks and Robberies
description: A young man is wanted in connection with the recent sexual assaults and robberies of several women at knifepoint on the usually safe streets of Forest Hills, Queens, the police said.

title: Smoothly, Sharapova Reaches the Semifinals
description: PARIS  For years, Maria Sharapova struggled on the red clay at the French Open, as if the court itself were a red light screaming at her to stand still. The alternative sometimes proved more embarrassing, at least initially. She ran so awkwardly, so rigidly, that she once compared her ungraceful movements here to that of a cow on ice.

title: U.S. Open Cup: Cal F.C. Hits the Wall
description: The dream of Cal F.C. is over.

title: Crop Insurance Proposal Could Cost U.S. Billions
description: WASHINGTON  At the same time that high crop prices are prompting farmers to expand into millions of acres of land once considered unsuitable for farming, Congress is considering expanding a federal insurance program that reimburses farmers for most losses or drops in prices.

title: For Ukraine Striker, Ending Is Also a Beginning
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The end is near, so much so that Andriy Shevchenko cannot precisely remember the distant beginning of his brilliant soccer career. He is said to have begun kicking a ball before he could walk.

title: Pete Cosey, Guitarist With Miles Davis, Dies at 68
description: Pete Cosey, a guitarist who played on many blues and R&B records in the 1960s but who became best known for his work in Miles Daviss electric band of 1973-75, contributing a sound drenched in distortion and punctuated by the wah-wah pedal, died on May 30 in Chicago. He was 68.

title: Former E.P.A. Official Pulls Out of House Hearing
description: A former Environmental Protection Agency official who stepped down this spring over controversial remarks he had made about punishing major polluters has sidestepped a grilling that he was expected to face on Wednesday at a House subcommittee hearing.

title: Grant on the Edge
description: In early June 1862, a few days after Union forces captured the vital rail lines at Corinth, Miss., William Tecumseh Sherman sat chatting with Henry W. Halleck, his superior and commander of the victorious Yankee army. With elaborate casualness, Halleck mentioned that Ulysses S. Grant, another of his subordinates, was departing the next morning for 30 days leave.

title: Sheryl Crow Says Brain Tumor Has Affected Her Memory
description: Sheryl Crow, the singer and songwriter who has survived breast cancer, disclosed this week that she has a benign brain tumor that has affected her memory. Ms. Crow, 50, mentioned her condition in offhand comments to an audience at a recent concert and her publicist later confirmed that she has a meningioma, a tumor common in middle-aged women that grows in thin layers of tissue around the brain and spinal cord, The Associated Press reported.

title: Nasdaq Sets Aside $40 Million to Settle Facebook Claims
description: 9:28 p.m. | Updated The Nasdaq OMX Group is taking its first step to quell investor anger over the flawed debut of Facebook shares last month  pledging $40 million to cover broker losses  but some customers and competitors quickly raised objections.

title: Sitting on the Other Side of the Desk
TimesCast Tech: New Xbox Services
description: Napsters founders introduce their latest venture. | Tumblrs founder shares his inspiration and mistakes. | Jenna Wortham checks out TaskRabbit, Pocketbooth and Uber.

title: Companies Try to Create Room on Radio Spectrum
description: Cellphone carriers like AT&T and Verizon say they are worried about running out of the radio spectrum that carries wireless calls and data, and they want the government to give them more chunks of it. But a number of companies are developing technology that could change the whole spectrum game by using radio frequencies more efficiently.

title: In Zenyattas Transition, a Life Lesson
description: I dont even remember the drive from Louisville to Lexington. I do remember getting up before sunrise to watch the morning workouts at Churchill Downs. It was there I received a message asking if I was available to come to Lanes End to visit Zenyatta and her colt. The next thing I knew, I was sitting in their reception area crying. When the Lanes End bloodstock assistant Sarah Campion came in, she took one look at me, patted my arm and said knowingly: I know; its always very emotional to see Zenyatta. I stumbled on my reply and fled to the bathroom to repair myself.

title: Tsonga Played It Safe, and Paid a Price
description: When Jo-Wilfried Tsonga watches a replay of his gripping match with Novak Djokovic he will wince at his lack of aggressive play on his four match points in the fourth set. In much the same way he thwarted Roger Federer in the 2010 United States Open semifinals, when he faced double match point at 4-5, 15-40 in the fifth set, Djokovic attacked. Like Federer, who twice chipped backhand returns on second serves, Tsonga elected to play it safe rather than hit out.

title: Are We Nearing a Planetary Boundary?
description: The earth could be nearing a point at which sweeping environmental changes, possibly including mass extinctions, would undermine human welfare, 22 prominent biologists and ecologists warned on Wednesday.

title: TimesCast Tech: Speaking With Tumblrs Founder
description: David Karp, Tumblrs founder, shares his inspiration and mistakes on the inaugural episode of The Timess weekly technology show. Also, Sam Grobart talks with Yusuf Mehdi, the chief marketing officer for Microsofts Interactive Entertainment Business; Napsters founders introduce their latest venture; and Jenna Wortham checks out TaskRabbit, Pocketbooth and Uber.

title: FX Orders New Comedy Series Legit
description: It may be the network of spooky houses, lawmen with bad attitudes and bikers with even badder attitudes, but FX also wants to be known as the cable channel that makes you laugh: on Wednesday it added to its roster of scripted comedy series, saying it had picked up a new show called Legit, starring the Australian comedian Jim Jefferies. In Legit, Mr. Jefferies, who created the series with Peter OFallon, plays a comedian named Jim who hopes to become legitimate in life, according to a release. The series also stars Dan Bakkedahl (of The Daily Show) as Jims best friend, Steve, and D.J. Qualls (Hustle & Flow) as Steves brother, Billy. FX is already the home of the comedy series Louie, about the life of the comedian Louis C. K., as well as Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia and Wilfred. Later this month the channel will introduce the comedy series Anger Management, starring Charlie Sheen, and Brand X, a late-night series hosted by Russell Brand.

title: Reviving Elvis, Just Like Tupac
description: The special effects company that brought Tupac Shakur back to life in the form of a ghostly image on stage at the Coachella music festival says it has plans for a similar project with images of Elvis Presley, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The company, Digital Domain Media Group, has said it has entered a deal with Core Media Group to produce images of Presley for a range of entertainment projects on film, television and at live events. Core Media owns the rights to Presleys image.

title: LinkedIn Was Breached. Now What Do You Do?
description: Security researchers have confirmed that a file containing 6.5 million encoded LinkedIn passwords has been posted to a Russian hacker site. LinkedIn has yet to confirm the breach, but it took to its Twitter account Wednesday to tell users it was investigating the matter.

title: Downton Abbey Castle Is Open to Tours
description: The next season of Downton Abbey wont be broadcast until January for American audiences, but fans of the show can visit the filming location long before then.

title: German Lawmakers Spar Over Child Care Subsidy
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels cabinet approved a bill on Wednesday to provide parents of toddlers with an allowance for keeping their children out of state-run day care, a move that critics say would derail recent efforts to encourage German women to return to work after starting a family.

title: Plays Well With Others: Video Game System Transcends Solitude
description: LOS ANGELES  Six years ago, while much of the video game industry continued to obsess over explosion-addled young men in basements, Nintendo had the gumption to move in a different direction with the introduction of the Wii. It was built around a vision of families having fun together in living rooms.

title: Beholding Nadals Empire of Clay
description: PARIS  Only one man has beaten Rafael Nadal at the French Open, and he is too ill to play here this year.

title: Ill Have Another to Start From Post No. 11
description: The post position draw for Saturdays Belmont Stakes featured some good-natured posturing at Belmont Park on Wednesday, when Ill Have Another was installed as the 4-5 morning-line favorite in his bid for the Triple Crown.

title: In Europe, a Shareholder Spring Leads to a Push to Curb Ad Executives Pay
description: PARIS  Maurice Lvy, one of the worlds most powerful advertising executives, issued a public call last year for higher taxes on the wealthy, saying it was only fair that they should make a greater contribution to reducing national budget deficits.

description: EVENTS

title: Hyundai Prices Veloster Turbo at $22,725
description: Notwithstanding its gray matte paint finish that so enthralled attendees at the 2012 Detroit auto show, the 2013 Hyundai Veloster Turbo is a known quantity. Specifically, $22,725.

title: Confessions of a Science Fiction Addict
description: Ray Bradbury, who died today at 91, introduced many young readers to science fiction.

title: Netanyahu Ministers Reject Move to Legalize Some Settler Homes
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel seemed headed for a showdown with hard-core Jewish settlers on Wednesday, after his ministers followed his instructions to vote against a draft bill that would have retroactively legalized illegally built settler homes in the West Bank.

title: G.O.P. Senators Oppose Cuomos Marijuana Plan
description: ALBANY  The Republican majority in the State Senate is not satisfied with a proposal by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to decriminalize the open possession of small amounts of marijuana and will not pass it in its current form, the chambers top lawmaker said Wednesday.

title: Off to Camp, but First ... a Wax?
description: LOTS of tweens and teenagers are gearing up for sleep-away camp, making sure they have stocked up on a seasons worth of bathing suits, sunblock and bug spray.

title: How Long Can You Hold Your Breath?
description: In describing Noomi Rapaces underwater cover shoot recently, we wrote that the actor was able to stay submerged for what seemed like minutes at a time. And it did seem like that  so much so that our original words didnt even include that what seemed like. But then a copy editor here, who obviously has no use for mermaids, raised a skeptical eyebrow at the claim that Rapace held her breath for minutes. So we added the qualifier.

title: Google Schools Apple on Maps
description: Google wants Apple, and the rest of us, to know just how expensive and hard it is to make good maps.

title: Nadals Latest Weapon: A Backhand Down the Line
description: Rafael Nadal speaks frequently about finding solutions. He continues to evolve, adapt, and improve his game, anticipating how his opponents will play him and adding new shots to keep them off balance. On Wednesday in his match against Nicolas Almagro, Nadal knew that Almagro would try to dominate play by ripping his heavy topspin forehand deep into Nadals backhand. If Almagro could make the match about his strength against Nadals weaker side, he would have his best chance at upsetting Nadal.

title: Finding Security Among the SPFs
description: EACH summer brings new and supposedly improved sunscreens, but this years really are quite different. With a set of the coming Food and Drug Administration regulations in mind, manufacturers have tweaked formulas and labels, and have even discontinued products, to comply. Words like waterproof and sunblock, which could give a false sense of protection, will be banned. Originally scheduled for this month, these requirements wont take effect until December, but most new products already abide by them. Here are some possibilities for the sunny days ahead.

title: Gupta Trial Judge Reprimands Law Student Spectator
description: Judge Jed S. Rakoff asked a law student attending the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta to stop sending him letters about the case.

title: Two Profound Slumps, With Some Parallels
description: Batting practice for the Class AAA Charlotte Knights had just finished on a steamy, hot afternoon in Fort Mill, S.C., when Conor Jackson emerged from the Knights Stadium clubhouse and took a seat in the dugout. It has been seven years since Jackson, 30, once a fixture in the Arizona Diamondbacks lineup, was a regular in the minor leagues.

title: Auction House Fights Seizure of Cambodian Statue
description: Sothebys filed papers on Tuesday urging a federal judge to dismiss efforts by prosecutors to repatriate a 10th-century statue to Cambodia, contending that there is no proof that the sculpture had been stolen from its homeland.

title: The Peoples Choice: An All-in-One, Mobile Utility Meter
description: The people have spoken, choosing VELObill as their favorite app among the 50-plus entries in the Energy Departments Apps for Energy contest.

title: The Urge to Punish
description: Ive been hearing various attempts to explain the ECBs utterly bizarre refusal to cut interest rates despite soaring unemployment, sliding inflation, and on top of all that the special problems of a monetary union that probably cant survive unless overall demand is strong. The most popular story seems to be that the ECB wants to hold politicians feet to the fire, letting them know that they wont get relief unless they do whats necessary (whatever that is).

title: As Twitter Matures, a New Bird Emerges
description: When a start-up grows up, it often signals its maturation by hiring a new chief financial officer or filing a prospectus. For Twitter, growing up means a new logo.

title: From The Lively Morgue: Republican National Convention, Chicago, 1952
description: July 4, 1952: Chicago. As part of its coverage of the Republican National Convention, The Times ran a full program and a chart showing the positions that delegates would occupy on the convention floor. Read more on The Lively Morgue.

title: In Hakalau, a Modern Success Story
description: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

title: After Flooding Stops, Hard Drive Costs Continue to Rise
description: A report issued by I.H.S. iSuppli, the research firm, found that last years extensive flooding in Thailand, where many hard drive components are made, will have a continued impact on the cost of computer drives into 2014.

title: Boys Being Boys, With Beer and Guns
description: As you watch The Bad Guys, an absorbing one-act comedy-drama by Alena Smith at the McGinn/Cazale Theater, your opinion of just which characters should be classified as miscreants may shift from scene to scene. The cocky investment banker would seem a natural candidate, right? Hedge funds! Cue the booing and hissing. But then his loyalty to a childhood friend whose life has unraveled earns some sympathy. The drug dealer who freely admits to selling to kids certainly appears to qualify, at least until the moving speech in which he reveals that his illicit trade is the only bulwark between his extended family and abject poverty.

title: Just One Look | Suno
description: This resort season, the Suno designers Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty expanded their collection to a total of 27 looks. They also showed a sportier Suno: silk racer-back tank dresses (in their signature mixed digital prints), techy Lucite windbreakers in colors like highlighter pink and lavender, and Suno-emblazoned graphic baseball tees. If you look closely at these boyishly boxy trousers and varsity jacket, youll see that the print is a basketball court.

title: Nokia Adds to Its Low-End Lineup of Phones
description: BERLIN  As Nokia waits for its high-end business to grow, it made another move to shore up its bread-and-butter market.

description: A scene from Gina Gionfriddos new play.

title: Dating Profiles of High-Tech, High-Worth Bachelors
description: From Pete Cashmore of Mashable to Jack Dorsey of Twitter, these young, bright, wildly overcompensated hyper-achievers are currently unattached.

title: No Comment Necessary: Homosexuality and the First Amendment
description: Bryan Fischer of the American Family Association said on his radio show yesterday that we have to choose between homosexuality and the First Amendment.

title: Bachelorvilles Big Fish
description: WHEN Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook married his longtime girlfriend, Priscilla Chan, recently, one of the worlds youngest billionaires was off the market.

title: Anna Teresa Callen, Cookbook Author, Dies
description: Anna Teresa Callen, an influential cookbook author who began her career as a cooking teacher in New York City, died on Sunday in a hospital in Lanciano, in Central Italy. She was 86, and died during surgery for cancer, said Nick Malgieri, the director of baking programs at the Institute of Culinary Education.

title: Limit Soda for Kids Sake
description: For some people, the central knock on Mayor Bloomberg is his eagerness to institute a nanny state, the most recent example of which is his administrations attempt (opposed by nearly two-thirds of Americans) to ban large servings of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs). In this scenario a nanny is unquestionably a bad thing: an excessive and patronizing intrusion, something to be feared and reviled.

title: At Best Buy, Lumia Is Selling O.K. but More Slowly Than Android
description: Nokia and AT&T have aggressively promoted the new Lumia 900 smartphone with a big marketing campaign, but at Best Buy, Lumia sales still pale in comparison to the hottest Android phones, a company executive says.

title: The Lessons of Pineapplegate
Should Ike Davis Be Sent Down?
description: Ike Davis was expected to be the Mets cleanup hitter this season. Instead, he has struggled from Game 1 and is now hitting .160, the lowest average of any regular position player in baseball, entering Wednesdays games.

description: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga had finally arrived at one of the most important moments in his career  his first match point three hours and eleven minutes into his French Open quarter final battle with world number one Novak Djokovic in Paris on Tuesday.

title: Baring Shoulders and Knees, Students Protest a Dress Code
description: The first hint of the looming rebellion came from the lips of Hao Yang, 17, as he practiced ballroom dancing outside Stuyvesant High School on Wednesday morning, the first licks of sunlight casting a long shadow that made a perfect dance partner on the wall behind him.

title: A Dark Tale of Tokyo That Only Gets Darker
description: The title of Richard Lloyd Parrys true-crime book People Who Eat Darkness, is creepy, especially now that zombies are in the news. Its sleek cover, which features a blurry sketch of a serial rapist and murderer, is creepier still. I read People Who Eat Darkness over the course of two days and always placed it face down in the kitchen, lest a glimpse of it unnerve the children and animals in the house.

title: Scene City: A Milestone for Gordon Parks
description: Karl Lagerfeld, Anna Wintour and Annie Leibovitz toast the photographers vision.

title: A Call for More Clarity on Net Access in Europe
description: BERLIN  In Europe, the debate over unrestricted Internet access  so-called net neutrality  has shifted to a core question: How much should the European Union intervene when mobile Internet service providers restrict Web access?

title: Memories of a Master of the Lens
description: TWELVE years ago, in an interview with The New York Times for an article that was part of the newspapers How Race Is Lived in America series, Gloria Vanderbilt described how she first met the photojournalist Gordon Parks, with whom she would have a longtime romantic relationship.

title: News Roundup: Panetta Defends Drone Strikes in Pakistan; Courts India
description: Gardiner Harris reports in The New York Times India Ink blog that Leon E. Panetta, the United States defense secretary, does not think drone strikes, like the one on Monday that killed Abu Yahya al-Libi, the Qaeda deputy leader, violate Pakistans sovereignty. They instead protect both Pakistan and the United States, he said on Wednesday in New Delhi.

title: YouTube Will Stream Olympic Coverage to 64 Countries
description: YouTube will stream 2,200 hours of live Olympic coverage free to 64 countries and territories in Asia and Africa at youtube.com/olympic during the Summer Games in London, which start July 27.

title: For Celtics, Not Practicing Seems to Be Working
description: BOSTON  One of the many responsibilities for Jeff Twiss, the Celtics media relations director, is updating reporters each day on the teams practice times. In this postseason it has pretty much been a robo call: the Boston Celtics will not practice today.

title: The Forehead Is the New Canvas
description: AT the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Gala last month, Ginnifer Goodwin showed off bangs as short as the mowed grass in Yankee Stadium. Jessica Biel had fringe so thick and long, she looked like one of the Beatles. And Marion Cotillard had a tuft on her forehead seemingly styled by a weed whacker. As if those bangs werent sufficiently extreme, days later at the Chanel cruise show in Versailles, the stylist Sam McKnight gave the models fringe in pastel hues typically reserved for Easter eggs.

description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

description: If this is Thursday, Apple must be revamping its online services again.

title: When Teasing Is Loving, and When Its Not
description: I was only teasing. Those are words that roll around our house a lot. From brother to sister, sister to brother, and occasionally, from parent to child, or even (less often, but occasionally) from my husband to me. We are a family that teases.

title: Sara Erranis Best Year Ever
description: PARIS  Sara Errani of Italy is playing the tournament of her dreams.

title: Jill Lepore Talks About Life, Death and the Stages in Between
description: In The Mansion of Happiness: A History of Life and Death (Knopf), Jill Lepore examines the ways in which weve historically defined where life begins, where it ends and how it should be conducted while it lasts. In a recent interview via e-mail, Ms. Lepore discussed why death is a less contentious subject than conception, why the word parenthood had to be invented and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

title: Giants Extend Coughlins Contract to Reward a Two-Time Champion
description: Once the Giants won the Super Bowl in February for the second time in Tom Coughlins coaching tenure, the question of his latest contract extension became a matter of when instead of if. The Giants answered Wednesday, announcing that Coughlins contract, which was set to expire after the coming season, had been extended through 2014.

title: Just One Look | Boy by Band of Outsiders
description: I just bought a 1930s-style house, and it actually looks a lot like this collection, said Scott Sternberg, the designer behind Band of Outsiders. The L.A.-based collection featured many California design influences (thanks to LACMAs recent interiors show): Bauhaus-inspired architecture and primary colors translated into classic captain blazers and striped kerchief dresses and anoraks (above), for example. In addition, Sternberg points out: We experimented with evening wear last season, and it went over really well. He has even taken a liking to jumpsuits. So were going to keep at it.

title: Dont Think College Is Worth It? Ask People Who Havent Gone
description: Last month the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development released data showing that college graduates generally do not regret going to college, despite lots of criticism of the value of higher education. Today the center released a new report focusing on the depressing state of Americas recent high school graduates, who seem to agree about the importance of further education.

title: LinkedIn Tweaks Calendar Feature to Stop Taking Meeting Notes
description: On Tuesday, Bits reported that LinkedIns mobile application for the iPhone and iPad contained an opt-in feature that transported sensitive information from users calendars  including meeting notes, dial-in information, passwords and participants contact information  back to its servers, without users knowledge. Security researchers noted that the practice could prove problematic in cases where people inserted sensitive information, like confidential financial data or strategic plans, for instance, into those meeting notes.

title: The Choir, the Clarinet and the Adrienne Rich Part
description: In the section of David Eaglemans work of fiction Sum: Forty Tales From the Afterlives called Egalitaire, a mature female God is imagined mulling the difficulties of arbitrating morality.

description: The author of Fahrenheit 451 brought science fiction to the literary mainstream.

description: KANSAS CITY, KAN.

title: Dates and Hours Announced for the Next New York Run of  The Clock
description: In April Lincoln Center announced that Christian Marclays much-loved The Clock  a 24-hour montage of clips from movies and television that depict particular minutes in the day, synchronized with the moment they are shown  is coming to Lincoln Centers David Rubenstein Atrium, on Broadway between 62nd and 63rd Streets, where it will be shown free.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Italy, Bahrain, Afghanistan and Gaza.

title: Happy IPv6 Day! But What the Heck Is IPv6?
description: Several technology companies on Wednesday celebrated World IPv6 Day, a historic moment when many big tech companies and Internet providers began switching to a new system for getting on the Web. Most of us will never even have to think about this.

description: A three-bedroom triplex in the Puerto Madero neighborhood is for sale for $980,000.
