title: Bill Fontanas Acoustical Visions
description: This work in International Orange, a FOR-SITE Foundation exhibition in San Francisco, uses the Golden Gate Bridge as a musical instrument, with real-time views under the roadway expansion joints.

title: Some Final Thoughts on a Booming Industry
description: Having covered the boom and bust of the e-commerce industry, and then the boom and bust of the mortgage industry, Im exiting the mobile apps beat before I see death and destruction again.

title: Balanchines Nocturnal Dream, Tailor Made for June
description: George Balanchines two-act ballet A Midsummer Nights Dream turns 50 this year. To return to it at New York City Ballet on Tuesday night was to find it fascinatingly different from the ballet I remembered. And I realize now, after many viewings over the years, that it has added up each time to a different whole. This time it was funnier than in its last revival here: the sound of children in the audience gurgling with laughter in Act I was delicious.

title: Just One Look | Organic by John Patrick
description: I kept thinking about the word throwback and realized I dont want to throw anything back, said the designer John Patrick of Organic, whose resort collection was inspired by Edit DeAk and Walter Robinsons 1970s zine Art-Rite. Im not watching Nick at Nite anymore. This is fresh. To get fresh, Patrick showed color-pops of cobalt blue, recycled polyester slip dresses and skirts, classic daisy embroidered tunics in voluminous proportions and  wait for it  mens wear. Monochromatic nylon uniforms were designed for everyone. Designing mens definitely made everything a bit more ambiguous for both, said Patrick, pointing out this all-white sports-set shown with Roger Vivier kitten heels. Not David Bowie ambiguous but pristine, healthy and active.

title: National Black Theater Clears Financial Hurdles
description: The National Black Theater, a cultural fixture in Harlem that was in danger of losing its home, has resolved a series of financial disputes that had endangered its future.

title: The Message From Wisconsin
description: When Gov. Scott Walker moved to strip Wisconsin public employees of their collective-bargaining rights last year, a few weeks after taking office, it was clear that he wasnt doing it to save the state money. If that had been the case, he would have accepted the unions agreement to pay far more in health care and pension costs. His real goal was political: to break the unions by demonizing their bosses, ending their ability even to collect dues and removing them as a source of money and energy for Democrats.

title: At Belmont Park, a Clinics Doctor Gets Track Workers Back on Their Feet
description: As a general practitioner with a practice in Nassau County, Dr. Fredric Cogan was familiar with the usual flus, fevers and fractures his patients dealt with.

title: Ray Bradbury Wants to Pass on a Message From Jules Verne
description: The story begins with Ray Bradbury, stepping out of a time machine. From the misty distance emerges a man in a dark suit. It is Jules Verne, who has been dead for 50 years to the day. The conversation between one master of science fiction and another starts with the practical.

title: A Singer With Many Influences but a Soul Thats Hers Alone
description: The story of the recent British soul revival is the story of ghosts. Artists like Adele and Amy Winehouse succeeded as much because of the memories they conjured with their reference points as because of their talent. They had the familiarity of yesteryear on their sides. And given that they summoned styles dating back to Motown girl groups and Dusty Springfield, they had a lot of peoples yesteryears in their arsenal.

title: Indisputably Out of Service
Stephen Tyrone Williams
description: STEPHEN TYRONE WILLIAMS has accumulated some impressive regional theater credits, including Cory Maxson in Fences at Seattle Rep and Syracuse Stage, and Simon in Ruined at the Geffen Playhouse and the Intiman Theater. But this University of Alabama graduate (Class of 2004), born and raised in Tuscaloosa, has been seen somewhat less onstage in New York.

title: A Comedian Retraces His Life Through 16 Homes
description: Adam Carolla, the comedian and radio personality, grew up in a string of semi-bad places, he said, in the San Fernando Valley in California. title: Mayer Keeps Top Spot on Album Chart
description: John Mayers Born and Raised (Columbia) topped the Billboard album chart for a second week, but that was not a huge accomplishment since sales were anemic all around. Mr. Mayer needed to sell only 65,000 copies to hold on to the top slot, the smallest number for a No. 1 album since February 2011 when Nicki Minajs Pink Friday was on top after selling only 45,000. Album sales are down 3 percent since January compared to the same period last year. Adeles 21 (XL/Columbia) remained at No. 2, and Regina Spektors What We Saw From the Cheap Seats (Sire/Warner Brothers) entered the chart at No. 3 with 42,000 copies sold. One Directions Up All Night (Syco/Columbia) was just behind at No. 4 with 41,000 in sales, and Edward Sharp and the Magnetic Zeros made their debut at No. 5 with Here, (Community Music) which sold 35,000 copies.

description: Doing what law and justice required, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on Tuesday granted a two-week reprieve to Abdul Awkal, who had been scheduled to be executed Wednesday morning. Mr. Awkal, who was convicted of killing his estranged wife and brother-in-law in 1992, has a long history of severe mental illness and has been found mentally incompetent by three courts in the past 20 years.

description: Labor unions led the failed effort to recall Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, and their defeat in Tuesdays election was a significant setback to organized labors political clout in both symbolic and tangible ways.

title: New Laureate Looks Deep Into Memory
description: The Library of Congress is to announce Thursday that the next poet laureate is Natasha Trethewey, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of three collections and a professor of creative writing at Emory University in Atlanta. Ms. Trethewey, 46, was born in Gulfport, Miss., and is the first Southerner to hold the post since Robert Penn Warren, the original laureate, and the first African-American since Rita Dove in 1993.

description: The Miami Beach police released the identity of the massage therapist who collapsed at the home of Miami Heat player Chris Bosh on Monday afternoon and died late that night at an area hospital. She was Chautele Mia Cooksey, 41, who managed Channels of Light Life Center in Miami. The cause of Cookseys death has not been determined. Foul play is not suspected.

description: After seven months of an ambitious review by the Obama administration of all deportations before the nations immigration courts, very few of them have been halted, disappointing immigrants President Obama hopes to court for his re-election bid.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP)  A federal judge denied a shareholder request to postpone the annual meeting of Chesapeake Energy on Wednesday, clearing the way for the large natural gas producer to convene the shareholders meeting on Friday as planned.

description: After blowing a four-run lead against the Los Angeles Angels, after his fourth ungainly start in a row, a stretch in which he had a 6.47 earned run average, Ivan Nova pointed the finger at himself. Im not pitching good, he said then.

description: June 7 is the beginning of the official summer reading season, at least as far as Motherlode, The Learning Network, The Choice blog and Room for Debate are concerned. The Choice has College Admissions Books for Your Reading Pleasure. And all day, well be posting tweets and retweets with the hashtag #summerreading. (Twitter handles @KJDellAntonia, @NYTMotherlode, @kschulten,  @NYTimesLearning, @roomfordebate and @nytimescollege).

title: Mets Are Sloppy Once Again, but Lethargy Dooms Them
description: WASHINGTON  Manager Terry Collins was not compelled to speak to his players after the Mets cringe-inducing, error-strewn loss here on Tuesday night. There had been worse games, he reasoned, and his players always seemed to bounce back, anyway.

description: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserves 12 districts, according to survey results released by the Fed on Wednesday. The survey is based on information collected on or before May 25.

title: Tseng Follows Sorenstam as She Pursues Another Major
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  Yani Tseng, the top-ranked female golfer in the world and the defending champion at this weeks L.P.G.A. Championship, acknowledges that she is motivated by chasing L.P.G.A. records. She also says that the voice she still hears in her head is that of the Hall of Famer Annika Sorenstam.

title: Up From the Depths of Pulp and Into the Mainstream
description: Martians, robots, dinosaurs, mummies, ghosts, time machines, rocket ships, carnival magicians, alarming doppelgngers who forecast murder and doom  the sort of sensational subjects that fascinate children are the stuff of Ray Bradburys fiction. Over a 70-year career, he used his fecund storytelling talents to fashion tales that have captivated legions of young people and inspired a host of imitators. His work informed the imagination of writers and filmmakers like Stephen King, Steven Spielberg and James Cameron, and helped transport science fiction out of the pulp magazine ghetto and into the mainstream.

title: San Diego and San Jose Lead Way in Pension Cuts
description: While the eyes of the nation focused on Wisconsin, where Gov. Scott Walker brushed back a recall attempt by critics of his move to strip most public-sector unions of their collective bargaining rights, a pair of less noticed local elections Tuesday in California could have more immediate ramifications for struggling state and local governments and for organized labor.

title: A Space Shuttles Final Voyage
description: The space shuttle Enterprise made its way up the Hudson to its new home at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum.

description: LOS ANGELES  Zach Parise, the Devils captain, found a glimmer of hope in a conversation with his father before Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Florida Defends Search for Ineligible Voters
description: MIAMI  Saying the state would not stop trying to scrub the rolls of ineligible voters, Floridas election chief told the Department of Justice on Wednesday that Florida was not violating any laws.

title: Seeking to Clear Roadblocks to Loan Repayment
description: With the default rate steadily rising among the nations 36 million student loan borrowers, President Obama is seeking to ease the repayment process by streamlining enrollment in the income-based repayment program, which helps low-income borrowers by capping monthly payments at 15 percent of their discretionary income, and 10 percent in 2014. Fewer than 700,000 borrowers are enrolled in the program, in part because registration is complicated. But beginning Sept. 30, Education Secretary Arne Duncan said Wednesday, most borrowers will be able to electronically import data directly from the Internal Revenue Service onto their application, letting them complete the application at one sitting, without going through their loan servicer. Mr. Duncan said the new process could avert a significant percentage of defaults.

title: Canada: Police Link Body Parts to Murder Victim in Montreal
description: The police said Wednesday that they were confident that a hand and a foot mailed to two schools in Vancouver, British Columbia, came from a man who was killed and dismembered in Montreal. The police in Montreal said the packages were mailed from that city, and other factors indicated that they were some of the remains of Lin Jun, a Chinese student. Luka Rocco Magnotta, a Montreal resident, is in a Berlin jail awaiting extradition to Canada on several charges, including first-degree murder.

title: China: Foreigners Barred in Tibet
description: Several travel agencies in China said Wednesday that foreigners were banned from traveling to the Tibet Autonomous Region, the Chinese name for central Tibet, for at least June. The agencies said they had been told of the ban recently. One agency said the ban was expected to last until September, while another said there was a chance the ban could be lifted by July. In late May, two Tibetans set themselves on fire in front of the Jokhang, the holiest temple of Tibetan Buddhism, in the center of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, to protest Chinese rule. One man died. Those self-immolations were among at least 38 that have taken place in Tibetan regions since 2009. Foreigners were barred from Tibet from late February to early April, a period that coincided with the anniversary of large protests against Chinese rule.

title: Eugene Ferkauf, 91, Dies; Restyled Retail
description: Eugene Ferkauf, the founder of the E. J. Korvette chain of discount department stores, whose 1950s strategy of low prices, quick turnover and high volume helped shape todays retail landscape, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: A Tour of Foursquares Redesigned App
description: Foursquare, the mobile app that lets people share their whereabouts with friends, has a brand-new look. On Thursday the company released an overhauled version of its application, built entirely from scratch. It is designed to turn the companys rich trove of data and location information into a handy guide that can be used to navigate a familiar or foreign city.

title: Rather Than Share Your Location, Foursquare Wants to Suggest One
description: Two years ago, Foursquare was the star of the New York start-up scene. Celebrities and major brands embraced its mobile app, and companies like Facebook and Yahoo were eager to buy it.

description: The Challenge: A woman develops a fever and an itchy, bright red rash on her torso and face while camping in Vermont. Can you figure out whats making her sick?

title: Thunder Headed to N.B.A. Finals After Knocking Out Spurs
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  If this was the last stand of the San Antonio Spurs, it was a valiant one, befitting a team from the Alamo city. But across as tense and furious a night of 48 basketball minutes as we have seen this N.B.A. playoff season, the Spurs aging legs failed to match the intensity of their resolve.

title: Rosa Guy, 89, Author of Forthright Novels for Young People, Dies

title: Putting Chinese Students to the Test
description: HONG KONG  Theyve been at it for years now, cramming for Chinas annual college-entrance exam, some of them hooked up to oxygen canisters and intravenous drips of amino acids during late-night and weekend study marathons. Their parents hire special tutors, force the kids into educational boot camps in the summer and promise lavish gifts of cash and cars for good results. Housekeepers and nannies with college degrees come at a huge premium. Some girls take contraceptives or get hormone injections to make sure they wont be distracted by getting their period during the exam.

Cristiano Ronaldo, Franck Ribry, Mesut zil, Robin Van Persie, Wayne Rooney, Xavi. They are the elite of the elite, and theyre all listed.

title: Celebratory Air at Obama Event for Gay Rights Supporters
description: LOS ANGELES  Nearly a month after President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage, on Wednesday night he got a rousing reception and at least $2.5 million at a gala of gay rights supporters and a private, celebrity-studded dinner afterward.

title: Stone Links: Robot Right and Wrong
description: Driverless cars may be just around the corner, but who do we blame if they cause an accident? An article in the Economist argues that the proliferation of robots, now in heavy use by the military and increasingly by civilians, demands that we reconsider long-held concepts of agency and autonomy in order to develop a machine ethics. Sorting out this new landscape may well involve asking the kind of questions experimental philosophy is currently asking about everyday moral intuitions. And at the very least, ethicists and engineers will have to get used to the idea of working closely together. The article also suggests it will be necessary to determine whether the designer, the programmer, the manufacturer or the operator is at fault if something goes wrong. But if responsibility can ultimately be assigned to a human being, its unclear why we would need to scrap the good old fashioned moral system we already have in place. If we cant blame the robots, why bother developing a system in which theyre accountable?

title: CHI 2012 Conference Q&A With Joseph Konstan
description: Eight weeks after the annual South by Southwest Interactive conference, Austin again became a hub for creative technologists. The CHI 2012 conference is an annual gathering for researchers who focus on human-computer interaction (HCI). CHI 2012 is produced by ACM, the Association for Computing Machinery, a professional society for computing researchers.

title: Playwrights Collective to Disband After Production of Ruhl Work
description: 13P, a New York City collective of 13 writers who teamed to produce one play by each member, will mount its final show in July before disbanding after nearly nine years, the organization announced on Thursday. The last production will be a chamber music adaptation by the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the composer Todd Almond of Ms. Ruhls 2001 farce, Melancholy Play, which will be performed July 18-27 at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn. The director will be Davis McCallum (February House), and the actors will be David Greenspan, Erik Lochtefeld, April Matthis, Sarah Tolan-Mee, and Amy Warren.

description: Inspired by the elements, designed for the city, Donna Karan is dressing women for parties with resort. At the presentation earlier this week, formal, celebration-ready cocktail dresses dominated the collections 43 looks, many of which came decorated with large pieces of quartz, crystal or jet (as pins on jackets and swinging as earrings). Here, a slimmer silhouette (long and lean is in this season) offers a new kind of tuxedo dressing.

title: Would You Want To Read Your Fetuss DNA?
description: Its now possible, although still financially impractical, to sequence the DNA of a baby from nothing but a blood sample from the pregnant woman and a saliva sample from the father. The New York Times reporter Andrew Pollack reported that genome scientists from the University of Washington say they took advantage of new high-speed DNA sequencing and some statistical and computational acrobatics to deduce the DNA sequence of the fetus with about 98 percent accuracy. For now, its expensive ($20,000 to $50,000) and still inaccurate, but:

Beautiful Ruins also includes wittily wrought excerpts from its various characters writings, among them a novel, a memoir, a play and a movie pitch. Proenza Schouler will open its first store this July on Madison Avenue, designed by the architect David Adjaye, who also did the showroom and offices. Resort finds McCollough and Hernandez not with their heads in the clouds on some fantasy surfing safari but thinking on their feet. In other words: How are we going to keep our store filled? The answer: wearable pieces steeped in the DNA of the brand, including tweeds (like the coat pictured here), tie-dyes, lace and, yes, an entire range of denim pieces their girl will definitely want to snatch up.

title: Bringing Table Tennis to the Schools
Meet the New Ethicist: Chuck Klosterman
description: Following a murderers row of guest Ethicists  Betsey Stevenson, Andrew Light, Cheryl Strayed and the poet laureate Philip Levine  a new full-time Ethicist starts this Sunday. He is Chuck Klosterman, who may be familiar to you for any number of reasons. He wrote for our magazine in years past, including this memorable 2002 profile of Billy Joel, and more recently, he was instrumental in the start of ESPNs Grantland, Bill Simmonss excellent sports journalism Web site (the magazine profiled Simmons last year). Chucks eighth book, I Wear the Black Hat, will be published next year. Now living in Brooklyn, he is from Wyndmere, N.D. Like other longtime Klosterman fans, I first heard of him when his first book, Fargo Rock City, was published to immediate acclaim in 2001.

title: Halfhearted Half Brother
description: My father recently died. His daughter from his first marriage (which ended several years before his marriage to my mother) has made efforts to stay in touch with me since his death. I have never had a direct relationship with my half sister. She has had a difficult life, missing out on many of the advantages my sister and I enjoyed. I want to be sympathetic to her struggles, but though Ive tried, Ive never felt an attachment to her. She has been an intermittent presence and not always a pleasant one. Is it ethical to decide not to carry on this relationship? Or does someone elses desire for connection, which perhaps comes out of a strong wish to be part of a family, outweigh my personal preference? J.G., NEW JERSEY

Using the crosshatch pattern on the original jackets hardware as a leitmotif, Cooper turned out a resort collection full of clever riffs on the Trialmaster  as a snappy linen jacket, say, or a fitted dress  that will get fashion motors running without any trouble at all.

title: 36 Hours in Osaka, Japan
description: OSAKAS concrete canyons and elevated freeways will never win the city any urban beauty contests. But when the ethos of a place is kuidaore  the concept of eating oneself bankrupt  aesthetics dont much matter. Fittingly, Japans third-largest city has no shortage of fine-dining establishments (the city now boasts 108 total Michelin stars, including five three-star restaurants); but the convivial, freewheeling local food culture can just as easily be tapped into at the inexpensive food stalls that line the recently renovated banks of the Dotonbori canal. And when the belly-busting glut becomes too much, Osakas top-notch museums and urban parks provide welcome, necessary respite.

title: Just One Look | Calvin Klein
description: Always looking to architecture for inspiration, Calvin Kleins Francisco Costa chose California modernism, and specifically the Eames house in Los Angeless Pacific Palisades, for resort. The contrast between the houses rigid exterior and softer, more comfortable interior spoke to the designer who, too, balances similar strictness with sumptuousness in his collections. Silhouettes were all very 70s  tunics and jackets with belts slung low around the hips and modern caftans over cropped pants. The shoes were clomping flat platforms. It feels sort of groovy, Costa said of the clothes, with their flowy, relaxed fits and long-over-short proportions. description: Would it seem odd not to mention that all five major exhibitions at the New Museum now are solos by female artists? The museums promotional material does not make a point of it, nor are the shows related by some umbrella theme, feminist or otherwise. Unless you are a gender-ratio scorekeeper, it would seem to be irrelevant that the artists in question  Ellen Altfest, Phyllida Barlow, Tacita Dean, Nathalie Djurberg and Klara Liden  are women. They are all variously celebrated artists first. And yet, in ways that are not necessarily obvious, and if only because of the all-female lineup, questions of gender come to the fore.

title: Tokyo Gas Attack Arrest Reawakens National Trauma
description: SAGAMIHARA, Japan  For two years, the woman who called herself Chizuko Sakurai lived with her boyfriend in a rundown old barn on the far western edge of Tokyos sprawl, where tracts of identical suburban homes fade into farms and mountains. She drew little attention, wearing drably colored clothes and no makeup. Neighbors said she avoided eye contact and kept to herself.

title: Points North
description: Willa Cather once wrote that a creative writer can do his best only with what lies within the range and character of his deepest sympathies. By that measure, and any other, Richard Ford is doing his very best in his extraordinary new novel, Canada, his first book since The Lay of the Land six years ago. Here, Ford is clearly writing within the range and character of his deepest sympathies  in this case, from the point of view of an abandoned 15-year-old boy  and hes doing it with a level of linguistic mastery that is rivaled by few, if any, in American letters today.

title: At Another Job Fair, Hope This Will Be the One
description: Linda Baker walked from employer to employer at a job fair in Brooklyn on Thursday, inquiring about opportunities. Ever since being laid off from her construction job three years ago, Ms. Baker, who is in her 40s, has been constantly searching for some kind of work.

title: A Bit of Dance, a Touch of Heat
description: PEOPLE have been talking about the supposed body-transforming powers of Tracy Anderson for several years. Shes the trainer who has traveled with Madonna, established her roots in Los Angeles and runs a studio there that has become a mainstay for stars like Jennifer Lopez, Gwyneth Paltrow and Courteney Cox. Word spread so quickly about her workouts that Ms. Anderson herself became a celebrity.

More or less in the space of a single season, a troubled organization has made something of a turnaround, thanks largely to its energetic artistic director, Alan Pierson, who was hired in 2011 and has set about restoring the orchestra to a status worthy of its home boroughs cultural cachet.

title: Street-to-Street Art
description: A look at the Bushwick art scene.

title: Theyre Running Away With the Circus
description: The humor is similar, but the scale is bigger, faster and brighter in Madagascar 3: Europes Most Wanted, this summers installment in DreamWorks Animations billion-dollar-grossing franchise. The images, styled after Miroslav Saseks illustrations, still charm, and the movies returning directors, Eric Darnell and Tom McGrath, keep their machine humming. A third director, Conrad Vernon, has joined them, perhaps to accommodate the heightened pyrotechnics.

title: Wait, the Bus Is Leaving Without Him

But it again illustrated that everything is political in an election year.

description: In March, The Choice introduced a series called Counselors Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track as they go through the admissions process.

description: A moralizing message sits awkwardly atop a crime story in For the Love of Money, a film that cant quite capitalize on the big names it has in relatively small roles.

title: At Graduation, Ohio High School Seniors Remember Fellow Students Killed in Shooting
description: Thomas M. Lane III, the 17-year-old accused of fatally shooting three students and wounding two others in the cafeteria at Chardon High School in Ohio last February, is scheduled to be arraigned Friday on charges of aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder.

description: Lay on Ground, Light Fuse, Retire Quickly and Do Not Hold in Hand After Lighting are the recurring warnings on 3,000 vintage firecracker packages for sale on June 22 and 23.

title: 70s Troubadour , From Prime Time to Vegas
description: Paul Williams, a singer-songwriter behind 1970s classics like Rainy Days and Mondays, Evergreen and the Muppet Movie anthem, The Rainbow Connection, was a kind of Zelig on 70s prime-time television as well, guest-starring on seemingly everything: Circus of the Stars, Police Woman, countless Tonight shows. Short and bespectacled, he was an unlikely celebrity, but his romance with drugs and alcohol was all too common. After embracing sobriety he largely dropped out of the public eye to rebuild his life and counsel other substance abusers.

title: Spoiling History at Belmont
description: In 2008, DaTara, ridden by Alan Garcia, pulled off a huge upset at the Belmont Stakes, preventing Big Brown and jockey Kent Desormeaux from winning the Triple Crown.

title: Italy: Man Arrested in School Bombing
description: Investigators in the southern Puglia region said Thursday that they had detained a suspect in a bombing that killed one student and wounded five at a Brindisi school three weeks ago. After hours of interrogation that started on Wednesday, officials said, a 68-year-old fuel vendor from the area was arrested on suspicion of attempted multiple homicides with the intent of terrorism. The authorities later identified the man as Giovanni Vantaggiato. Because the school was dedicated to Francesca Morvillo, who was killed with her husband, Giovanni Falcone, a prosecutor, by a Mafia bomb 20 years ago, investigators had initially investigated links to organized crime. The prosecutor Cataldo Motta said the suspect had admitted to having economic problems, but could not explain how that might have prompted him to carry out what Mr. Motta called a terrorist act. He did not explain, he did not give justifications, he said.

title: Pakistan: Judge Quits His Sons Case
description: Amid accusations of conflict of interest, Pakistans chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, removed himself from a panel investigating corruption accusations against his son and announced the formation of a two-member bench to look into the claims. The day before, the son, Arsalan Chaudhry, testified before his father that rumors that he had accepted bribes worth $3 million to $4 million from a powerful and well-connected real estate developer were untrue. Justice Chaudhry had insisted he could rule fairly in the case, but he stepped aside after mounting criticism that he was hurting the courts credibility.

title: After Juneteenth Project Stalls, a Replacement Emerges
description: The Tejano Monument, unveiled in March on the Texas Capitols south lawn, stands to honor the states early Spanish and Mexican settlers. But for some Texans, it is a reminder of the failed Juneteenth monument project, approved two years before the Tejano Monument.

title: House Acts to Repeal Medical-Device Tax
description: WASHINGTON  In another assault on President Obamas health care law, the House passed a bill on Thursday to repeal a new tax on medical devices.

title: Middle East: Sentence for Former Adviser to Arafat
description: A Palestinian Authority anticorruption court sentenced Yasir Arafats former financial adviser to 15 years in prison with hard labor and a $15 million fine, according to the official Palestinian news agency, Wafa. The adviser, Muhammad Rashid, was convicted in absentia of embezzlement of public funds and money laundering from the period when he ran the Palestine Investment Fund. Mr. Rashid has denied wrongdoing in the past. He left the Palestinian territories after Mr. Arafats death in 2004, and his current location is unknown. His was the highest profile corruption case to have been dealt with to date by the court in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

title: A Troubled Silence
description: THE revelation this week of alleged widespread child abuse at the elite Horace Mann School in New York City, most of it occurring during the 1970s and 80s, is only the most recent instance of men coming forward, many years after the fact, with horrific stories of sexual molesting from their childhood.

title: Bad News for the Badlands
description: I HAVE good news and bad news from the Badlands of North Dakota, one of our loveliest and most fragile wildernesses. And even the good news is mostly bad: The National Trust for Historic Preservation announced on Wednesday that Theodore Roosevelts Elkhorn ranch beside the Little Missouri River, an exquisitely peaceful meadow revered as the cradle of conservation, is one of Americas 11 most endangered historic places.

title: Hardware at All Hours
description: Nuthouse Hardware, in Kips Bay, is a basement and three floors of nuts, bolts, housewares, do-it-yourself supplies and building materials, with the added bonus of being open all night.

description: IT was shortly before midnight on a recent Saturday in Kips Bay, and Third Avenue was teeming with 20-somethings in stilettos and hair gel, ready for a night out.

description: BOLOGNA, Italy  When Eugenio Brivio first started coaching blind baseball players in 2002, getting across one basic tenet had him stumped.

Toughened Up, St. Johns Makes Run in N.C.A.A. Tournament

description: ALBANY  Now that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has abandoned his dream of building the nations largest convention center at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, he is handling multiple offers from the gambling industry to develop a combination casino and convention center at other sites around New York City.

title: Portuguese Just Shrug and Go On in the Face of Cuts and Job Losses
description: LISBON  Behind the cheery yellow edifice that is this countrys Finance Ministry, where the news is not so cheery these days, Joaquim Maralos waterfront grill is open for business, any business at all, seven days a week.

title: Donations to Key Cuomo Ally Show a Rift Among Unions
description: Backed with millions of dollars in contributions from business, the Committee to Save New York has been Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos most important ally in his battles with public-sector unions over government spending, pensions and teacher accountability.

title: A Failure of Discretion
description: When the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, John Morton, said in a June 2011 memo that his agency would focus on deporting convicted criminals and repeat immigration violators rather than noncriminals who pose no threat, he raised hopes of restoring balance to a broken system. He told agents and prosecutors to use all appropriate discretion with immigrants who lack criminal records, have deep family ties to this country and are pursuing legitimate civil-rights complaints.

description: For 40 years, the Istanbul Music Festival has brought performers from around the globe to evocative settings in Turkeys cultural capital, and this year is no exception.

description: Every spring, corporate chieftains and their boards squash uprisings from a familiar batch of pugnacious investors, a ritual that shields many companies from major change.

description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Soon after health officials announced they would dole out Arizonas first licenses for medical marijuana dispensaries, Ryan Hurley, co-chairman of the medical marijuana practice at the Rose Law Group here, noticed a common trait among some of the people most eager to enlist his services: They were already in the business in other states.

title: As Grain Piles Up, Indias Poor Still Go Hungry
description: RANWAN, India  In this north Indian village, workers recently dismantled stacks of burned and mildewed rice while flies swarmed nearby over spoiled wheat. Local residents said the rice crop had been sitting along the side of a highway for several years and was now being sent to a distillery to be turned into liquor.

title: Antigua, Tiny U.S. Foe With Big Aspirations
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  On the banks of a lake at the IMG Academies here, two members of the Antigua and Barbuda national soccer team were arguing over whose turn it was to hold the fishing rod.

title: Sons Cigarette Caused Fatal Fire in Putnam County, Police Say

title: Barry Unsworth, Writer of Historical Fiction, Dies at 81
description: Barry Unsworth, considered one of the foremost historical novelists in English, who was known for rich, densely textured fiction that conjured lost worlds  those of the Trojan War, medieval Europe and the Napoleonic age, among many others  died on June 4 in Perugia, Italy. He was 81 and had lived in the Umbria region of Italy for many years.

title: Common Sense on Marijuana
description: Dean Skelos, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, shows a serious lack of good sense in opposing Gov. Andrew Cuomos plan to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana in public view. Mr. Skeloss flippant remark  that the proposal would allow people to walk around with 10 joints in each ear  trivializes a serious problem and misrepresents a sound proposal that has broad support from law enforcement.

description: Dood! cried the former jockey Jerry Bailey, shaking the hand of Doodnauth Shivmangal.

title: Youre Likable Enough, Mitt.

Polls report that Obama is more likable than Romney, and that his favorable to unfavorable ratio is more positive.Other things being equal, it is no doubt better for a candidate to be liked than disliked, but when other things are not equal, historical data suggest that a candidates likability is a relatively minor factor in deciding modern presidential elections.

title: Battling Tight Fairways, Three Tie for L.P.G.A. Lead
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  Three players were tied for the lead of the Wegmans L.P.G.A. Championship on Thursday while seven others were one stroke behind.

title: The Moral Diet
description: In the 1970s, the gift shop at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was an informal affair. It was staffed by about 300 mostly elderly volunteers, and there were cash drawers instead of registers. The problem was that of the shops $400,000 in annual revenue, somebody was stealing $150,000.

title: Ex-Pitchers Video Game Company Goes Bankrupt
description: The video game studio run by the retired baseball star Curt Schilling filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, while Rhode Island and federal officials began investigating the operations of the company, which was buoyed by financial support from the state.

title: Reagan Was a Keynesian
description: Theres no question that Americas recovery from the financial crisis has been disappointing. In fact, Ive been arguing that the era since 2007 is best viewed as a depression, an extended period of economic weakness and high unemployment that, like the Great Depression of the 1930s, persists despite episodes during which the economy grows. And Republicans are, of course, trying  with considerable success  to turn this dismal state of affairs to their political advantage.

title: The Bills to Nowhere
description: This is now the pattern of business in the House of Representatives: Spend most of the time passing bills designed not to become law but to satisfy the ideological desires of conservative voters. And block laws that actually need to get passed.

title: Who Should Teach Our Children?
description: As at most colleges, our semester at Notre Dame ends with student evaluations of their teachers. Each time I wonder what the students  and their parents  make of this exercise. Wait, I imagine them saying, weve just paid you tens of thousands of dollars in tuition to take courses at your school, and now youre asking us to tell you if the teachers you hired are any good? If you didnt already know that theyre first class, you had no right taking our money.

title: A Car Shop Promises: Just the Work You Need
description: A NEW commercial for Jiffy Lube, the oil-change chain, opens on a quiet road, where a mechanic working underneath a car at a repair shop spots a woman driving by in an S.U.V.

title: Another Official Resigns in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  The government of the nations capital was in turmoil this week after the chairman of the City Council, Kwame R. Brown, was charged with bank fraud and violating campaign finance rules, a high-profile move by prosecutors that expands a growing circle of defendants in federal investigations.

title: Man Linked to Saudi Prince Draws 10-Year Term for Rape
description: A member of the traveling entourage of a Saudi prince was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison for the rape of a 26-year-old woman who fell asleep in his room at the Plaza Hotel after a night of barhopping.

title: Prosecutors in Seabrook Case Cant Use Just His Last Name
description: At the June 19 retrial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, federal prosecutors may seek to characterize the defendant as a liar or a cheater, as they had in the first trial. What they cannot do, however, is simply refer to him by only his last name.

title: Molded for Success on Clay Courts
description: PARIS  That Rafael Nadal is not simply great on clay, but historically great on clay, perhaps the best ever on clay, is not an unfamiliar notion. The pertinent question is: What is it about Nadal that makes him dominant on all surfaces but nearly unbeatable on this one?

title: A West Bank Curfew, but Whats for Dinner?
description: Even the most meticulously prepared cook cannot be expected to cope with all kitchen disasters. A fully stocked spice rack, an ample larder and even a closet full of pickled staples will not necessarily suffice when a curfew keeps you housebound for more than a week with a family to feed.

title: Queens Thief Didnt Count on Missionaries
description: The thief who snatched a taupe, buckle-covered bag from a young woman with a glossy black ponytail and designer sunglasses on Thursday afternoon in Queens might have thought it would be an easy crime.

title: School Rings
description: Administrivial Fun Puzzle Event Alert! The Napa Library Foundation is sponsoring a day of puzzle events  including a crossword tournament  on Saturday, June 30. After a morning session of kid-friendly puzzles and games, and a free afternoon screening of the movie WORDPLAY, three-time A.C.P.T. champion Dan Feyer hosts the tournament at the Napa City County Public Library. The tournament will feature three unpublished New York Times puzzles as well as an exclusive Napa-themed crossword created especially for the event. Between the preliminary rounds and the championship round, puzzle experts will lead a Q&A and discussion of crossword solving and construction. Scheduled to appear: Tyler Hinman, Andrea Carla Michaels, Jeremy Horwitz, and moderator Dan Feyer. Visit the Napa Library Foundation website for more information!

title: Ex-Aide to Senator Pleads Guilty in Scheme That Snared Only Him

title: The Hundred Years War Certainly Did Drag On
description: Bloated, gaseous, archly self-conscious and on occasion truly funny, Kenneth Lonergans Medieval Play is like a vintage Saturday Night Live sketch that wont die. Imagine a skit from, say, the mid-1970s, in which John Belushi and Chevy Chase portray violent, inept knights clunking around in cumbersome armor and talking about looting and plundering in goofy pseudo-chivalric speech.

title: No Eviction After Renter Didnt Pay for 9 Years
description: The states highest court ruled on Thursday that a Brooklyn loft tenant who has not paid rent since 2003 could not be evicted because the landlord had not brought the building up to residential standards.

title: Lottery Numbers

title: 3 Men Are Found Dead in BMW Near Columbia U.
description: Three men were found dead on Thursday inside a car parked near the campus of Columbia University after an apparent shooting, the authorities said.

title: Nadals Clay Supremacy
description: Since 2005, Rafael Nadal has dominated on clay, compiling a 221-9 match record and a 34-4 mark in clay court finals

description: NEWARK  Adam Henrique, the 22-year-old rookie center who seems to score a big goal whenever the Devils need one, was asked again Thursday about his decision Tuesday to turn his playoff goatee into a playoff mustache. He said he just wanted to lighten the mood.

title: Obstacles Mar Quest for Arab Dictators Assets
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Soon after the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi began in Libya last year, foreign banks and governments began freezing billions of dollars in assets held by his family and government, just as they had frozen accounts of the toppled governments in Tunisia and Egypt.

title: Pressing for Leak Inquiry by a Special Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  Calls for a special counsel to investigate leaks of classified information by Obama administration officials gathered momentum on Thursday after the Justice Departments national security division partly recused itself from the inquiry, apparently because of the possibility that the department might have been a source of some of the disclosures.

title: Triple Crown or Not? Picking the Belmont Stakes
description: Who will win the Belmont? A half-dozen New York Times staffers offer their thoughts, led by Joe Drape, who writes about racing and would love to see a Triple Crown winner. But hes not holding his breath.

description: Rob Hughes of The International Herald Tribune has been previewing the tournament all week. In case youve missed any of his columns, and with only hours to go before the tournament kicks off, here are slimmed-down versions of five teams to watch:

title: A Church, and Its Faithful, Both Lost
description: An image, at once arresting and overly symbolic, sums up whats good and bad about Corpo Celeste, the writer-director Alice Rohrwachers feature debut: Blindfolded almost-teenagers grope their way around a spartan church sanctuary in Reggio Calabria, Italy.

title: Teixeira Gets Diagnosis for Persistent Cough
description: Mark Teixeiras mysterious, lingering cough finally has an identifiable reason. Teixeira visited an ear, nose and throat specialist in New York on Thursday and was found to have nerve damage in one of his vocal cords.

description: After a day off in Detroit, spent ruminating over recent trends with his pitching staff, Manager Joe Girardi called catcher Russell Martin into his office at Comerica Park last Saturday for a short meeting before Martin went behind the plate.

title: The Only Thing Missing Is a Swamp Monster
description: Refusing to slot comfortably into any recognizable genre, The Oregonian teases us with horror and amnesia-mystery conventions without sealing the deal either way. From a commercial standpoint this is more than a little risky, encouraging nonplused critics to dust off the experimental tag that sends most moviegoers running for the hills. Yet this first feature from Calvin Lee Reeder (who also wrote the story, such as it is) doesnt feel like an experiment; it feels like a journey whose destination was firmly predetermined.

title: The Jets Have California on Their Minds
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Coach Rex Ryan opened his final news conference of the Jets voluntary workout period with an equation. Of the 2,211 possible workouts this off-season  multiplying the number of players on the team by the number of workout opportunities  the Jets players completed 2,178 of them.

title: A Problem of Distribution
description: India holds the second-largest stockpile of surplus grain in the world, after China. Yet advocates say that more than 252 million poor Indian residents reap few benefits and often go hungry.

title: U.S. Gymnasts in a Jam on the Road to London
description: ST. LOUIS  Martha Karolyi, the woman with the ability to make or break an American gymnasts Olympic dream, stared stoically out onto the competition floor Wednesday on the eve of the United States gymnastics national championships.

title: A Part of Chile About to Change Forever
description: Documentaries about the pollution, scarcity and general mismanagement of our planets freshwater supply have been popping up with increasing regularity. title: Hes a Rainbow | Hiroshi Sugimoto for Herms
description: Light is my medium to be investigated, says the Japanese artist Hiroshi Sugimoto, who spent years chasing bands of prismatic color around his studio in Tokyo and capturing them, with what was for him rapid-fire succession, using a Polaroid camera. In collaboration with Herms, 20 of the artists abstract color studies have been translated into silk scarves in signed, limited editions of seven each. Couleurs de LOmbre (Colors of Shadow), as the collection is called, is a moving tribute to the lowly Polaroid, which faces imminent extinction. (Sugimoto in fact exhausted his last batch of the film to make the images.) Herms, on the other hand, developed new inkjet technology in order to faithfully recreate the subtle gradations of intense color. Where the original Polaroids are small and precious, the scarves are large  just over 55 inches square  and dynamic, playing with light in ways the artist had never anticipated. Though at around $10,000, you might think twice about actually wearing one. Its serious art for me, Sugimoto says, with a nod to Herms. And if its serious art, for me, its also very reasonably priced. Available at hermes-editeur.com.
