title: Quinoa Salads With Spring Vegetables
description: Im always tweaking the way I cook quinoa, and this week I changed my method for basic quinoa. Id been cooking it sort of like pasta, in 3 parts water, then draining it and letting it dry out in a towel-covered pan. Ordinarily, this is a good way to obtain very fluffy grains, and you get a lot of volume too. But lately Ive been finding that my quinoa is soggy  more waterlogged than fluffy  when I cook it this way, even after it rests under the towel. Are the grains different? I dont know. Whatever the reason, I decided to change the grain-to-water ratio and followed the directions on my Alter Eco quinoa packages (Alter Eco is a company dedicated to fair-trade foods, and they import red, rainbow and pearl quinoas). I cooked the pearl and the red quinoas in 1 1/2 parts water and the rainbow in 2 parts water. The black quinoa in the rainbow mix takes a little longer to soften and requires a little more liquid to be properly hydrated. The grains were tighter and less moist than quinoa cooked in abundant water, and the yield was not as great because the grains dont swell as much. But I liked the results, especially for salads, which were the destination for my quinoa experiments.

title: How Big Can a Small Business Be? (And Why It Matters)
description: There is an age-old debate about what constitutes a small business. Most likely, we think about the question differently depending upon our vantage point in life. Ive met corporate folks before who think a business with 500 employees or less is small. And Ive met self-employed massage therapists who think theyre too small to be considered a small business.

title: China Shows Interest in Afghan Security, Fearing Taliban Would Help Separatists
description: BEIJING  In a sign of Chinas growing interest in neighboring Afghanistan after the departure of the United States and NATO-led forces, President Hu Jintao met the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, in the Great Hall of the People on Friday and announced a new strategic partnership between the two countries.

title: Things That Make My Publisher Happy
description: From the Guardian Bookshop:

title: A Gifted and Talented Program Grows in Carroll Gardens
Obama Prods Congress, Citing Euro Crisis
description: President Obama on Friday urged Congress to take another look at his proposals to spur job growth and warned that economic problems in Europe were producing headwinds that made Congressional action even more critical for the United States.

title: Inside the List
description: MANS WORLD: The cutoff for this weeks list was June 2  too early, youd think, to reflect any kind of Fathers Day sales bump. Yet with subjects including the Civil War, international espionage, Navy SEALs and the most trusted man in America, the lists new titles throw off a decidedly masculine funk. The Civil War book is Jeff Shaaras Blaze of Glory, a novel about the Battle of Shiloh that hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 7 and contains one character as notable to literary historians as military ones: the Union general Lew Wallace. Blamed for the battles heavy casualties after he was late with reinforcements, Wallace went on to serve as governor of the New Mexico Territory before becoming, like Shaara, a wildly popular historical novelist. (His Ben-Hur, published in 1880, was the best-selling American novel of the 19th century, and has never gone out of print.) Shaara, a former coin dealer who started writing after the death of his novelist father, told a Florida newspaper recently that he tries to grab his audiences right away: A very good friend of mine who is not especially a reader said to me, If you expect me to read your books, youve gotta hook me in Chapter 1.

title: Well-Oiled Machine
description: In the great reach for colonies that Europe began hundreds of years ago, at center stage were several curious entities that wielded more power than many governments. The United Company of Merchants of England Trading to the East Indies (commonly known as the East India Company) and its counterpart, the Dutch East India Company, fielded their own warships and armies, coined money and ruled territory eventually taken over by Britain and the Netherlands. Later, the seizure of land by Cecil Rhodess British South Africa Company also preceded the spread of British pink across the map.

title: Words Per Minute
description: I share my name with an aerobatic bird that can whiz across a whole summer sky in seconds. A swift is so equipped for speed that it can scarcely cope with being stationary. I once came across an unlucky young specimen that had somehow grounded itself on a lawn and, with its minuscule legs and long encumbering wings, couldnt regain the air. I lifted it on the perch of my finger and it was gone in a flash.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Free cupcakes, one per person in any flavor, will be handed out between 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. Friday at Georgetown Cupcake SoHo, 111 Mercer Street (between Prince and Spring Streets), for an upcoming episode of DC Cupcakes, a reality show that follows the two sisters behind this popular bakery.

title: Mysterious Light Seen Over Middle East Coincides With Russian Missile Launch
description: A glowing celestial pinwheel spun in the night sky over the Middle East on Thursday night, grabbing attention across the region and fueling speculation about the possible origin of the unexplained phenomenon.

title: Trail of Shadows
description: I opened this book as a skeptic. I am not a lover of true crime, and as a parent I recoiled from the lurid tale of a 21-year-old English bar hostess in Tokyo who was drugged and dismembered by a serial sex offender. But Richard Lloyd Parrys remarkable examination of that crime, what it revealed about Japanese society and how it unsettled conventional notions of bereavement, elevates his book far above the genre. People Who Eat Darkness is a searing exploration of evil and trauma, and how both ultimately elude understanding or resolution.

title: Becoming a Legend
description: During the great performance that was her life, Lillian Hellman always addressed the 20th century from center stage. While she defended many causes  justice, loyalty, American civil liberties, anti-fascism and Soviet-style Communism among them  what she represented most staunchly was herself, and what she believed in most fiercely was her own unassailability.

title: Light, Truth and Whatever
description: Andrew Delbanco must be a great teacher. A longtime faculty member at Columbia, he is devoted to the development of his students as individuals, and recognizes that their time in college should be formative: They may still be deterred from sheer self-interest toward a life of enlarged sympathy and civic responsibility. Like most professors devoted to teaching, he has no interest in telling undergraduates what to think, but he does want to draw them toward a sense of skepticism about the status quo and to a feeling of wonder about the natural world. College, he tells us, is a time to learn to make connections among seemingly disparate phenomena, to see things from anothers point of view and to develop a sense of ethical responsibility. At a time when many are trying to reduce the college years to a training period for economic competition, Delbanco reminds readers of the ideal of democratic education.

title: First Foodie
description: The richest, most influential restaurant owners lived in fear of a single critics word, a man whose enthusiastic home visit to an amateurs kitchen might well inspire a lucrative career as a cookbook writer. Drawing on his limitless budget, he could roam the earth and report back on what he found.

title: To the Bone
description: Although the 58 years between the rise of Hitler and the fall of the Soviet Union have been as well documented as any comparable historical period, there are fewer literary accounts of their most evil components than might be expected. Of course most of those who suffered directly are dead or otherwise incapacitated, and few indirect sufferers have been sufficiently talented. We do have marvelous books by Primo Levi; Fatelessness, by Imre Kertesz (who dismissed the film Schindlers List as kitsch); Solzhenitsyns Gulag Archipelago; and perhaps Wiesels Night, but its a small list. Now we can add The Hunger Angel, by the 2009 Nobel laureate Herta Mller.

title: City of Dreams
description: Early on in The Chaperone, Laura Moriartys fourth novel, it becomes clear that Cora Carlisle is fighting a losing battle. Her charge is Louise Brooks, soon-to-be silent-film star and something of a force of nature. As the critic Kenneth Tynan wrote, Brooks was a creature of impulse, a creator of impulses, a temptress with no pretensions, capable of dissolving into a giggling fit at a peak of erotic ecstasy, . . . with that sleek jet cloche of hair that rings such a peal of bells in my subconscious. Moriartys Louise is only 15, a Jazz Age lost girl playing uncertainty as brashness, but impulse and temptation are already in bloom.

title: The Displaced
description: In Against Simplification, an essay posted on the Project Syndicate Web site last August, Norman Manea rightly pointed out that in North America literary translation is too rare a practice, arguing that imported books are thought to be too complicated, which is another way of saying that literature should deal with simple issues in a simple way, obeying the rules of the mass market, with its tricks of packaging, accessibility, advertisement and comfort.

title: Winds of Fate
description: When it was published in Britain last year, Jo Bakers fourth novel was called The Picture Book. The title made some sense  it referred to both a cherished postcard album and, presumably, the snapshot structure of the narrative  but Bakers American publishers were wise to change it. The Picture Book suggests something sweet and nostalgic. In its best moments, this novel, Bakers first to be published in the United States, is gripping and ruthless.

title: Uncertain Times
description: In his eloquent essay The Great Christmas Killing, the Hungarian novelist Peter Nadas describes his intense, ultimately chagrined response to a documentary about the execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu. Neither his opposition to capital punishment nor his belief in the importance of just, legal procedures keeps Nadas from feeling a surge of vengeful delight as he witnesses the final hours of the Romanian dictator. Ceausescu just kept looking at his wife, rolling his small, shifty eyes and grinning nervously; you could tell he couldnt grasp what was really happening or figure out how he might gain the upper hand.

title: Vetted, Altered, Blessed
description: When the Qaeda leader Abu Zubaydah was captured, six months after the terrorist attacks of 9/11, C.I.A. lawyers were asked to approve a battery of tough interrogation techniques hastily thrown together. They did not much fear that posterity would think them ruthless. On the contrary, the C.I.A.s No. 2 attorney worried that with all the restrictions and precautions and scrutiny by lawyers and doctors and psychologists, theyd look like a bunch of wimps.

title: From Here to Infinity
description: When Simon Norton was 3 1/2, his I.Q. was measured at 178. For three years running in high school, he was among the top scorers in the world at the International Mathematical Olympiad. At the age of 27, he and a colleague, John Conway, formulated an audacious conjecture in group theory called monstrous moonshine, which inspired a frenzy of mathematical work around the globe that culminated in a Fields Medal-winning proof by Richard Borcherds almost two decades later.

title: Money Ball
description: The mantra in America is that everyone needs a dream. So why not dream that your kid will be the one to land an athletic scholarship or sign a pro contract? Because  as Mark Hyman has documented in two important but troubling books  the lengths to which many of us go in pursuit of that vision can turn it into a nightmare.

title: Forget the Alamo
description: Texas  that vast and various landmass of nearly 26 million souls  boasts some of the most acclaimed public and private universities, a vibrant art and architecture scene, and world-class symphony orchestras and opera companies. It is one of the nations leaders in medical research; rightly celebrates its reputation for manned and unmanned space exploration; rejoices in its richly diverse and tasty cultural stew; and glories in its professional football teams.

title: Triple Crown Chase Ends Day Early, in Farewell
description: There was Ill Have Another at one end of the leather tether, looking every bit the wonder horse, with his coat combed to a chestnut glow and his mane braided and glimmering. At the other was his trainer, Doug ONeill, leading his colt out of Barn 2 at Belmont Park for a shockingly final bow before a battery of cameras on Friday.

title: The Return of Tirunesh Dibaba
description: One of the most anticipated entrants at this years Adidas Grand Prix track meet in New York on Saturday is Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia, the defending womens Olympic champion at 5,000 and 10,000 meters and quite possibly the fastest finisher in the history of womens distance running.

title: Wheelies: The Lone-Star Speed Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Why the Baltics Matter
description: Some readers have urged me not to spend time on Latvia, Estonia, etc., on the grounds that they are too small to matter. Sorry, but thats not true. For one thing, every economy  even a small one  is potentially a natural experiment that teaches us more about how economies in general work. Beyond that, the Baltics now loom large in the imagination of austeritys defenders, particularly since Ireland keeps refusing to play along and be a success story.

title: DC Comics Going Even Further Back in Time
description: Last fall, DC Comics reintroduced its heroes in 52 new series, all starting with issue No. 1. This September the publisher will be going even further back in time, with plans to unveil an issue No. 0 for each of those series.

title: Hosts of Car Talk to Retire After 35 Years of Automotive Banter
description: 6:23 p.m. | Updated For years now, after their broadcasts, Tom and Ray Magliozzi, the hosts of the public-radio hit Car Talk, have been ranking the listener calls they receive on a scale from five to one, with five being the most entertaining.

title: Morning Walkabout  6/8: SeaWorld Killer Whales Ruling, and Where to Sleep Outside in New York City
description: SeaWorld and Killer Whales More than two years after a whale killed a trainer during a show at SeaWorld, a judge has ruled that the park cannot resume similar shows that allow trainers in the water to ride and kiss the animals. SeaWorld has introduced a new show that keeps trainers our of the water, which doesnt seem to have dimmed ticket sales. (The New York Times)

title: The Newest Rap: Intense, Authentic and Accidental
description: THREE years ago Waka Flocka Flame arrived loudly with O Lets Do It, a bumpy burst of rowdy boasts and gunfire onomatopoeia. It was a rough and tumble song in a time when that style was beginning to seem extinct. Not surprisingly, when he recorded it, the goal wasnt to fit in to the hip-hop of the day.

title: Collaborators Dead and Very Much Alive
description: Jesse Davis

title: Real Reporters on the Screen? Get Me Rewrite!
description: BACK when paper and ink still mattered, I fell into a job as a nightside reporter at The Providence Journal, in the habitually newsworthy state of Rhode Island. This was many years ago, before exercise, sobriety and good hygiene had ruined the misanthropic bonhomie of the typical newsroom  or so the romanticizing journalist in me likes to think.

title: Image of the Day: June 8
Fashion Web Start-Up Raises $36 Million
description: Everyone loves a bargain, but some shoppers just want access.

title: Former UBS Trader Is Granted Bail
description: LONDON  Kweku M. Adoboli, the former UBS trader charged with false accounting related to a $2.3 billion trading loss, was granted bail by a London court on Friday.

title: The Most Expensive Campaign Ever
description: The Romney and Obama campaigns are already spending millions of dollars to attack each other on television. Its a bit early for that, as Jeremy Peters pointed out in The Times today, and theyre battling for the attention of an incredibly tiny slice of voters.

title: Shareholders Rebuke Chesapeake Leadership
description: HOUSTON  Shareholders sent an angry message to the board and management of Chesapeake Energy on Friday, withholding support for the two directors up for election, rejecting the pay plan for top executives and urging the company to allow major shareholders to nominate their own board candidates.

title: Wilson Quarterly to End Print Publication
description: The Wilson Quarterly, the 36-year-old general interest magazine published by the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, has announced that it will put out its final print issue in July.

title: Live Sunday: Coverage of Euro 2012
description: Goal blog reporters, editors and contributors will provide coverage and live analysis of selected games during Euro 2012, starting with Sundays Italy-Spain game from Gdansk, Poland, and Mondays France-England matchup in Donetsk, Ukraine. Check back next week and beyond for more matches.

title: Nadal and Djokovic to Vie for Title and Much More
description: PARIS  By late Friday, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic had guaranteed that history would be made at this French Open, with their latest Grand Slam final meeting now scheduled as scripted. Tennis record books will be rewritten Sunday, one way or another, by one of two players who spent the last two weeks on a clay-court collision course.

title: Predicting the Rise and Rise of 3-D
description: Dreamworks Animation/Walt Disney PicturesDreamWorks Animation is releasing Madagascar 3 on Friday.

title: Real Estate Giant Domus Holdings Files for an I.P.O.
description: 1:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Errani and Vinci Win Doubles Title
description: PARIS  Sara Erranis streak held on Friday as she and Roberta Vinci of Italy won a rain-interrupted French Open womens doubles final at Roland Garros against Nadia Petrova and Maria Kirilenko of Russia.

title: A Mythical Bayous All-Too-Real Peril
description: MONTEGUT, La.

title: Just One Look | Club Monaco
description: With 14 deliveries a year, Club Monaco doesnt map out its collections season to season but rather month to month. So when you go into one of the brands New York City stores in December, there you will find  surprise!  not bathing suits and cover-ups but clothes that are perfect for New York City in December. In other words, festive fare that you dont have to be floating on a sailboat in the Caribbean to pull off. Among the best looks is this sweatshirt, brilliantly gussied up with a panel of Lurex and a multibeaded skirt. Holiday party, anyone?

title: No Charges to Be Filed in Deadly Christmas Fire, Connecticut Prosecutor Says
description: A Connecticut prosecutor said Friday that he would not file criminal charges in connection with the Christmas morning fire in Stamford that killed three girls and their grandparents.

title: Obama Speaks About Job Growth
description: President Obama spoke on Friday about the European financial crisis and job growth in the U.S.

title: Jamaican Drug Lord Gets Maximum Term
description: Christopher M. Coke, the Jamaican drug lord whose extradition to the United States in 2010 followed a furious manhunt in his homeland that led to the deaths of more than 70 people, was sentenced on Friday in Manhattan to 23 years in prison, the maximum he faced.

title: Judge Allows Protesters Suit Against Police to Proceed
description: A federal judge indicated Thursday that the police did not adequately warn Occupy Wall Street protesters against walking on the roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge before arresting about 700 of them in October.

title: Postcards From the Resort Collections
description: Its all about comfort, Alber Elbaz said as he introduced his latest Lanvin collection to a small group of editors and retailers at Milk Studios. To me, thats the only definition of modernity.

title: Earning Less and Worth Less
description: Adjusted for inflation, per capita disposable personal income has yet to recover to the peak reached in 2008. Household net worth, also adjusted for inflation and measured on a per capita basis, is still nearly 20 percent below the high reached in 2007. The charts show four-year changes in both figures, both before and after adjusting for inflation.

title: Scenes from Bonnaroo
description: The 2012 Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival got under way in Manchester, Tenn., on Thursday.

title: The Rams of Memphis
description: In the annals of the Civil War, there were many unlikely heroes, but perhaps none more unusual than Charles Ellet, who built the first  and only  Union Ram Fleet. One of the most accomplished civil engineers of all time, and with no military experience, Ellet created a fleet of ramming steamships independent of the military hierarchy, stocked it with nearly a dozen of his own family members and courageously commanded it to victory in the Battle of Memphis in June 1862.

title: The Sweet Spot | Broadway and the Tonys
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott give their regards to Broadway, still an authentic New York experience.

title: The Sweet Spot: June 8
description: With the Tony Awards on Sunday, David Carr and A. O. Scott give their regards to Broadway, still an authentic New York experience. For live coverage of the Tonys, log on to NYTimes.com at 7 p.m. Eastern.

title: Go West, Young Man, and Sell Out
description: Too Late Blues

title: One Reporters Journey Through a Sports Day Like Few Others
description: From the French Open to an Argentina-Brazil friendly to an Oscar Pistorius 400-meter run to the Belmont Stakes to Yankees-Mets, Saturday will be a sports marathon. Having covered six sporting events in 24 hours last year, Mike Tanier is uniquely qualified to report for the fan who wants to experience championship hockey, horse racing, track and other sports in one whirlwind day.

title: Income and Wealth Are Down in U.S.
description: AMERICANS are used to recessions, but they are also used to relatively fast recoveries.

title: Britain Confirms Tae Kwon Do Choice Is Not No. 1 Fighter
description: The British Olympic Association ratified the nomination of Lutalo Muhammad to its tae kwon do team Friday.

title: A Child, a Gadget, a Guest and a Question of Etiquette
description: Yesterday, R. wrote, my 6-year-old child and the rest of our family visited another family with a child (also 6) who spent the whole time on an iPod touch.

title: The Car of Your Dreams
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about collectors of classic cars. Like any other type of collectible, some cars  often those that were widely produced  have little value as an investment. And other cars may be falling out of favor, like sedans from the 1920s and 30s, whose biggest fans were people who remembered riding in them as youngsters. Car collecting, in other words, needs to be done with some knowledge and, often, advice from those with experience.

title: Waiting For Non-Lefties
description: Samuel Brittain: You dont need to be a lefty to support Krugman:

title: Aurora Stokowski and Anthony Mazzei
description: ANTHONY MAZZEI didnt begin his romance with Aurora Stokowski by asking her on a date. They were on the carousel at Bryant Park when, out of the blue, he confessed that he loved her  risking not only his heart, but also the business it had taken them more than a year to build.

title: Bonnaroo: Kendrick Lamar and Rappers With Vocal Bite
description: Qualifications for rappers at Bonnaroo 2012: technique, inclusiveness, vocal bite, stage presence. Thursday night brought three in a row to the This Tent for a deluge of multiply rhymed lines and polysyllabic precision: Danny Brown, Yelawolf and Kendrick Lamar. (More are due in the next days, both well-qualified on those fronts: GZA and Ludacris.) But their shticks were different, and in my earnest way I prefer Kendrick Lamar, who equally earnestly presents pleasuresbooze and sexas ways to ease the pain of a deprived upbringing and a competitive adult life.

title: Scenes from Bonnaroo
description: More Photographs

title: Planning a Financial Tuneup
description: There comes a point in most peoples lives when the pile of undone financial tasks  the un-automated bills, the out-of-balance retirement accounts, the out-of-date budget, the under-optimized rewards programs  becomes large enough to provoke a sort of low-grade anxiety.

title: Love Story in Residence
description: LUCAS MATTHIESSEN was born in 1950s Paris, the son of a free-spirited couple who were looking for Hemingway, as the title of a famous essay by Gay Talese described their generation of expatriates. His father is Peter Matthiessen, the writer, and his mother was Patsy Southgate, described in an obituary as the most beautiful woman in Paris during those years.

title: Romney Calls Obama Out of Touch on Jobs
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, IOWA  Mitt Romney seized on President Obamas remark Friday that the private sector was doing fine by calling it an extraordinary miscalculation and misunderstanding by a president whos out of touch.

title: Townsend and Bouchard Lose in Semifinal
description: PARIS  This wasnt Taylor Townsends tournament but she wasnt blaming anyone. Everyone has their good days, everyone has their bad days, she said after losing in a quarterfinal singles match on Wednesday.

title: Book Review Podcast: Richard Fords New Novel
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Andre Dubus III considers Richard Fords new novel, Canada, in which a teenage boys life is changed forever when his parents make the unlikely decision to rob a bank. Calling the book a masterwork by one of our finest writers working at the top of his form, Mr. Dubus writes:

title: Whos Got Your Back?
description: IN a city with more than 20,000 registered real estate agents, is it any wonder that choosing one can be a difficult and sometimes fraught process?

title: A Career Resurrected After McCain and Palin
description: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev.

title: E-Mails Offer Look at Deal-Making Over Health Care Law
description: Emails released by the House Energy and Commerce Committee open a window into the negotiations between the White House, Senate Democrats and pharmaceutical industry in 2009 as part of President Obamas drive to overhaul the health care system.

title: Readers Pick Their Favorite Tony Awards Moments
description: On Thursday, The Timess Charles Isherwood provided a brief and highly arbitrary list of his favorite moments from past Tony Awards shows. He called out show-stopping performances like Angela Lansbury and Bea Arthur doing Bosom Buddies from Mame; and Jennifer Holliday doing And Im Telling You Im Not Going from Dreamgirls.

title: Man of The Moment | Ryan Gosling
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Obama Was Pushed by Drug Industry, E-Mails Suggest
description: WASHINGTON  After weeks of talks, drug industry lobbyists were growing nervous. To cut a deal with the White House on overhauling health care, they needed to be sure that President Obama would stop a proposal intended to bring down medicine prices.

title: Uncle Rays Dystopia
description: IF youd wanted to know which way the world was headed in the mid-20th century, you wouldnt have found much indication in any of the days literary prizewinners. Youd have been better advised to consult a book from a marginal genre with a cover illustration of a stricken figure made of newsprint catching fire.

title: Tracking Turkeys First Starchitect
description: The only way to arrive at Semsi Pasha Mosque is by water, my guide said as our little boat dodged two tankers on the Bosporus. On every shore around us, the domes and minarets of some of Istanbuls nearly 3,000 mosques delineated the skyline of a city that looks like no other.

title: What You Did for Your Financial Tuneup
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I encourage readers to take a day to do a financial tuneup and cross off as many things as possible from their money to-do lists.

title: The Structures of Sinan
description: He built on a monumental scale for the most powerful people on earth. Here is some of what he created.

title: Have Elite Fliers Been Downgraded?
description: A STEADY rain was soaking the windows of La Guardia Airport when Nancy Thode, an elite frequent flier with Delta Air Lines, approached a gate agent with a pressing question: Had her request for an upgrade cleared?

title: How to Fly V.I.P., Perk by Perk
description: Dont fly enough to earn elite status on an airline? There are plenty of other ways to buy those perks and preferred treatment, either  la carte or through the right credit card. Here is how you can fly like an elite passenger, even for one trip a year, on several airlines. (Carriers without an elite program were not included.)

title: No Extra Points for This Quiz
description: Not an elite flier? Youre in the vast majority. Globally, only about 4.2 million out of some 320 million frequent fliers are elite, according to Randy Petersen, founder of frequent-flier Web sites like FlyerTalk.com and MilePoint.com; most of us are just hoarding miles in hopes of one day swapping them for a coach ticket. The multibillion-dollar airline-loyalty industry has been around for more than 30 years. How much do you know about it?

title: New Russian Law Assesses Heavy Fines on Protesters
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin signed into law on Friday a measure that will impose heavy fines on people who organize or take part in unsanctioned demonstrations, giving the Russian authorities powerful leverage to clamp down on the large antigovernment street protests that began six months ago and seemed to be re-energized after Mr. Putins inauguration last month.

title: Shedding a Seedy Past in Paris
description: A sleek hotel, a natural wine shop and other businesses are giving the Bagnolet neighborhood new vitality.

title: Bed and Breakfast, Goats and Pigs
description: I ALMOST wanted to sleep right there in the barn, snuggling with Judy and Patsy. The 700-pound pigs, sisters abandoned as piglets, were living out their days on the Woodstock Farm Animal Sanctuary with a couple of hundred other creatures.

title: An American Safari in Montanas Outback
description: AS we crept out of camp, the morning sky was slowly turning pink. Smoke billowed from the kitchen tent where we had just filled our mugs with wood-fired coffee. A Smith & Wesson pistol hung awkwardly on my hip. The tops of the surrounding Swan Range began to glow orange with the sunrise. Our guide, Jack Rich, scoped the grassy patches below the closest ridgeline, looking for movement. After spying a small cluster of animals from a distance, Jack led my friend Marie and me even deeper into the Bob Marshall Wilderness Complex, a tranquil pocket of Montana backcountry commonly referred to as the Bob.

title: Rocking Summer Music Festivals
description: MADELINE FOLLIN, 23, a singer in the indie-pop duo Cults, grew up going to music festivals around San Diego, her hometown. Now she knows her way around them as a performer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re 36 Hours in Dresden, Germany (May 27): Weve been to Dresden many times and have always loved it. The collections in the Zwinger Palace can easily take a day, and the VW plant tour is fascinating. Did I miss a reference to the Green Vault? Its an amazing collection of decorative arts, some of which were shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Rob HouckMount Kisco, N.Y.

title: In South Korea, All Roads Lead to Yeosu
description: UNTIL five years ago, Yeosu was an unremarkable, out-of-the-way city on the southern coast of South Korea. Despite a temperate climate, scenic islands and a spicy local cuisine, the city was, among tourists, virtually off the map. A largely rural municipality spread out over a peninsula and 317 islands, it has three commercial and residential hubs that used to be the only places to find anything resembling bustle. Then fate smiled on the city. Yeosu (pronounced YUH-sue) was chosen to host the 2012 World Expo, the smallest city in a generation to have the honor.

title: Briton There at Pakistans Birth Stays at 94, a Living Textbook
description: CHITRAL, Pakistan  During a grand gathering of tribal elders in this rugged and remote mountain district recently, one guest of honor stood out: an elderly Englishman in a suit and polished shoes, his snowy hair carefully combed, the morning newspaper folded on his lap.

title: In Telematics Realm, Varying Approaches to Delivering a Connected Drive
description: Three deals struck this month in the arena of telematics demonstrate the speed with which connected features can migrate among platforms, as well as the influence large companies may exert over the content featured on the dashboards of the future.

title: People, Shops and Roads Converge Here
description: NO matter which neighborhood a Bronx resident calls home, most have been to the Hub, a convergence of streets in the South Bronx that is one of the boroughs most dynamic commercial centers. For Michael Reed, it was when his parents took him shopping for Easter clothes as a boy.

title: Name the Art That Calls Your Name
description: There is only one valuable thing in art: the thing you cannot explain, Georges Braque once said. It may be possible, however, to explain why you love a particular work of art, and in a column in Fridays Times, I made a stab at doing so, writing about my repeated visits over a decade to a wonderful, deeply unsettling Caravaggio painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Denial of St. Peter. It has become like a fascinating, stubborn, moody old friend  one I admire, argue with and dont pretend to know very well, even after so many years.

title: Living In | The Hub, the Bronx
description: A South Bronx neighborhood where most residential property is rent-stabilized, apart from a few new two-families.

title: Shooting at Laws in Ads (Literally)
description: Ron Gould, an Arizona state senator running for Congress, really, really doesnt want government to mess with anybodys health care. I noted that in a post yesterday, linking to a campaign ad that shows him blasting President Obamas health-care reform, the Affordable Care Act, with a pump-action shotgun.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.25 Million
description: The apartment on Park Avenue whereLeon Hess, the oil magnate and New York Jets owner, lived until his death in 1999 sold for $17.25 million, the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Jamess Brilliance, Considered on Its Own Merits
description: The most instinctive response to the play of LeBron James is a wide-eyed stare. The relentless loathing directed toward him may provide a constant white noise, but when LeBron is LeBron, all else is mute; theres no delight or celebration, but an awe that what weve witnessed should not be possible. James is often portrayed as both a hyper-flawed mortal and a peerless physical specimen, but at his most astounding, James is merely a transcendent basketball form. He doesnt steal our attentions with some uncharacteristic seriousness. He captures us in his raw gravity.

title: Just One Look | Derek Lam
description: There was a lot going on in the Derek Lam resort collection: leather pieces and safari/military jackets; stripes and animal spots; some swim, some chunky knits. Together it addressed every side of what is known as a rather schizophrenic season. (In November, when these clothes arrive in stores, are women shopping for the coming winter in New York or a holiday vacation in St. Barts? Or both?) The favorite, which three T editors each gravitated toward separately, was this belted handkerchief dress with buttons on the diagonal.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom lakefront contemporary in Wayne, N.J., and a five-bedroom colonial in Riverdale.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An East Village trilevel, a Turtle Bay duplex and a Brooklyn Heights duplex.

title: Business Day Live: Entrepreneur Moms
description: Sallie L. Krawchecks proposals for bank reform. Joseph E. Stiglitz on economic inequality. Balancing entrepreneurship and motherhood.

title: Birthday Gifts for Economists
description: Via Tyler Cowen, heres a novel gift idea for that beloved, binge-drinking economist in your life:

title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 460,000 Toyota RAV4s After Reports of Suspension Failures
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether about 460,000 Toyota RAV4s from the 2006-8 model years should be recalled because of suspension failures.

title: Dressing for Gilligans Island
description: As Ginger Grant on Gilligans Island, Tina Louise had a rather remarkable wardrobe for someone who was shipwrecked while on a three-hour tour. Those marvelous beaded dresses that just matched her skin tone surely were not just lying around on the S.S. Minnow.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batmans Early Days
description: Absolute Batman: Dark Victory lands at No. 8 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. The Absolute hardcovers from DC tend to cost $99.99, but they present the comics in an oversized format, with better paper and rich colors, so they are often worth the price of admission. Dark Victory, written by Jeph Loeb and illustrated by Tim Sale, is a sequel to The Long Halloween, in which Batman was learning the ropes, confronting the mob, discovering a new breed of freak (the Joker, the Penguin and more) and trying to discover the identity of the Holiday killer. Dark Victory is still set in the earliest days of the heros career. It picks up some dangling threads, brings Robin into the fight for justice and introduces the Hangman, another serial killer. These early looks into the careers of heroes have become something of a trademark for Mr. Loeb and Mr. Sale. Other recommend books: Superman For All Seasons, Daredevil: Yellow, Spider-Man: Blue and Hulk: Gray.

title: For the Patient Baseball Fan, a Beautiful Reward
description: Baseball fans are frequently asked by people who arent fans, How can you watch such a slow game?

title: June 10  16
description: THE desire of the worlds have-nots for a more prosperous and secure life in Western Europe informs two films  Emanuele Cialeses Terraferma and the twin brothers Massimiliano and Gianluca De Serios first feature, Seven Acts of Mercy  in the Film Society of Lincoln Centers series OPEN ROADS: NEW ITALIAN CINEMA. The series, which began on Friday and continues through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater, showcases the latest in contemporary Italian movies.

title: Sharapova vs. Errani: Serves Will Be Crucial
description: Maria Sharapova looks to complete a career Grand Slam when she faces Sara Errani in the womens singles final at Roland Garros on Saturday. Sharapova will be the overwhelming favorite, with her extensive experience and formidable arsenal of offensive weapons, but Errani has made an improbable run to the finals with upsets over former French Open champions Ana Ivanovic and Svetlana Kuznetsova, and Samantha Stosur, a finalist in 2010.

title: Touring Is a Tonic for Australians
description: ITS not every season the Lincoln Center studios ring with Gday! But thats about to change, at least for a week, when the Australian Ballet visits New York for the first time since 1999.

title: Electronic Woe: The Short Lives of Instruments
description: IN an onstage interview during an evening of music by Kaija Saariaho at Zankel Hall this spring Jeremy Geffen, Carnegie Halls director of artistic planning, asked Ms. Saariaho a provocative question, suggested by the nature of the music she was presenting. Though she writes prolifically for conventional ensembles, Ms. Saariaho also composes electronic music, and the works performed that evening not only combined live voices with recorded or electronically altered live sounds but also had video components, by Jean-Baptiste Barrire, that combined live and recorded elements.

title: TV Viewers Not Enamored With The Choice
description: The series premiere of Foxs new reality dating show The Choice on Thursday proved that simply putting celebrities in swivel chairs does not instantly create a ratings hit.

title: Video Preserves Hints of Future For a Director
description: JUST out of Harvard, the director Peter Sellars made his name in the early 1980s with a series of productions of Mozart and Handel operas set in the modern world. The broad outlines of the shows could be easily summarized: Le Nozze di Figaro in the Trump Tower, Cos Fan Tutte in a roadside diner in Massachusetts, Orlando in outer space.

title: Think Like a Doctor: An Ugly Rash Solved
description: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a 55-year-old woman with a fever, rash, bloodshot eyes and blood-filled blisters in her mouth.

title: Europe Preparing to File Charges in Universal-E.M.I. Deal
description: PARIS  The European Commission intends to file an antitrust complaint against Universal Music Groups proposed $1.9 billion acquisition of the E.M.I. music recording business, a top commissioner said Friday, citing concerns that the deal would reduce competition.

title: Detail by Detail, Guptas Lawyer Deconstructs Goldman Testimony
description: 6:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Reporter Accuses Syrian Rebels of Luring Him Into Death Trap
description: A British television journalist attempting to gain access to the site of a reported massacre in Syria accused rebel fighters on Friday of trying to get him and his colleagues killed by the Syrian military in an effort to draw condemnation against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Touch, Speak, Tap: Taking 5 Connected Cars for a Spin
description: IN the past, when an automaker wanted to distinguish itself, it simply had to show up its competitors: Ford had to beat Chevy, BMW had to outdo Mercedes, Morgan had to...

title: Merging Cellphones and Dashboards
description: SEEKING to please those customers clamoring for more features in their cars, General Motors will soon make a novel offer: give them less.

title: Rhythms for the Highway, Before the Age of the iPod
description: FROM the arrival of the earliest car radios in the 1920s to the advent of todays colorful dashboard display screens, automakers have been playing catch-up with consumer tastes and trends. Yet the key to providing an ideal blend of in-car information and entertainment  infotainment, in the lexicon  has long been close at hand.

title: Avedon to Warhol: Madrid Hosts Visual Arts Festival
description: PHotoEspaa is one of the worlds most wide-ranging photography festivals, encompassing the visual arts as well as photography. This year, works by more than 250 artists from 44 countries will be on view in galleries, installations, major museums and art centers through July 22. More than 700,000 people visit the festival annually, making it Spains most popular cultural event. Andy Warhol, Richard Avedon, Carlos Garaicoa, Santiago Sierra, Chen Chieh-jen, Alberto Garca-Alix and Helena Almeida are just a few of the top artists whose works will be exhibited.

title: Physicists, Stop the Churlishness
description: A KERFUFFLE has broken out between philosophy and physics. It began earlier this spring when a philosopher (David Albert) gave a sharply negative review in this paper to a book by a physicist (Lawrence Krauss) that purported to solve, by purely scientific means, the mystery of the universes existence. The physicist responded to the review by calling the philosopher who wrote it moronic and arguing that philosophy, unlike physics, makes no progress and is rather boring, if not totally useless. And then the kerfuffle was joined on both sides.

title: Not a Pretty Picture (Rowing = Pain)
description: When crews are seen from high overhead, as they are in our latest Look pages, they arent bodies pulling on oars; theyre geometries  parallels and circles and angles acute and obtuse. Seen from the shore, they typically strike viewers as all swinging gliding gracefulness.

title: A Close Bond and the Unending Toll of 9/11
description: Eleven years ago this summer, Lt. Harry Wanamaker Jr., a 58-year-old veteran New York City firefighter assigned to Marine Company 1, posed proudly on a fireboat against the skyline of Lower Manhattan with Welles Remy Crowther, 24, an equities trader at Sandler ONeill & Partners who worked on the 104th floor of 2 World Trade Center.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 8
description: Subjects include the ceremony for the new Ashanti chief, the plummeting population of red knots and the space shuttle Enterprises arrival at the Intrepid.

title: Comcast Is Said to Be Mulling Bid for BSkyB
description: 5:05 p.m. | Updated Comcast is exploring whether the British Sky Broadcasting Group, Britains largest satellite broadcaster and a lucrative pay TV asset 39 percent owned by News Corporation, could become available for purchase, according to several people briefed on the companys strategic thinking.

title: Joyce Carol Oates Wants To Clear Things Up About Mudwoman
description: No, Joyce Carol Oates says forcefully: the protagonist of her new novel is not based on Harvard University President Drew Gilpin Faust.

title: Republicans Take Aim at Obamas Doing Fine Comments
description: Four years ago, President Obama eagerly seized on Senator John McCains comment that the fundamentals of the economy are strong to paint his Republican rival as out of touch with a plummeting reality.

title: Just One Look | Roksanda Ilincic
description: Roksanda Illincic has never been one to shy away from color, and resort has her seeing red  and lots of it. At the heart of the collection is a lacquered cotton that the designer cut into a simple car coat (which she showed cinched with a sliver of a white belt), a high-waisted dress and a pair of skinny trousers. The pants served as the underpinning for a series of lean, almost tuniclike dresses, whose graphic, asymmetrical color blocking, she said, was inspired by the work of Ellsworth Kelly and Kazimir Malevich.

title: Obama Backs Away From Fine Comment
description: President Obama on Friday afternoon backed away from his earlier comments that the private sector is doing fine, telling reporters that he does not believe the economy is doing fine.

title: Now Click It, Rent It And Buy a Plane Ticket
description: The vacation rental company HomeAway joins with Priceline this week to allow customers to book plane tickets and car rentals in addition to homes.

title: Nader Criticizes Ads on Yankees Radio Broadcasts
description: Ralph Nader, famous for his consumer crusades and presidential campaigns, has found a new target for his advocacy: ads read on WCBS-AM during Yankee games by John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman.

title: Senator Raises Questions About Nominee for Iraq Ambassador
description: Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, is raising questions about Brett McGurk, President Obamas nominee for ambassador to Iraq, after leaked e-mails surfaced purporting to show that Mr. McGurk had a relationship with an Iraq correspondent for The Wall Street Journal while he was the Bush White Houses top Iraq adviser.

title: Pressed to Take Bailout, Spain Tries to Measure Its Need
description: MADRID  Spain appears poised to seek a bailout of its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment by the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of the depths of Spains economic crisis.

title: Sept. 11 Health Fund Given Clearance to Cover Cancer
description: A federal health officials ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: For Euro 2012, Germany Has Impressive Depth
description: Soccer, like most sports, is a team game which, in the vaguest definition, revolves around 11 players who must work together in a series of carved out positions and tactics to enable the most efficient means of obtaining and exploiting a small leather ball to allow them to win a game.

title: Peter Gleicks Pacific Institute Return
description: After an internal investigation, Peter Gleick has been reinstated as president of the Pacific Institute, the environmental group largely focused on water and climate that he founded in 1987. The career of this seasoned and lauded scientist and policy analyst ran off the rails when Gleick masqueraded as a member of the board of the anti-regulatory Heartland Institute to obtain internal documents on budgets and strategies. (He undertook this deception even as he was heading a task force on scientific ethics for the American Geophysical Union.)

title: Live From Lincoln Center Creator to Depart
description: John Goberman, who created PBSs much-honored series Live From Lincoln Center more than three decades ago, is leaving as the shows executive producer at the end of the month, Lincoln Center said Friday.

title: DealBooks Week in Review: Nobody Is Happy
description: Institutional investors joined in on proxy fights, JPMorgans front-line regulator faced a fiery round of questioning, Nasdaqs plan to settle Facebook claims met investor anger and the turf war between MF Global trustees grew increasingly tense. A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in ferocious finance.

title: Bonnaroo: Alabama Shakes Commands the Big Stage
description: Alabama Shakes have had a wild year: a transformation from small-town bar band to national and international exposure.

title: Vintage M.F.K. Fisher
description: Inextricably bound up with M.F.K. Fishers lifelong passion for food was the pleasure she took from sipping and serving a simple house wine, a crisp aperitif or a prickly, delicious glass of Champagne. In M.F.K. Fisher: Musings on Wine and other Libations (Sterling Epicure; $19), Fishers biographer, Anne Zimmerman, gathers all of the eminent food writers essays on drink under one beautifully designed cover. Some of these gems have been plucked from well-known collections, like The Art of Eating and Long Ago in France, but many others  the entertaining a Vintage Spat, for example, and the rousing Wine is Life  have been out of print for decades. For Fisher fans, coming across these is like reading an as-yet-unopened letter from a dear old friend.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Bahrain, West Bank and Egypt.

title: Badgley Mischka Previews Resort Collection via Pinterest
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated Every day another brand tries exercising its digital muscles, from starting a Tumblr to live-streaming its runway shows. The bridal and resort seasons seem to be an opportune time for designers to experiment.

title: As Summer Nears, Cold Noodles to Chill With
description: MAYBE cold pasta makes you think of some mediocre quasi-Italian grab-and-go deli choice in a plastic clamshell. Or perhaps that classic American picnic oddity, the macaroni salad.

title: Even With All Those Seats, the Driver Is Left Out
description: INFINITIS advertising tagline is Inspired Performance. And the mission statement of the Nissan luxury brand has long been clear: performance means taking whacks at BMW, and inspiration typically means undercutting BMWs prices, especially with the estimable G sedan and coupe.

title: Home 3-D Scans Made Cheap
description: This weekend, lots of people will head to theaters to see Prometheus and Madagascar 3 in 3-D. A year from now, people could be seeing themselves that way, in their own homes.

title: Under Budget Pressure, Regulator Gets Support From Former Chief
description: Republican lawmakers want Wall Streets smallest regulator to shed some more pounds.

title: Sure, He Can Spell Opodeldoc, but Hows His Noo Yawk-Speak?
description: Twelve-year-old spelling whiz Arvind Mahankali of Bayside, Queens, barely bats an eyelash at words like distelfink, phrontistery, opodeldoc and uayeb, all of which he has successfully dispatched at the Scripps National Spelling Bee, where he placed third last week, the second time in two years.

title: Has Guns, Wears Dress, Seeks Justice
description: Revenge is between seasons, and Dog the Bounty Hunter is on its last legs. Whats a fan of revenge-and-bounty-hunting-themed television to do? On Saturday night the Hallmark Movie Channel steps forward with relief: Hannahs Law, a tasty western tale that seems just right for a weekend in June.

title: At Least It Has Seven Seats...
description: The Infiniti JX35 crossover tries so hard to mimic other brands family values  while still being different  that it ties itself into a knot.

description: Historic events always make instant souvenirs out of the tickets that proved you were there. This was certainly the case when Johan Santana pitched the Mets first no-hitter last Friday and ostensibly reserved for the 27,069 officially in attendance at Citi Field.

title: The Shepherdess in All Her Glory
description: Odd and original but not quite satisfying, The Golden Veil, a production of the National Theater of the United States of America at the Kitchen, is like a cabinet of curiosities, stuffed with bits and pieces of European and American culture: myths and pastoral legends; gothic dont-go-into-the-woods stories; songs that wouldnt be out of place on Harry Smiths Anthology of American Folk Music; dances, courtly and otherwise.

title: House Ethics Panel Wont Release Waters Report on Misconduct Investigation
description: The House Ethics Committee refused to release on Friday the internal material it used for its decision earlier this week to move ahead with charges against Representative Maxine Waters of California.

title: At a Concert, Even the Birds Chime In
description: OJAI, Calif.  The superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes was a natural choice to be music director of this summers Ojai Music Festival, which opened on Thursday evening here in Californias beautiful Ojai Valley. Mr. Andsnes has long felt strongly about the culture and environment of his homeland. For years he was a co-director of the Risor Chamber Music Festival in a small coastal town in southeastern Norway, where distinguished musicians young and old gather each summer for six busy days of concerts and camaraderie, and the music-making takes inspiration from the place itself: a charming, rustic fishing village.

Vladimir Krutov, Wing for Soviet Hockey Teams in the 80s, Dies at 52
description: Vladimir Krutov, a husky Russian hockey player who combined speed, strength and lightning-quick wrists to become a critical component of the superb Soviet teams of the 1980s, earning the nickname the Tank, died on Wednesday in Moscow. He was 52.

title: Cold and Warm, Chicken and Noodles
description: This weeks City Kitchen column features one of my warm-weather favorites, a rice noodle salad garnished with sweet herbs, peanuts and grilled chicken.

title: Employment of Recent Law Grads at an Ebb
description: The share of law graduates employed a year out of school fell again last year to its lowest level since 1994, according to NALP, the Association for Legal Career Professionals.

title: Senior Team Trial for World Mind Sports Games
description: The 90-board final of the senior team trial for the second World Mind Sports Games ended on Wednesday in Schaumburg, Ill. The winner will represent the United States in Lille, France, in August.

description: Ready for a cocktail? Jim Meehan, owner of Please Dont Tell, shows Melissa Clark a few tips and tricks of making cocktails.

title: A Loud Call for Cheering at Classical Concert Halls
description: It is a grim vision of the classical music concert: a sea of hollow-eyed faces in the dark, shushing the slightest peep during boring evenings stifled by ritual. The antidote? Audience members should be able to laugh, to clap in midperformance and to whoop with joy, if so moved. That would make classical music less boring and less awful, less a musical North Korea.

title: Cocktails: Mixing an El Presidente
description: Ready for a cocktail? Jim Meehan, owner of Please Don't Tell, shows Melissa Clark a few tips and tricks of making cocktails.

title: From the Union of Concerned Scientists, a Framework for Reducing Oil Consumption
description: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit American watchdog group, released a framework document this week for reducing the projected oil use of the United States by half over 20 years. On its Web site, the organization characterized its Half the Oil Plan as a clear, achievable road map to significantly curb the nations dependency on oil.

title: Yesterdays Latest Things
description: Over the years, automakers have overcome many technological challenges to introduce their in-car information and entertainment systems. Some proved fabulous, while others were flops.

title: For Romance as a Game, Heart Gets in the Way
description: SAN DIEGO  The mushrooming of reality television and its lunatic subgenres might seem an unpromising subject for satire. How can you spoof a phenomenon that has metastasized so quickly that late-night comics have mostly left it behind as barren turf?

title: Chic in Review | Miley Cyrus, Unavailable
Successes in Rhetoric: Language in the Life of Churchill
description: The orotund proclamations will be unavoidable at the new exhibition Churchill: The Power of Words, at the Morgan Library & Museum, because at the center of the gallery is a semi-enclosed theater. And from it, however muted, will emerge recordings of Winston Churchills voice, speaking to Parliament, to British radio listeners and to American audiences, breaking on the ear like waves, rising and falling with every breath, sometimes suspended unexpectedly in midair, other times rushing forward with renewed vigor.

title: Small Fire Breaks Out in De Niros Apartment Building
description: A small fire broke out Friday afternoon in an apartment building on Central Park West where Robert De Niro lives, according to Fire Department officials and residents of the building.

title: For Labor, a Fight to Lead Heats Up
description: The nations largest union of state and local government workers  the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees  faces another important election this month, beyond last Tuesdays recall vote on Wisconsins governor, Scott Walker, who retained his job despite the unions all-out effort to oust him.

title: Traveling Far From Home, but Without Adventures
description: What has the choreographer Marie-Christine Giordano received for exchanging her native Switzerland for the urban jungle of New York? In honor of her companys 10th anniversary, she has created In and Out, a new work, press notes say, about trading the security of home for a life of surprises.

title: Young Lovers Thwarted by Crime, Jail and a Mean Stepmother
description: The Runaway, a British mini-series being shown by the Ovation channel, is not your average tale of young lovers battling a coldhearted society. Its bloodier, for one thing  in the first three hours, the young lovers kill three people between them, in gruesome fashion. Also, everyone thinks theyre brother and sister.

description: A list of cancers now covered under the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act.

title: Democrats Hit Romney on Message of Wisconsin Comments
description: Democrats sought to turn the tables on Mitt Romney Friday afternoon by seizing on comments he made in Iowa that suggested the country doesnt need more firefighters, police or teachers.

title: Derek Jeter, Mets Killer
description: If any player deserved to be excited by the arrival of the Subway Series, Derek Jeter was a likely candidate. The slumping Jeter went into Fridays game with the highest career batting average, .381, of any player against the Mets with a minimum of 150 plate appearances.

title: Warm, Spicy Fare From the Himalayas
description: ITS sometimes said that what Nepal grows best are mountains; the cold, rocky altitudes there pose significant challenges to farming. But despite the limitations of their environment, the people living in the valleys of the Himalayas have developed delicious dishes incorporating grains, nuts, and local meats and vegetables.

title: The Hard Life on The Rock
description: Theres a scene late in Murder in the First in which Willie, a prisoner at Alcatraz, recalls his grim and troubled life. Why have people been so cruel to me, he wonders aloud to his lawyer.

title: Ryan Lochte, Olympic Swimmer and Sex Symbol
description: Mr. Lochte, 27, is being groomed to be a breakout Olympic superstar, with millions in corporate sponsorships to match his athletic accomplishments.

title: Egyptians Warned Not to Talk to Foreigners. Really.
description: Updated | Saturday, 1:42 p.m. CAIRO  An advertisement broadcast on Egyptian television this week warned a talkative public not to open up to foreign visitors, in case their new friends turn out to be spies seeking to undermine the state.

title: A Repertory Far Beyond Italian
description: WHEN Joseph Tartaglia was searching for a name for his newest restaurant, someone suggested the fruit his family cultivated when he was growing up. Thats how he settled on Figs Wood Fired Bistro, a lively lunch and dinner spot in Sandy Hook that is much more about wood-fired than it is about figs.

title: Formula One and Civil Unrest, Chapter IV: Montreal
description: MONTREAL  Remember Bahrain? In April, the Formula One series received near universal criticism for holding its race in a country experiencing a social uprising that brought daily demonstrations against the government, where the safety and the smooth running of the race were in doubt  to say nothing of the questionable morality of running the race in place accused of oppressing its citizens.

description: Word began to circulate just after 11 at Belmont Park on Friday morning. It almost seemed unbelievable. But it was true.

description: There will be more indie bands, I promise. But for now a gorgeous performance suggested by reader Andre from Warsaw.

title: U.S. Agency to Sell Off Loans to Stem Foreclosures
description: In a move intended to prevent foreclosure for thousands of homeowners and shed some seriously delinquent home loans, the Federal Housing Administration will sell off distressed mortgages in bulk, the housing secretary said Friday.

title: Next Stop: Lattes or Gumbo
description: Two new cafes have sprung up on Walnut Street, near the New Jersey Transit rail station, close enough to serve trainbound commuters but appealing enough to tempt customers to settle in for a while.

title: L Trains Are About to Become More Frequent
description: Claustrophobic Brooklynites rejoice: Starting on Sunday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will add 98 weekly round trips on the L line, an attempt to ease overcrowding and waiting times on one of the transit systems most popular punching bags.

title: Political Passions
description: AS the whirring election-year political machinery whips us into an us-versus-them frenzy, a visitor from another planet might look at it all and assume that Washington was either the entertainment capital of the country or an entirely fictional place brought to life on a Hollywood soundstage.

title: Persian Cooking, Old-World Style
description: SUBTLETY is the hallmark of the kind of traditional Persian cooking on the menu at Ravagh Persian Grill, a nondescript-looking place flush up against a narrow strip of River Road in Edgewater. More fragrant than spicy, long on delicate, balanced flavors and short on anything startling, its stoutly Old Worldish fare; the focus is on pita dips, kebabs, stews and rice, with a few seafood dishes thrown in for American diners.

title: Reviewing the Infiniti JX35
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2013 Infiniti JX35, a midlevel luxury crossover with three-row seating. Infinitis targets include the Acura MDX and Lexus RX, but the JX shoots wide of the mark, Mr. Ulrich writes:

title: Week in Pictures for June 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the ceremony for the new Ashanti chief for metropolitan New York, the plummeting population of red knots, and the space shuttle Enterprises arrival at the Intrepid museum.

title: Bill Cunningham | Frontiersmen
description: There is not a shadow of a doubt that the spotlight on dressing today is totally on mens wear.

title: Holder Directs U.S. Attorneys to Track Down Paths of Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday assigned two United States attorneys to lead separate criminal investigations into recent disclosures to the news media of national security secrets, saying they were authorized to follow all appropriate investigative leads within the executive and legislative branches of government.

title: A Pioneer in a Mad Mens World
description: SINCE Mad Men arrived five years ago, immediately ascending to the status of compulsion, weve been spared few reminiscences from survivors of corporate debauchery in mid-20th-century Manhattan.

title: The Space Age Prophet
description: Austin, Tex.

title: Exciting Firsts at Shades of Jazz
description: IN his six years as the curator of Shades of Jazz, a summer concert series at the Katonah Museum of Art, the guitarist John Scofield has built a reputation for pushing programming boundaries  a reputation that stands to grow this year with his booking of two decidedly eclectic performers, the multiethnic singer Cyrille Aime and the Saturday Night Live saxophonist Lenny Pickett.

title: The Irrepressible Auntie
description: Louise Pitre knows how to punch home a song. Starring as the irrepressible title character in Mame at the Goodspeed Opera House, she lends a fierce energy to the snazzy choreography by Vince Pesce and the efficient book scenes of Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee. But its not until everyone else departs and shes left alone on James Youmanss stylish set to sing the shows rueful, climactic Jerry Herman ballad, If He Walked Into My Life, that this production comes fully into its own.

title: Blowing Glass Is His Day Job, and His Other Job, Too
description: JERSEY CITY  As he wielded a hand torch in a cluttered two-car garage one recent night, Kiva Ford admitted, I really dont have time for a relationship because I love glass too much.

title: Untraded Yankee Keeps Trying to Justify Teams Faith
description: The Yankees were playing in Detroit last Friday night, while Johan Santana was twirling the first no-hitter in Mets history back home. Phil Hughes noticed  it was all but impossible to miss  and he said he was happy for Santana. But the two have never met.

title: Finding Humor and Pathos in Divorce
description: Angela Kennedy Lipsky was once half of the happy couple Angela and Matt. But as we meet Angela, now middle-aged, in My Brilliant Divorce, by Geraldine Aron, Matt has left her for a 25-year-old woman from Argentina after a long affair that Angela knew nothing about.

title: Majoring in Eligibility
description: The lead article in The Chronicle of Higher Education this week is about a University of Memphis football player named Dasmine Cathey. He lives not on campus but in his aunts home nearby, where he helps raise his siblings, who were essentially abandoned by their mother. He has two children of his own (with different mothers). He uses his Pell grant money to help pay the household bills and often skips class because he has to drive a family member somewhere. Its a lot for a college student to shoulder, but he doesnt shirk it.

But New York City police pension officials have refused to disclose the names of retirees receiving pensions and the amount of the benefits. Those officials  unlike other state and local officials  decided to hide behind an ambiguity in the states Freedom of Information law.

title: How Morning-After Pills Really Work
description: Religious conservatives are losing one of their primary arguments for trying to ban the morning-after birth control pill that can prevent pregnancy if taken within days after sexual intercourse. They and their political allies have long contended that the pills work by aborting an embryo at the earliest stages of development. But, as Pam Belluck reported in The Times on Wednesday, the latest scientific findings and expert opinion indicate that the pills work by delaying ovulation so that sperm cant fertilize an egg to create an embryo.

title: A Day of School Revelry, Capped by Wine
description: The neighborhood restaurant plays a limited, but critical, role in New Yorks culinary life: It is the place one goes not to be surprised, but satisfied. Its always a little surprising, then, to find one thats more than satisfactory. Saggio, a homey, full-flavored trattoria at 829 West 181st Street, is one of the newer restaurants in the micro-neighborhood that sits on the downslope between Fort Washington Avenue and the Henry Hudson Parkway in Washington Heights. On a late spring evening, you will find its front window invitingly thrown open to homebound commuters, congregating dog owners and perhaps a group of teachers from a local elementary school relaxing after a hard day with some pasta and a glass of wine.

The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement.

title: Shh! Scholars Fight Over Library Plan

And yet here we are. During recent weeks, the debate surrounding the New York Public Librarys plan to expand its central branch at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street has fiercely intensified in print, online and in public forums. Amid the heat and acrimony, few have taken the time to recognize what this might signify for the progress of civilization in a world otherwise dominated by 140-character discussions of Mob Wives.

title: Devils Receive Possible Cash Infusion

A person briefed on the pending transaction said that Vanderbeek had found at least one investor to inject cash into the team and deal with its overdue debt. The person who described the estimated $200 million deal said it would lead to a reduction of the 47 percent stake owned by Ray Chambers and Michael Gilfillan. At the same time, part of the $77 million debt payment owed by the team and Prudential Center will be repaid as part of the complex transaction. Banks have extended the deadline for repaying the debt; if they had not, the team would have been in default. The deal was first reported by The Sports Business Journal.

description: At the United States Open championship, the charm and the challenge for the worlds best golfers is coping with a course many of them have not played for more than a decade, if at all. This years site is the Lake Course of Olympic Club in San Francisco, a little bit of heaven with mostly sidehill fairways that drift down from the sandy cliffs above the Pacific Ocean through sentries of cypress trees and sloping target greens to the shore of Lake Merced. The clubs name calls to mind Mount Olympus, the home of the mythical Greek gods, but at its four previous Opens over more than half a century, Olympic has treated human golf gods rudely. And what glorious gods they were.

Her mother, Patti Barton, was a trailblazer for women jockeys, and Brothers, her sister and her brother followed in her footsteps. When Brothers retired in 1998, she was the second-winningest female rider in the United States by money earned. But she never strayed too far away from the sport she loved. She is married to a horse trainer, Frank Brothers, and works as an analyst for NBC Sports and TVG.

Kushner of Ransomville, N.Y., and the late Michael G. Kushner. Rabbi Dov Taylor officiated at the Lareau Farm Inn in Waitsfield, Vt.

Doty and George E. Doty Jr. of New York. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.
