description: Lilian E. Yip and Anthony A. Yang were married Thursday at Holy Trinity Church in Honolulu. The Rev. Dennis Koshko, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Libert, Daniel Sterner
description: Elizabeth Clark Libert and Daniel Brent Sterner were married Saturday evening at the Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston. The Rev. Cheryl Rubin Lloyd, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Bruce Edelstein, Francesco Spinelli
description: Bruce Leon Edelstein and Dr. Francesco Luca Spinelli were married Wednesday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a staff member in the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Jocelyn White and Robin Martin
description: Jocelyn White and Robin Bradley Martin were married Saturday evening at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Crisis for Italy? Lets Have a Look at Them First
description: In an age when the term crisis is applied to almost every degree of hardship, no matter how trivial or petty, its meaning is often lost. In soccer, a series of injuries or a streak of defeats often constitutes such a classification. Under this criteria, to label the problems faced by Cesare Prandellis Italy squad heading into this summers European Championships as a crisis seems something of an understatement.

title: Mets Wait for Davis to Show More Power
description: The Mets roster is constructed differently from the Yankees, so the fact that the Yankees have four more home runs than the Mets in the first two games of the Subway Series should not be surprising. But playing in a small ballpark, the Mets need more power in their lineup to match the Yankees. And Manager Terry Collins simply does not know where to find that power.

title: Prometheus Offers a Creationist Indulgence for Science Geeks
description: Prometheus, the new movie from the director Ridley Scott, operates on several levels. Most importantly and impressively, it is an unforgettable reminder not to open anything, ever. Doors, caves, containers  never open them!

title: Parise Scores All-Important First Goal for Devils
description: NEWARK  The inexhaustible Zach Parise finally had one of his own goals to celebrate in the Stanley Cup finals Saturday, and, as a bonus, it came with the Devils on the power play. Parise whooped it up, slamming his right fist into the glass before his teammates swarmed him.

title: Conflicts Endanger Reform in Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  Its a sad and nasty problem thats playing out in western Myanmar, a dispute that has turned violent in recent days and perhaps even threatens to derail the countrys fragile attempts at democratic reform.

title: Pacquiao Loses to Bradley in Stunning Split Decision
description: LAS VEGAS  Timothy Bradley talked about timing.

title: A Day With No Timeouts
description: Images from a supremely busy June day in sports, around the world and in the New York City area.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: There seems to be no escape from bad news this week, with in-depth analysis of Indias faltering growth story dominating leading publications. Indias recently announced gross domestic product growth, at 6.5 percent for the year ending March 31, 2012, was the lowest in a decade. The figures come as the rupee is plummeting, faith in the economy is waning and the criticism of the current central government rises.

title: From Las Vegas to the Philippines, Shock Over Pacquiao Loss
description: HONG KONG  The undefeated American boxer Timothy Bradley won a controversial upset over Manny Pacquiao of the Philippines on Saturday night in Las Vegas, scoring a split decision that brought Pac-Mans Filipino fans, celebrity supporters and even other boxers onto Twitter to express their outrage.

title: Where Electoral Forecasts Agree and Disagree
description: FiveThirtyEights initial 2012 presidential forecast found President Obama as a slight favorite to win re-election. These projections are unique, both in means and ends, but the FiveThirtyEight model is operating in a crowded field.

title: Bonnaroo: DAngelo, Back in the U.S.A.
description: Bonnaroos late-night surprise was a doozy: the return of DAngelo, the all-around soul man who has not played a concert in the United States since the end of his 2001 tour for his album Voodoo, a masterpiece released the year before.

title: The EuroTARP Cometh
description: OK, so Spain gets a bank bailout. Its basically like the TARP: a Spanish government agency will give banks cash, presumably in return for an ownership stake, with the goal of reassuring depositors and interbank lenders that their funds will remain safe even if the banks turn out to have big losses; the point is that these losses will initially come out of the new cash hoard, so that default on debts wont happen.

title: Latvian Competitiveness
description: As Simon Wren-Lewis says, theres something about the Latvian experience that causes many people to leave their critical faculties at the immigration desk. I think its mainly the fact that austerians need a hero, and Ireland keeps failing to deliver. But whatever.

title: Three Killed in Shooting Near Auburn University
description: AUBURN, Ala.  Three young men, two of them with ties to Auburn Universitys football team, were killed and three others were wounded during a pool party on Saturday night at an apartment complex near the campus here.

title: Mens Final of French Open Postponed Until Monday
description: Play was halted in the 2012 French Open mens singles final between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal with Djokovic to serve in the fourth set at 4-6, 3-6, 6-2, 2-1. It was the first mens final at the tournament since 1973 to be postponed to another day.

title: Uniting Through a Prayer Call
description: On a recent Tuesday at noon, a dozen live-in home health aides  all from the Bronx  dialed a conference-call number. They phoned from their elderly patients small apartments in Queens and from spacious houses in New Jersey and Connecticut. Within seconds, they were connected to their pastor, Benjamin Boakye, of Ebenezer Assembly of God Church on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Wright Gallery Opens
description: For aficionados of Frank Lloyd Wright, the new SC Johnson Gallery in Racine, Wis., offers another attraction on the fan circuit.

title: Snorting the Good Grade Drug
description: Students feeling pressure to succeed arent snorting cocaine or heroin, but Adderall, an amphetamine prescribed for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. One student told a New York Times reporter that he and his friends routinely shared to study late into the night, focus during tests and ultimately get the grades worthy of their prestigious high school in an affluent suburb of New York City. The drug did more than just jolt them awake for the 8 a.m. SAT; it gave them a tunnel focus tailor-made for the marathon of tests long known to make or break college applications. Read the full story here, and follow more stories from high school students hereor share your own.

title: Disruptions: For HBO, Still Beholden to a Cable Company
description: After cutting the cable TV cord two years ago, Im often a bit late to the conversations about hot new shows. So last week, after hearing friends rave incessantly about Game of Thrones, I gave it a try.

title: London Theater Journal: Another Prisoner of Noble Title
description: LONDON  What do you suppose shes really thinking beneath the mask of majesty? All that nonstop pomp and pageantry must feel like a straitjacket. And surely she has disturbing things on her mind at the moment  worries about her husband, for one  as her reveling subjects pay such ostentatious tribute to her. Wouldnt you just love to know whats going on inside that serene head of hers?

title: Euro 2012: Italy-Spain As it Happened
description: Heres how The Times called the action from Gdansk as tournament favorites Spain battled Italy.

title: In Europe, Banks Borrowing to Stay Ahead of the Tide
description: LONDON  As Europe works to prop up Spains wobbling banks, its leaders still face a problem that plagues the Continents increasingly vulnerable financial institutions  a longstanding addiction to the borrowed money that provides the day-to-day financing they need to survive.

title: Crisis in Myanmar Over Buddhist-Muslim Clash
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar declared a state of emergency on Sunday in a western state where at least 17 people have been killed this month in violence between Buddhists and Muslims.

title: Santorum Ready for Convention Battle with Paul
description: Rick Santorum plans to lead a strong pro-Romney effort at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., that can serve as a counterweight in case Representative Ron Paul and his supporters are looking for a platform fight, he said in an interview that was broadcast on Sunday.

title: A Higher Calling
description: Benjamin Boakye, pastor of the Ebenezer Assembly of God Church in the Bronx, reaches out to his congregation through modern means.

title: Watch the U.S. Open for Free Lessons
description: While the Masters in April heralds the flowering of another golf year, the United States Open lures Americans to the television for a midseason challenge more vicarious in character and charm.

title: Kenyan Government Official Killed in Air Crash
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon  A top Kenyan official, who grew up chasing cows in the Great Rift Valley and went on to become one of the most powerful men in the country, was killed Sunday morning when the police helicopter he was riding in plunged into a forest west of Nairobi, Kenyas capital.

title: Madagascar 3 and Prometheus Lead Weekend Box Office
description: Strong turnout for the latest Madagascar movie gave DreamWorks Animation a shot in the arm over the weekend, while Ridley Scotts Prometheus proved an R rating isnt always a ticket-selling handicap.

title: Pro-Obama Super PAC Up With New Bain Attack
description: Priorities USA Action, the pro-Obama super PAC, is up with a new anti-Mitt Romney advertisement that takes aim at Bain Capitals stewardship of a steel mill whose closing led to the loss of hundreds of jobs.

title: Europe Dodges a Bank Crisis in Spain, but Perils Lurk
description: FRANKFURT  With an agreement to bail out Spains struggling banks, Europe again avoided financial chaos in a debt crisis that is in its third year. But Europe still faces far bigger challenges that threaten the Continent and, with it, the world economy.

title: Lax Security at LinkedIn Is Laid Bare
description: SAN FRANCISCO  LinkedIn is a data company that did not protect its data.

title: Pentagon and Congress Argue Over Hospital for Troops
description: WASHINGTON  As the Pentagon and Congress argue over how to shrink the military to fit smaller federal budgets, no debate over matching money to mission is more heartfelt than the order to shut down the premier overseas hospital for grievously wounded troops and replace it with a new one.

title: Bonnaroo: The Red Hot Chili Peppers Get Funky
description: With the Red Hot Chili Peppers playing the headlining set, one through-line for Bonnaroo on Saturday was funk. The festival offered up funk as motion, as repetition, as a mathematical pattern, as a process, as a communal project, as a yardstick of history and a reason to just dance.

title: Mad Men Creator Matthew Weiner Reflects on the Season So Far
description: Warning: this post contains spoilers for the first 12 episodes of the Mad Men season.

title: Used to Winning With Ease, Kings Tripped Up by Final Victory
description: NEWARK  In the end, as the minutes wound down in Game 5 on Saturday night, as they had in Game 4, the officials never had to think about pulling the Stanley Cup from its protective case. The Los Angeles Kings, who were poised to parade it around a rink in celebration, proved in two losses to the Devils that they may still be the better team, but that they are not ready to hoist the prize. They proved the theory that the final win is the hardest, and perhaps that the Stanley Cup will not be won  cannot be won?  until you have done something truly hard.

title: Once and Clybourne Park Win Top 2012 Tony Awards
description: On Sunday night, The New York Times brought you live coverage of the Tony Awards with photos from the red carpet and the show, commentary from Charles Isherwood and Dave Itzkoff and behind-the-scenes reports.

title: A Mahler That Stands or Falls on Its Finale
description: NEWARK  Mahlers Ninth Symphony is a brave undertaking for a smallish band. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra ended its season, its second with Jacques Lacombe as music director, with performances of that work over the weekend. (Mr. Lacombe closed his first season, last year, with Mahlers Third Symphony, also a difficult but arguably less challenging assignment.)

title: Excavating Family Truths
description: Playwrights, be fearless about what you put into your plays. But then be ruthless about what you cut out of them. Even your best lines can be lost if theyre just tossed into an ocean of words.

title: Movement, Interrupted and Extreme
description: When Andrea Miller began choreographing her latest dance, Sit, Kneel, Stand, her point of inspiration was the myth of Sisyphus and his eternal task of rolling a boulder up a hill, only to watch it roll back down. For its premiere at the Joyce Theater on Friday night, what lingered from that initial impulse were the ideas of effort and resilience, both spiritual and physical. Members of Ms. Millers Gallim Dance compressed or stretched their bodies to extremes, returned to form and started all over again. Presented in conjunction with the Gotham Dance Festival that concluded over the weekend, the production did offer a glimpse into a new direction for Ms. Miller, whose dances, up to this point, have been energetic but unoriginal. They take much from Gaga, a movement practice created by the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin. There are traces of Gaga in Sit, Kneel, Stand but, encouragingly, the performance is more than a Gaga class.

title: Poems in Four Voices, a Concerto in Two
description: That David Robertson is a superb conductor of contemporary classical music hardly needs repeating. Evidence is everywhere in reviews worldwide and in the vivid memories of those who have heard concerts he has led. But what makes Mr. Robertson one of the most extraordinary musical advocates of our day has just as much to do with what he does off the podium.

title: A Dancers Strange Route to Paradise
description: Amy Sherman-Palladino loves an idyllic hamlet. On her signature series, Gilmore Girls, for which she was creator and executive producer, it was Stars Hollow, with its town-square gazebo and folksy diner and ample places for unlikely intimate conversation.

title: Festive Late Nights, Festive Mornings
description: OJAI, Calif.  As much as you love a masterpiece, as much as you think you know it well, you can still be perplexed by its hold on you. Composers experience this with particular intensity. Most spend lots of time analyzing great works of the past to uncover their inner secrets.

title: Velvet Gloves Over Iron Fists
description: Here we go, Tony Soprano said in the first episode of The Sopranos when Dr. Melfi, his psychiatrist, reached for her prescription pad. Here comes the Prozac.

title: True to Form, Mets Are Sloppy and Yankees Need a Homer
description: The baseball that leapt off Russell Martins bat, splashed into the left field stands and brought a sudden end to a wild contest at Yankee Stadium also reinforced two recently popular notions about the teams playing there Sunday afternoon.

title: The Fallacy of the Hijacked Brain
description: Of all the philosophical discussions that surface in contemporary life, the question of free will  mainly, the debate over whether or not we have it  is certainly one of the most persistent.

title: Dylan Ratigan Leaving MSNBC
description: Dylan Ratigan, the opinionated and sometimes hotheaded television host, is leaving MSNBC, the cable channel where he has worked for the last three years.

title: Gupta Wont Testify at His Insider Trading Trial
description: Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs accused of leaking secrets about the bank, will not testify at his insider trading trial, according to a letter from his lawyers that was filed with the court on Sunday.

title: Expo Offers a Peek at Games of the Future
description: LOS ANGELES  You know youre at the worlds most important video game convention when breakfast is a bacon double cheeseburger scarfed while crouched on the floor of a hallway packed full of nerds like me and young women in skimpy, corporate-branded halter tops.

title: Mix of New and Newer for an Eclectic Festival
description: BUFFALO  June in Buffalo has a bifurcated mission that makes it an odd duck among new-music festivals. Founded in 1975 by the composer Morton Feldman and held annually on the campus of the University at Buffalo, it is partly a celebration of recent works performed by expert ensembles, both local and imported, and partly an intensive weeklong boot camp for budding young composers: 25 of them, from around the world, winnowed this year from nearly 100 applicants.

title: Liberation as Death Sentence
description: When Civil War History published a paper this spring raising the conflicts military death toll to 750,000 from 620,000, that journals editors called it one of the most important pieces of scholarship ever to appear in its pages.

title: Festival Plans to Connect Jewish Arts
description: For almost 100 years the National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene in New York has churned out productions in the old language of Eastern and Central European Jews, nursing and expanding a cultural connection. Theater officials are now stretching their horizons with plans for an ambitious international Jewish arts festival in New York in 2015, featuring performances and workshops in many languages exploring Jewish identity.

title: A Backstage Pass to a High-End Food Festival
description: WHILE affluent connoisseurs sample the offerings this week at the annual Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., the public will get a look behind the scenes.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Sweet Core, Steely Edge
description: To follow Billy Joels sober hymn, And So It Goes with the frantic chromatic babble of Clifford Brown and Jon Hendrickss Joy Spring is quite a leap for any singer. But Karrin Allyson made it look easy on Thursday evening at Birdland. Her show, whose selections change with every set, is a celebration of a 13-album career that is one of the most stable in jazz. She has an easy mastery of bebop, bossa nova, chanson and soft rock, to name four of the many styles in which she is comfortable.

title: Bridging Past, Present and Future
description: This season the Brooklyn Philharmonic, revived from the dead, traveled to three of the boroughs communities with tailor-made concert series. In October the orchestra took Russian cartoon music to Brighton Beach and in March, an ambitious program full of premieres to Downtown Brooklyn, a new-music epicenter as of late.

title: Like Buttah
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  This one left a great taste with me. Clean. Smooth. All the answers FELL into the right place at the right time. My pencil point never even broke, not once.

title: Ensemble With Piano Wires, Off the Wall and Ceiling
description: Whenever an artist produces something so boggling and so inexplicable as to defy more than a cursory understanding at first brush, I am reminded of the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarkes suggestion that any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic. There was magic in the air on Thursday evening at the Eyebeam Art and Technology Center in Chelsea, when a new piece by Eli Keszler, L-Carrier, was introduced before a rapt audience.

title: Newspaper as Business Pulpit
description: There is a growing worry that the falling value and failing business models of many American newspapers could lead to a situation where moneyed interests buy papers and use them to prosecute a political and commercial agenda.

title: With Nadal Ahead but Out of Sorts, Final Is Suspended
description: PARIS  The Rafael Nadal on court late Sunday afternoon at Roland Garros seemed more like an impostor, so unlike Nadal, on his favorite surface, at his favorite tournament, getting bullied around on clay. The snarl was still there, the face all twisted and contorted; however, it came not from the usual dominance but from anger over circumstance.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be reported this week will include import prices for May (Tuesday); retail sales for May, the Producer Price Index for May and business inventories for April (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for May and the current account deficit for the first quarter (Thursday); and industrial production for May and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for June (Friday).

title: Google Outsells, but Apple Cultivates Loyalty of App Developers
description: Smartphones running Googles Android operating system outsell iPhones more than two to one. And yet, even as Googles system has gobbled up market share, Apple has held onto one critical advantage  the loyalty of mobile app developers.

title: Judi Radin at Trial for World Mind Sports Games
description: Some top players just grind out wins, playing better than their opponents. But there are a few who have an extra insight into the game, seeing possibilities that many would reject or never consider.

title: Getting to the Heart of a Joycean Masterpiece
description: Bloomsday  June 16, the day of the events in James Joyces masterpiece Ulysses  approaches and with it the release of Alan Adelson and Kate Tavernas documentary In Bed With Ulysses, a film that strips away the academic clutter surrounding that kaleidoscopic novel to reveal the vital human pulse between its lines. It does so with staged readings of the livelier passages (not, I emphasize, re-creations of them), period footage and insightful commentators (including the Irish novelists Colum McCann and Edna OBrien), not to mention humor and a palpable enthusiasm.

title: A Chronicle of Cairo Protests
description: Begun in January 2011 amid mass demonstrations in downtown Cairo, Tahrir: Liberation Square had its official premiere scarcely six months later at the Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland. That makes it a hot document as far as movies go, recording events with ramifications yet unknown to Egyptians or the rest of the world.

title: A Conversation with Pea Nieto
description: An excerpt of an interview with Enrique Pea Nieto, the former governor of Mexico State who is the front-runner ahead of the July 1 presidential election in Mexico.

title: Russia Arrests 5 in Inquiry on Protest
description: MOSCOW  Russian authorities said Sunday that they had arrested five more people in a continuing investigation of clashes between protesters and riot police officers at a demonstration on May 6, the day before Vladimir V. Putins inauguration for a third term as president.

title: Allies Restrict Airstrikes on Taliban in Civilian Homes
description: WASHINGTON  The senior allied commander in Afghanistan has ordered new restrictions on airstrikes against Taliban fighters who hide in residential homes, coalition officials said Sunday, a move in response to a NATO attack in the eastern part of the country last week that Afghan officials say killed 18 civilians.

title: A Fan at an Event She Once Dominated
description: ST. LOUIS  Shawn Johnson, a gold medalist at the 2008 Olympics, walked into the arena to watch the United States gymnastics national championships on Sunday and felt her stomach flutter and her body start to shake.

title: Radio Royalty Deal Offers Hope for Industrywide Pact
description: For decades, the recording industry has lobbied Congress to change how radio stations pay royalties. The broadcasters have lobbied just as hard to preserve the status quo, making an agreement look all but impossible.

title: Luck and Shooting Accuracy in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  One of the great mysteries of the 2012 playoffs is how the Kings suddenly transformed from a mediocre team that barely made the playoffs to the juggernaut they have been in the postseason. Even after losing two straight games for the first time this spring, courtesy of the revivified Devils in the Stanley Cup finals, they are still 15-4 in the postseason.

title: Gay Parents and the Marriage Debate
description: Slate is out with two pieces today on an attention-getting new study that looks at adult outcomes for children raised by parents in same-sex relationships  one by the studys author, the University of Texas sociologist Mark Regnerus (who co-authored the excellent survey Premarital Sex in America), and a response by Will Saletan that tries to tease out some of the studys implications for the gay marriage debate. The background to the study is the striking fact that even as traditional marriage has declined in the United States  marriage rates tumbling, out-of-wedlock childbirth climbing, and cohabitation becoming as respectable as wedlock  the evidence has mounted for the institutions importance to the well-being of children. A happy childhood is possible in many different environments, of course. But a growing body of research indicates that no other parental arrangement, from single motherhood to cohabitation to shared custody, affords as many social, economic and emotional advantages as being raised by two biological parents joined in a lifelong commitment. (Isabel Sawhill from the Brookings Institution and Kay Hymowitz from the Manhattan Institute have both had good recent pieces elaborating on some of these themes.)

An oversize botanical print tee bloomed over a pair of pin-thin white trousers with a black waistband  ideal for gardening with the C.Z. Guest crowd. Contrasting the prim and pretty pieces Wu is known for were electric blue leather separates: a motorcycle jacket, a pencil skirt with an exposed zipper. Flourishing alongside these were a bevy of evening looks, including a black crystal embroidered dress and a peekaboo black and cream jersey top over a navy sheer skirt. This sporty crochet striped bikini with matching boy shorts and color-blocked backpack is destined for a trip to Turks and Caicos, where Wu is headed as soon as the season closes.

title: Warming Will Unlock Carbon in Forests, Study Warns
description: Climate scientists have long been concerned about the possibility that warming temperatures will speed changes on the earths surface that will in turn accelerate global warming. The best illustration of such a feedback loop involves the melting of sea ice in the Arctic. The ice reflects solar radiation back into space rather than absorbing it. When it melts, it leaves open water that absorbs the heat rather than reflecting it. The more warm water there is, the more ice melts, and so on.

The conviction that led to Mr. Smiths death sentence arose from another multiple murder that year. Lawyers for Mr. Smith had argued that his death sentence in the latter case was obtained largely on the basis of the previous conviction and should be vacated because of the Supreme Courts ruling. The Orleans Parish District Attorneys office plans a retrial in the case the court addressed.

title: Ice Cream or Candy

Collinss puzzle. Weve got MOON RIVER, RED RIVER, WILD RIVER and even THE BRIDGE OVER THE RIVER KWAI running through the grid. Oh, yes, and theres the RIO BRAVO there in the southeast.

title: Faith and Commerce, Precariously Balanced
description: Burdens are just about equally distributed among the eclectic characters in Storefront Church, John Patrick Shanleys unwieldy but affecting new play about a handful of Bronx dwellers whose lives become tangled in unexpected ways when a mortgage goes sour. With the exception of one willfully oblivious bank executive, the men and women who find themselves gathering for a church service at the plays conclusion all feel a measure of sorrow from the hard compromises life demands  but perhaps also a sense that burdens are lightened when shared.

title: U.S. Expects Tough Game, and Rough Reception, in Guatemala
description: Tuesdays weather forecast in Guatemala City calls for scattered thunderstorms and a 40 percent chance of rain: pretty much what one would expect for a Central American country during its wet season.

title: Growing Jewish Population, Especially in Brooklyn
description: After falling in the 1990s, the Jewish population of New York City and three suburban counties has rebounded.

title: Now, Spain
description: Two weeks after Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain vowed there will be no Spanish banking rescue, and after days of delay in which Mr. Rajoy pressed European officials for sounder rescue terms, Spain has now joined Greece, Ireland and Portugal as the latest bailout recipient. Catastrophe averted? Hardly.

title: Debates Main Quarrel: If Rangel Should Retire
description: Congressman Charles B. Rangel, participating in the first debate of his primary campaign, looked around at his four Democratic challengers on Monday and decided that none of them had made a very good case about why they should replace him.

title: A New Outsider Arrives at the United States Open
description: SAN FRANCISCO  He is a multiple champion this year who won one of his titles in a playoff at the expense of the three-time major champion Ernie Els. And he is not Jason Dufner. The South African Branden Grace comes into this weeks United States Open  his first  with three European Tour victories in 2012, including one in sudden death against Els and Retief Goosen, a two-time United States Open champion.

title: Giants Lineman Charged With D.W.I. After Crash in Queens
description: David Diehl, a longtime offensive lineman for the Giants, was arrested and charged with drunken driving after crashing his BMW into a row of parked cars in Astoria, Queens, on Sunday night, the police said. Diehl was alone in the car. No injuries were reported.

title: An Election Half Empty
description: It was a statement of such unqualified certainty that Jeb Bush made it pretty much in passing, as if it required no elaboration, accommodated no dissent and was the obvious starting point from which all political discussion should flow.

title: Ukraine: Gunpowder Accident
description: Eight people were injured in a small fire on a trolley car on Monday in the city of Dnipropetrovsk. Local prosecutors said the accidental fire occurred when a passenger dropped a bag of gunpowder, causing it to ignite. The accident renewed fears of terrorist attacks in the city, where four explosive devices detonated in late April, wounding 38. This was not an explosion  this was an ignition of gunpowder that is not a terrorist action, a prosecutor, Natalya Marchuk, told the Interfax news agency, adding that an investigation would be conducted.

title: Miscues Costing a Mets Team With No Room for Them
description: First, there was the optimism engendered by the Mets surprising start to the season. Then came the euphoric afterglow from Johan Santanas historic no-hitter. But now all the good feelings have been pushed aside by a week of deflating losses in which the Mets were continually victimized by their own defensive lapses.

title: Health Reforms Consumers Want
description: UnitedHealthcare, one of the nations largest health insurers, announced this week that it would keep some of the popular benefits and consumer protections required by the federal health care law even if the Supreme Court strikes down all or part of it.

title: Israel: Memorial Vandalized
description: Vandals spray-painted graffiti overnight Monday on the walls of Yad Vashem, Israels official Holocaust memorial, with messages attacking Zionism and blaming Zionists for the Holocaust. Nearly a dozen messages were scrawled around the Warsaw Ghetto Square monument and other parts of the campus. One said, If Hitler hadnt existed, the Zionists would have invented him, and another said, The Zionists wanted the Holocaust. One message was signed Global Haredi Judaism, fueling suspicions that those behind the act were ultra-Orthodox Jewish extremists who reject the modern state of Israel.

title: San Francisco Hotel Has Ties to Champions
description: SAN FRANCISCO In the city billed as the gateway to San Francisco there sits a hotel that can claim to being a portal to the United States Open championship. The El Camino Inn on Mission Street has ties to two of the four United States Open golf champions crowned a few miles away at the Olympic Club.

title: Keeping the Mountains Safe
description: Members of Mountain Rescue-Aspen are responsible for saving those lost or injured in the mountainous terrain of Pitkin County.

title: Detained in Libya
description: A Libyan militia has detained four officials of the International Criminal Court since Thursday on spurious charges. They should be released immediately.

title: Keeping a Mountain Rescue Team on Its Game
description: ASPEN, Colo.  More than 70 people were focused on one stout rock cliff here. Forty were members of Mountain Rescue-Aspen, the team responsible for saving those lost or injured in the mountainous terrain of Pitkin County. The rest, drawn from other rescue teams in the region, were watching to see how they did.

title: Could Reagan Lead This G.O.P.?
Goldman Brings Back a Former Partner
description: Goldman Sachs has rehired Mark Schwartz to serve as the chairman of the banks Asia-Pacific region and as a vice chairman of the overall bank.

title: Novas Strong Outing Helps Yankees Vault Into First
description: ATLANTA  After an odd few weeks in the wilderness, when no one could get a clutch hit or pitch a dominant game, the Yankees finally got back to a place they always expected to be. With a 3-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Monday night, the Yankees were back in first place in the American League East for the first time since April 24.

title: In Greece, Cultural Costs of Austerity
description: Greek budget cuts are affecting archaeologists, which in turn means fewer protections for antiquities.

title: Greek Antiquities, Long Fragile, Are Endangered by Austerity
description: KYTHIRA, Greece  A jarring public-awareness ad that has appeared recently on Greek television news shows a little girl strolling with her mother through the National Archaeological Museum in Athens, one of the countrys cultural crown jewels. The girl skips off by herself, and as she stands alone before a 2,500-year-old marble statue, a hand suddenly sweeps in from behind, covering her mouth and yanking her away.

title: Saving a River, and Its Species
description: On Monday morning, wrecking crews began demolishing the 1,000-foot-long Great Works Dam in Bradley, Me., the first step in a multiyear effort to restore ancient fish runs on the Penobscot River. This is a very welcome development for the environment and a tribute to the willing collaboration of many players, public and private.

title: Kodak Concedes Difficulty in Drawing Lead Bidder for Patents
description: Eastman Kodak late on Monday sought to set up a confidential auction for its portfolios of over 1,100 patents, after the bankrupt film pioneer acknowledged it had encountered difficulty drawing a lead bidder.

description: With a 3-0 victory over the Braves in Atlanta, the Yankees reclaimed a piece of first place in the American League East for the first time since April 24. They had fallen as far as last place on May 21. Since then, they have won 14 of 18 and climbed 10 games over .500, a season high, to catch the idle Tampa Bay Rays.

description: Voucher is a fighting word in education, so it may be understandable that when Mitt Romney speaks about improving the nations schools, he never uses that term.

description: Frank Cady, a character actor best known for playing the down-home shopkeeper, Sam Drucker, on the popular 1960s sitcoms Petticoat Junction and Green Acres, died on Friday at his home in Wilsonville, Ore. He was 96.

description: LOS ANGELES  After 62 days of playoff domination, spearheaded by sensational goaltending, the Los Angeles Kings completed their improbable Stanley Cup run Monday night in a mere five minutes.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY  In a moment of introspection and thoughtfulness, LeBron James was short-circuited by a short circuit. A slight crackle, then silence as the podium microphone sputtered in midsentence.

description: This years N.B.A. finals feature two strikingly different offenses. Over all, the Oklahoma City Thunder rely on penetration-and-pitch plays that create 3-point and close-range shots. The Miami Heat, in contrast, rely on strategic player positioning to create effective spacing for isolation plays that enable midrange and close-range scoring chances for their superstars.

title: In a Time to Shine, India Cant Get Off the Ground
description: Like China, India has long been eager to showcase the best features of its fast-growing economy on the international stage, Gardiner Harris writes in The New York Times. But whenever it gets a chance to shine, something almost invariably goes wrong.

description: LOS ANGELES  Minor disturbances broke out around Staples Center on Monday night after the Los Angeles Kings beat the Devils, 6-1, in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals to capture their first championship.

title: Dial 108 for Ambulance in Tamil Nadu
description: The village of Kottaiyur is about a three-hour drive southeast from Bangalore, in the Krishnagiri district of Tamil Nadu. Kottaiyur is inhabited by 4,000 Irulars, who are classified by the state government as a tribal community. Although the village is connected with the nearest town, Denkanikottai, which is 30 kilometers (19 miles) away, by a concrete road, the bus service linking the village with the outside world is sporadic and unreliable.

description: In some Gulf states, schools have a surprising problem: To fight against the ubiquity of English while teaching Arab students high-quality Arabic, of the sort that could be used at a professional broadcaster like Al Jazeera.

description: LOS ANGELES  The N.H.L. released a list of notes and numbers surrounding the Kings Stanley Cup run. Taken together, they form an impressive portrait of just how good the Kings were this postseason. A look at some of those facts and figures:

title: Trial of Son Taints Pakistans Venerated Chief Justice
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans chief justice has wielded his court as a whip against the status quo, the countrys rich and powerful, calling top government officials and military spymasters to account and asserting himself as a political force in his own right. But on Tuesday he found himself at the center of a new political firestorm when a well-connected property baron stood up in court and accused his family of corrupt dealing, detailing $3.7 million in kickbacks and cash payments.

title: Euro 2012: A Quick Take on 4 Days, 8 Games and 16 Teams
description: Every team at Euro 2012 has played one game, so what do we know? In a tournament with some of the most expensive talent from some of the most expensive leagues in the world, Alan Dzagoev (CSKA Moscow), Mario Mandzukic (Wolfsburg) and Andriy Shevchenko (Dynamo Kyiv) are the unlikely leaders in the race for the Golden Boot; Carlos Velasco Carballo  the Spanish referee who flashed four yellow cards and the tournaments only two reds in the events first game  has a future as a blackjack dealer; and the only Dutchman on track for the quarterfinals is Russias coach, Dick Advocaat. Lets recap briefly the standings after the first four days:

title: British Ex-Premier Says Murdoch Press Lowered Tone
description: LONDON  As the judicial inquiry into the British press sifts painstakingly through competing claims about the influence of Rupert Murdochs newspapers, former Prime Minister John Major disclosed on Tuesday, for what he said was the first time, that Mr. Murdoch withdrew his newspapers support for the Conservatives after Mr. Major refused a demand for changes in his policies on Europe.

description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article The Making of an Olympic Sex Symbol.

title: India Gets Waiver for Oil Trade With Iran
description: Less than three weeks before stringent American sanctions intended to reduce Irans oil exports take effect, the Obama administration announced on Monday that it would exempt seven major importers of Iranian oil  but not China  from the measures because these countries had significantly reduced their oil purchases from Iran, Mark Landler writes in The New York Times.

title: So You Think You Can Be a Hair Braider?
description: Jestina Clayton grew up in a village in Sierra Leone where every girl learns traditional African hair-braiding. Then, when she was 22, she moved to Centerville, Utah, a place where no one learns traditional African hair-braiding. So Clayton was pleasantly surprised to find a niche in the market among a small group of Utah parents who had adopted African children but didnt know how to style their hair.

title: Yes, Bob Kerrey Wants to Go Back to Washington
description: When Bob Kerrey left the Senate after two terms in 2001  mainly, he says now, so he could remarry and start a new family away from politics  he was considered a statesmanlike and contemplative presence in a city that still valued both qualities. Kerrey had been a serious presidential candidate, a respected voice on health care and intelligence and co-chairman of one of those bipartisan commissions to reform entitlement programs. His closest friends included the small crowd of Vietnam veterans from both parties  John McCain, John Kerry, Chuck Hagel, Chuck Robb, Max Cleland  for whom party loyalty seemed well down the list of daily concerns.

title: Africans Documenting Africa
description: Taking something as broad  and, for many, abstract  as climate change,and making it a palpable reality is the task undertaken by the Ghanaian photographers Nyani Quarmyne and Nii Obodai. Mr. Quarmyne, 39, objects to a common, Western understanding of climate change: whether to buy double-glazed windows or hybrid cars is, for many Westerners, as tangible as the situation is going to get.

title: Heavier Weapons Push Syrian Crisis Toward Civil War
description: WASHINGTON  With evidence that powerful new weapons are flowing to both the Syrian government and opposition fighters, the bloody uprising in Syria has thrust the Obama administration into an increasingly difficult position as the conflict shows signs of mutating into a full-fledged civil war.

How Greece, the birthplace of Western democracy, votes may have fateful consequences both for this country and for the dozens of countries who use the euro or belong to the European Union, the most ambitious project of free states and free people that this Continent has ever known.

title: Large Anti-Putin Protest Signals Growing Resolve
description: MOSCOW  Tens of thousands of protesters thronged central Moscow in a drenching rain on Tuesday, voicing renewed fury at President Vladimir V. Putin and defying recent efforts by his government to clamp down on the political opposition movement.

description: As someone who rarely chooses to pay the prevailing rate at auction for top-tier closers, Im often left spending the next six months chasing anyone on my waiver wire(s) who may be even remotely in the mix for saves. description: Despite Union Ragss stirring rally in Saturdays Belmont (for which I congratulate him and his connections heartily), I missed the hoopla and anticipation of seeing Ill Have Another take a crack at the Triple Crown.Then again, is it that surprising that a racehorse that went all out to win the Derby and the Preakness came up injured before the last dance? Just another argument that todays thoroughbreds are genetically engineered for speed and aggression, not the soundness and stamina it takes to win three Grade I races in five weeks.

title: It Is What It Is

Id hoped to lighten the mood with a game of backgammon, but we struggled through each roll of the dice. Maans literary cafe in Damascus, once a haven for bright minds and dissident intellectuals, shuttered months ago. Now he wore the exhaustion of a drawn-out struggle. Without adding to his anguish, I wanted his take on one question: has Syria passed a mark, into a state of civil war?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Why the Bailout in Spain Wont Work | The euro zones offer of $125 billion to bail out Spanish banks over the weekend was hailed by finance ministers and officials across Europe as a masterstroke. But by now, it should be apparent that the bailout has failed  or is at least on its way to failing, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column.

Given his position, and the sacred status Latvia has acquired among the austerians, he is necessarily cautious in his wording. But the substance is pretty much the same as what I said: one year of pretty good growth after an incredible decline  growth that still leaves you 15 percent below previous peak  is not exactly a proof of concept for fiscal austerity.

title: A Regular Evening Escort
description: Dear Diary: As a very tired floor nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital in Harlem, I often took a cab home after work to my apartment in Inwood. Over the course of two years, a particular livery cab driver began to anticipate my schedule and would often wait for me outside the hospital around the end of my shift. I appreciated this, as it meant I did not have to haggle over the price of my ride with a different driver every night.

title: The Get | Perrins Attelage Minaudire
description: The specialty leather-goods brand Perrin Paris is probably foreign territory to even the most seasoned Madison Avenue shopper. But theres nothing low profile about Perrin. After nearly 12 decades of being availableexclusively in France, and more recently in Beverly Hills, Calif., the Parisian fashion house has opened shop in New York Citys Carlyle Hotel (987 Madison Avenue). The house is known for glove making, sunglasses and handbags, and is a favorite among high-profilers like Beyonc (a fan of the Menotte Clutch), P. Diddy (Cabriolet driving gloves) and Martha Stewart (who helped design the companys jet-set travel pouch). Often, American women look for practicality in a bag whereas les Francaises understand it is more about the image and the completion of a look, says Sally Perrin, the creative director of the fourth-generation-run business. We bridge the past with the present by creating witty and unique designs. The Attelage Minaudire is a perfect example: a classic ladylike purse by all accounts but made new in a novel itsy-bitsy size. Its a wrist ornament, Perrin says, noting that the bag is available in goatskin, crocodile, lambskin, shagreen and, come fall, lacquered wood. Its an accessory in every sense of the word.

title: The White Light Festival Turns to Dark-Hued Mahler
description: White Light, Lincoln Centers fall festival dedicated to humanitys spiritual side, will present Esa-Pekka Salonen conducting Mahlers Symphony No. 9 with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London next season, the center said on Tuesday. The festival will feature the jaw-harp virtuoso Wang Li; the organist Cameron Carpenter playing Bach in Alice Tully Hall; and a Stockhausen program. The announcement of the new season, to run for a month starting on Oct. 18, said the series would also include the United States debut of the Latvian Radio Choir; a Charpentier program by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants; a music-theater work by Heiner Goebbels called I went to the house but did not enter, with the Hilliard Ensemble; and an appearance by the singer Mary Chapin Carpenter.

description: Amid the claps, sweat and tears at the Adidas Grand Prix on Saturday in New York was a major victory for the high jumper Jamie Nieto.

description: Trader Joes Secrets: An advertising executive, one Mark Gardiner, was curious about how Trader Joes became so successful without any advertising. So he went undercover as an entry-level employee when the chain opened its first store in Kansas City.  Julia Moskin

title: Speaking to the Haves, in a Plea to Consider All the Have-Nots
description: Rich people have more power than poor people, and they use that power to get what they want  which is, normally, more wealth and more power. Across America, politicians invariably reflect the views of their richest constituents. And the Federal Reserve, too, appears to have been captured by the rich: It seems much more worried about the specter of possible future inflation (which might be bad for the rich) than it is about the tragedy of present-day unemployment (which is calamitous for todays jobless).

title: Artisanal Threads | Graymarket in Williamsburg
description: Williamsburg is already recognized as a center of artisanal pickle, jam and cheese production. With the recent opening of Graymarket, a by-appointment-only boutique-cum-gallery dedicated to dead-stock clothing made by designers like Paul Harnden, Carpe Diem, Carol Christian Poell and Katie Gallagher, its time to add artisanal clothing to that list. The Graymarket founders, Wei Du and Alex Kasavin, met online, where artisanal clothing fans buy, trade and spend many, many characters analyzing the provenance and lineage of their limited-edition obsessions. Buttonholes, stitching, dye lots  these kind of things are taken very seriously, Du says. People try to find out exactly what tannery the leather in a jacket comes from. Many artisanal clothing designers work in black, the better to emphasize the tailoring and technique that goes into each garment, and thats reflected in the goth cast of many of the clothes on Graymarkets racks. But Due and Kasavin stress that theyre not purists, a stance theyve underlined both in the tongue-in-cheek name they gave their shop  its a reference to goods being traded legally but not via the distribution channels intended by their manufacturers  and in the stock they carry, which includes the work of both small-scale, cult studios and boldface names like Balenciaga, Givenchy and Alaa, designers that not all artisanal enthusiasts would accept as legit. We dont want to be about labels, Kasavin says. To us, its about technique and narrative, not about limiting what we can sell. We take something glam, like a jacket by Givenchy, and hang it next to something with a more street feel. We want to open up the possibilities.

description: During last summers lockout, Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra returned to his native Pacific Northwest and, from the sidelines of a University of Oregon summer football practice, found basketball inspiration. As he watched the Ducks cut and fly about the field, their mad scientist coach  Chip Kelly  orchestrating a gridiron alchemy that helped put the struggling program back into the national spotlight, Spoelstra forged in his mind a template for what the Heat could be: fast, quick, devastating, and  perhaps most important  built around precise spacing and the peerless penetrating abilities of LeBron James and Dwyane Wade.

description: In the end, Los Angeles threw hockey a proper party Monday night. The silver streamers were a classy touc,h and the Kings fans were more than appropriately raucous for a Stanley Cup-clinching victory over the Devils. The Kings who skated with the Cup over their heads were nothing but completely deserving after a 6-1 scorching, proving all the necessary grit and resilience, proudly representing underdogs everywhere by having accomplished this as a No. 8 seed. The only glitch came when the crowd failed to follow hockey etiquette and boo Commissioner Gary Bettman, at which point you might have noticed Canada collectively rolling its eyes. Amateurs.

description: LONDON  Pay for top managers in Britain rose 10 percent last year, a report released on Tuesday showed, providing fresh ammunition for critics who argue that executive pay has become excessive.

description: There were plenty of familiar elements at Cline yesterday  wide-leg slacks, car coats, color blocking and scarves wrapped tightly around the neck, to start  but the familiar felt desirable, still. Loyalists, a k a the creatures of comfort who have the luxury of getting very comfortable with wearing Cline, appreciate designer Phoebe Philos consistency, and the fact that she builds collections upon collections and offers new pieces that work seamlessly into a wardrobe of old ones. Come November, you might layer in this animal spot, for example, but you need not buy a brand new white pant or scarf to achieve the look.

But watching The Witness, Vivienne Franzmanns absorbing new play at the Royal Court Theater, I really felt like part of the family, as if I might be allowed to lean over and nibble off a characters sandwich or change the television channel. And when the insults and accusations started flying, my first instinct was to run to my bedroom and slam the door.

description: My latest Drink column is, essentially, an updated Dublin pub crawl, culminating at the charming L. Mulligan Grocer in Stoneybatter. My friend and I enjoyed our dinner there as much as our drinks: he had chicken stuffed with black pudding and beets, and I had one of the best steaks Ive had in recent memory. There were no false notes: this was delicious and honest food featuring Irish ingredients, thoughtful but not overthought. (And the menus are a treat, too: beautifully written and fitted inside vintage books. It was this attention to detail that impressed us most on our visit to Mulligans.)

title: Fire and Warming  Different Forecasts for Tropics and Temperate Zones
description: Researchers using a decade of satellite data on fires and a suite of climate models have produced the first thorough global estimate of changes in the frequency of fires in the worlds forests under greenhouse-driven global warming. Theres ample uncertainty but the study, published today in the peer-reviewed online journal Ecosphere, points to a variety of outcomes, with fires likely becoming more frequent in zones you might expect  like temperate North America and particularly the western United States  but rarer in the tropics.

title: Pressures on Predators Lead to Marshland Die-Offs

They crouch like low, dark smudges on the salt marshes at dawn after feeding on the surfeit of Sesarma crabs through the night.

He is referring to the looks, like this one, inspired by the 26-year-old artist Aaron Moran, whose reclaimed and rough-edged wood sculptures always have a smooth finish (sort of like Gurungs work). Here, a cubist silk and cotton mikado blazer and tuxedo short would be fun even without the red waistband and bright blue collar.

You look out the window and your grass is so long its waving like wheat. Your car, unwashed for weeks, is splotched with branches and pollen. And theres a stranger at the breakfast table. Oh, its your spouse. Sorry about that, hon. Youre looking so good I almost didnt recognize you.

title: An Offbeat Guide to Confident Cocktails
description: They call themselves the Jellymongers, but Sam Bompas and Harry Parr, who have created models of St. Pauls Cathedral and other landmarks in gelatin, do not include Jell-O shots in their new book, Cocktails With Bompas & Parr. Instead, they have written an exceptionally sensible if somewhat cheeky treatise on the cocktail, with recipes. It will make you smart, able to comprehend the cocktail long before you reach for a shaker, and primed to mix a fine drink once you do.

title: Wines and Spirits With Provenance
description: Wines that are true to their terroir, and to the history and culture of their region, line the light wood shelves of Flatiron Wines & Spirits, a new no-frills shop. If they are natural, organic or biodynamic, so much the better. Thats the wine philosophy of its managers, Beau Rapier and Dan Weber, who worked at Uva in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Regions they like include Burgundy, the Loire Valley, Piedmont, the Rhone Valley, the Mosel, Champagne and Northern California. They also regularly curate three tables of 100 wines each (red, white and ros), all for less than $15 a bottle, from the 1,500 or so wines in the store.

title: Reverting to Ice to Chill the Wine
description: As the heat bears down once again, there are scores of gadgets for chilling wines. But instead of frozen gels and wraps and whatnot, these glass carafes rely on the simplest method: ice. You pour in the wine, then fill an insert with ice cubes, cooling the wine from the inside out. A bottle of room-temperature white can be a palatable 45 to 50 degrees in about 40 minutes. (You may have to refill the ice holder to maintain the chill during serving.) The insert in the Metrokane model (below, left) is metal, so the ice does not melt quite as fast as in a glass insert.

title: Artists Fearless Aura, in Film, Chair or Tub
description: The Artist Is Present, the centerpiece of an identically named 2010 retrospective of work by the performance artist Marina Abramovic at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was one of those rare events that breach the wall dividing the art world from popular culture. Over 90 days  from the beginning of March through the end of May  hundreds of thousands of people streamed through MoMA, lining up (sometimes after camping out on 53rd Street the night before) for the opportunity to see Ms. Abramovic face to face. She sat in a plain wooden chair, gazing straight ahead, silently, into the eyes of whichever museum patron happened to be seated across from her.

title: World Bank Warns Euro Fears May Slow Global Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank on Tuesday warned that fears about the euro zone had reduced investors tolerance for risk, and it urged poorer economies to protect themselves by reducing their debts.

title: Sweet and Spirited, Chocolates for Dad
description: Mom is the one who usually gets the fancy chocolates; for Dad, its a bottle. But Vosges Haut-Chocolat has come up with a gift that has both, putting the booze in the bonbons. The company has packed an assortment in a handsome vintage-style cigar box. There are two sleek dark chocolate bars with a thin filling of gooey caramel flavored with stout; a box of nine chocolate truffles with rye whiskey, Scotch, bourbon or chocolate stout ganache inside (the Scotch, a smoky Islay, is the most assertive); some nonalcoholic peanut butter bonbons; and caramels with and without bacon.

Perhaps there will be some breathtaking dunks from Dwyane Wade and LeBron James, or late-game heroics from one of the Thunders young stars. Certainly the first championship for either James or Kevin Durant will be one for the history books. For statisticians, however, it will be another case of great offense versus great defense.

title: Requiem for the Oddities of Isa
description: One time a food critic from another city asked me what kind of food Prune served. I had a hard time answering, because the restaurant seemed uncategorizable to me; the place looked like a bistro, but the menu didnt look like a bistro menu, or like any other menu in town. Finally I resorted to telling him about the dishes: They serve canned sardines with Triscuits, I said. Theres bone marrow, and a dish that has an octopus tentacle next to a beef tongue.

description: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

title: Girlfriend of Crime Boss Gets 8-Year Prison Sentence
description: BOSTON  Catherine E. Greig, the longtime girlfriend of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger, was sentenced on Tuesday to eight years in prison for her role in helping him elude the authorities during the 16 years the two spent in hiding.

title: Wayne Roberts, Stay High 149 in Graffiti Circles, Is Dead at 61
description: Wayne Roberts was a pioneering 1970s graffiti writer known as Stay High 149 who borrowed the haloed stick figure from the title sequence of the 1960s television series The Saint, put a joint in its mouth and turned it around. His Smoker tag, or signature, turned the heads of legions of imitators and admirers, including the anonymous teenagers who slipped into train yards at night to paint whole cars, as well as Norman Mailer, who featured him in his book The Faith of Graffiti.

description: TUCSON  Ron Barber, whom former Representative Gabrielle Giffords picked as her successor, defeated his Republican rival on Tuesday in a closely followed special election seen by many political strategists as testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive races.

title: For One Day, Formula One Parks at the Crossroads of the World
description: Short of strumming a guitar in ones underwear, there are few fail-proof ways to compel passers-by to stop and gawk in Times Square. Formula One, the international open-wheel racing series, gave it a shot Monday, bringing a white and gray racecar from the Sauber team to promote coming races in the United States.

description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank called on Tuesday for euro zone leaders to form a banking union to oversee its big banks, a move that would help shield countries and their taxpayers from the misfortunes of their troubled lenders.

description: Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday strongly criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.s recent decision to appoint two United States attorneys to investigate recent disclosures of classified national security information, saying the move was not enough and that he should appoint a special prosecutor.

title: ING Bank to Pay $619 Million to Settle Inquiry Into Sanctions Violations
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $619 million settlement with ING Bank to settle an investigation into compliance with United States sanctions against Iran, Cuba and other countries. It is the largest fine a bank has paid to settle accusations of sanctions violations.

title: Food Prize for Pioneer in Drip-by-Drip Farming Efficiency
description: Ive intersected a few times with Daniel Hillel, a pioneering agricultural innovator from Israel, and each time Ive come away with new insights, often about subjects far broader than the efficient irrigation methods he devised and refined, which have helped dry regions around the world feed themselves. Its great to see him named this years recipient of the World Food Prize, an award created in 1987 by another agricultural leader, Norman Borlaug (read Justin Gilliss fine obituary of Borlaug here).

title: Mirror, Mirror | David Adjaye
description: A mirror, to me, reflects life, said David Adjaye of his most recent creations. They create luminosity and brightness, and you can see the brightness more the less it acts like a mirror and the more it behaves like a reflecting plane. The London-based architect, who was the 2011 Designer of the Year at Design Miami (and who is designing Proenza Schoulers soon-to-open first store, on Madison Avenue) had been thinking about mirrors following a conversation he had about a year ago with his friend, the fashion designer Duro Olowu, about the act of gazing. Thats what inspired the thinking, that a mirror is more than an object to look at yourself in, Adjaye recalled. Olowu included Adjayes mirrors in Material, a group show he curated at Salon 94 Freemans earlier this year.

title: Oil Slick: Serums for Sleek Summer Strands
description: Many people dont realize that the sun can wreak as much havoc on their hair as their skin.The UV light damages your hair, said Dr. Debra Jaliman, a New York dermatologist and author of Skin Rules. It breaks the chemical bonds, which causes split ends and makes hair more susceptible to breakage.David Lopez, a hairstylist in New York who has worked with many celebrities, said that sun exposure can also lead to dryness, frizz and even cause hair color to fade if you dye it.Perhaps counterintuitively given that hot, humid weather can result in lank strands, oil-based emollients can help protect hair throughout summer, as well as facilitating the wet look that was seen on many spring runways. Here are some hair oils currently on the market.

title: Embellish Like Bartenders

Curating a short list of drinks, instead of casting around for something novel to mix with that gin, allows you to serve drinks that will please even your most discerning guests, and to be a more nimble host.

title: La Guardias Retail Therapy
description: Travelers who pass through La Guardia Airports terminal D will likely do a double take when, in place of the usual newsstand, coffee shop or kiosk selling noise-canceling headphones, they spot the new boutique Zona. The shop delivers a major upgrade to the retail offerings at the airport; its stocked with beauty products, jewelry and accessories for men and women, stationery and childrens toys and gifts, all by a roster of innovative designers and manufacturers. Our first sale, at 4:30 in the morning while we were still setting up the space, was a $60 John Derian paperweight, says Jesse James, the founder and creative director of Aesthetic Movement, the company that was hired to merchandise and brand the store. (It is run by the airport retailer A.E.I. Retail.) Prices range from $4.99 for Hurraw! Lip balms to $100 for a handmade necktie by Forage to $150 for a Thomaspaul wool shawl, and top out at $425 for a pearl and pyrite necklace by Carolina. Besides carrying items a traveler would expect, like a stylish toothbrush, James said it was important to bring in a few things that made no sense, like a gold leather Websters dictionary or Harry Allens gold pig bank  things that are interesting and lovely, but we thought, honestly, Who will buy this in an airport? Plenty of people, apparently. Journal sets inscribed with Oscar Wilde quotes, $109, have already sold out.

title: A Couple of Gin Cocktails
description: What to pair with gin? Back in the day it would have been a cigarette. Instead, in place of a food pairing, here are a couple of cocktails to mix with the more flavorful American gins, provided by the drinks historian David Wondrich, one of our panelists. His cocktails are light and summery, and a refreshing change from your usual gin and tonic. The punch recipe makes 20 servings; assume that refills are likely to be in demand. The other recipe was adapted by Mr. Wondrich from one by the 19th-century bartender Jerry Thomas. The optional sparkling ros is my own idea, a felicitously chic addition that turns the drink into something close to a French 75.

Woods appeared determined, while Mickelson seemed playful.

title: Judge Rules Restaurant Law Stifles Ohio Cities
description: A state judge in Ohio has ruled that a state law placing sweeping limitations on local governments ability to control restaurants in the interests of public health violates the state constitution.

title: The Case Against Jos Trevio
description: Court documents unsealed yesterday provide details of how the Zetas laundered drug money through the poorly regulated equine industry each month.

title: Boy, 14, Drowns Off Beach in Far Rockaway
description: A 14-year-old boy drowned on Tuesday in the waters off a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, after ignoring warnings not to swim in an area with no lifeguards, the authorities said.

description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.

Im a Mormon, Not a Christian
