title: Hot, Hot, Hot
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Wednesday is better known to some as Hump Day because, while you can see the past weekend in your rear view mirror, you cant quite see the weekend ahead just yet. So lets see if todays puzzle by Susan Gelfand can get us over that hump.

title: After a Crash, New Anxiety for Travelers in Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  The ordeal of flying in Nigeria begins with the chaotic crowds waving wads of cash who surround ticket agents in sweltering terminals lacking air-conditioning.

title: Corrections: June 13
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Hard Choices, Same as They Ever Were
description: A good, old-fashioned consciousness-raising session flares into life in the first act of Rapture, Blister, Burn, the intensely smart, immensely funny new play by Gina Gionfriddo that opened Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons. Over late afternoon martinis, four women representing three generations dive into a freewheeling conversation about how womens lives have and have not changed since the 1970s.

title: Tefilo Stevenson, Cuban Boxing Great, Dies at 60
description: Tefilo Stevenson, one of the greatest amateurs in boxing history, the winner of three Olympic gold medals for Cuba and a national hero who shunned the prospect of turning pro, possibly fighting Muhammad Ali and becoming rich in the United States, died on Monday in Havana. He was 60.

title: An Independent Monitor for the Police Is Proposed
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency have inspectors general who function as independent monitors. So do the police departments of major cities like Los Angeles and Chicago, as well as the nations capital. Even most New York City agencies, like the Education Department and the Housing Authority, have similar monitors.

title: Group Planning Centers to Treat Combat Trauma
description: Pledging to overhaul the way the military handles the least visible wounds of war, a private foundation will unveil a $100 million plan on Wednesday to construct state-of-the-art treatment centers for brain injuries and psychological disorders at nine of the largest bases in the country.

title: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer
description: Diesel fumes cause lung cancer, the World Health Organization declared Tuesday, and experts said they were more carcinogenic than secondhand cigarette smoke.

title: Pink Slips
description: The school district in Reading, Pa.  the nations poorest city  laid off 110 teachers last week, along with hundreds of other employees. As elementary students watched in shock, many of their favorite teachers were pulled out of an assembly one by one and given the bad news by district officials, The Reading Eagle reported.

title: Denials Over Google Street View
description: Google has long prided itself on not being a conventional company. But there is one characteristic it apparently shares with the most sclerotic bureaucracy: the willingness of its employees to say, Not my job.

title: Wealth Erased
description: Americans know, all too well, the pain unleashed by the Great Recession of 2007-9. Still the numbers on the loss of personal wealth during those years are staggering and say a lot about why the economic recovery has been so sluggish  and why the government will need to do a lot more to turn things around.

title: Once Illegal, Health Rumors Now Have Mubarak Die Daily
description: CAIRO  Former President Hosni Mubarak uses a wheelchair, is able to eat little more than Jell-O, and has his two grown sons by his bedside. He suffers from sore joints in his feet, high blood pressure, shortness of breath and, according to rumors widely circulated in the Egyptian and foreign press, he required artificial respiration and heart defibrillation within the space of just 24 hours last weekend. Twice, doctors could not find his pulse, the reports said.

title: Photo Replay: June 12
description: The day in sports included Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals and Euro 2012 first round matches.

title: Most Would-Be Successors Assail Mayor on Diversity
description: Bill de Blasio, New York Citys public advocate, called him imperial. William C. Thompson Jr., the former comptroller, described his record as an embarrassment.

title: Santa Monica Resets Its Parking Meter System
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  It is a ritual known by tourists and residents alike: circling the blocks looking for an open parking spot and noticing that the meter still has plenty of time left on it? Why, what a lucky day.

title: Mets Win an Easy One for a Change
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Mets cathartic 11-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays here on Tuesday seemed to unfold as one long, collective sigh of relief.

title: Rodriguez Ties Gehrigs Grand Slam Record in Win Over Braves
description: ATLANTA  As well as the Yankees have played this month, the one bothersome aspect of their game has been their inability to hit with the bases loaded. That even applied to Alex Rodriguez who, despite being one of the most productive hitters ever with the bases full, has struggled terribly in those situations this season.

title: Allen Wins Republican Senate Primary in Virginia
description: George Allen, the former Virginia senator whose political career imploded after a disastrous re-election campaign in 2006, moved a step closer to redemption on Tuesday after easily defeating three conservative Republican opponents in the Virginia Senate primary.

title: Will the Vaticans Crackdown on Nuns Work?
The Ordeal of Flying in Nigeria
description: Boarding the aging jetliner itself can seem an accomplishment, given the lack of audible announcements, working signboards or informed employees. Then the real adventure begins.

title: McIlroy Tries His Hand as a Pitcher
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Rory McIlroy was spotted on the Olympic Club driving range throwing a golf ball at his bag. He was practicing  not for his United States Open defense, beginning Thursday, but for his appearance Tuesday night at the Giants home game against the Houston Astros. It was Irish Heritage Night and McIlroy, who is from Northern Ireland, was asked to throw out the first pitch.

title: New Orleans Struggles With Latest Storm, Newspaper Layoffs
description: NEW ORLEANS  Brett Anderson kept his face out of the paper and gave fake names when making reservations, as dining critics customarily do, but in a town like New Orleans he was not fooling many people. They know Mr. Anderson by sight, just as they knew that a reporter named Katy Reckdahl had had a baby in New Orleans 24 hours before Hurricane Katrina hit  she wrote a big article about it in the paper five years later, but people knew.

title: Stanley Cup Viewership Down From Last Year
description: The Los Angeles Kings 6-1 throttling of the Devils on Monday night to win the Stanley Cup was seen by an average of 4.9 million viewers, down 10 percent from the nearly 5.5 million who watched the comparable game last year between the Boston Bruins and Vancouver Canucks. NBC carried the last four games of the Stanley Cup finals, averaging 3.5 million viewers, down 34 percent from the five games the network showed last year, when the Bruins won.

title: The Great Immigration Reform Mirage
description: In a breakfast interview with Bloomberg View on Monday, Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, expressed general disappointment with the Republican Partys rightward drift since his brother left the White House in 2009. He also cited a specific place where his party needs to return to the center: The issue of immigration reform. According to Bush, Mitt Romneys focus on border enforcement has placed him in a box and limited his appeal to Hispanic voters.

title: Fleck Had Suggestions  for Woods, but Not a Way to Reach Him
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At the 2010 United States Open in Pebble Beach, the former Open champion Jack Fleck was among those following Tiger Woods. After watching him play early in the week, Fleck, a tireless student of the game, had some swing suggestions he wished to share with Woods. He said he sent a friend into the locker room, to ask if Woods would be amenable to meeting with him.

title: States Progress on Exchanges
description: The health care law, now under review by the Supreme Court, requires states to have health insurance exchanges by January 2014. Some states have made extensive plans, while others have done little.

title: Iran Says It Is Building a Nuclear-Powered Submarine
description: An Iranian naval commander said Tuesday that Iran had begun work on its first nuclear-powered submarine. We have taken the first steps in the direction of building nuclear-powered submarines, Deputy Navy Cmdr. Abbas Zamini said, according to the Fars news agency. Some analysts fear Iran could use the submarine project to justify enriching uranium to higher levels. Mark Hibbs, a nuclear proliferation expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was cited by Reuters as saying that many nuclear-powered submarines use uranium fuel enriched to levels that could also be suitable for atomic bombs. Iran is scheduled to meet next week with international negotiators over its nuclear program.

title: Navigating the Health Care Maze
description: BOSTON  Even a self-described data nerd like Peter Kim was nearly undone by his hunt for health insurance.

title: The Vatican: U.S. Nuns Meet With Church Officials
description: After meeting Tuesday with representatives of an association of American nuns that it had deemed to be too feminist, the Vatican reiterated that the group remained under the supreme direction of the Holy See and that it was bound to promote the teachings of the church as faithfully taught through the ages. The Leadership Conference of Women Religious, which represents 80 percent of Catholic nuns in the United States, had requested the meeting with officials in Rome to discuss a critique that led to a Vatican decision to overhaul the organization. The groups president, Sister Pat Farrell, said in a statement that during an open meeting the groups representatives were able to directly express their concerns. The nuns said they would report back to the groups board in the United States and determine a course of action to respond to the Vatican.

title: Floridas Approach to Purging Voter Rolls of Noncitizens Prompts Federal Lawsuit
description: The Department of Justice on Tuesday followed through on warnings that it would sue Florida over the states plan to remove noncitizens from its voter rolls.

title: Poland: For Russia-Poland Pre-Game, a Street Fight
description: Russian and Polish soccer fans clashed in the streets of Warsaw on Tuesday, injuring at least 15 people and leading to more than 120 arrests. Riot police used water cannons, tear-gas and rubber bullets to contain the street fighting that broke out hours before Russia and Poland played to a draw in the European soccer championship, an event that Polish officials hoped would showcase the countrys recent strides. But enmity between Russia and Poland runs centuries deep and a march by Russian fans in honor of their national holiday, Russia Day, brought out Polish fans and clashes erupted. Polish soccer hooligans chanted, Hit the red trash with a hammer, with a sickle and Instead of leaves, therell be communists hanging from the trees.

title: Word of the Day | connotation
description: connotation \k-n-ta-shn\ noun

title: New Report Says Captive U.S. Soldier Left His Post Willingly
description: HONG KONG  Two weeks from now, a young soldier from Idaho, Bowe Bergdahl, will have been in the hands of the Taliban for three years. He is Americas only prisoner of war.

title: After Liposuction, Exercise Keeps the Fat Off
description: Liposuction, generally considered the most popular cosmetic surgical procedure in the United States and worldwide, involves suctioning out subcutaneous fat cells, those that accumulate just beneath the skin. But to gain lasting benefits, a new study suggests, people need to exercise. Otherwise they risk regaining the fat lost during surgery and redistributing that fat to their midsections, an outcome that has the potential to make them less healthy than before the operation.

title: To Bolster Web Reach, CNBC Joins With Yahoo
description: Seeking to improve its standing among business news Web sites, CNBC will announce a new partnership on Wednesday with Yahoo Finance, the largest such Web site in the United States.

title: North Dakota Voters Reject Effort to Abolish Property Tax
description: Voters in North Dakota on Tuesday rejected a constitutional amendment to abolish the property tax, turning aside arguments by advocates of the measure who say the tax has proved inconsistent and is in conflict with the basic concept of property ownership.

title: After Struggling Early, Sabathia Limits Damage
description: ATLANTA  C. C. Sabathia struggled and battled over seven innings Tuesday but was lucky to get a victory as the Yankees rallied for six runs in the top of the eighth for a 6-4 win over the Atlanta Braves.

title: With Poise and Power, Thunder Rally in Opener
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  It took patience to endure the 23-win season, the four straight lottery appearances, the long slog through a Western Conference dominated by superstars and dynasties.

title: Airborne Tales of Fistfights, Diuretics and Crooning Pilots
description: A plane on approach to Lagos, Nigeria, crashed two weeks ago, killing all 153 passengers plus a still-uncounted number of people on the ground. Then on Friday, the runway lights failed at the airport in the Nigerian capital of Abuja.

title: Soccer Fans from Poland and Russia Clash Ahead of Euro 2012 Match
description: Centuries of enmity between Poland and Russia manifested in bloody clashes between soccer fans on the streets of Warsaw on Tuesday hours before the two countries faced off in the European soccer championship.

title: India, Spain and Singapore Win Awards in International Yoga Competition
description: Silence prevailed during the yoga asana routines of the ninth annual Bishnu Charan Ghosh Cup  except for one distinct sound: the low engine rumble of airplanes lifting off and landing at the Los Angeles airport, Sara Beck wrote in The New York Times.

title: Press Inquiry Strains Britains Coalition Government
description: LONDON  Britains coalition government came under renewed strain on Wednesday after its junior partner, the Liberal Democrats, withheld parliamentary backing for Prime Minister David Camerons handling of events flowing from a failed bid by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation to take full control of BSkyB, the countrys biggest satellite broadcaster.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Guatemala (1)
description: The United States national team has historically struggled in Central America, but Tuesday nights 1-1 tie in Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier will still feel disappointing despite the teams earning a point.

title: Bomb Attacks Around Iraq Target Shiites, Killing Dozens
description: BAGHDAD  In the deadliest day in Iraq since the withdrawal of the United States military in December, a series of explosions that mostly targeted Shiite Muslims amounted to an emphatic demonstration of the still-potent capabilities of the Sunni insurgency and a reminder of the instability left behind by American forces.

title: For Muslim Women in Delhi, a Breath of Fresh Air
description: Yasmeen Khan dons her burqa and steps out of her house in the Nizamuddin neighborhood of Delhi every evening to walk a short distance to a 10-foot-high stone wall. Behind the wall is paradise  a place where she can remove her burqa and hijab, enjoy cool fresh air in her hair, exercise and gossip with friends.

title: Consortium to Buy Saab Automobile
description: More than a year after it last made a car, Saab Automobile of Sweden was sold on Wednesday to a group of Chinese, Japanese and Swedish investors who plan to convert the company into a manufacturer of electric vehicles.

title: A Rare View of Conflict in Syria
description: In one of Robert Kings photographs from Qusayr, Syria, a gray-haired man in blue scrubs holds a crying child who is tangled in IV tubes (Slide 11). Behind them, on a bed covered with disheveled blankets, three more children lie bandaged; plastic sheeting covers a window and a bookshelf, as if the room was quarantined, or as if its owner were clinging to normalcy by protecting the furniture. In another picture (Slide 13), wounded men, one in camouflage fatigues, lie cheek by jowl on floral print couches.

title: Fantasy Focus: Buy Good Pitchers Running Bad
description: An odd thing has happened this year, though perhaps it happens every year: pitchers who were former (or prospective) aces, but recently left for dead, have recaptured their form for stretches of varying lengths. Consider Jake Peavy and Johan Santana, two former Cy Young Award winners you could have drafted in the later rounds. Santana, even after being shelled by the Yankees, has a 73:22 strikeout/walk ratio in 73 innings and an earned run average of 2.96. Peavy has fallen off of late but still has a 72:20 K/BB ratio in 82 2/3 innings, a 3.05 E.R.A. and an 0.968 WHIP.

description: Along with predictions of German triumph, supermarket beer promotions, organized Oranje invasions and metatarsal injuries, the Group of Death has become a time-honored element of major tournament culture.

description: LONDON  The money manager BlackRock has hired Philipp M. Hildebrand, who resigned under a cloud from the Swiss National Bank in January, to oversee institutional client relationships outside the United States.

title: The Devil in Marina Abramovic
description: Watching the new documentary about you, The Artist Is Present, got me curious about the economics of performance art. In 2010, you did a show at the Museum of Modern Art, where you sat for 700 hours, staring at visitors. It was seen by as many as 750,000 people, and during that time the museum collected millions in receipts. Did you get a cut of the door, like a musician? I got so little I dont even want to tell. I was paid an honorarium of exactly $100,000. It covered one year of my work, plus how much I pay for assistants and office rent.

title: Using Your 401(k) to Buy a Small Business
description: It takes a creative and determined buyer to purchase a small business in todays lending environment. If theres any doubt that small-business lending has yet to recover in any meaningful way, look no further than Ami Kassars new contribution to this blog: Searching for Capital. While frozen credit markets have made it difficult for small businesses to get loans for expansion and working capital, they have also had a major impact on the business-for-sale marketplace.

description: If youre an experienced computer user, you probably remember explaining to newbies how a desktop computer worked: Your photos should go in this folder; your documents in that one. You will need to use this application to open that image; that application to open this document.

description: Mehdi Hassan, the Indian-born Pakistani singer, died on Wednesday in the Pakistani city of Karachi at the age of 84. Mr. Hassan had been suffering from multiple organ disorders for the past several years.

description: Theyre like cave paintings, Jeanne Greenberg Rohatynsaid during the installation of the group show Pothole that opened at one of her two downtown galleries, Salon 94 Bowery, last week. We were all inspired by Werner Herzogs film, she said, half joking, and adding that initially the show was to be called Square Cave, a reference to the both the physical space (a subterranean white box on the Bowery) and the 10 participating artists inclination toward gestural, expressionistic mark-making in their practices.

But Im loving a total, head-to-toe print look. Saunders pulled out a pair of fluid palazzo pants in a bamboo print, one of several late-70s-inspired motifs he designed for resort, including a graphic floral and a multicolored dot pattern that brought the artist Victor Vasarely to mind. The bamboo palazzo pants can be worn with a simple black top, of course, but paired with one in the matching bamboo print, the look could have easily passed for an evening dress  very chic and not in the least over the top.

description: SHANGHAI  The former head of the Chinese soccer association and 10 other former national team players and executives were sentenced by Chinese courts Wednesday to lengthy prison terms for accepting bribes and fixing matches, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

title: The Business of Good Horsemanship
description: The fans of thoroughbred racing, once again, will have to go another year without a Triple Crown winner and many of them have expressed their frustration as paranoia, accusing Doug ONeill, the trainer of Ill Have Another, of a host of different motives: he was afraid of a drug test, he was afraid of losing, he was afraid that, like Big Brown, an abysmal showing in the Belmont would have cast doubt on his horses triumphs in the Preakness and the Kentucky Derby. The subsequent announcement that he was retiring the Flower Alley colt has led some to observe that Ill Have Anothers value as a breeding animal has trumped his value as an athlete.

description: Long before America cuddled up with those wholesome gay pixies on Will and Grace and Modern Family, there was Torch Song Trilogy, a play that scratched the surface of a fierce drag queen to discover a lovable Jewish mother with good family values beneath. Arnold was this comforting creatures reassuringly plain name. title: Stone Links: Addiction and Agency
description: This week The Stone featured an essay by Peg OConnor on addiction, the brain and the will. Philosophy Now has more on the topic. Addictive actions are often thought to undermine the will. But can we think of them more simply as representing nothing more than capricious changes of mind? There is a view of temptation and the will, tracing back to Platos Protagoras, that takes them to be just that. It is an elegant theory, as it makes no use of the thorny notion of akrasia, or weakness of will. Alan Brody argues at Philosophy Now, though, that we can find another view in Plato that also refuses the concept of akrasia while still respecting the way addiction disrupts agency, in particular our capacity to regulate our actions. The view is this: when one acts on an addictive impulse, ones will remains intact. It is, rather, the capacity to judge what is the best course of action that fails one; the addictive course momentarily appears to be the best available.What Rorty Wrought: Santiago Zabala marks the five year anniversary of Richard Rortys passing with this tribute in Al-Jazeera. Rorty ought to be the model for 21st century philosophy, Zabala argues, owing to his eclectic approach to philosophical method and the capacity it gave him to transcend narrow debates within Anglo-American philosophy and see the way philosophy might figure productively in the broader intellectual and political life of America and Europe. But politics should also inform philosophy: If you take care of freedom, Rorty says, truth will take care of itself. For Rorty, truth ought to be conceived not as correspondence to a mind-independent reality, but pragmatically, as consisting in those conclusions an open and free community might arrive at in the long run of inquiry.

title: Seeing Reflections in John Waters and Carrie
description: Its not surprising that John Waters, a director longcelebrated and reviled for his trashy, outr, queer films, would be represented in a queer arts festival.  And there he  or, rather, an extended excerpt from his sordid, classic film Desperate Living  was on Saturday night at the Abrons Arts Center, when the French choreographer David Wampach performed two works as part of the Queer New York International Arts Festival.

title: With Ballard Gone, the Giants Must Adjust
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jake Ballards locker at the Giants training facility looked the same Wednesday morning, as if it still belonged to him. Jackets hung underneath a shelf holding his red, white and blue Giants bag, which was underneath his shoulder pads. Below that was a pile of mismatched shoes. On the wall inside the locker hung a tribute to his alma mater, Ohio State: a rag with Ohio scripted in scarlet and gray. Above it was a picture of the Giants tight ends from last season: Travis Beckum, Bear Pascoe and Ballard.

title: Vision Problem Subsides, but Hitting Problem Lingers for Freeman
description: ATLANTA  A hitter is nothing without his eyes, which is why anxiety gripped Atlantas Freddie Freeman last month when his vision started blurring. What if his career was being sideswiped? A hitter might as well have a Wiffle ball bat in his hands if he goes to the plate and his vision is not right. Freeman, 22 and in his second season as the Braves regular first baseman, was scared, and rightfully so.

title: Joe Average, Just Waiting for Salvation
description: The hero of Dave Eggerss absorbing new novel A Hologram for the King is a penny-ante Job named Alan Clay, who finds himself in an absurd situation. Alan is deeply in debt, unable to pay his daughters college tuition and plagued by a scary golf-ball-size lump on the back of his neck. Hes betting everything on a last-ditch chance at a big payday, hoping he can sell the Saudi king, Abdullah, on a lucrative technology contract  a contract that depends on Alans going to a remote real estate development in Saudi Arabia and making an elaborate holographic presentation to the king, who may or may not even show up.

title: Jazz Acts, Blowing Superhot and Cool
description: So much about the Vision Festival communicates openness, multiplicity, fluctuation. An independent summit of experimental jazz, the festival has an aesthetic descended from the scrappy, permissive mood of downtown New York in the 1970s. Look closer, and over time you might notice that its a tended garden like any other. It plays favorites and exercises biases. Theres an outsider ethos at work in its presentation, but also an implicit closing of the ranks. Even the outside has an outside, for practical purposes.

title: New Composers and New Sounds Converge in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO  In a lecture on Saturday morning for an audience of student composers at Baird Hall on the University at Buffalo campus, Robert Beaser offered a brief but detailed overview of the travails of writing his Guitar Concerto (2009). Mr. Beaser, one of four faculty members in town to preside over master classes at the June in Buffalo new-music festival, spoke of agonizing over the concerto for a decade. He still considers the work unfinished, he said, and just last week he spent four hours with the guitarist Eliot Fisk, for whom it was written, tweaking the solo guitar line.

A couple weeks ago Hot 97s annual Summer Jam devolved into a conflagration between Nicki Minaj, the genre-agnostic star, and the morning-radio host Peter Rosenberg, who derided her for having forgotten where the invisible lines she shouldnt cross were. Mr. Rosenberg, a committed classicist, bad-mouthed Starships, one of Ms. Minajs big pop hits, and dismissed the young women he presumed were there to hear it; at the behest of her Young Money labels boss, Lil Wayne, Ms. Minaj opted not to perform.

Koch Theater with the first of two performances of a triple bill with the ambiguous title Infinity. Its first third, Luminous, was a retrospective of repertory highlights and dancer showcases, interspersed with video; its centerpiece, Dyad 1929, choreographed by Wayne McGregor, was impeccably modern; and the finale, Warumuk  in the dark night, by the choreographer Stephen Page and including performers from Bangarra Dance Theater, was a mythic evocation of Australias aboriginal past.

The other brother, already paralyzed and blind, died of starvation days later.

The installation, Fireflies on the Water, consists of a small room with mirrored walls, two inches of water on the floor, a raised platform for a viewer to stand on and 150 colored lights dangling from the ceiling.Only one person is allowed in the room at a time. Once the door closes behind you, its like youre suspended in outer space. An infinity of lights surrounds you.

He even ventured that too-big-to-fail banks have negatives, including you know, greed, arrogance, hubris, lack of attention to detail.

title: We Who Are Left When a Generation Passes
description: Sometime in 1931, my dad and his four siblings, farm kids all, posed for a formal photograph. The boys are wearing suits, and the girl, my aunt Janelle, is wearing an infants white dress. The oldest boy, Everon, is perhaps 12 years old, and my dad is 5. And now they are all gone. Everon and Janelle, the last of them, died six days apart in early June.

title: Copters in Syria May Not Be New, U.S. Officials Say

title: The Court Retreats on Habeas
description: When the Supreme Court ruled in 2008 that Congress could not strip federal courts of jurisdiction to hear habeas corpus petitions from non-American prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, the 5-to-4 majority opinion written by Justice Anthony Kennedy appeared to be a landmark victory for the rights of detainees. The laws and Constitution are designed to survive, and remain in force, in extraordinary times, Justice Kennedy wrote in Boumediene v. Bush, and the framers decided that habeas corpus, a right of first importance, must be part of the American legal framework.

title: Michigan: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Challenging Detroit Solvency Deal
description: A judge on Wednesday threw out a legal challenge to an agreement intended to spare Detroit from financial ruin, ending a showdown that had threatened to leave the city unable to pay its bills as early as Friday. The judge, William Collette, of Ingham County Circuit Court, dismissed a suit that had been brought by Detroits corporation counsel, though opposed by its mayor, Dave Bing. The suit said that Detroit, which in April agreed to a deal with the state to steady its finances, could not enter into the contract because, the suit asserted, the state owes Detroit hundreds of millions of dollars from past debts. Mr. Bing said the city could now move forward in its effort to recover.

title: China: Actress Sues Publications Over Bo Allegations

The actress, Zhang Ziyi, sued Apple Daily, a well-known tabloid newspaper, and Next Magazine Publishing, both of which are owned by Next Media. Executives at the companies have declined to comment. Apple Daily reported this spring that Ms. Zhang made $110 million by sleeping with Mr. Bo and other officials in recent years; the article said she was introduced to Mr. Bo by Xu Ming, a tycoon who has been detained in the Bo investigation. title: Pakistan: Supply Detour Costs $100 Million a Month
description: Pakistans closing of NATOs ground supply routes to Afghanistan has added about $100 million a month to the costs of the Afghan war, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta told Congress on Wednesday. Mr. Panetta, left, said the added expenses were a result of using the longer northern route to supply the military and carry out the American drawdown in Afghanistan. Pakistan closed NATOs supply routes across its border in November after an American airstrike mistakenly killed 24 Pakistani soldiers at a frontier outpost. Talks with Pakistan to reopen the route have stalemated. Mr. Panetta also said he would advise Congress on recommendations to deal with Pakistan in the future, including on the question of American financial assistance to Islamabad.

title: South Carolina: Man Gets 50 Years for Molesting Over 20 Children
description: A graduate of The Citadel who went on to work with children there and at other schools and served as a foster parent pleaded guilty to 22 counts of child sexual abuse and was sentenced to 50 years in prison on Wednesday. The man, Louis ReVille, 32, who was arrested in October after an investigation revealed he molested more than 20 children he taught and coached in the Charleston area, apologized to his victims. Some are suing the institutions that hired him, including The Citadel, a military college. Victims have claimed that The Citadel knew Mr. ReVille molested teenagers at a camp in 2002, luring boys into his room with the promise of pizza and Chinese food and then showing them pornography and encouraging group masturbation sessions. The college, which investigated the complaint but did not report it to police, apologized.

title: Cuba: Senators Condemn Treatment of Cuban Dissident
description: Several United States senators are condemning the arrest and abuse they say a Cuban dissident endured after he testified by video conference before a Senate subcommittee looking into repression on the island. Lawmakers said Jorge Luis Garca Prez, known as Antnez, was released Wednesday, four days after he was beaten and arrested by authorities. He had testified last Thursday from the United States Interest Section in Havana on the short-term detention of dissidents. Mr. Garca Prez still faces charges, including spreading false information, senators Robert Menendez of New Jersey and Marco Rubio of Florida, both Cuban-Americans, said in a statement. The Cuban government has not responded, but generally treats dissidents as common criminals in the pay of the American government and exile groups.

Children who dont read over the summer lose two to three months of reading development while children who do gain a month  but research shows that children surrounded by reading material dont appear to be at much risk. Summer reading is as effective as summer school, and it doesnt matter what children read, as long as the reading is happening.

title: Benjamin Walker, Sexypants Vampire Hunter

He made this admission on a mild evening in early April to an attentive audience of mostly young women. Walker, 29, was hosting an installment of Find the Funny, his charmingly slack monthly comedy show, and dressed in a fitted gray hoodie, charcoal pants and brown work boots, he surveyed the tightly packed room and ran a hand through his floppy brown hair. Then he started to play the ringing intro to Kings of Leons swooning hit Use Somebody. With his foot, he tapped a device on the floor to loop his guitar line so he could play in harmony with himself. This is not an easy trick to pull off. Theres a reason Kings of Leon has two guitar players.

title: Bruces Bellport
description: The celebrated photographer Bruce Weber has always used his home bases  in Montana, the Adirondacks, Montauk, and Miami  as settings for his distinctly American fashion shoots. Tomorrow, the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society on Long Island will unveil A Bellport Tale, a new exhibit of photos that Weber took when he resided in Bellport in the 1970s and 80s. Everyone knew each other, Weber said of the quaint bayside village. You could knock on any door and just invite a neighbor over to be part of a photography sitting. It was as easy as borrowing a cup of sugar. The images in the exhibit come from a shoot that appeared in British Vogue in 1982 called Under Weston Eyes. Starring Talisa Soto and the male model of the moment, Bruce Hulse, that story was styled by Grace Coddington and inspired by the work of another photographer, Edward Weston. He took things that were very personal to him and let us see into that world, Weber said. I thought it would be interesting to do a series of pictures of my own imaginary family, living together in the dysfunctional, neurotic, beautiful way that families do. The exhibit (on view through Sept. 3) includes many memorable images, but perhaps none is more evocative of a quiet life on the bay than that of a shirtless Hulse, sitting on the stern of a boat, cigarette in hand, wearing calf-revealing baggy trousers, rumpled socks and dress shoes.

description: Despite the glut of travel guides available, its sometimes hard to find ones that are actually instructive, that get at the heart of whats going on in a given city and spare us the travel-writing clichs. Thats why its a welcome treat to discover Marc Santo and Scott Newmans scrappy little Revel in New York series, the third edition of which went on sale last week. The pocket-size Revel isnt a typical guidebook  half of its pages are devoted to freewheeling interviews with chefs, artists and architects about their work. But each of these subjects, New Yorkers either by birth or disposition, also shares a dozen or so deeply idiosyncratic recommendations. Taken together, their tips offer a unique way of exploring the city, even for its current residents.

Everyone looked shocked, Ruiz de la Prada says. But soon enough, the looks transformed into smiles, and the stiff formality dissipated from the room. She credits the events success solely to the headband. Now, for Ruiz de la Pradas second exclusive collection for Yoox.com, she has created 30 one-of-a-kind fascinators (priced from $90 to $105). title: Ooh La La Maison | Paul & Joe Comes Home
description: Sophie Albou-Mechaly, the designer for the French clothing label Paul & Joe, doesnt claim to be an avid chef, but delights in collecting china  from the high-end Hungarian manufacturer Herend to kitsch treasures like Ridgewood  at the Paris flea markets. I love to dress a dinner table in colorful prints the way I dress myself, says Albou-Mechaly, who is now expanding the brand to include home goods. My idea of fashion is not to be only about clothes but about living well. Paul & Joe La Maison is making its first foray into design with a three-print collection of kitchenware: cherry blossoms, kittens and Asian-inspired koi motifs. The brands DNA is all about the happiness in colors and prints, so this feels like a natural extension, she says, which is another way of saying that La Maisons prints are derived from the current season and past collection hit makers. As a woman and a mother, I am constantly thinking about women and the clothes and things that they need in their lives: practicality and appeal, she adds. The collection includes everything from porcelain dinner plates and linen dishcloths to butter dishes, egg cups and even charming lunch boxes. And, with everything priced between $30 and $150 (similar to its sold-out 2006 Target collaboration), customers can afford the luxury of changing their home dcor as often as they change their mood and clothes. Theres no trend to it, Albou-Mechaly says. Mixing pieces and decorating your kitchen with them is fun. The designer also suggests swapping tired hostess gifts (wine, flowers, desserts) with a La Maison item, since each piece comes beautifully packaged in a matching print box. Arent American kitchens needs different from those of French kitchens? Albou-Mechaly begs to differ: We are the American kitchen, English kitchen, French kitchen, Italian kitchen  its just the taste that is different. Expect La Maison to take over every inch of your home, maison, flat or casa.

title: Tomorrows Recriminations Today

(Mickey Kaus pre-emptively summarizes this narrative: Hell have lost because he wasnt populist enough, he demoralized his base, he didnt pursue single-payer, he foolishly tried to win over swing voters instead of registering new voters, he was too nice to the Republicans. Rachel Maddow and both her guests will nod sagely.) There will also be a group of liberals (smaller, but perhaps more influential) who argue that Obama mostly made the right choices, but fell victim to economic forces beyond any presidents control. And then there will be the liberals (joined by some conservatives) who focus intently on monetary policy, and argue among themselves over whether the White House could have exerted more pressure on Ben Bernanke and the Federal Reserve.

title: 36 Hours in Montreal
description: CANADAS second-largest city may be the second-largest French-speaking metropolis on the planet (after Paris), but the attention lavished on its Frenchness  Bistros! Baguettes! People saying Bonjour!  tends to nudge aside the many other ethnic communities within Montreals remarkably diverse urban sprawl. Italians, Portuguese and Lebanese have a very visible presence, and the city hosts annual festivals dedicated to everything from Asian-American films to Caribbean food. Throw in a pulsing alternative community and creative scene (this is a place that engendered talents as diverse as Saul Bellow, Arcade Fire and the irrepressible William Shatner), and a whole new Montreal opens up. Whether your passion is Syrian cuisine, contemporary art or vintage shopping, Montreal is serving it up with aplomb. Cest vrai.

Word had spread quickly about an extraordinary photo-realist painting by the Italian-born artist Rudolf Stingel. Based on a 1980s photograph of the New York dealer Paula Cooper looking glamorous with sultry eyes and a cigarette in one hand, the large canvas (it measures 11 by 15 feet) was hung dramatically in a space by itself. Its price was around $3 million, and it was bought by Franois Pinault, the French luxury goods magnate and owner of Christies, before the fair even opened.

But the drama has also tended to overshadow a central fact: the Iranians have managed to steadily increase their enrichment of uranium and are now raising their production of a concentrated form close to bomb grade.

description: ROME  By the eighth century one of the earliest churches in Rome was considered quaint enough to be called Santa Maria Antiqua. title: The Making of the President
description: During his 2008 campaign, Barack Obama so often stressed the improbability of his story that we have grown inured to how unlikely it really is. Everyone knows that his name, along with his inexperience, was an electoral handicap; that his mixed-race background made his victory historic; and that his transformation within five years from local Illinois politician to the most famous person on earth (and first incumbent president since Woodrow Wilson to win the Nobel Peace Prize) has no obvious parallel. The great virtue of David Maranisss huge and absorbing new biography is to demonstrate that Obamas saga in its full and previously unexplored detail is more surprising and gripping than the version the world is familiar with.

title: Songs of Innocence and Aspiration

The temptation for the singer is to swallow the hype and breathlessly await the imminent glory predicted by pundits. But it should be remembered that over the last 50 years scores of baby Barbra Streisands have been promised show business conquests that havent materialized. And as 18-year-old Alex Getlin, a confident, engaging young Broadway-style singer with a big voice performed her show, Youre Gonna Hear From Me, on Monday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, I worried.

title: Guiding a Future Star, but Finding Her Own Shine
description: When Louise Brooks, the queen of silent-movie flappers, was a wicked little minx of 15, she traveled from Wichita, Kan., to New York City to study modern dance. It was the summer of 1922, and she was accompanied by Alice Mills, who Louise would later describe as a stocky, bespectacled housewife of 36.

title: A Birthday Concert in Three Parts
description: Thematic tightness is the name of the game in classical music these days. The onus is on artists to organize events that are as satisfying for the mind as for the ear.

title: Jobs Forecast Is Steady, but Stay Tuned
description: The economic data of the past week has been close enough to expectations that Moodys Analytics, a research firm, has not changed its forecast for job growth in coming months. As it did last week, the firm forecasts an average of 157,000 net new jobs a month in the six months leading up to Election Day. But the data has been weak enough to make the Moodys economists nervous.

title: A Slow Unraveling of Family Secrets
description: It would be quite possible, based on its first 10 minutes or so, to dismiss  or perhaps to celebrate  Americano as an exercise in cinematic nepotism. The main character, Martin, is played by Mathieu Demy, who also directed (this is his first feature) and who is the son of two great French filmmakers: Agns Varda, the lioness of the Nouvelle Vague, and Jacques Demy, beloved by discerning romantics around the world for The Umbrellas of Cherbourg. Martins girlfriend, Claire, is played by Chiara Mastroianni, daughter of the Umbrellas star Catherine Deneuve and Marcello Mastroianni. When a family emergency summons Martin to Los Angeles, the first person he meets is a woman named Linda, played by Geraldine Chaplin, whose pedigree hardly needs elaboration.

title: Art Show as Unruly Organism
description: KASSEL, Germany  The longtime curator Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev has a lot on her mind, and she has managed to wedge a remarkable amount of it into Documenta 13.

title: Margaret Dunning and Her Packard, Bound for Pebble Beach
description: Margaret Dunning, who turns 102 this month and was featured in The Times last July, was invited to show her beloved 1930 Packard in August at the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,993 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: New Ads in Indiana Frame a Stirring Senate Race
description: Something surprising seems to be stirring in Indiana: a Senate race.

title: Just One Look | Tory Burch
description: Tory Burch showed her resort collection in her Madison Avenue townhouse shop (near her Upper East Side home), befitting the designers reputation for dressing the leisure set. Burch explained that she focused on down-to-earth fabrics, mixing brocade with a military jacket. There were tile-print jersey dresses, traditional sun dresses in white with pintuck pleats and to-the-knee skirts (khaki with silver embellishments, brocades). Its how I hope I personally dress, Burch said. Mosaic prints in sea blues were shown alongside youthful striped pencil trousers. Here, Burch pairs a brocade bandeau top in mint and gold with a military shirt and textural heavy silk skirt  the perfect look for a trip to the boulangerie in the south of France.

title: Painting Romney With the Bush Brush
description: Mr. Obama gave a major speech in Cleveland today, by which I mean it was really long (6,607 words) and dreary. Mr. Romney spoke the day before, delivering what is now called a prebuttal, which is sort of like a Star Wars prequel, but just not as interesting or well-acted.

title: Wanderer Who Still Searches for Home
description: Soothing, swaying tunes hold despair and a quest for faith in the songs of Michael Kiwanuka, who performed at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night.

title: Songs of Love, Religious or Otherwise
description: The ancient Hebrew love poem called the Song of Songs has long been interpreted as a religious allegory and incorporated by Jews and Christians into scripture. In the program notes that accompanied Blue Herons concert on Sunday afternoon, Scott Metcalfe, the music director of this excellent Renaissance choral ensemble based in Boston, writes that for those who read the poem from a secular viewpoint, it is clearly about an amorous young couple.

title: Syrian Liberators, Bearing Toy Guns
description: If deception has always been part of war, it has not often been as bungled as in the video announcement by Syrian opposition fighters of the formation of a special forces brigade joining the battle against President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Apps I Want to Go Away
description: In my most recent Tool Kit column, I explained how to better organize the apps on your smartphone. But in the article, I wrote half a sentence thats been bugging me:

title: Boys Bonding and Roughhousing
description: In Larry Keigwins new Contact Sport four men dressed as schoolboys stand in front of a sparkly blue curtain. The gloriously pseudo-European voice of Eartha Kitt sings Come on-a My House in Japanese, and the dancers shove one another around with a combination of speed, design and play that signals choreographic wit. A good time, it seems, is in store.

title: Gershwin Shows Tonys Fuel Plans for a Musical
description: Winning the Tony Award for best musical revival is great, and s wonderful to have two popular shows on Broadway that have potentially lucrative national tours starting next year. But for the trustees of George and Ira Gershwins estates the sweetest feeling this week is the satisfaction  they were loath to call it vindication  that their stewardship of the Gershwin brothers legacy is reaping laurels and dividends after some high-powered criticism.

title: Heroes, Villains and the Invisible
description: It hardly needs to be said that any armed force has the potential for internal as well as external violence. But The Invisible War, Kirby Dicks incendiary documentary about the epidemic of rape within the United States military, is a shocking and infuriating indictment of widespread sexual attacks on women. Such behavior, the film argues, is tacitly condoned and routinely covered up; the victims are often blamed and their reputations destroyed.

title: Two Artists Salute a Legacy
description: POINTING her camera, the artist Carrie Mae Weems lobbed directions. A little more smoke! and Women, raise your mirrors! she instructed the performers gathered recently in a black-box theater on the Lower East Side. Geri Allen, the jazz pianist and composer, sat nearby, scribbling notes.

title: Response to U.S.T.A. Renovations: Wheres the Roof?
description: After the United States Tennis Association revealed a renovation plan to the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center that will include a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, a new Grandstand court, improved pedestrian walkways and a two-story viewing platform that will make it easier to watch players practice, the reaction focused on what the project does not include: a roof.

title: Anything Goes and The Lyons to Close
description: 6:34 p.m. | Updated  The Tony-winning revival of Anything Goes will close on August 5, five weeks earlier than planned but after a 565-performance run that was extended three times. And The Lyons, Nicky Silvers caustic comedy of family dysfunction, will close at the Cort Theater on July 1.

title: The Rented Guinea Pig and Other Snippets From The One-Page Magazine
description: Each week, we commission several spot illustrations forThe One-Page Magazine. Because it hasso much going on, the images usually end up being quite small. To commemorate the six-month anniversary of the page (which was last month), here is a belated look back at some of the more compelling illustrations, at sizes larger than you get to see in print.

title: The First Ladys Family
description: Twelve presidents were slaveholders, and perhaps another dozen (including the two named George Bush) came from families that once upon a time owned slaves. In common with many of our most venerable institutions, the presidency has ample connection to slavery time: the White House is like an Internet link that, if you click on it, bounces you to the lawn of a plantation.

title: The Paranoid Next Door Has Guns
description: Escape, a new play by Susan Mosakowski, follows three eccentric pairs of neighbors, all of whom are seeking some form of liberation.

title: New Orleans Paper Invites its Critic Back
description: 10:51 a.m. | Updated Three days after it was reported that Brett Anderson, the well-regarded restaurant critic for The Times-Picayune in New Orleans, was being laid off along with about 200 other employees, the newspaper announced on Friday that it had offered Mr. Anderson a position writing about restaurants and dining.

title: Excerpt: The Lathe of Heaven
description: A scene from the Untitled Theater Company #61 production at the 3LD Art and Technology Center.

title: Movie Listings for June 15-21
description: Movies

title: Where Dreams of the Future Are Nightmares
description: Its oddly encouraging that a theater only blocks away from ground zero has become a home for apocalyptic plays about damaged landscapes. New York has come a long way since Sept. 11.

title: What He Sees May Be Closer Than He Thinks
description: Ethan Hawke, his angular features slicing across the screen, is one reason to see The Woman in the Fifth. Another is that this psychological thriller (or perhaps, psychothriller) about an American writer down on his luck in Paris and maybe out of his mind creates a sense of dread that builds and builds though never resolves, even in the final fade out. It doesnt have the kind of payoff that details who did what and why, which is a problem only if you demand tidy endings. If youre up for some narrative drift, you can just go with the ambiguous flow created by the Polish-born filmmaker Pawel Pawlikowski, who I suspect is a fan of Antonionis Passenger.

description: LONDON  Yasser el-Mallawany and Hassan Heikal are accustomed to turmoil. In recent years, they have steered EFG-Hermes through political upheaval, economic pain and market volatility, transforming the Egyptian financial firm into the leading investment bank in the Arab world.

description: Classical

description: The pulpit at the Harlem church where a funeral service was held Thursday for a recent shooting victim served multiple purposes: to mourn, to pray, to preach and to advocate.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Even amid the air-conditioned confines of Tropicana Field, it was surprising how little the Mets were made to sweat this week.

title: Let Me Get That for You
description: DOMINICK TORRES, a doorman on the Upper East Side who knows the name of almost every tenant in his 689-unit building, says he can often spot a certain something in the eye of new residents. Whether it manifests itself as unease or presumption, it is the look of someone who has never lived in a building with a doorman before, and does not know quite how to act.

description: TEEN NIGHT

description: STEPHANIE RUDNICK never cooked. She even had the gas turned off in her Chelsea studio, though she sometimes heated frozen dumplings in the microwave.

description: President Obama delivered a speech on the economy in Cleveland.

title: Documenta 13
description: Scenes from the art show in Kassel, Germany.

title: A Hospital With Fine Bones
description: CHARTERED in 1771, New York Hospital is the citys oldest, having made peripatetic progress up Manhattan Island. In 1932 it opened a broad new campus at 68th Street and the East River, with a central tower rising in an upward cascade of almost-white masonry, Gothic arches and intricate brickwork 350 feet high. Generally, medical institutions and architectural sensibility do not coexist well, but New York Hospital, today NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, has managed, through circumstance and design, to keep much of its architectural character in good health.

title: Taking Advantage of Low Rates
description: THE mortgage market seems to have been dancing its own version of the limbo, as interest rates headed lower and lower for six consecutive weeks.

title: Q & A
description: Co-op Shareholder Kept in the Dark

title: Echoes of Better Times
description: THE evidence is beginning to stack up. In Seaford, a couple selling a house listed at $369,000 received three competitive offers on the day of the first open house.

description: To the Editor:

description: IN White Plains recently, 16 couples attended an open house at a wood-frame colonial with four bedrooms and two and a half baths listed for $799,000.

description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Funds Face a Deadline
description: PHONES in the offices of Morris Habitat for Humanity have been ringing off the hook lately as town officials throughout Morris County have been seeking its help in spending money. The same has been true for other nonprofit housing groups in New Jersey, as local governments scramble to use up affordable-housing funds before they are forfeited to the state.

description: The racer Sebastian Vettel drives spirited laps on the New Jersey streets where the Grand Prix of America is expected to be run.

Archers in Queens
description: Archers of all skill levels, from the rankest novices to competitors who might survive the Hunger Games, can be found at Pro Line, an indoor archery range in Queens.

title: The Rush of Hitting the Bulls-Eye
description: BEGINNERS on an archery range are almost as easy to spot as the targets: just look for a mean black-and-blue patch where a bowstring has sliced against an incorrectly positioned bicep. Few injuries inspire such rapid correction of form.

title: Glass Is Pretty but, He Hopes, Troubling, Too
description: JOSIAH McELHENYS studio is strangely unremarkable. A narrow office furnished with a desk, a drawing table and library shelves packed with books, it betrays few signs of art making, just a couple of rows of neatly pinned photocopied images and black pencil drawings on one white wall.

title: Glass Darkly
description: A look at the work of the artist Josiah McElheny.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 15, 2012
description: The New York Times film critics on Rock of Ages, The Woman in the Fifth and Your Sisters Sister.

title: For Some Druggists, Medicaid Changes Mean Pain
description: Not long after the state rolled pharmacies into Medicaid managed care in March  an effort to save tens of millions of dollars a year  Ronald Barrett noticed something unusual at his store, Oak Cliff Pharmacy in southern Dallas. When he entered a childs prescription into his computer to see how much he would be reimbursed by CVS Caremark, the managed care plans pharmacy benefit manager, he got an error message. A phone call indicated that the prescription had already been filled, at a CVS pharmacy down the road.

title: The Heady Rush of Freedom in College, and How to Manage It
description: Ariha Setalvad, who is studying journalism and psychology as an undergraduate at New York University, was raised in India and graduated from B.D. Somani International School in Mumbai. She is a summer intern on The Choice blog.

title: Give Schools the Power to Punish
description: SINCE November, when the investigation into sexual abuse at Penn State University dominated the news, the nations attention has repeatedly turned to such abuse in schools. Similar allegations followed at Syracuse University and in many athletic programs in schools across the United States.

title: Candidates Provide a Test for El Paso
description: Ahead of the states May 29 primary, Beto ORourke, a Democratic candidate in Congressional District 16, wanted to talk about something other than decriminalizing marijuana.

title: Forthcoming Facebook Motion Said to Discuss Nasdaqs Role in I.P.O.
description: Facebook is preparing for battle.

title: The Old Neighborhood, in India
description: Patang (The Kite), Prashant Bhargavas first feature, has a lovely, unforced quality. Thats because Mr. Bhargava lets his story, set during the annual kite festival in Ahmedabad, India, tell itself, unfolding slowly as he follows filmmakings most basic and most sinned-against dictum: Show, dont tell.

title: Redistricting for Ethnicity Isnt Always a Sure Thing
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Jurors Begin Deliberations in Insider Trading Trial
description: As head of the elite consulting firm McKinsey & Company, Rajat K. Gupta associated with corporate chieftains and heads of state around the world.

title: A Hip-Hop History, by Those Who Made It
description: You write complicated rhymes, Ice-T says to Eminem in the new film Something From Nothing: The Art of Rap. Do they start out that way, he continues, or do you complicate them?

title: Mountain People With a Bad Reputation
description: A nagging junior high memory prompts a perilous trek to the back of beyond in Ikland, Cevin Soling and David Hilberts offbeat meditation on human nature and academic hubris.

title: Ari Seth Cohens Portraits of Older Women
description: Discovering Mimi Weddell, the gauntly stylish actress who, at 90, was the subject of a 2009 documentary, was a turning point for Ari Seth Cohen. Mr. Cohen, a 20-something photographer living in Seattle at the time, quickly decamped for Manhattan in pursuit of his new fashion idol.

title: How Greece Squandered Its Freedom
description: Athens

title: Brooklyn Bridge Park Expected to Announce Developers of a New Hotel Complex
description: The Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation is expected to vote on Tuesday to select Toll Brothers and Starwood Capital Group as the development team for a new hotel and residential complex that will be built in the park next to Pier 1, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, according to an official with knowledge of the deal.

title: Judge Dismisses Mobleys Lawsuit
description: A federal judge Wednesday dismissed Cuttino Mobleys lawsuit against Madison Square Garden for forcing him to retire from the Knicks in 2008, soon after being acquired, because of a heart condition.

title: How the Supreme Court Could Rule on the Health Care Law
description: What could happen to the health care law depending on what the Supreme Court decides on key questions.

title: Sensible Sentences for Nonviolent Offenders
description: The enormous strain prison costs put on state budgets has led some conservatives and liberals to do something sensible together. Democrats and Republicans in several states are pushing to reform criminal justice policies based on strong evidence that imprisoning nonviolent offenders for ever longer terms adds huge costs with little benefit to public safety.

title: Strangers, With Aliens Above
description: Alien invasion is just an excuse for romantic farce in Extraterrestrial, a tiresome roundelay of lies, lust and leaping paranoia.

title: Bad Dad, With Juniors Wedding to Spoil
description: Rejoice, fifth-grade fellas! Thats My Boy is a movie just for you. It has beer, hot-for-teacher sex, beer, gross-out sex, beer, strip clubs, beer, lots of bodily fluids and, mostly, a family of blue bloods gaga over an uncouth man-child.

title: Merkel Stresses Limits to Germanys Strength
description: BERLIN  Europes currency union may be inching ever closer to the brink of collapse, but Chancellor Angela Merkel has a message for those pressing her to ride to the rescue: Germany is not as strong as it looks, and certainly not strong enough to prop up the rest of Europe.

title: Asia Is Rising When It Comes to Expatriates Costs, Too
description: Mercer, a human resources consultancy, has released its annual survey ranking cities according to the cost of living for expatriates. Tokyo regained its place at the top, as last years No. 1, Luanda, Angola, slipped a notch. Of course, this is not a list that it necessarily pays to be at the top of.

title: President Obama in Albany
description: President Obama spoke to supporters in Albany.

title: Behind Those Cool Squirts in Summer, Many Plumbers
description: So many fountains. So little time.

title: Call Girl Dies, Manhunt to Follow
description: Theres a lot to like about the action film The Girl From the Naked Eye, especially some crisp martial arts fight sequences and the subtle sense of humor that surfaces now and then. But the filmmakers make a mistake in telling the story via flashback and a voice-over by Jason Yee, who plays Jake, the main character. As graceful as Mr. Yee is in those fights, he proves that delivering a compelling voice-over is harder than it seems.

title: In the Facebook Era, Reminders of Loss After Families Fracture
description: Not long ago, estrangements between family members, for all the anguish they can cause, could mean a fairly clean break. People would cut off contact, never to be heard from again unless they reconciled.

title: After Century-Long Wait, Stage Is Set for Man Daring to Cross the Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  The last time a man walked across the Niagara Gorge, Grover Cleveland was president. Utah had just become a state. And, that same year, the first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens.

title: Payback From Mom and Dad
description: Murkily shot and lazily plotted, The Tortured is the latest bone tossed in the general direction of flayed-flesh enthusiasts. And notwithstanding a smidgen of originality in the unpleasantly familiar setup of helpless victim and instrument-wielding sadist, this wearying entry in the canon suggests only that ferreting out new ways to inflict pain requires more imagination than anyone on hand realized.

title: Breaking Ties Is Complicated
description: So you think you know the tiebreaking procedure in the group stage of the European Championships as the third round of matches approaches?

title: Understanding the European Crisis Now
description: Europes debt crisis has been caused by too much sovereign debt and growing problems in its banking system.

title: Burnett Brings a Steady Presence to the Pirates
description: BALTIMORE  Outside it was pouring, a cold and sideways rainstorm that wiped out batting practice Tuesday at Camden Yards. Yet the pitchers still needed to throw, so A. J. Burnett dressed at his locker stall in the visitors clubhouse and got ready. While he did, he explained what he tells his younger teammates on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Libya Refuses to Release Hague Court Workers
description: PARIS  Despite pressure from international courts, NATO and rights groups, the Libyan authorities who are detaining a lawyer from the International Criminal Court and three members of the courts staff say they will not be released until the lawyer answers questions about her dealings with Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of the former dictator, a Libyan official in Tripoli said.

title: We Dont Need No Education
description: Hope springs eternal. For a few hours I was ready to applaud Mitt Romney for speaking honestly about what his calls for smaller government actually mean.

title: Dialysis Companys Failure to Warn of Product Risk Draws Inquiry
description: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating whether the nations largest operator of dialysis centers violated federal regulations by failing to inform customers of a potentially lethal risk connected to one of its products, an F.D.A. official said.

title: Sniff Test Does Not Prove Public Drinking, a Judge Rules
description: The police in New York City wrote 124,498 summonses last year for drinking in public  far more than for any other violation. After having to adjudicate so many of these public drinking cases, a Brooklyn judge has decided he has had enough.

title: The Democratic Road Not Taken
description: For more than four decades most Americans identified the Democratic Party with a social contract and safety net, equality of justice and opportunity, and progressive  yes, even liberal  causes. Sometime in the last 30 years the party of progress and change  Emersons party of hope  became the party of reactionary liberalism.

title: Gardners Elbow Needs More Rest
description: Outfielder Brett Gardner will get an additional three to four weeks of rest and his injured elbow will be placed in a brace during that period, the Yankees said.

title: No Theft Charge for Chronic Fatigue Researcher
description: Nevada authorities have dropped criminal charges against a researcher who gained wide attention for scientific reports linking chronic fatigue syndrome to an obscure mouse retrovirus.

title: Na Still Sore After Minor Fender Bender
description: Eight days before the start of the United States Open, Kevin Na was involved in a minor fender bender in Southern California while visiting his parents. The car he was driving was stopped at a light, he said, when it was rear-ended by a car that he estimated was traveling 40 miles an hour. He hasnt felt right since the collision.

title: A Senate Primary Stuck in the Shadows
description: ALBANY  Wendy E. Long, a Manhattan lawyer, is trumpeting endorsements from conservatives like the antitax activist Grover G. Norquist, the diplomat John R. Bolton and the former presidential candidate Steve Forbes.

title: Survival Skill Abandoned By Schools
description: On the warm days of summer, merry pilgrims depart a city where a fair number of public school swimming pools have been dry so long that they are used to store office supplies, and where generations have grown up with no more ability to swim than a box of photocopy paper.

title: The Clown and the Cop
description: Trapped with a Fox News big screen in my stable of trotters at the gym a few weeks ago, I took in the worldview that may give the White House to Republicans this year. After burning 400 calories, I was ready to torch the capital.

title: Secession and Ascension in St. Louis
description: The Unionists would all go to hell, and the secessionists to heaven.

title: Russian Official Apologizes for Threatening Journalist
description: MOSCOW  Russias chief federal investigator apologized on Thursday for an emotional breakdown, a day after he was publicly accused of threatening the life of a journalist.

title: Bahrain Compounds the Injustice
description: Bahrain had a chance to correct a grave injustice and set the country on a better path by dismissing specious cases against 20 Shiite doctors convicted last year after they treated protesters injured during the popular uprising against the Sunni-led monarchy. Instead, the High Criminal Court of Appeal on Thursday upheld the convictions of nine of them and imposed sentences of up to five years in jail. And 15-year sentences against two other doctors, who have fled the country, were upheld.

title: Armstrong Seemingly Readies for Battle
description: Earlier this spring, Lance Armstrong said he would not fight any more doping charges that cropped up against him because he was tired of it. But now that the United States Anti-Doping Agency is set to bring formal charges against him, it appears that he has changed his mind.

title: Anything-but-Ordinary Mom Pitches for Chobani Yogurt
description: TOO bad for Greece, and perhaps the euro, that the Greek economy is in no way helped by the surging popularity of Greek yogurt among American shoppers. In another sign of that interest, Chobani, the market leader in Greek yogurt in this country, is stepping up efforts to sell its new childrens product.

title: Smithfield Foods Profit Drops on Lower Margins for Pork
description: RICHMOND, Va. (AP)  Smithfield Foods, the pork producer, said Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 19 percent on lower margins on fresh pork, slow sales growth and higher selling costs.

title: Ground Zero Cancers
description: Federal health officials took a reasonable and humane step last week when they proposed to add 50 cancers to the list of illnesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund to treat and compensate emergency workers and residents exposed to toxic fumes, dust and smoke from the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Parlors Face Age-Limit Bill Over Tanning by Teenagers
description: Under a bill working its way through Albany, teenagers under 17 would be able to get suntans only the old-fashioned way: from the sun.

title: In a Star Pairing, Woods Is the Star
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The first tee box at the hilly Olympic Club is a tabletop plateau perched 25 feet above a winding sidewalk. The customary way to reach the tee is a 15-step staircase.

title: The Political Contrast
description: President Obama sometimes forgets that an important speech does not have to be endless. On Thursday, appearing before supporters at a Cleveland community college, he spent 53 minutes on the stark contrast between his goals and the failed Bush-era policies that Mitt Romney is trying to resurrect. Its hard to imagine that the speech, overgrown as it was with policy details, won the hearts of many independent voters yearning for a clear understanding of how much is at stake in November.

title: Accused Chinese Party Members Face Harsh Discipline
description: BEIJING  Membership in the Chinese Communist Party has many advantages. Officials often enjoy government-issued cars, bottomless expense accounts and the earning potential from belonging to a club whose members control every lever of government and many of the nations most lucrative enterprises.

title: Before Retrial of Lawmaker, More Discord
description: A federal judge in Manhattan raised questions on Thursday about aspects of the governments corruption case against City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, whose retrial is scheduled to begin on Tuesday.

title: What Republicans Think
description: Democrats frequently ask me why the Republicans have become so extreme. As they describe the situation, they usually fall back on some sort of illness metaphor. Republicans have a mania. President Obama has said that Republicans have a fever that he hopes will break if he is re-elected.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stanley Comfortable With New Caddie
description: After closing with a 69 in Memphis in his final tuneup for the Open, Kyle Stanley made a radical move. He fired his caddie, Brett Waldman, who was on his bag for his first tour victory in February in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Shot by Officer After Car Crash, Woman Dies
description: A woman was fatally shot by a plainclothes New York City police detective on Thursday after running a series of red lights in a stolen vehicle in Brooklyn, colliding head-on with a minivan, then scrambling to evade the police, the authorities said.

title: Revolt Leaders Cite Failure to Uproot Old Order in Egypt
description: CAIRO  They toppled a pharaoh, but now the small circle of liberals, leftists and Islamists who orchestrated Egypts revolution say they realize they failed to uproot the networks of power that Hosni Mubarak nurtured for nearly three decades.

title: A Police Hot Line for Abuse Claims at Horace Mann
description: The New York Police Department said Thursday that it would join the effort to identify past victims of abuse at the Horace Mann School, creating a confidential hot line for anyone with information, regardless of how old, about inappropriate sexual contact by adults with students.

title: New Detroit-to-Canada Bridge to Be Unveiled
description: American and Canadian leaders are to unveil plans on Friday for a new bridge linking Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, opening a new chapter in a long and contentious debate over the future of a region that has become one of the nations busiest border crossings.

title: Pressured, E.P.A. Proposes Soot Limit
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new national air quality standards that would significantly reduce levels of fine-particle soot.

title: What Was Yours at One Time
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  To what extent do you recognize and appreciate when an entry in a crossword puzzle is fresh, or is appearing for the first time (in The New York Times, anyway)?

title: Hope Is a Thing With Long, Fuzzy Ears
description: During the heyday of Studio 54 it was probably not unusual for patrons to see visions of strange beasts roaming the dance floor. And didnt Bianca Jagger once make an appearance on a white horse?

title: Pop Warner Weighing Research and Risks in Concussion Prevention Efforts
description: The unremarkable football career of Dr. Julian Bailes, who is now the chairman of the Pop Warner medical advisory board, ended quietly during his college days in the 1970s. He never sustained a concussion that he knew of, but he can recall a friend in high school who did. Confused and concussed, his friend started describing a car he had just bought; there was no new car, and Bailes found it hilarious. We didnt know any better, he said.

title: The Vatican: A Reconciliation Bid
description: The Vatican said Thursday that it had proposed granting the Society of St. Pius X a special legal status as part of a continued effort on the part of Pope Benedict XVI toward reconciliation with the breakaway traditionalist group. The status of personal prelature, similar to a diocese without specific boundaries, was introduced during the Second Vatican Council and until now has been given only to the conservative Opus Dei movement. The proposal was made during a meeting between Bishop Bernard Fellay, superior general of the Society of St. Pius X, and Cardinal William J. Levada, the Vaticans chief doctrinal officer, to discuss elements of the doctrinal preamble that the group must accept before reconciliation can be reached. Bishop Fellay promised to respond in a reasonable amount of time. The group does not have canonical status in the church. In 1988 Pope John Paul II excommunicated Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the groups founder, as well as four bishops he consecrated without the Vaticans approval.

title: Cocaine Incorporated
description: One afternoon last August, at a hospital on the outskirts of Los Angeles, a former beauty queen named Emma Coronel gave birth to a pair of heiresses. The twins, who were delivered at 3:50 and 3:51, respectively, stand to inherit some share of a fortune that Forbes estimates is worth a billion dollars. Coronels husband, who was not present for the birth, is a legendary tycoon who overcame a penurious rural childhood to establish a wildly successful multinational business. If Coronel elected to leave the entry for Father on the birth certificates blank, it was not because of any dispute over patrimony. More likely, she was just skittish about the fact that her husband, Joaqun Guzmn, is the C.E.O. of Mexicos Sinaloa cartel, a man the Treasury Department recently described as the worlds most powerful drug trafficker. Guzmns organization is responsible for as much as half of the illegal narcotics imported into the United States from Mexico each year; he may well be the most-wanted criminal in this post-Bin Laden world. But his bride is a U.S. citizen with no charges against her. So authorities could only watch as she bundled up her daughters and slipped back across the border to introduce them to their dad.
