title: Inside the List
description: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE: The female / Is a chaos, Ezra Pound wrote, but if the savage women of Gillian Flynns critically acclaimed novels are anything to go by, chaos is only the half of it. Theyre women with dark pasts and big appetites  for booze, men and mutilation. In Gone Girl, Flynns third and latest novel, which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, a happy housewife goes missing on the morning of her fifth anniversary, but naturally, nothing is what it seems. Both husband and wife are skillful liars, and the book turns out to be a two-sided contest, Janet Maslin wrote recently in the daily New York Times. Each addresses the reader: Nick in the present tense, and Amy by way of an italics-filled, giddily emotional diary about the marriage. . . . They lied to each other a lot. Now they will lie to you. Nick starts looking guilty pretty quickly, and flighty Amy turns out to be harboring some secrets of her own.

title: By Mapping a River, Volunteers Take a Stake in Its Future
description: Dodging quicksand and rattlesnakes, Ted Mouras will spend Saturday morning walking along a five-mile stretch of a remote section of southeastern Arizonas San Pedro River Basin in triple-digit heat for the annual wet/dry mapping of its water levels. A retired Army officer, he has volunteered annually to help the Nature Conservancy and its partners determine how the prolonged drought in the Southwest and the depletion of aquifers from local use affect the river.

title: The Sport of Kings
description: With his graceful depictions of the embattled American West, Wallace Stegner remains unrivaled in his ability to humanize the clash between frontier beauty and progress. But there is always more gold in those hills, and Alyson Hagy isnt a writer to mistake pyrite for something precious. In her third novel, Boleto, the alluring wilds of Wyoming and the horses wrangled there come with price tags affixed. The question is: Are we buying?

title: Fantasy Island
description: Can the hoary trope of mistaken identity still play in the age of Google images? Especially if its a young, handsome womanizer with tousled blond hair being mistaken for the middle-aged, balding keynote speaker at the meticulously planned conference of a prestigious foundation?

title: Interpreter of Maladies
description: We need to talk about Alice. Alice, with her black hair and big mouth. With her beautiful body and poor impulse control. Alice, criminal and savior, the victim and heroine of Our Lady of Alice Bhatti, a deft, evil little novel of comic genius by Mohammed Hanif, author of the prizewinning Case of Exploding Mangoes.

title: The Avengers
description: This is the hardest part, confides one of the untrustworthy narrators in GONE GIRL (Crown, $25), waiting for stupid people to figure things out. Theres no need to rub it in, because Gillian Flynns latest novel of psychological suspense will confound anyone trying to keep up with her quicksilver mind and diabolical rules of play. Not that theres anything underhanded about her intentions: she promises to deliver an account of the troubled marriage of Nick and Amy Dunne, who alternate as narrators, and so she does. The trickery is in the devilish way she tells their story.

title: What Would Keynes Do?
description: Nearly four years on from the financial meltdown that plunged it into recession, the global economy remains fragile. The latest green shoots of recovery in the United States already show signs of turning brown. It is touch and go whether Barack Obama will enter the polls with unemployment above or below the 8 percent rate that usually means defeat for an incumbent president. Across the Atlantic, the euro zone stumbles from crisis to crisis; the continuing problems of the heavily indebted PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Spain) remain the basis for many a nightmare, some of the worst involving the banks around the world that own much of the debt.

title: Changing Lanes
description: The subtitle of Dan Gets a Minivan  Life at the Intersection of Dude and Dad  nicely encapsulates a genre that has provided rich fodder for former dudes like Bill Cosby (Fatherhood), Robert Wilder (Daddy Needs a Drink) and Dave Barry (take your pick). It has also spawned a lucrative second career for the actor Paul Reiser (Couplehood, Babyhood, Familyhood).

title: The Transcendentalist
description: The poet April Bernards latest work of fiction, Miss Fuller, opens in 1850, on the day the translator, literary critic, essayist, political activist and journalist Margaret Fuller died in a shipwreck off the coast of Long Island. Fuller, who had been in Italy reporting for Horace Greeleys New-York Tribune, was returning home to the United States with her husband and young son when the ship foundered during a storm. Most of the novel is seen from the point of view of a woman named Anne, a fictitious sister of Henry David Thoreau; other parts are narrated by Fuller herself, via fabricated letters supposedly found by Thoreau on the day he visited the site of the wreck.

title: Express Yourself
description: Americans love to talk about feelings. We do it almost compulsively and generally go about with the assumption that expressing emotion is a good idea. We are always articulating anger, jealousy and anxiety while people from more decorous cultures know when to keep their inner lives and dirty laundry to themselves.

title: The Third Child
description: Adolescence is  for almost everyone, at least some of the time  excruciating. (Those few for whom this is not so, beware: there can be few things more dismaying than to find that adolescence was your zenith.)

title: What Minty Knew
description: This is a book about secrets. What secrets do we keep? Whom do we trust? Why?

title: Bookshelf: Dragons
description: New picture books starring the fire-breathing creatures.

title: Bookshelf: Dragons
description: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS  By Adam Rubin.Illustrated by Daniel Salmieri.  40 pp. Dial. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

title: BASE Jumpers Double the Dare
description: MOAB, Utah  Castle Valley spread out about 1,500 feet below, and Mario Richard scooted his toes to the edge of the cliff. It can be an awkward shuffle when there is another person fastened to the front of him.

title: Security Worker Is Sought in Shootings on Canadian Campus
description: OTTAWA  Police officers throughout Canada were searching Friday afternoon for a security company employee after three of his co-workers were fatally shot and a fourth was critically wounded during an early morning robbery attempt at a university residence and student services center in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: German Rectitude Has Its Risks
description: As markets pummeled Spanish and Italian government bonds this week after Europes latest effort to contain the euro crisis, Germany seemed increasingly isolated in its demands for more austerity. The June 9 cover of The Economist portrayed the world economy as a sinking oil tanker with the caption, Please can we start the engines now, Mrs. Merkel?

title: Investigation of Jeep Grand Cherokee Portends a Recall, Safety Advocate Says
description: With the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration having decided to upgrade its investigation of rear-impact fires involving Jeep Grand Cherokees, a recall of millions of those vehicles is certain, said Clarence Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, the organization whose work prompted the federal inquiry.

title: Practical Travelers Tips for Summer Travel With Kids
description: If youre planning a trip involving flights with children this summer, youll want to check out Practical Traveler Michelle Higginss advice for traveling families. At a minimum, especially if youre traveling with small children, take a change of clothes onboard for the child and yourself. That way, when she spills cranberry juice all over you, or her diaper leaks, you have options. My oldest son once soaked himself at the infinity fountain in the Detroit airport

title: Lets Eat!
description: I like to claim I grew up watching Julia Child on TV, though what really happened is, I watched my parents watch her. I also like to believe Mastering the Art of French Cooking was a huge influence on my own, though Im not sure Ive ever even looked at the vegetable chapter. I was there for Julia when she got all Californian. (A recipe for pita? Come on.) Im here for her even now that shes no longer around. We all love Julia and the stories from her wonderful life: the O.S.S., the sophisticated husband who introduced her to sole meunire, the Cordon Bleu, The French Chef, Paris, Provence, the fact that she was over six feet tall and was said to have dropped a chicken on live television. (Alas, it was only a potato pancake.)

title: In Investments, as in Life, Passion Can Cloud Judgment
description: IVE been talking to a lot of wealthy people in the last few weeks who have followed their passions into a variety of investments: vineyards, baseball teams, restaurants and racehorses. But I couldnt help wondering what it would take for these people, who had made the money for such investments by being shrewd in other lines of work, to sell their stake in a fascinating second career.

title: A Gleam Off the Samovar
description: Some fantasy novels deal out the tropes of the genre like cards from a dog-eared deck. Others affirm the elemental power of these tropes, reminding us not only why we read fantasy, but also why we read at all. There may be nothing new under the sun, but a good story makes you just not care. Like the expert strike of a reflex hammer, it hits precisely the right spot.

title: Studies Find That Gossip Isnt Just Loose Talk
description: GOSSIP. Almost all of us do it, most of us are embarrassed about it, and sometimes, to our horror, we get caught.

title: The Gray Zone
description: Two months ago at the London Book Fair, where China was this years guest of honor, Ma Jian, the exiled author of the Tiananmen-era novel Beijing Coma, inked a red X across his face in an emotional protest against Chinese censorship. It may be a sign of the times that while drawing attention from the Western press, the move went almost unnoticed by other Chinese authors present, many of whom still live in China and find ways to circumvent the authorities.

title: In Duel of Stars, Heats James Gains Early Edge
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Their statistics were nearly identical, mirror images of dueling superstars in search of the slightest of edges. But as LeBron James and Kevin Durant spoke late Thursday night, it was clear that the psychology of the N.B.A. finals had been flipped in favor of the Miami Heat.

title: Kids Draw the News | Nik Wallendas Big Night
description: Update: This assignment is closed. The more results can be seen here.

title: Immigration Announcement May Overshadow Romney Bus Tour
description: BOSTON  Mitt Romney begins a five-day bus tour on Friday, during which he had hoped to make his case to small-town voters that President Obamas economic policies are failing everyday Americans. But the Romney campaign may find it more difficult to stay on message in the wake of the Obama administrations announcement that it would stop deporting younger immigrants who came to the United States as children.

title: Siblings, Squabbling in the Car
description: This weeks parental quandary is mine again  or rather, one Ive solved, at least temporarily, but one on which I thought we could all use a little good crowd-sourced advice. The problem? Children squabbling madly away in the car.

title: Prince Charles Kicks Off London Mens Fashion Week
description: The season of international mens-wear fashion shows kicked off in London on Thursday, which was unusual in that London, apart from its Savile Row traditions, has more recently treated mens wear as an afterthought when it comes to the runway. Londons attempt to start a new mens event was also unusual in that it was introduced with a party given by Prince Charles in the State Apartments of St. Jamess Palace.

title: The Well Quiz: All About Fathers
description: How much do you know about todays fathers? And how do they compare to mothers? Take our Dad Quiz to find out.

title: What About Dad?
A First for the Golden Flashes
description: Its been a dramatic and exciting season for the Kent State baseball team, and its not over yet. The Golden Flashes are one of this years Cinderella teams in the College World Series, which starts Friday in Omaha. Kent State (46-18) is scheduled to play on Saturday against Arkansas (43-20).

title: McCain Says Adelson is Putting Foreign Money Into Campaign
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona suggested in an interview posted online on Friday that a super PAC backing Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, may have provided a conduit for foreign money to enter the presidential race.

title: In Euro Crisis, Obama Looks to Merkel
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of a summit meeting at Camp David last month, as the other world leaders were heading for their helicopters, President Obama did what has become a habit during his years in the White House: he made time for an informal but deadly serious talk with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.

title: Richard F. Stolz Dies at 86; Headed C.I.A. Spy Operations After Iran-Contra
description: Richard F. Stolz, a career intelligence officer who was called out of retirement in 1987 to run the Central Intelligence Agencys spying operations and cleanse its image after the Iran-contra scandal, died on June 9 in Williamsburg, Va. He was 86.

title: Just One Look | Rag & Bone
description: As Rag and Bones David Neville and Marcus Wainwright expand their line to include womens bags, theyre stepping back and revisiting the essence of the brand with their clothing. In the designers resort collection youll find reworked favorites like silk and satin midnight-blue track pants, dark knit sweaters and leather minidresses. Pops of color came in floral printed pieces and gold sequined dresses and blouses. Their signature Newbury ankle boots came in perennial black, blue and brown. If you have the classic colors covered, check out the new shiny gold leather version.

title: Loves DeBarge. And Fred Astaire.
description: THE fun-loving pop-rock duo LMFAO have been a major presence on the Billboard charts since last year, when they released their sophomore album, Sorry for Party Rocking (Interscope). Spoiler: They werent sorry. Their single Party Rock Anthem was just that: an inescapably addictive soundtrack for clubs, parties, barbecues, street fairs, anywhere people gathered to have a good time. Hits like Sexy and I Know It became remixed staples for nightlife-worshiping fans, not least because LMFAO created dance moves along with them.

title: Loud Enough to Be Heard in Another Country
description: IF everything had gone according to the plan drawn up by Japandroids, they would already be long forgotten. Formed in Vancouver in 2006, this garage-rock duo had decided to call it quits in late 2008 after failing to break out of the British Columbia music scene, but not before commemorating their departure with Post-Nothing, a debut  and farewell  album. But after their song Young Hearts Spark Fire was posted by the online music publication Pitchfork in March 2009, Post-Nothing went from a would-be posthumous release to an industry calling card, leading to a record deal and two years of relentless touring.

title: Exotic Creatures, Naughty and Nice
description: Gremlins 2: The New Batch

title: Euro 2012 Highlights: Sweden (2) vs. England (3)
description: The distance between England and a European championship is vast  in real and psychic terms. But maybe, just maybe, those hurdles are not quite as high after England took the lead, lost the lead, tied the game and roared back to defeat Sweden in a Group D game in Kyiv, Ukraine, at the European Championships.

title: Morning Walkabout  6/15: Airport Makeovers and a Niagara Falls High-Wire Act
description: Bigger, Better Airports The biggest airports in the country Los Angeles, Dallas, Atlanta, Chicago and the three that serve New York City have been undergoing major renovations and expansions. (The New York Times)

title: Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading
description: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, was found guilty on Friday of conspiracy and securities fraud for leaking boardroom secrets to a billionaire hedge fund manager.

title: ResCap Rejects Berkshire Bids for Assets
description: Residential Capital, the mortgage arm of Ally Financial, has rejected bids by Berkshire Hathaway to buy most of its assets out of bankruptcy, and will instead follow its original sales plans.

title: Music Box as Muse to Puccinis Butterfly
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.

title: When Slow Growth Looks Good
description: Among the Group of 7 industrialized countries, only the Canadian, United States and German economies are now larger than they were at their prerecession peaks. The top set of charts shows the seven G-7 countries, ranked by performance since each economy peaked in 2007 or 2008, with members of the euro zone in italics. The second set shows the performance of seven other euro zone countries, similarly ranked.

title: Norway Has Noir; Just Ask Jo Nesbo
description: Jo Nesbo, the Norwegian writer of crime thrillers, is already being called the next Stieg Larsson. The comparison is a little premature: Mr. Nesbo, who has sold some 14 million books worldwide, is a household name in Europe, but in this country, even though Martin Scorsese recently announced plans to film Mr. Nesbos 2007 novel, The Snowman, his reputation is not yet Larssonesque.

title: Keeping a Cool Head About a Passion Investment
description: Paul Sullivan has been writing for the last few weeks about various people who have followed their hearts and invested in everything from vineyards to baseball teams to racehorses. He raises the question in this weeks Wealth Matters column about whether decisions by these people on when to buy sell or how much to pay are any better than the decisions by people who put their money into stocks and bonds.

title: Weekend Fare
description: In recognition of National Lobster Day, which is Friday, Eds Lobster Bar Annex, 25 Clinton Street (between East Houston and Stanton Streets), on the Lower East Side, will hold a lobster fest starting at 4:30 p.m. For $60 a person, you can taste everything from half a chilled lobster and lobster rolls to lobster-filled ravioli and tacos.

title: Let Them Eat Cinnamon Buns
description: KELLIE CICCONI has always been a picky eater.

title: London Theater Journal: Mary Tyrone, Deglamorized and Unforgettable
description: On the first truly sunny afternoon on offer since I arrived in London, I chose to descend into a deep American fog. Oh, I knew that light-starved, water-logged people were out there romping around Piccadilly Circus like newly escaped captives of a crypt. Yet there I was, some feet below street level in the Apollo Theater, grinning away at a fine, murky spectacle of unhappiness like a member of the Addams Family in a torture chamber.

title: In Health Care Ruling, Vast Implications for Medicaid
description: ENGLAND, Ark.  As a construction worker and logger, Bryan L. Mashburn does what he describes as backbreaking, muscle-pulling work, laying concrete foundations for water towers and felling 3,000-pound trees. He has no health insurance, and he tried to avoid going to doctors when he crushed a finger on one occasion and metal shavings flew deep into his eye another time.

title: Image of the Day: June 15
Little-Known Firm to Reap Millions in Exchanges Sale
description: LONDON  A little-known metals trading company owned by an Indian family stands to become one of the biggest winners in London Metal Exchanges sale to Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing.

title: A Slow Recovery in the United States, but Its All Relative
description: THE slow pace of the American economic recovery seems likely to be a major issue in this years presidential election. But by the standards of other developed countries, the United States has done rather well since the credit crisis blossomed in 2008 and sent the world into recession.

title: A Breakthrough on Immigration Policy
description: Expect Republicans and other hardliners on immigration (the few who are not Republicans) to go berserk over this one: The administration has announced that it will stop deporting many illegal immigrants who came to the United States before they turned 16.

title: A Better Way to Prepare Quinoa
description: If you enjoy cooking with quinoa (pronounced keen-wah), then youll appreciate the latest preparation tips from Martha Rose Shulman. Once you perfect your prep, youll be rewarded with five delicious new salads made with quinoa. Ms. Shulman writes:

title: Big Names Flock to Michael Grandages New Theater Company
description: Judi Dench, Jude Law and Daniel Radcliffe will play major characters in the inaugural season of London theater from a new producing company formed by the Tony Award-wining director Michael Grandage (Red) and his business partner, James Bierman, who together ran the Donmar Warehouse from 2006 to 2011, according to an announcement from the two men on Thursday night. The season will include a new play, Peter and Alice by John Logan, the Tony-winning author of Red, with Ms. Dench and the actor Ben Whishaw playing the two real-life figures who inspired Alice in Wonderland and Peter Pan.

title: Just One Look | Alexander Wang
description: All you need to know about Alexander Wangs resort collection is: mock croc (on everything from bags to puffer jackets!), transparency (in flowing paneled dresses and sturdy gossamer heeled shoes) and bras galore. This look features faux-croc track shorts and a classic knit tank, which from the front is a halter top but from the back is more of a bodysuit, with classic bra straps. Undergarments as outerwear also came in cropped corsets, spongy lime-colored compact knit tubes and new neoprene bibbed dresses. The response was supportive.

title: An Earlier Housing Bubble
description: Bloomberg Views excellent economic history blog tells of an earlier housing bubble, from the same country and era that brought us tulip-mania.

title: The Sweet Spot | Setting 9/11 in Stone
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott debate the relative merits of museums and memorials and discuss how to best make sense of Sept. 11.

title: Obamas Decision on Immigration Is Met With Joy, Anger and Skepticism
description: Updated, 6:10 p.m. As my colleagues Julia Preston and John H. Cushman Jr. report, an Obama administration policy announced Friday morning will halt the deportation of illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children and allow them to obtain work permits.

title: The Sweet Spot: June 15
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the relative merits of museums and memorials, and how to best make sense of Sept. 11.

title: For Ann Romney, a Different Sort of Horse Race
description: The Romneys face a different sort of fierce competition this weekend: a horse co-owned by Ann Romney will compete for a berth at the London Olympic Games.

title: Ukraines President Says He Has No Authority to Pardon Jailed Rival
description: MOSCOW  Ukraines president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, said in an interview published this week that he wanted to pardon Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the countrys jailed former prime minister and his main political rival, but did not have the legal authority to do so, a claim Ms. Tymoshenkos lawyer scoffed at on Friday.

title: Guest Column: Yes, Oil Prices Are Cyclical
description: Amy Myers Jaffe is an energy consultant and the Wallace S. Wilson Fellow for Energy Policy Studies at Rice University.

title: Gracie Mansion Kitchen, New in Kochs Day, Is to Be Updated
description: Any sentence that begins, Even for a small dinner for 100 guests  is bound to claim attention.

title: A School With Plenty of Air-Conditioners, All Sitting in Storage
The Designs of Brave
description: A look at how the red-haired firebrand Merida of Pixars new movie, Brave, was developed.

title: Five Small Communities Within Manhattan
description: For a few fortunate people living in Manhattan, home lies on one of a handful of short streets that run for just a block, or two or three at the most.

title: Over a Decade Later, Still Learning the Lessons of Stop-and-Frisk
Arch Basel
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Beyond-the-Grid Manhattan
description: THE vast majority of Manhattan residents live on streets that seem to run forever. Twenty-third Street clocks in at about two miles, Second Avenue at nearly seven. Thanks to Manhattans grid plan, which is celebrating its bicentennial with an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, the bulk of the island is laid out in rigid checkerboard fashion.

title: Evolution of a Feisty Pixar Princess
description: IN some form or other  toys, monsters, cars, rats and even little boys  male characters have been at the center of Pixar Animation Studios feature films. But now for the first time in its 17-year history, Pixar has a female lead. The studio spent more than five years bringing Merida, the empowered girl at the center of Brave (opening Friday), to life. It took a number of designs and two directors to do it.

title: Spotwag Helps Facebook Friends Find Pet Sitters
description: If you have a pet and you travel a lot, you know how difficult it can be to find someone to look after your furry buddy. Asking a friend, and then trying to give them money for their troubles, is often a pretty awkward affair.

title: Movie Endings
description: Images from apocalyptic films of recent years.

title: Walcott Seizes on Charges of Sexual Abuse in Harlem School
Nancy Coffey and Timothy Nagler
description: IN August 2005, F. Timothy Nagler believed, as he put it, that he had the happiest marriage on the planet.

title: TimesCast: Changes in Immigration Policy
description: Richard W. Stevenson on the political implications of President Obamas announcement.

title: ReRun Gastropub Theater to Close
description: The reRun Gastropub, a movie theater and bar in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, is to close for an unspecified period of time, the sites programmer, Aaron Hillis, announced in an email this week. With the subject line Farewell to reRun Gastropub Theater, Mr. Hillis wrote that he would be stepping down from curating films there and that the owner, Jason Stevens, would temporarily shut the space to revamp it for whatever its next incarnation will be.

title: Book Review Podcast: The First Ladys Family
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Edward Ball reviews Rachel Swarnss American Tapestry, an intricate look into the family history of Michelle Obama. The book, which includes what Mr. Ball calls herculean investigations, goes back to the 1800s, following Mrs. Obamas relatives through slavery in South Carolina, Georgia, Virginia and Kentucky. Mr. Ball writes:

title: Glen Tonche
description: A 35-acre estate on top of Mount Tonche in the Catskill Mountains.

title: Zeus of the Catskills
description: IT breaks Randall Wallaces heart to have to sell Glen Tonche, the 35-acre estate he owns on top of Mount Tonche in the Catskill Mountains.

title: TimesCast Politics: Changes in Immigration Policy
description: Richard W. Stevenson discusses the political implications of President Obamas announcement on immigration policy.

title: Shaw Festival Turns to a Former Leader
description: Elaine Calder, the president of the Oregon Symphony, will become the executive director of the Shaw Festival in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, for the second time in her career, the theaters board announced on Thursday.

title: Top Gear, Stig-less on Apples Screens
description: What is it about the Top Gear television series that makes otherwise upstanding companies act like used-car salesmen?

title: This Is the Way the World Ends
description: SOME say the world will end in fire,/Some say in ice, Robert Frost wrote nearly a hundred years ago, but for moviegoers of the 21st century both the giant conflagration and the big freeze have become a bit been there, done that.

title: Threat of Russian Hooliganism Looms Over Championships
description: Besides tossing a few firecrackers, pummeling some stadium ushers and brawling in the streets of Warsaw, Russian soccer fans, it can be said, have so far been pretty disciplined at this years European soccer championships.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An 1853 Greek Revival town house in Fort Greene and a one-bedroom Upper West Side condo.

title: Stockholm, and the Strangers Who Brought Me There
description: THE view was peerless but not pierless. I was sitting on the patio of the chic Hotel Skeppsholmen, which, located on an island in the middle of Stockholm, seems to embody all thats good about a city that is roughly one-third water and one-third green space. I could see lawn, palisades, boats and ferries, very few tourists, Northern Europes best-preserved medieval city, an amusement park built in 1883, important shrubbery, ducks.

title: The Modern Pentathlon Just Got Even More  Modern
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  You may have missed it, but there is something big going on in the world of modern pentathlon.

title: Palace-Hopping in Poland
description: WHEN I was a little girl living in Texas and visited my family in Poland, my grandfather would always take us to palaces. He had been an art historian and curator of a couple of the palaces around Warsaw during some of Polands bleakest years of Communism, and even though I was too young to understand that era, or much of Polands complicated history, I knew that through these palaces, something about Poland and its once-luxurious glory had been preserved. My imagination conjured images of princesses running through lavishly decorated hallways and grand, echoing rooms.

title: Where Polish Royalty Lived
description: Travel to Warsaw for a tour of castles and palaces.

title: Free Spirits in a Sonoma Hamlet
description: UNDER a blinding noonday sun, my boyfriend and I pulled onto the comfortably worn commercial strip of Guerneville, Calif., a former lumber town in Sonoma County. Two men, hand-in-hand, ambled past the mix of rustic, renovated and retro storefronts on Main Street, a backdrop that suggested a dash of San Franciscos Union Street and Mayberry. A chic restaurant sat near a pawnshop that sat near the Guerneville 5 & 10, whose metal marquee and wooden sign made the place look like a relic from the 40s, which, in fact, it is.

title: A Jersey Shore Rebound
description: WHILE towns along the Jersey Shore reinvented themselves during the boom of the aughts, sprouting boutique hotels and upscale restaurants, Asbury Park retained a refreshing, rare Americana charm. Restaurants  and boutique hotels  arrived, but they have had to share the Boardwalk with nostalgic attractions like a pinball museum and a psychic. And a majestic urban ghost presides over it all: the Boardwalk ends at the magnificent shell of a 1920s-era casino and carousel house.

title: June 17  23
description: IT seems that New York City abounds with free summer outdoor movie screenings nowadays, but perhaps the daddy of them all is the HBO BRYANT PARK SUMMER FILM FESTIVAL, which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year with some of its biggest hits from the past. It starts Monday with Psycho and concludes Aug. 20 with Raiders of the Lost Ark, and on Mondays in between are heavyweights like On the Waterfront (July 9), All About Eve (Aug. 13) and The Wizard of Oz (July 2), which, weather permitting, may well generate the seasons biggest turnout. (I remember when Casablanca closed the festival a few years back. Some viewers reverently whispered famous lines a moment before they were uttered on screen.)

title: A Czech Trove of Minimalist Design
description: FLAT-FACED, devoid of frills and anonymous, the synagogue stood at the end of a narrow street in the Czech city of Brno, not far from a railroad trestle where trains could be heard building speed for points farther east. Beyond the two slightly angled gray walls at either side of its four glass entry doors, the synagogue appeared remarkably plain, standing out among the neighboring buildings with an unwelcoming facade, and showing no sign of life.

title: Restaurant Report: State Bird Provisions in San Francisco
description: In 2003, after dining at Tapawingo, in Ellsworth, Mich., the Times reporter R. W. Apple Jr. observed that it may be the best restaurant anywhere in the country thats a four-hour drive from the closest major city. Mr. Apple took note of Tapawingos chef, Stuart Brioza, then 28, predicting that he will be one of the best chefs in America, full stop, in just a few years. He also lauded Tapawingos pastry chef, Nicole Krasinski, as an adroit match for Mr. Briozas restless spontaneity.

title: Mad Men to Turbans
description: Im not a big shopper, confessed Janie Bryant, costume designer for feature films and for Mad Men, the AMC television series whose season finale was shown last Sunday. She finds much more inspiration in traveling to far-flung destinations and, say, riding a camel, than in riffling through clothing store racks.

title: Hotel Review: Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel Chicago
description: UPSHOT

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $70 Million
description: A 14-room duplex penthouse apartment above the Ritz-Carlton that sold for $70 million to the casino magnate Steve Wynn was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. It was also the second-highest price ever paid for an apartment in New York City.

title: Gracie Mansion to Get a New Kitchen
description: The kitchen at Gracie Mansion is about to be renovated for the first time in 27 years, City Room reports.

title: Just One Look | Theyskens Theory
description: Come this resort season, the Theyskens Theory girl (whos either a downtown model or someone working a downtown-model-off-duty look) will have to shelve her black leather motorcycle pants and tattered tees. Because the designer Olivier Theyskens is showing the softer side of cool, in the form of an all-white palette. Jumpsuits, trousers, cropped jackets  everything you already have in black, youll now want in white. Even those velour hot shorts now come in a white (and more covered) version. Denim vests and overall shorts are washed in light blue, and theres an even brighter side: rainbow jeweled crop tops and threaded mini dresses.

title: Microsoft Is Expected to Introduce a Tablet
description: For decades, Microsoft has made the software that runs a majority of the worlds personal computers, leaving a gang of outside hardware companies to design the machines. Apple, its rival, makes it all.

title: Flights of Fancy, Indeed: French Ptissier Onboard
description: The innovative French pastry chef Pierre Herm, one of the worlds most famous ptissiers, has enjoyed a long love affair with Japan. In 1998, he introduced the first outpost of his Pierre Herm Paris pastry boutique in Tokyo, three years before opening one in Paris.

title: Advice for the Estranged, Online and Off
description: People who are estranged from family members often dont speak about it  out of shame, embarrassment or to avoid the judgment of acquaintances. Elizabeth Vagnoni, a documentary filmmaker, whose two sons no longer speak to her, said: They think, What did you do? What kind of mother must you be?

title: Why the Thunders Starting Lineup Isnt Working
description: For evidence of the power of lineup manipulation in basketball, one need look no further than the intriguing circumstances that have forced Serge Ibaka to (rather unsuccessfully) check Shane Battier. An incredibly athletic defensive player of the year candidate has been humbled in his attempts to defend an aging spot-up shooter, largely due to Scott Brookss reluctance to make what could be the N.B.A. finals most crucial adjustment.

title: China Suspends Family Planning Workers After Forced Abortion
description: SHANGHAI  China suspended three local family planning officials in northwest China this week following a public outcry over reports that they had forced a young woman to undergo an abortion seven months into her pregnancy, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency.

title: Movies That Flicker Only on the Page
description: Janet Maslin recently reviewed two novels that each featured fictional movies. Jess Walters Beautiful Ruins includes the idea for a movie called Donner! about the Donner party, which, Ms. Maslin writes, might just be the worst screenplay idea Hollywood has ever known. And in Alan Fursts new novel, Mission to Paris, an actor stars in a movie about World War I called Aprs la Guerre, or After the War, which begins filming at the dawn of World War II.

title: In Motion, Facebook Lays Out Defense and Highlights Nasdaqs Missteps
description: Nearly one month after its bungled initial public offering, Facebook is breaking its silence.

title: Reporter Interrupts Obama During Statement on Immigration
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated The interruption stunned White House correspondents and television viewers. And it clearly surprised President Obama, too.

title: Photo Replay: June 15
description: The day in sports included swimming in Rome, the European soccer championships and badminton in Jakarta, Indonesia.

title: Good Dad, Bad Dad
description: Fathers Day is a complicated holiday for me. As an adult, my relationship with my dad is pretty good. Hes attentive and tries to be available to my brother and me. But when we were growing up, he was the worst: always focused on work or sports  anything but us. So, Im grateful to him now, but resentful about the past. Worse, he wont apologize. How would you handle him?Sue, New York

title: Red Crayon, Blue Crayon
description: WHEN Really Big Coloring Books published a 32-page childrens book about the Tea Party in 2010, the book received a lot of unwanted attention. The Los Angeles Times called it kiddie propaganda art; its author and publisher, Wayne Bell, said he received death threats.

title: Italy Makes Plans to Cut Debt and Revive Growth
description: ROME  The Italian government moved forward on Friday with a wide-ranging package of economic measures worth about 80 billion euros, or $101 billion, that were meant both to spur economic growth and make a dent in the countrys unsustainably large public debt.

title: For Fathers Day, the Gift of a Fellow Fan
description: The Devils came within two games of winning the Stanley Cup, the biggest prize in hockey. As a longtime fan, I should have been bitterly disappointed. But I wasnt, because while I followed their two-month playoff run, an unexpected hockey-watching companion developed: my six-year-old son, Nicholas. The boy who was once more interested in watching the Zamboni than the hockey game turned into a sports-page-reading fanatic.

title: Lumire | The New Normal Chic
description: The French like their leaders to be regal, so Franois Hollandes pledge to be a normal president will take some getting used to. Not that Hollande seems ready to surrender any of the powers of his office or abandon Charles de Gaulles certain idea of France as an exceptional nation. For now, the changes are a matter of style. Less spending, less glamour, less Versailles. More caution, more prudence, more modest living. So what is the new normal in Hollandes France?

title: London Shows Open With Up-and-Comers
description: On the first day of the inaugural edition of London Collections: Men, as this city got used to the idea of having its very own Fashion Week for men, the look for spring 2013 was black dress socks worn with shorts. Both Lou Dalton, an up-and-comer, and the designers at Topman, the premium mens division of Topshop, styled their models in black socks, which did not exactly suggest the sort of directionality for which London designers are supposedly known. That middle-aged look for lawn-mowing has been all over Brooklyn already.

title: Transcript of Obamas Speech on Immigration Policy
description: The following is the full text of President Obamas speech on Friday from the Rose Garden.

title: Internet Unshackled, Burmese Aim Venom at Ethnic Minority
description: BANGKOK  Over the past year, Myanmars government has ended its heavy censorship, allowing citizens unfettered access to a wide variety of Web sites that had been banned during military rule. When the government first began dismantling its Internet controls in August, visits to sites like YouTube soared.

title: Romney Kicks Off Bus Tour in New Hampshire
description: STRATHAM, N.H.  Mitt Romney kicked off his bus tour in the same place he kicked off his campaign a little more than a year ago, a farm here on New Hampshires Seacoast. But while the ambitious barnstorm through small-town America was billed as an effort to introduce Mr. Romney to a new set of voters, the first event kept him solidly in his comfort zone.

title: The Characters Are Dead, but the Soundtrack Is Live
description: The Black Belly of the Tarantula is a 1971 film directed by Paolo Cavara, an over-the-top Italian giallo thriller about a murderer who slices open women, with a pop-art Roman backdrop.

title: Russia Sending Missile Systems to Shield Syria
description: MOSCOW  Russias chief arms exporter said Friday that his company was shipping advanced defensive missile systems to Syria that could be used to shoot down airplanes or sink ships if the United States or other nations try to intervene to halt the countrys spiral of violence.

title: Jerry Springer Show Is Signed Up Through Fall 2016
description: A lot is changing in daytime television, but this is not: teenage mothers, cheating spouses and sex addicts still have a forum on The Jerry Springer Show, and will for years to come.

title: President Obama on Immigration
description: President Obama spoke to reporters in the White House Rose Garden on Friday afternoon

title: How Depressives Surf the Web
description: IN what way do you spend your time online? Do you check your e-mail compulsively? Watch lots of videos? Switch frequently among multiple Internet applications  from games to file downloads to chat rooms?

title: Sandusky Judge Tells Jurors to Tune Out an Audiotape
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  Bob Costass interview with Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant football coach at Penn State who is on trial on child sexual abuse charges, received considerable attention when it was broadcast on NBC last fall. And this week it received some attention in the courtroom.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 15
description: Subjects include the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the arraignment of a police officer in the killing of Ramarley Graham and a proposed new development for the Chelsea Market.

title: 21 Years After Winning Nobel, Democracy Leader Reaches Oslo
description: OSLO  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the symbol of Burmese resistance to dictatorship, arrived in Norway on Friday to finally deliver the Nobel lecture for the peace prize she won in 1991, which she will do Saturday. But even during her years of house arrest, she said at a news conference here, she never doubted that one of her first trips abroad would be to Norway. She repeated, I never doubted that, then grinned and asked, Did you?

title: More Pre-K Seats Open for Bid, Starting Monday
Photos of The Moment | Topman Designs
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: McConnell Accuses Obama and Aides of Schemes to Curtail Free Speech
description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Friday accused President Obama, his campaign and his administration of engaging in Nixonian dirty tricks, including keeping an enemies list, inciting mob attacks on its critics and leaking confidential tax information, in a concerted effort to curtail the free speech of his opponents.

title: The Thurmond Rule
description: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell announced this week that he is imposing a blockade on President Obamas nominations to the circuit courts. The G.O.P. will likely hold off on blocking district court judges until early September.

title: In Tokyo, Grown-Up Utility From Toyota Toys
description: Toyota is showing off two diminutive concept cars at the Tokyo Toy Fair, running through June 17. The vehicles together are called Camatte, an adaptation of a Japanese word intended to signify caring for others, Toyota said, and are aimed at bringing delight to parents and children alike.

title: Pizza to Go
description: Jonathan Darsky couldnt find a suitable site to open a pizza restaurant, so he installed an oven in a truck and hit the road.

title: For Gupta, What Lies Ahead
description: Rajat K. Guptas conviction on four of six counts shows that federal prosecutors can still win an insider trading case based largely on circumstantial evidence. In the end, it appears that the jury was quite persuaded by wiretaps. For the two charges that he was acquitted on, the government did not present overheard conversations of Raj Rajaratnam describing his source of inside information.

title: Still a One-Hitter, Baseball Says
description: 5:34 p.m. | Updated R.A. Dickey will have to keep working to get a no-hitter. As expected, Major League Baseball on Friday upheld the ruling made Wednesday, when the official scorer decided that B. J. Uptons chopper to third base in the first inning was indeed a hit and not an error by David Wright, who grabbed at the ball with his bare hand but never gained control.

title: New Energy in Palm Springs
description: Lively hotels, restaurants and boutiques are lending vitality to this part of Southern California.

title: A Second Life for Discarded Fishing Nets
description: Abandoned and lost fishing gear makes up about 10 percent of the trash that collects in the worlds oceans, according to a report from the United Nations. Much of this debris is lost in storms, vandalized or simply discarded. It piles up on beaches, creates a navigational hazard for boats or settles to the bottom, where it can damage sensitive ecosystems. Discarded nets can cause a particular problem as they continue to ghost fish, trapping fish and other sea animals like turtles, seabirds and dolphins.

title: Putting the Whole Beet to Work, Including the Tops
description: I SPEND a lot of time meandering through the greenmarkets. When planning my pedestrian itinerary, I always make a deliberate detour, and not just for research, but also to pick up something for dinner.

title: It Took a Village for a Play (7 Writers and 4 Directors)
description: The title of We Play for the Gods, a slight production from the Womens Theater Project, comes from Ellen Stewart, the founder of La MaMa, who died last year. We play for the Gods, Ms. Stewart said, and in return, they play for us.

title: Daredevil Takes a Successful Walk Across a Popular Void
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario  Nik Wallenda became the first man to walk over the Niagara Gorge in 116 years Friday night  and the first ever to walk right over the falls.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs
description: If you love soft-shell crabs, why not try cooking them at home? Melissa Clark shows how.

title: Beet Salad for Summer
description: At the outdoor markets in France, most vegetable merchants customarily sell beets already cooked, as a convenience to shoppers. The beets sit in a bowl along with a big fork. Generally there are two kinds, both red, one large and round and the other more elongated. You ask for the type you want and it gets forked into a paper wrapper, ready to slice for a beet salad when you get home.

title: Digital Notes: Call Me Maybe Is an East Coast Hit, Spotify Says, but Gotye Is Tops
description: Who streams what, and where?

title: Breaking All the Rules
description: IF youre worried all this Emily Post-style rule-mongering will squeeze the life out of your wedding toast, consider jettisoning the rules entirely to follow the example of Selma and Kenny Furst. The couple, who this year will celebrate their 72nd anniversary, became YouTube sensations this spring when a spirited toast they made for their grandsons wedding was posted on awkwardfamilyphotos.com.

title: The Art of the Wedding Toast
description: MY friend was distressed. His brother was getting married this summer, and he knew he would be expected to give a toast. Not just any toast, but one that would be funny, heartfelt and memorable.

title: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton
description: Louis Vuitton was on fire for resort, playing with the notions of heat and shine. Sinewy separates in warming tones of cream and brown pleasantly melded with pops of blue and pink on dresses and jackets. Returning in less exaggerated forms from fall were oversize buttons and bell skirts, all of which paid homage to the film Indochine with Catherine Deneuve. The film, set in the the French colonial era of the 1930s to 1950s, inspired the tribal yet grand nature of the collection, which featured cutoff trousers, romantic lace blouses and waistcoats, some embellished for extra sizzle. Here, a visor secured with a silk tie rises to the occasion of a single-sleeve sequin and lace dress.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs in Balance
description: TWO things happen when you bite into a perfectly cooked soft-shell crab.

title: Herb Butter: Spread It Around
description: Herb butters are excellent, instant meal enhancers, worthwhile to have on hand.

title: Seeing an Omen on a Faded Newspaper Page
description: THIRTY years ago, Nancy LeSage and Fleur Marks were strangers with something in common. Miss LeSage, of Madison, Conn., and Miss Marks, of Princeton, N.J., saw their photos side by side on a Society News page of The New York Times on Sunday, May 2, 1982.

title: From Pie-in-the-Sky Dream to Hottest Truck in Town
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The crisis in Europe took new turns; Jamie Dimon testified about JPMorgan Chases trading loss; R. Allen Stanford was sentenced to 110 years on his Ponzi scheme conviction; and Rajat K. Gupta was found guilty in his insider trading trial.

title: 35 Years Ago, the Mets Traded Tom Seaver
description: In their 51-year existence, the Mets have had their share of happy where were you when moments: the 1969 World Series win, Robin Venturas game-ending grand slam single in 1999 and, of course, Mookie Wilsons famous dribbler up the first-base line in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series.

title: A Classic From Loewys Portfolio
description: THE Studebaker Avanti was one of those rare cars whose design seemed to arrive fully formed  and without precedent. But it arrived as the company was on its last legs.

title: From Savior to Orphan
description: A BREAKTHROUGH design introduced 50 years ago in a last-ditch attempt to salvage a gasping automaker, the Studebaker Avanti has been called the car that never dies.

title: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga Reeks of Fame
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Sports Illustrated to Cut Editorial Staff
description: Weeks before the Summer Olympics in London and the start of the National Football Leagues training camps, Sports Illustrated is cutting editorial staff through buyouts and possible layoffs.

title: Momentary Minglings, Like Encounters on La Rambla
description: The Barcelona collective known as por instantesisnt as exotic as it sounds. Led by the German-born choreographer Julia Koch and the American director Daniel Zippi, the group named itself after the phrase by moments, which seems to mirror the way its collaborators bring pedestrian encounters to fleeting life. A woman sways seductively while caressing her shoulder. A couples lips brush slowly for a kiss, then draw apart. Another woman speaks incessantly to anyone who will listen.

title: The Car That Never Dies
description: The Avanti began as a rakish grand touring car, the result of a whirlwind design program in 1961.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Superhero Story With Humor
description: The seventh volume of Empowered hits No. 3 on our paperback graphic books best-seller list this week. Created by Adam Warren and published by Dark Horse, this manga-influenced black-and-white series follows Elissa Megan Powers (a k a Empowered) as she attempts to navigate a life filled with superheroes, ninjas and self-esteem issues.

title: A Makers Beloved Designs
description: STUDEBAKER hired Raymond Loewy in 1936, who then brought in top talent like Virgil Exner from Pontiac and later, Gordon Buehrig, a designer for Auburn, Cord and Duesenburg, and the promising Robert Bourke. He established a studio in South Bend that he visited from New York every few weeks, traveling on a Pennsylvania Railroad train that his firm designed.

title: An Affordable Icon
description: IN all its forms, the Avanti still turns heads, but its value as a collectible has never equaled its stature as a design icon.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Myanmar, Malaysia and Egypt.

title: Week in Culture Pictures, June 15
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Fight Over Post Tests India Partys Mettle
description: NEW DELHI  Ordinarily, Pranab Mukherjee might be considered a shoo-in for the largely ceremonial position of president of India. The job usually goes to someone of stature, or at least someone with good political connections, and Mr. Mukherjee has both. At 76, he has spent a half century in Indian politics, often appearing on the global stage, and he is well prepared for the elder statesman role.

title: City Ballet: Vivacity Breaks Up Doldrums
description: Its fair to say that New York City Ballet has begun a renaissance. The recent season at the David H. Koch Theater kept supplying evidence of this, not least at Sundays closing performance of George Balanchines two-act Midsummer Nights Dream, led by Teresa Reichlen as Titania and, even better, with Tiler Peck in the Act II divertissement.

title: Judge Seems Reluctant to Follow CBS and Block Glass House on ABC
description: The latest effort to stop what appears to be a copycat version of a hit reality show is heading in the same direction all the others have traveled: nowhere.

title: Troubled Greek Economy Is Being Left to Fend for Itself
description: ATHENS  No matter what happens in this weekends elections, Greece is rapidly becoming an isolated economy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Wi-Fi and Amtrak: Missed Connections (June 3): Beside issues with Internet connection, theres no corporate accountability at Amtrak. Im on Amtrak regularly and often find the Wi-Fi is entirely shut off, not just spotty. When asked to fix it, conductors invariably say, Service needs to be switched on from a central office.

title: E.P.A. Casts New Soot Standard as Easily Met
description: As anticipated, the Environmental Protection Agency announced on Friday that it was proposing to update and tighten national air quality standards for fine-particle soot.Somewhat surprisingly, however, the agency said that by the time these new standards were fully in force in 2020, all but six counties in the United States would be in compliance with them as a result of steps taken to abide by other tightened rules.

title: Another Little VW
description: The Up, a cute-as-a-Bug Volkswagen, is perfect for the parking-starved city, but wont be trolling for spaces in America. Its not coming here.

title: Just Passing Through, Impressively
description: YOU might assume, on the petite heels of the Mini Cooper, that car companies would be amassing an army of Lilliputian cars to sell here. But consider the Volkswagen Up, AWOL from our shores.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the arraignment of a police officer in the killing of Ramarley Graham and a proposed development for the Chelsea Market.

title: A Conflicted Jury Finds Rajat Gupta Guilty
description: The jury for the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta took only two days to reach its verdict. But the process was not easy, with several jurors saying they felt conflicted.

title: Picking The Best Target-Date Mutual Fund
description: Before we get to the business of target-date fund selection, which is the subject of this weekends Your Money column, a quick word on the basic merits of target-date mutual funds.

title: Celebrating Bloomsday, With James Joyce (and Other Irish Writers)
description: Readers picked up on the not-so-subtle nod to James Joyces Ulysses at the end of my June Drink column. Hey, it was hard to resist: for those who love the book, any walk around Dublin in some way evokes the company of Leopold Bloom, Stephen Dedalus and others. It seems you can never get far without passing a landmark that appears in the novel.

title: Players Who Are a Study in Contrasts
description: It was an Elliott Carter kind of week in New York, and few would complain. On June 8 Mr. Carter, still astonishingly productive at 103, was present for the premiere of his latest work, Two Controversies and a Conversation, in Contact!, the New York Philharmonics new-music series.

title: The Midwife as Status Symbol
description: BESIDES being impossibly gorgeous mothers, what else do Christy Turlington, Karolina Kurkova and Gisele Bndchen have in common?

title: Revisiting a Passion of the Past
description: If briefly during the late 1960s the symphonies of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen seemed to be catching on with American audiences, this was almost entirely because of the advocacy of Leonard Bernstein. In addition to conducting the works prominently, Bernstein recorded three of Nielsens six symphonies, as well as the flute and clarinet concertos, with the New York Philharmonic.

title: Wealth Destruction
description: I havent weighed in on the Survey of Consumer Finances, which shows a sharp decline in net worth and real income between 2007 and 2010. I guess the basic response should be Well, duh  thats what happens when you have a massive housing bust and a severe economic slump.

description: More Photographs

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Great Beards and Russian Robots
description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

title: Crony Keynesianism
description: George Osborne, the architect of Britains austerity policies, has just done an about face (without, of course, admitting it). Jonathan Portes has the goods: he points out that the assumptions under which the UK governments new policy of subsidizing private investment  including infrastructure investment!  through loan guarantees makes sense are exactly the same assumptions under which debt-financed government spending on, say, infrastructure makes sense.

title: Target-Date Funds Not Equally Safe
description: Lets say youre 63 years old and trying to figure out how to invest the money youve managed to put aside over the years.

title: This Romeo Doesnt Fall Short at Love
description: Its hard to believe now, but there was a time, 5 to 10 years ago, when one of the most serious questions in the ballet world was whether Herman Cornejo could play Romeo.

title: Smith Street, Brooklyn
description: Scenes from Smith Street, including a birthday party at Carroll Park, a sidewalk sale, Momofuku Milk Bar and the Gowanus Yacht Club.

title: Formerly Captive Israeli Soldier Now a Sports Columnist
description: JERUSALEM  In his most expansive public comments since he was released eight months ago, Gilad Shalit revealed how his love for sports had kept him going through five years of captivity in Gaza, while providing some personal connection with his captors from the Islamic militant group Hamas.

title: What Do DNA, Insects and Bullets Have in Common?
description: The phrase DNA evidence is so common in real-life cases and on police procedurals these days that its easy to forget how relatively new it is to the lexicon. The premiere of Forensic Firsts, Sunday on the Smithsonian Channel, takes us back to that eureka moment in the 1980s when genetic science met police work.

title: Friday Night Music: Save Yourself
description: Some people have recommended for months that I listen to Sharon Van Etten, and Ive resisted  basically, did I want to listen to another confessional singer-songwriter?

title: Power Is Always in Vogue
description: WHEN Anna Wintour was in Paris for Fashion Week in March, there was one topic the Vogue editor couldnt stop talking about. And it had nothing to do with the winter collections.

title: Block by Block | Smith Street, Carroll Gardens
description: Carroll Gardens is the quiet Brooklyn neighborhood that lies between Red Hook and Gowanus and is known for its Italianate brownstones with spacious front yards.

title: A Garden? Chess? PTAs Face Choices About How to Spend Parent Money
Declaration of Independence
description: LAST January, Amy Chua got an unexpected e-mail just before an excerpt from her provocative child-rearing manual, Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, appeared in The Wall Street Journal. It was from Wendi Murdoch, the wife of Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The Journal.

title: Smile! Its Time for a Guilty Plunge Into Summer TV
description: Theres a surprising amount of television this summer that threatens to be good for you: The Newsroom on HBO. Michael Woods Story of England on PBS. N.Y. Med on ABC. Political Animals on USA. You might as well still be in school.

title: The Costs of Pre-K
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | Impressions
description: One of the prettiest sights is the New York Botanical Garden dinner dance in the Bronx.

title: A Leader in Saving Rivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Group of 20 to Urge Quicker Action in Europe
description: WASHINGTON  The rest of the world has a message for Europe, whose intensifying debt crisis will dominate the agenda at the Group of 20 summit meeting next week in Mexico: Tell us how you will end this.

title: Remembering a Dad, and the Little Things
description: My friend Barry just lost a three-year battle with a rare form of lung cancer, the kind you can get even if youve never smoked. My grandmother used to say that every persons life is a novel waiting to be written. In their eulogies, Barrys children told his story, and the beauty of it was in all the things I didnt know about Barry, the little things.

title: Reviewing the Volkswagen Up
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Up, an impressive supermini that began colonizing the urban cores of Europe this year.

title: The Flowers of Carroll Gardens
description: The neighborhood is known for its Italianate brownstones with spacious front yards, a civilized buffer between home and sidewalk. These are planted in various styles  from garden-club meticulous to near-jungle  but there are recurring plants and flowers, creating a floral theme.

title: The Health Care and Broccoli Analogy
description: To the Editor:

title: First Major Talent Exit After Facebook I.P.O.
description: Bret Taylor, Facebooks chief technology officer, announced Friday afternoon he was leaving the company to start his own. It was the first major exit of a Facebook executive since its public offering nearly a month ago and signals a recurrent challenge in Silicon Valley: How to retain talent after the company goes public and employee shareholders make their millions.

title: Turn Left at the Roses
description: ON a recent Sunday morning, at the Carroll Gardens Greenmarket in Brooklyn, the pickle guy from Divine Brine in Suffolk County was cutting up some samples, and the bird man from Dipaola Turkeys, out of New Jersey, was grilling bite-size pieces of turkey burger. More than a few fathers with infants strapped to their chests had wandered over from Carroll Park, just across the street, while groups of friends in knee-skimming skirts bought peonies and baby bok choy from the stalls that start at the corner of Smith Street.

title: For Sale: Avantis and Studebakers. Must Have Good References.
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, I write about the enduring appeal of the Avanti, created by Studebaker 50 years ago. I also offer an update on the most recent Avanti maker, who is serving time for timeshare fraud and whose cars are being offered in a court-ordered sale.

title: At Camp Sweden, the Party Goes On Even After England Ends the Dream
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The Caravan of Love had traveled more than 800 miles, hoping not to get sideswiped so soon by heartbreak.

title: The Founding Myth of a Master Pizzaiolos Food Truck
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In Sundays Automobiles section, I write about the Del Popolo pizza truck and how it came to be a foodie phenomenon in the Bay Area. From the beginning, the truck project was in seasoned hands.

title: Microsoft and Samsung Try Out Apples Secret Sauce
description: There is something different about Microsofts event scheduled for Monday in Los Angeles, but also something very familiar. The secrecy surrounding this particular product introduction feels a lot like Apples.

title: A History of Making Protest Messages Heard, Silently
description: They marched down Fifth Avenue on that summer Saturday without saying a word. They chanted no chants, sang no protest songs. The only sounds were the disconcertingly mournful thuds of muffled drums  and, of course, the marchers footsteps on the hot pavement.

title: Prescription for Kids in Trouble
description: From the first moments of Recall, as a parent drones on about reality TV while an adolescent scrubs ineffectually at a giant bloodstain on the carpet, we are firmly in the realm of arched-eyebrow mayhem that has proved rewarding for the likes of Quentin Tarantino and Martin McDonagh.

title: Ratings for Finals Remain High
description: The Oklahoma City Thunder and Miami Heat have split the first two games of the N.B.A. finals  exciting matchups that have so far attracted more viewers than any finals since ESPN and ABCs current deal with the league began in 2002-03, according to Nielsen.

title: Creating Rules for Natural Gas Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: V-Green, an Online Bridge Magazine
description: Didier Lvy, a Frenchman who has retired to Guadeloupe, has developed some terrific software that easily puts bridge articles into an interactive form. You can play numerous deals at vubridge.com in a more realistic way than when reading about bridge in a newspaper, magazine or book.

title: Egyptian Activists Debate How Not to Vote
description: CAIRO  As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, many of the Internet activists who helped drive Egypts 2011 revolution are dismayed about the choice offered by this weekends presidential runoff between two conservatives. In meetings with bloggers in Cairo all this week, conversations returned again and again to how best to respond to a deeply unpalatable choice: voting for Ahmed Shafik, Hosni Mubaraks last prime minister, or Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that was Mr. Mubaraks main opposition but has managed to alienate many former allies from last years protest movement.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An Amityville modern, a Fairfield colonial and West Windsor retreat.

title: Lockheed Is Replacing Strikers at Fighter Plane Plant
description: Lockheed Martin said Friday that it had hired 300 temporary workers to replace striking union employees at its fighter plane plant in Fort Worth and could hire hundreds more.

title: Obama Acknowledges U.S. Is Fighting Groups Tied to Al Qaeda in Somalia and Yemen

title: Dance Position No. 6: Rest

(The troupe, based in Brooklyn, just got back from its first visit to China.) The peripatetic life sets limits: Mr. Morris has no pets or house plants  I would have to have a python and a cactus, he said  and he has trained himself to drink his coffee black so he does not have to go out for milk after a long trip.  JOHN LELAND

title: China: Tibetan Dies in Protest Fire
description: A Tibetan herder in Chinas northwest Qinghai Province died Friday after setting himself on fire to protest government policies in the region, according to exile groups and Radio Free Asia. The herder, Tamdin Thar, thought to be in his early 60s, set himself on fire in Markethang, in the Huangnan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, said the group Free Tibet. Since 2009, at least 39 Tibetans have set themselves on fire. Of those, 30 have died, according to the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group in Washington. If the human rights situation doesnt improve, such tragic incidents will keep happening, said Tsering Woeser, a Tibetan writer in Beijing. Many Tibetans think the pain of self-immolation is nothing compared to the pain of living without religious freedom.

title: Louisiana: Dining Critic Has a Job, Paper Says
description: Three days after it was reported that Brett Anderson, the well-regarded restaurant critic for The Times-Picayune in New Orleans, was among about 200 employees being laid off, the paper said Friday that it had offered Mr. Anderson a position writing about restaurants and dining. Mr. Anderson, 41, is headed to Harvard University in the fall on a journalism fellowship that he landed before the layoffs took place. We told Brett then that he would have a job with us when the fellowship ended, Jim Amoss, the papers editor, said in a report on the newspapers Web site. We should have communicated that this week when we announced the changes. Mr. Anderson had said earlier that he was told the fellowship was the reason for his dismissal. Mr. Anderson said that he did not have to make a decision about the job until his fellowship nears its end in 2013. I dont know yet, he said. Im going to kick that can down the road a ways as to whether or not Ill take it.

The courts mandate is to investigate large-scale and systematic atrocities. It is recognized by 121 countries. Ms. Bensouda, left, who has been deputy prosecutor for the past eight years, said that she intended to expand investigations of large-scale sexual abuse and crimes involving children in conflicts.

These markers are much bigger than the players who, technically, accomplished them.

Game 2, won by the Heat, 100-96, was seen by an average of 16.7 million viewers on ABC, 7 percent better than the comparable broadcast last year between the Heat and the Dallas Mavericks. Through two games, the average viewership of 16.4 million is also up 7 percent.  Tina Charles had 20 points and 8 rebounds to lead the host Connecticut Sun to a 97-55 victory over the Liberty. Connecticut led by 61-27 at halftime, setting the league record for the largest lead at the break. Essence Carson scored 14 points for New York (3-7). (AP)

title: After Niagara Falls Tightrope Walk, Hope for a Boost in Tourism
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario  After 116 years, a man on a wire conquered the Niagara Gorge again.

title: Bombs in Pakistan Kill at Least 32
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two bombings killed at least 32 people on Saturday in the Khyber tribal region, according to a senior regional administration official and The Associated Press.

title: Death Throes
description: My colleague David Brooks tells us that Republicans see the economic crisis as showing that the welfare state is in its death throes. And its true  that is what they think, or claim to think.

title: Romney Accidentally Puts Obama in Governors Office, but Goes With the Idea
description: WEATHERLY, Pa.  At an early morning stop on Saturday here in Weatherly  a town in a county in which President Obama barely eked out a victory four years ago  Mitt Romney had some backhanded advice for the president.

title: Goodbye, Bell Bottoms
description: I GREW up in West Palm Beach, Fla. My dad took me hunting, trapping and fishing when I was a kid. Years later, when I was working for I.B.M. in the Midwest, a customer invited me to go pheasant hunting in South Dakota. I havent missed a season there in 20 years.

title: Disputing Whether a Treasure Needs a Name Upgrade
description: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo.  In 1906, a vagabond with an eye for beauty named John Otto fell in love with the unscarred land out here. After seeing the sandstone spires and hypnotic canyons that rise above this town, he made a decision: Im going to stay and build trails and promote this place, he wrote, because it should be a national park.

title: For Palmer, One That Got Away
description: Arnold Palmer couldnt miss winning the 1962 United States Open. Two months earlier he had won the Masters for the third time in five years. He had won the 1960 Open with a final-round 65 and also the 1961 British Open. More popular than ever at age 32, the charismatic commander of Arnies Army made the cover of Newsweek with the caption Arnold Palmer: Perfection Under Pressure. In the cherrywood-paneled basement of his Latrobe, Pa., home a coffee table was inlaid with 24 gold medals, each representing a tournament he had won. But one space was empty.

title: Game Loses One of Its Voices
description: Last Sunday morning, at the Phoenix Communications office in South Hackensack, N.J., Steve Insler spotted Warner Fusselle with a stack of newspapers, pens and a pair of scissors.

title: One Night Only: Syria in Revolt, on a Beirut Stage
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian playwright Mohammad al-Attar considers the common wisdom about the uprising in his country  the fear is gone  somewhat overstated.

title: Amid Tight Security and Low Expectations, Egypt Votes Again
description: CAIRO  As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, voters went to the polls in Egypt on Saturday, starting two days of voting in the countrys presidential runoff election, which pits ousted President Hosni Mubaraks former prime minister against an Islamist candidate from the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Journalist Is Killed in Bangladesh
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh (AP)  A journalist hacked to death by unidentified assailants was probably killed because of his reporting on the illegal drug trade in southwestern Bangladesh, the police said Saturday.

description: When youre a dad, life sometimes tosses miracles. You have to be enough of a child to catch them.

title: In Long-Overdue Speech, Dissident Says Nobel Opened Her Heart
description: OSLO  When she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, while under house arrest in Myanmar, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi said Saturday, she realized that the Burmese were not going to be forgotten.

description: June 15, 2012 - Why you should be taking a break right now.

description: To the Editor:

title: As Singapore Loosens Its Grip, Residents Lose Fear to Challenge Authority
description: SINGAPORE  Those accustomed to thinking of this booming city-state as a bastion of apolitical strivers and shopaholics might be stunned by the burst of civic activism sweeping this crowded flyspeck of an island.

title: Variety: A Visual Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  I must confess that I found todays acrostic fairly easy because I had already read the book from which todays quote was taken. That didnt make the puzzle any less entertaining; on the contrary, one of the reasons I had read the book is because the author, Dr. Temple Grandin, is someone I greatly admire.

title: Otherworldly Pitch Meets Its Jedi Master
description: In the far corner of the Mets clubhouse at Citi Field, propped against the wall near the showers, is a fans painting of R. A. Dickey as an alien. On the shelf in Dickeys locker, next to his usual passel of hardbacks, is a stuffed Yoda, from Star Wars, knitted for him by a fan.

title: Why Punish the Savers?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Car Bombs Target Shiites in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  A security clampdown aimed at protecting Shiite pilgrims failed to prevent a new round of carnage on Saturday as two car bombings in Baghdad killed more than 30 at the end of a weeklong celebration.

title: In Moscow, Iran to Face Critical Choice in the Latest Round of Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The calendar will loom large over the next round of Iran nuclear talks.

title: Caution, Please: The Bosss Office Is a No-Spin Zone
description: This interview with  Shawn H. Wilson, president of Ushers New Look Foundation, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: One Crowd Rumbles; the Other Slumbers
description: A few short years ago, Oklahoma City was primarily known in basketball circles as the place where the former Knicks player John Starks had bagged groceries on his way to the N.B.A. Now, the city has a new calling card: an aural mayhem that its Thunder fans unleash on a nightly basis.

title: Whatever Greek Voters Decide, the Euro Looks Likely to Suffer
description: IT will be a late Sunday night for financial pros like Markus Krygier. In New York, London, Tokyo and beyond, nearly everyone is focused on one thing right now: Greece. To be precise, they are focused on a Grexit  the possibility of the countrys eventual exit from the euro. For many, the prospect has moved from if to when.

title: As Greeks Head to Polls Again, a Fear That No One Will Win
description: ATHENS  Greeks head to the polls on Sunday for the second time in two months with a pervasive sense of dread that any government that comes to power will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens the countrys future  and the financial stability of Europe itself.
