title: A Contrarian Case for Investing in Europe
description: BANK bailouts, political upheavals, spiking bond yields and falling stock markets: the troubling headlines from Europe just keep on coming.

title: Lynn Having a Breakout Year for the Cardinals
description: In all the pitching excitement last Wednesday, when the Giants Matt Cain fired a perfect game and the Mets R. A. Dickey tossed a one-hitter, it was easy to miss Lance Lynn of the St. Louis Cardinals. Lynn struck out 12 White Sox while allowing three hits in seven and a third shutout innings, matching Dickey for the National League lead in victories, with 10.

title: European Leaders to Present Plan to Quell the Crisis Quickly
description: The head of the European Central Bank and other euro zone leaders worked on Saturday on a grand vision for the euro zone meant to reassure investors and allies that flaws in the currency union will be addressed quickly.

title: Broken Trust Takes Time to Mend
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA caused a stir recently when he said that the private sector is doing fine and pinned many of the nations economic troubles on a decline in public-sector employment. He cited some interesting numbers, but he didnt draw the right lesson  namely, that America is witnessing a collapse of trust in politics, including the shaping of its broad economic policy.

title: With Every Shot, Olympic Club Tests the Best
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It is all Rorys fault.

title: The Surprising Mr. Smith, and Other Party Notes
description: One of the obvious names missing from the mens catwalking calendar in London this weekend is Paul Smith, one of the most recognizable names in British fashion for more than 40 years. The reason he is not showing his collection here, however, is simple. Since 1977, he has presented his mens wear in Paris, where he has a showroom with hundreds of employees, so it was too big a job to move it all back to London.

title: Meet Your Cousin, the First Lady: A Family Story, Long Hidden
description: REX, Ga.  Joan Tribble held tightly to her cane as she ventured into the overgrown cemetery where her people were buried. There lay the pioneers who once populated north Georgias rugged frontier, where striving white men planted corn and cotton, fought for the Confederacy and owned slaves.

title: Miracles Happening
description: In a video posted on Community Education Centers Web site, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey praises the work of one of the companys halfway houses at its tenth anniversary celebration.

title: A Source of Laughter
description: Viviana Tulli dives into a bush in front of her home in Garfield, N.J., as her sister records it. The video was posted on YouTube.

title: Governor Christie and John J. Clancy
description: Governor Christie praises John J. Clancy, the founder of Community Education Centers. Mr. Clancy was one of the first entrepreneurs to realize that halfway houses could be big business.

title: Halfway House Alumni
description: Former inmates of Delaney Hall share their experiences. Its just been an amazing journey, one man said.

title: Tracking Down Halfway House Fugitives
description: Thaddeus B. Caldwell spent four years hunting escapees. He retired from state corrections in 2009 and worked for Community Education, but resigned after less than a year.

title: Unlocked: Coming Monday
description: Reports of gangs flourishing inside a halfway house.

title: Honey, the Baby Is Coming; Quick, Call the Photographer
description: Lynsey Stone does not set foot in the shower without placing her cellphone on a nearby ledge, lest she miss an urgent text from a woman in labor. She schedules vacations 10 months in advance to ensure they do not conflict with due dates, and on family outings she and her husband leave their Granbury, Tex., home in separate cars, in case she needs to race to the hospital.

title: Unlocked: Coming Tuesday
description: A murder inside a halfway house.

title: Formula One Track, Nearing First Race, Gets Wary Embrace From Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Less than 15 miles from the state capitol, and just down the road from Wild Bubbas Wild Game Grill, Austins next big thing is rising from a sprawling patch of rock, clay and shrubs.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: Jonathan Saunders Mens
description: London

title: 30 Seconds With Johnny Bench
description: Johnny Bench played his way into the Hall of Fame with power hitting and defense during a 17-year-career as a catcher with the Cincinnati Reds. In addition to his 389 home runs and 1,376 runs batted in, Bench won 10 Gold Glove awards and led the National League three times in percentage of runners caught stealing. He had a .990 fielding percentage as a catcher.

title: With Casino Revenues, Tribes Push to Preserve Languages, and Cultures
description: COARSEGOLD, Calif.  Inside a classroom of some 20 adults and children studying the language of their tribe, a university linguist pointed out that Chukchansi has no r sound and that two consonants never follow each other. The comments seemed to stir forgotten childhood memories in Holly Wyatt, 69, the only fluent speaker present, who was serving as a living reference book.

title: Two Fathers, Two Sons, Two Ball Games
description: When New Yort Times writer (and Motherlode contributor) Matt Richtel was 10, his father took him to the watch the Yankees in the World Series. It was an impulsive trip, one they extended to watch a rained-out game play the next day.

title: Unlocked, Part 1
description: A 10-month investigation reveals that New Jerseys privatized halfway houses have become a largely unregulated shadow correction system.

title: China Closes Window on Economic Debate, Protecting Dominance of State
description: BEIJING  As China heads toward a once-a-decade change of its top leadership, its vaunted embrace a generation ago of markets and economic openness  which catapulted the country from isolated poverty to its place as a global export powerhouse  is also at a turning point.

title: As Escapees Stream Out, a Penal Business Thrives
description: After serving more than a year behind bars in New Jersey for assaulting a former girlfriend, David Goodell was transferred in 2010 to a sprawling halfway house in Newark. One night, Mr. Goodell escaped, but no one in authority paid much notice. He headed straight for the suburbs, for another young woman who had spurned him, and he killed her, the police said.

title: Be Prepared for an Extra-Long Off-Season in the N.H.L.
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs and the coronation of the Los Angeles Kings may well be the last N.H.L. action hockey fans will see for some time  perhaps until Christmas.

title: South Africa Debates Law to Support Tribal Courts
description: CANDU, South Africa  The courts verdict was swift and sure: Nomvulo Ludonga was guilty as charged. To atone for her offense, Ms. Ludonga, a widowed schoolteacher, had to give the court a live sheep, 50 liters of maize beer, two cases of regular beer, two bottles of brandy and two bottles of juice.

title: The Catcher: Toughest Job on the Diamond
description: The rigors of being a catcher in the major leagues.

title: Behind the Plate
description: Russell Martin on the demands of being a catcher for the New York Yankees.

title: Yes, Wall Street Can Reach Out
description: WITH unemployment just above 8 percent, its clear that finding a job is tough for many Americans. But for war veterans, particularly disabled ones, its even tougher. Nearly one of every three young male veterans was out of work last year.

title: Defamation Suit Puts New Law to the Test
description: In September 2010, two Democratic candidates for the State Board of Education posted a YouTube video satirizing the work of the boards right-wing extremist members in revising Texas curriculum.

title: C.E.O. Pay Is Rising Despite the Din
description: YOU call this a revolution?

title: Two Different Parties, Two Very Different Moods
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Mapping, and Sharing, the Consumer Genome
description: IT knows who you are. It knows where you live. It knows what you do.

title: Band of Brothers Pulls Strings for Cruz Campaign
description: The establishment nearly always wins in Texas politics, so Jason Johnson, a longtime Republican consultant, said he thought it would be next to impossible to stop a powerful and wealthy lieutenant governor who would never run out of money or friends.

title: Iranian Nuclear Progress
description: The uranium enrichment process seeks to raise levels of U-235, a rare isotope used to fuel bombs and reactors.

title: One Hard Way to Play Ball
description: It was a typical moment in an ordinary game on an average day for a major league catcher. This one happened to be May 30 in Anaheim, but it could have been August in Kansas City or March in Tampa.

title: Plumbers in the Outfield: Meet the All-Watergate Team
description: Richard M. Nixon was a baseball fan whose presidency was wrecked by the Watergate break-in, which happened 40 years ago Sunday. How do you properly commemorate the seismic political scandal of the 1970s while recognizing Nixon for rooting for the Washington Senators and witnessing Dave Righettis no-hitter from George Steinbrenners private box at Yankee Stadium? With an All-Watergate team.

title: Romney Paints Himself as the Anti-Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Speaking by video from Pennsylvania to a crowd gathered at the Faith and Freedom Coalition conference here on Saturday, Mitt Romney presented himself as the antithesis of President Obama and his policies.

title: Niagara Falls Tightrope Walk Is a Ratings Bonanza for ABC
description: The live telecast of a tightrope walk over Niagara Falls on Friday night did exactly what ABC hoped: it lifted the network to a first-place finish for the night and provided evidence that theres an audience out there hungry for big television stunts.

title: Changing Locations for Lunch
description: QUAKERTOWN, Pa.  It was hoagie interruptus for Mitt Romney on Saturday afternoon in this small town north of Philadelphia.

title: Its Not the Years, Its the Miles
description: The first two games of the 2012 N.B.A. finals played out like repeats of the same horse race. The Miami Heat ran to an early lead, looking nearly invincible, then the Oklahoma City Thunder stormed from behind.

title: Reagan and Inflation
description: Hmm. I thought I might respond to something that has been coming up in comments and emails recently. Ive been writing about how macroeconomic reality under Ronald Reagan didnt actually match the myth, and many people are inevitably upset. And one of the things they tend to bring up is the hoary old myth that the 80s success in taming inflation was somehow a terrible shock and surprise to Keynesians, who had no explanation.

title: Egyptians Head to the Polls
description: Egyptians lined up Saturday to pick the first president since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, choosing between a stalwart of the old secular autocracy and a veteran of its Islamist opposition.

title: Michelle Obamas Ancestors
description: The first ladys family tree includes pioneers who once populated north Georgias rugged frontier, fought for the Confederacy and owned slaves.

title: The First Family, Redefined
description: Michelle Obamas ancestry links her to a white woman named Sherry George through the painful legacy of slavery.

title: Romney Horse Wins Spot on Olympic Dressage Team
description: GLADSTONE, N.J.  Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, who plan to attend the opening of the Olympic Games in London this summer, now have a personal rooting interest in the event.

title: Too Small? An Astro Responds to Doubts in a Big Way
description: The first time he saw Jose Altuve, in the summer of 2006, Omar Lopez liked almost everything. Altuve was 16 years old and ripped line drives from gap to gap. He showed good range and hands at second base. He always hustled. To Lopez, a scout and minor league manager for the Houston Astros, there was only one problem: Altuve was very, very small.

title: Journey to the Center of the Video Game Universe
description: The annual Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, attracted tens of thousands of video game aficionados at the Los Angeles Convention Center this month.

title: Before and After Title IX: Women in Sports
description: Its hard to exaggerate the far-reaching effect of Title IX on American society. Here are a few of the landmarks along the timeline of women in sports, before and after the passage of the law.

title: F1 on Pause for 24 Hours  of Le Mans
description: It is rare for the worlds greatest endurance automobile race to not take place during a Formula One Grand Prix weekend. But that is what is happening this weekend, as the 24 Hours of Le Mans starts at 3 p.m. in France Saturday and ends at 3 p.m. Sunday. A lot of Formula One media, fans and other people within the series will be watching the race closely in a way they usually cannot do. And it will be a race very much worth watching, from many points of view  some even relevant to Formula One.

title: This Week at Film Forum
description: The Terrible Elbows (1965, Georges Millefeux) Determined to improve his station, Claude LeFevre  a heavy-lidded pickpocket from the wrong side of the tracks  hatches a reckless plot to seize the tracks and move them 200 yards to the right. While hurrying across the Pont Neuf, he meets Lulu, an enchanting schoolgirl of 37, when her head gets stuck between the spokes of his bicycle wheel. They quickly become lovers  then rivals, then acquaintances, then paramedics, then lovers once again  in this New Wave romance that dispenses with traditional notions of theme and structure in order to set the world record for jump-cuts.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Schools for Rich and Poor
description: Readers discuss how to reduce educational inequities.

title: First Theater, Then Facebook
description: THE 300th birthday of Jean-Jacques Rousseau falls next week, and it is only proper to wish him a happy one. He had a few choice words to offer on the theme of happiness  the sort associated not with fleeting social pleasures but with nothing external to ourselves, nothing if not ourselves and our own existence.

title: National Secrets and National Security
description: ON May 29, a New York Times article depicted President Obama as deciding case by case on secret drone-strike assassinations, personally poring over photos of prospective targets.

title: Capt. Mike Carriker
description: Capt. Mike Carriker, a chief test pilot for Boeing, was involved in ensuring the safety of the most commonly used commercial airplanes that will carry travelers this summer. A former Navy pilot who flew A-7E and F-18 combat jets, Captain Carriker has logged more than 8,000 flight hours in more than 130 airplanes.

title: The Strange Career of Juan Crow
description: THE depth of my alienation from home hit me last January, when Alabama shut out Louisiana State for the college football championship. Even in the familiar afterglow of Bamas second title in three years, I had to ask myself, what right did my state have to brag, about anything?

title: Thoughts on Fathers and Families
description: A FEW years ago, while I was preparing to write a memoir about my father, I spent time looking through old photographs. One in particular, which I hadnt seen in years, caught my attention. Its not a typical family portrait. But by mid-20th-century Americas stingy definition, we werent a typical family.

title: Reform, in the Name of the Father
description: Abuja, Nigeria

title: Summonses Often Issued, Mostly Tossed
description: Of New York Citys summonses in 2011, most were dismissed or thrown out.

title: Inside the Warped World of Summons Court
description: Step into the dingy hallways of New York City summons court in Lower Manhattan and you are instantly struck by the racialized nature of this system. New York is a multiracial city, but judging from the faces in cramped courtrooms, one would think that whites scarcely ever commit the petty offenses that lead to the more than 500,000 summonses issued in the city every year.

title: Stronger Medicine for What Ails Horse Racing
description: Regulators in Kentucky, the heart of the horse breeding industry, have taken a significant step against the widespread doping that is putting horses lives and the sports credibility at risk at racetracks across the nation. A diuretic drug routinely used on race days to shed water weight and boost horses performance will be banned under an overdue regulation adopted last week by the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission.

title: The Children Deserve Justice
description: There has been no shortage of child sex abuse scandals during the legislative session that is going into its final week in Albany  the Penn State case and the cover-up trial of Msgr. William Lynn in Pennsylvania and, closer to home, the abuse allegations at Syracuse University and the private Horace Mann School in New York. That makes it all the worse that lawmakers have done little to fix New Yorks weak laws for protecting children from sexual predators and providing victims with justice.

title: Energy Etch A Sketch
description: As governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney endorsed an aggressive program to reduce the states greenhouse gas emissions, pushed to close old coal-fired power plants and embraced wind and solar power. Then came his bids for the Republican presidential nomination, first in 2008 and now in 2012. On climate change as on other issues, he has transformed himself, bit by reactionary bit.

title: Fair Use, Art, Swiss Cheese and Me
description: NONE of the thoughts that occurred to me on that tranquil afternoon when a slice of Swiss cheese was deposited on my face were so exotic as to include the notion that, 15 years later, I would listen to judges debate whether I should be allowed to remove the cheese and set it on fire.

title: First Tahrir Square, Then the Classroom
description: Istanbul

title: Moral Dystopia
description: EVERYONE is good, until were tested.

title: Buddhists Delight
description: WHY was I in a tent in northern Vermont? Much less a tent in the woods at a Buddhist meditation center, reading Sakyong Miphams Turning the Mind Into an Ally by the light from my smartphone?

title: Sympathy for the Radical Left
description: IT is difficult to envision an American parallel to Syriza, the far-left political coalition that has a chance to throw Europe into further turmoil with a victory in this weekends Greek elections. But imagine a movement that combines elements from Occupy Wall Street and Ralph Naders 2000 presidential campaign, and you have a sense of where Greeces leading opposition party would fit in the American political spectrum.

title: 2012s Financial Free-for-All
description: FRIENDSHIP brings such blessings. And such bargains! Only because of our closeness was President Obama willing to drop his asking price and offer me a picture and a moment with him on the cheap. At least thats what my invitation to a fund-raiser last Thursday night said.

title: Pinched and Griping in Iran
description: TEHRAN

This is the Persian-language translation of a New York Times Op-Ed column by Nicholas D. Kristof. If you cannot view the Persian, you might need to adjust the settings on your Web browser or on your computers operating system.

title: Female Athletes, Thank Nixon
description: POOR Richard Milhous Nixon. Loathed by the left and having left no estate for the right, Nixons stock sells cheap these days and still finds no takers.

title: Readers Comment on Iran Sanctions
description: My Sunday column, based on my road trip across Iran, looks at economic sanctions there. Bottom line is that they are working pretty much as Washington wants them to: they are inflicting real pain, often on ordinary citizens, in ways that inflame discontent with the system.

title: Playable
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad that is worth reading in tomorrows (Mondays) puzzle that says: When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading from left to right and top to bottom, will reveal who wrote the seven songs in the theme.

title: Pettitte Goes 7, but the Yankees Take Twice That to Win
description: WASHINGTON  Oh, the lengths the Yankees must go just to win a game without a home run.

title: Stage Collapses Before Toronto Radiohead Concert
description: A massive rooflike structure collapsed onto a temporary stage for a Radiohead concert in Toronto on Saturday afternoon, hours before the band was supposed to go on, killing a stagehand and injuring at least three other workers, CNN and the CBC reported.

title: Wambach Stunner Helps U.S. Women Beat Sweden
description: The United States womens national team began a two-game trip to Sweden on Saturday with a 3-1 victory over the host country. Alex Morgan scored in the first half and Tobin Heath in the second, but the goal of the day  and that includes the Euro 2012 action  was the 35-yard, first-touch half-volley scored by Abby Wambach in the eighth minute.

title: How to Beat the Heat Without Having to Go Too Far
description: This time last year was the beginning of a record-busting heat wave that gripped Texas, with several cities experiencing 50-plus consecutive days of 100-degree-plus temperatures and an average 2011 summer temperature of 86.7 degrees. The rains this spring have cooled things off, but the first day of summer is approaching, and with it expect above-average temperatures, says John Nielsen-Gammon, the states climatologist. While some people flee the oppressive heat and vacation in cooler climates in the North, there are ways to stay in state and keep cool.

title: Eugene Selznick, Beach Volleyball Pioneer, Dies at 82
description: Eugene Selznick, a celebrated volleyball innovator who helped raise American players game to international caliber in the 1960s, and whose shrewdness in drafting Wilt Chamberlain for a 1970s exhibition of beach volleyball helped make Californians beach-party game an Olympic sport, died on June 11 in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: 4 Climbers Presumed Dead in Mt. McKinley Avalanche
description: Four Japanese climbers are presumed dead days after an avalanche consumed a stretch of Mount McKinley where they had begun their descent.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 17
description: As the presidential race heats up, Mitt Romney will appear on his first Sunday show  other than Fox News  to discuss the things both he and President Obama said last week on the campaign trail. David Plouffe, Mr. Obamas senior adviser, will make the network rounds as well, defending the presidents words on the economy and promoting his new policy shift to cease deportations for some young illegal immigrants.

title: Mickelson, With Plenty to Celebrate, Is Hoping for One More Reason
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The United States Open falls on Fathers Day weekend, a quirk in the calendar thats seen as serendipitous since fathers and sons often treat golf as a bonding exercise. A dozen times in Phil Mickelsons playing career the tournament has fallen on his birthday, a scheduling oddity that is beginning to feel more like a barb than a bonus for Mickelson, whose struggles continued on Saturday at the event he most wants to win.

title: Schwartzel Pushes Through Pain
description: The South African Charl Schwartzel grimaced after almost every swing on the practice range on Saturday at the United States Open. A few times, he clutched his stomach. Somehow, he kept going. Schwartzel, the 2011 Masters champion, was three over par in the first 36 holes of the United State Open despite playing with an abdominal tear.

title: Woman, 88, Is Killed in Bronx Apartment
description: Neighbors at the Pelham Parkway Houses in the Bronx knew Evelyn Shapiro as a well-dressed, agreeable woman who, even well into her 80s, remained independent and active, still driving and doing her own grocery shopping.

title: Greens Slow as Tournament Goes On
description: Several players early in Saturdays third round remarked how much slower the greens at the Olympic Club were compared to the first two rounds. Customarily, the greens at the United States Open get quicker as they dry out.

title: For Many Immigrants, Policy Offers Joy and Relief
description: LOS ANGELES  Ana Sochitl graduated from the University of California, Los Angeles, on Saturday, with a degree in sociology. But until Friday, she had worried that even after she threw her cap into the air, she would be stuck at her job at a taco shop, the price of having immigrated here illegally at age 4.

title: Bay Enters Disabled List With Another Concussion
description: Call it bad luck. Call it a bad break. Call Jason Bay injury prone. Whatever it is called, it had Mets Manager Terry Collins fidgeting Saturday, clearly worried after Bays latest stroke of bad luck, his latest bad break, his latest injury.

title: Under Fire, Westbrook Will Keep Shooting
description: MIAMI  Two games into the N.B.A. finals, Oklahoma City point guard Russell Westbrook is averaging nearly a triple double against the Miami Heat, but do not confuse him with the next Magic Johnson.

title: The Pitfalls of a Counterattack
description: Levon Aronians two losses in the early rounds of the Tal Memorial tournament in Moscow last week  games in which he was quite soundly beaten  illustrate one of his tactics that his opponents may be able to exploit.

title: On Going Forth in the World
description: At colleges and universities across the country, many notable names have sent the Class of 2012 on its way with words of wisdom, doses of reality and touches of comedy.

title: Familiar Faces Offering Advice, Idealism and Humor
description: Alongside the statesmen, tycoons and artists who addressed the class of 2012 at commencement exercises this spring, a popular choice of speakers seemed to be people were used to seeing on television, offering a dose of comforting familiarity to young people headed into a parlous world.

title: Cuomo and Christie Request Federal Financing for Sept. 11 Museum

title: Steve Ben Israel, a Living Theater Performance Artist, Dies at 74

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: The cover story in Tehelka magazine, entitled Jailhouse Rock, uncovers the continuing goonda raj  or thugs reign  in the state of Uttar Pradesh despite assurances from the newly elected chief minister, Akhilesh Yadav, of stringent action against criminals in the state. The author, Ashish Khaitan, cites several examples of convicted gangsters, incarcerated for a broad range of crimes including murder, extortion, abduction, assault and others. Abhay Singh, a notorious don, is back in business under the new administration in the state, the article notes. On 24 May, the Samajwadi governmenttook the decision to withdraw a case registered in Faizabad district court under the U.P. Gangster Act  the only case out of 18 pending cases in which [Abhay] Singh had not got a bail, thus allowing Mr. Singh to go free. The district police signed off on this. Incidentally, exactly two years ago, the same district police had booked Mr. Singh under the U.P. Gangster Act, Mr. Khaitan reported.

title: The Gift of Being Gay and a Dad
description: Im in my mid-40s. Growing up, there was no such thing as gay parenting. I had a vague notion, I think, probably from television or a movie, that some kids fathers or mothers could end up running off with someone of the same sex. So, technically, they were a parent and they were gay  but it was a roundabout, devastating way to do it, kind of like demolishing a building by using a hurricane. It gets the job done but you wouldnt want to see it.

title: Egypts Military Cements Its Powers as Voting Ends
description: CAIRO  The Muslim Brotherhood early Monday projected its candidate, an Islamist, as the winner of Egypts first competitive presidential election, hours after the ruling military council issued an interim constitution granting itself broad power over the future government, all but eliminating the presidents authority in an apparent effort to guard against just such a victory.

title: Supporters of Bailout Claim Victory in Greek Election

title: Canyon Ranch Opens Its Doors to Teenagers
description: Canyon Ranch, the upscale spa that usually caters to adults, is dedicating two weeks this summer to a weight-loss program for parents and teenagers 14 to 17 years old. The seven-night program, held at the Tucson spa on July 8 and again starting Aug. 12, offers participants group and individual sessions with a nutritionist who instructs them on how to prepare healthy meals together, and with an exercise physiologist who gives guidance on incorporating fitness into their lives. The program also offers exercise classes and a meeting with a life coach. Every participant goes home with a customized plan and receives nine 50-minute follow-up sessions with his or her choice of specialist.

description: After the E. Tautz show, in a wharf building on the east side of London, I stopped with Jonathan Player, who is shooting the mens collections for The Times this weekend, for a coffee at an Italian place nearby. The clearly fashionable couple at the next table struck up a conversation, and, as it turned out, they were Alex and Zofia Torun-Shaw, the founders of Laird & Co., a young company making gentlemens hats here in Londons grand millinery tradition. They made the hats for some of the cool shows this weekend, including a pastel pink crusher for E. An Irving Berlin ditty evokes the place (lets have another cup of coffee) as do the lyrics of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. The advertising slogan Less work for mother became a middle-class mantra.

description: Fans of James Joyce who were unable to attend the annual Bloomsday on Broadway readings at Symphony Space on Saturday  along with anyone who appreciates the sound of famous literature read aloud by trained actors  will want to sample the BBC Radio 4 production James Joyces Ulysses, currently accessible to American listeners on the BBC Web site. Broadcast on Saturday  June 16 being the day when the action of Ulysses takes place  this new radio adaptation consisted of segments scattered across the days schedule, at times roughly corresponding to the movements of Leopold Bloom and Stephen Dedalus across Dublin in the novel.

None of them was available for an encore.

title: A Tea Party of a Circus: No Mad Hatter Here
description: In calling her company Wind-Up Dances, Emily Faulkner has hit upon an accurate label. In the two dances she presented at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Friday, her default way of moving is toylike. The body twists in segments, softly but mechanically, all elbows and knees. Occasionally one part of the toy helps another part along. A less flattering label might be Chiropractic Choreography.

title: A Baldwin Play Reading Will Benefit Theaters
description: To raise money and awareness for African-American theater and playwrights, Project1Voice, a nonprofit organization, will stage a one-night-only benefit reading of James Baldwins 1954 play, The Amen Corner, in 18 cities and 28 theaters across the country. Part of Project1Voices second annual event 1 Voice, 1 Play, 1 Day, the reading was chosen to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Baldwins death. Set in Harlem in the 1950s, The Amen Corner, like Baldwins first novel, Go Tell It on the Mountain, explores the role Christianity plays in the lives of African-Americans. The New York reading, which will be performed on Monday at 7 p.m at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, is to be hosted by Norm Lewis (below, of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess) and directed by Walter Dallas with Lillias White, Chuck Cooper and Adriane Lenox starring. Speaking in a telephone interview, the Project1Voice founder Erich McMillan-McCall said that the goal of the annual reading was to help preserve the legacy and tradition of black theaters for future generations, adding, By creating awareness and reigniting what I call lesser-known classics by African-American playwrights we can get people to realize that there is a voice that is missing, and that is the voice of many minority professionals. Tickets are available through (631) 464-7421 or project1voice.org.

title: Melrose in Talks to Buy German Manufacturer for $2.3 Billion
description: LONDON  The British private equity firm Melrose said on Monday that it was in talks to buy the Elster Group, a German utility meter manufacturer, for $2.3 billion.

description: From the editorial page

title: Deutsche Borse Asks Court to Overturn Decision to Block NYSE Deal
description: LONDON  Deutsche Brse has asked a European court to overturn a decision by antitrust regulators that blocked its planned merger with NYSE Euronext.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: When Buffett Is Your Boss
description: Whats it like when Warren Buffett is your boss? Thats the question on the mind of hundreds of journalists at the newspapers the Berkshire Hathaway legend has recently bought. The best answer, writes Christine Haughney, may be at The Buffalo News, the daily Mr. Buffett bought in 1977 and has run ever since. The verdict: Mr. Buffett is a hands-off boss who invests in local journalism and provides a great pension plan, but The News hasnt been immune from the downturn facing the rest of the business.

title: In Defense of Parasites
description: Would you purposely allow Schistosoma worms to burrow into your body and take up residence in your bloodstream, lungs and liver? Or perhaps allow writhing botfly larvae to feast upon your juices before popping out of your skin as a hairy fly?

description: The Man Group, the worlds largest public hedge fund, has a new finance director.

description: MOSCOW  A tiny, frayed Russian military base on Syrias Mediterranean coast has jumped into international focus amid concern over how far Russia might go to bolster the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Philippines and China Ease Tensions in Rift at Sea
description: BEIJING  Chinese fishing boats near the disputed Scarborough Shoal off the Philippine coast were heading back to port on Monday after Philippine vessels withdrew from the same area in an easing of tensions in the South China Sea, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said.

title: Aiming for School Diversity in Williamsburg, With Little Progress

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Daily Report: Apple Takes On Google in Maps
description: Last week, Apple announced that its phones would no longer come with maps from Google built in, but instead would feature Apples own map service, part of its new mobile operating system. In Mondays New York Times, Quentin Hardy looks into whether Apple can build a map service that does as good a job as Googles  or a better one.

description: If there is wisdom to be gleaned from the torrent of emotions over the police practice commonly known as stop-and-frisk, it is that City Halls worship of statistics has distinct limitations. And if there is anyone who youd think would have understood that point instinctively, it is the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Dont Look Now
description: Championships do not come with a guarantee that they'll be worthy of framing. Often, in the slog of a drive for a title, many of a sport's fine artistic points are lost, their beauty obscured in the sheer effort it takes to win. Or, in the case of the United States Open golf championship or the N.B.A. finals, it gets buried in a cloud of fog and unrepentant fairways or drowned out by referees' whistles and bodies hitting the floor.

title: Sweden 1912: Thorpes Olympic Moment
description: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, well take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

title: Pearl Buck Novels to Be Published as E-Books
description: Thirteen novels by Pearl S. Buck will be released in e-book form for the first time, her publisher said on Monday, the latest works by an acclaimed author to be published digitally after being available only in print.

title: Dealing With the Facebook Lawsuits
description: The campy 1980s hit Its Raining Men could well be translated into a new song called Its Raining Lawsuits to describe the deluge of cases triggered by Facebooks botched initial public offering on May 18.

description: Acknowledging recent missteps by the government, Indias chief economic adviser said Monday that he was confident that economic reforms like increased foreign investment in the retail sector and reduced fuel subsidies would soon be enacted.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Telegraph: The 9-year-old Scottish school-lunch blogger Martha Payne (right), whose blog, Neverseconds, has received more than five million hits in the last month, was ordered to stop by local authorities last week. You can guess how that turned out.  Julia Moskin

title: In London, the Ones That Stand Out
description: One peculiar thing about the London mens collections taking place this weekend is that the coolest young designers, or at least the ones with the most buzz here, tend to show in what would seem to be the worst time slots. Jonathan Anderson, whose label J. W. Anderson has been on the hot list for mens and womens wear in recent seasons, showed at 9 a.m. on Sunday, on the last day of the mens shows.

title: Winslet and Branagh Among Those Honored by Queen
description: The film stars Kate Winslet and Kenneth Branagh and the architect Zaha Hadid were among the Britons honored for their contributions to the arts this weekend by Queen Elizabeth II. They were named to the Order of the British Empire in the Queens birthday honors list along with hundreds of others who received a variety of awards for their work.

title: Bank of America Hires Senior Oppenheimer Health Care Banker
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Brian McCarthy as a vice chairman of health care investment banking, the firm announced on Monday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook. Mr. McCarthy came over from Oppenheimer & Company, where he was the head of the health care investment banking team, and previously worked at JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers.

title: British Prosecutor Drops Suspect in Kaupthing Investigation
description: LONDON  Britains Serious Fraud Office on Monday dropped the property tycoon Vincent Tchenguiz as a suspect in its investigation into the collapse of Icelandic bank Kaupthing, less than a month after it admitted mistakes in the inquiry.

title: Business Day Live | June 18, 2012
description: After the Greek election defuses one crisis, looking for the next. | Bayer's chief executive on Europe's economic outlook.

title: Professional Photographers in the Delivery Room
description: I want to see that moment when Im in labor, said Rhisie Hentges of Long Beach, Calif., who paid $1,895 to have Briana Kalajian, a co-owner of Shoots and Giggles Photography, document the birth of her first child. That moment when both my husband and I look to see what the sex is? Thats something that I want to see happen. For Honey, the Baby Is Coming; Quick, Call the Photographer, Elissa Gootman spoke to parents, photographers and doctors about the new front lines of documenting childhood: birth photographers.

title: Really? Ginseng Can Help Relieve Fatigue
description: THE FACTS

title: On Our Radar: The Negotiating Text in Rio
description: Environmentalists complain that the negotiating text being readied for the Rio+20 environmental conference this week in Brazil is riddled with words like support and encourage rather than must or will, the language of commitment; a coalition, meanwhile, organizes a Twitterstorm calling for an end to fossil-fuel subsidies. The conference opens on Wednesday. [W.W.F., endfossilfuelsubsidies.org]

title: 70 Major Art Dealers  at Kensington Gardens Show
description: Though it was just established two years ago, Art Antiques London has already become an important nexus for international dealers, collectors, museum curators and academics. This years fair, in a handsome pavilion in Kensington Gardens through June 20, brings together more than 70 major art dealers, including specialists in modern British art, 20th-century design, tapestry and antique textiles and European jewelry.

title: Get the Speculators
description: The Greeks got all the attention, but the more important election Sunday may have been in France, where the Socialists and their allies won a clear majority in Parliament.

title: Soups That Taste Like Spring
description: I wanted comforting food this week that would showcase the wonderful late spring/early summer vegetables that are appearing in markets all over the country right now  great big bunches of chard with wide stems and lush leaves, tender leeks, the last of the fava beans, first of the green beans and the first of the summer squash, still small and delicate. I didnt have a lot of time, and I wanted to make dishes that I could serve as the main dish for dinners throughout the week, so I did what the French do: I made soup.

title: Russian Arms Dealer Was Classified as a Small Business, Briefly
description: Heres a new topic for Youre The Boss: Russian arms for Syria. Russian-made helicopters are en route to Syria, sold to the Assad regime by Rosoboronexport, the Russian state-owned arms exporter. Since 2007, Rosoboronexport, the sole Russian arms exporter, has supplied Syria with 78 percent of its arms imports, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. (The New York Times has reported that the copters heading to Syria were most likely already part of that countrys fleet, returning after routine maintenance in Russia.)

title: His Domain Transformed, Parks Chief Is Leaving
description: He got his start as a teenager cleaning locker rooms at a city pool in the East Village and picking up litter in East River Park, and ended up overseeing the most ambitious program of building and refurbishing New York Citys parks since the era of Robert Moses. Now, after a decade on the job, the parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, 55, is stepping down to take a position with a national conservation group.

title: Monday Motorsports: After Four-Year Absence, Dale Earnhardt Jr. Visits Victory Lane
description: It was described by various motorsports media as a pinch-me moment. Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, had won a Sprint Cup race for the first time in four years.

title: The Musicians Words: Interviews With Stars Donated to Library of Congress
description: A trove of interviews with more than 200 giants of the music industry including Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, Barbra Streisand, Little Richard, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Elton John, Paul Simon, David Bowie, Billy Joel, Tony Bennett, Joan Baez and Tina Turner has been donated to the Library of Congress by Joe Smith, the former president of Capitol Records/EMI.

title: Some Humility Looks Good on the Heat
description: MIAMI  With three simple words that were more playful than derisive, Kevin Durant helped along the continuing reputation reset of a team that for much of its two seasons in present form has been the essence of entitlement and presumption. Dwyane Wade didnt initially hear the remark after Durant effortlessly canned a second-quarter jump shot over Wade, though from Durants lips to television viewers eyes, the message was perfectly clear.

title: Morning Walkabout  6/18: Couch Seats on Planes and Greece Beckons Tourists
description: RT@Greece: Its Still Nice HereGreeces national tourism agency has started a social media initiative to promote travel to the economically challenged country and to counter inaccuracies or speculations that have caused a dip in tourism there. (The International Herald Tribune)

title: First Defense Witnesses Called in Sandusky Case
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant coach at Penn State accused of sexually abusing 10 boys, regularly took boys into locker-room showers reserved for coaches, according to two longtime colleagues who testified on Sanduskys behalf Monday.

title: Vain Glorious | You Can Rest Easy at Mohonk Mountain House
description: Who: Mohonk Mountain House Spa. For a 143-year-old mansion, which still offers horse-and-buggy rides in and around its cavernous quarters, its refreshing  oh, so very refreshing  to see how its eco-friendly spa continues to adapt to frenetic modern lives.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Patrick Radden Keefe on the Sinaloa Drug Cartel
description: Patrick Radden Keefe wrote this weeks cover story on Mexican drug cartels. A fellow at the Century Foundation, Keefe is the author of The Snakehead: An Epic Tale of the Chinatown Underworld and the American Dream and Chatter: Uncovering the Echelon Surveillance Network and the Secret World of Global Eavesdropping.

title: Many Americans Struggle to Pay for Health Care, Survey Finds
description: As the nation awaits the Supreme Courts ruling on challenges to the health care law, Americans continue to report that they struggle to pay for medical care.

description: The best summer nail designs for the week of June 11.

title: Numberplay: Mixed-Up Wires
description: Welcome to Numberplay, the week-long game of collaboration and discovery that also happens to be about math. If youre new to the game, give it a try by leaving a comment at the end of this post. You dont have to solve the problem; hunches are good. So are wild conjectures. At Numberplay, the standard answer is just the beginning.

title: New Efforts Begin to Form a Government in Greece
description: ATHENS  Antonis Samaras, the leader of the center-right party that placed first in Greek parliamentary elections, began talks on Monday to form a coalition government aimed at keeping Greece in the euro zone and renegotiating its loan agreement with the foreign creditors keeping the country afloat.

description: Moments from the campaign trail last week, including the launch of a bus tour, fund-raising and a dressage championship.

description: Who thinks Hillary Rodham Clinton might run for president in 2016? Democrats? Republicans? Her husband? The vice president?

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, With Hairspray Song Team, Plans London Opening
description: A new musical version of Roald Dahls beloved childrens book Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, directed by Sam Mendes, will open at the London Palladium in June 2013, according to a news release. The ubiquitous Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman, who co-wrote the lyrics for the Tony-winning musical Hairspray (Mr. Shaiman wrote the music) and created the music for the NBC series about Broadway, Smash, will be writing songs for the show.

title: What Rodney King Said During One of His Final Interviews
description: Since last November, when we introduced the The One-Page Magazine, Ive interviewed more than 30 celebrities and cultural luminaries for a mini how-to column. (Its our version of what would be the back page of a multipage magazine.) Dr. Phil told me how to break off an engagement nicely; Diahann Carroll divulgedhow to look great in your 70s; Fran Drescher spoke about how to stay friends with your ex.

title: Image of the Day: June 18
Putting Obamas Jobs Proposal in Context
description: With federal borrowing costs virtually at zero, President Obama has been pressing Congress for months to pass a major infrastructure program aimed at putting Americans to work and rebuilding the countrys creaking roads, bridges, rails and tunnels.

description: Manchester City will open defense of its Premier League title at newly promoted Southampton on Aug. 18 in the schedule released Monday by the league and its title sponsor, Barclays.

title: With Each Passing Memorial Day, What Changes?
description: Another Memorial Day has come and gone. We had our barbeques and enjoyed the day off, and some of us paid respects to the fallen. Now were back to the routine of doing what it is that Americans do. As for the war? Out of sight, out of mind.

description: Mary Cadwallader joined the Washington office of TPM Media, the publisher of Talking Points Memo, as vice president for advertising sales. She succeeds Waldo Tibbets, who left, the company said, to pursue other professional interests. Ms. Cadwallader had most recently been national sales manager at The Hill, Washington, part of News Communications.

description: In the book All Business Is Local: Why Place Matters More Than Ever in a Global, Virtual World, John A. Quelch makes the case that the push for globalization is obscuring the significance of local tastes, preferences and ways of life.

description: For many graduating seniors, going to college this fall means that they will no longer need to devise ways to sneak out of the house at 2 a.m., writes Ariha Setalvad, a student at New York University.

title: Rodney Kings Starring Role in Citizen Journalism
description: Rodney King, who died on Sunday at age 47, came to represent many things during his life  the brutality of the Los Angeles Police Department, the explosion of the citys long-simmering racial tensions and the simple wish that we could all, as he pleaded, get along.

title: TimesCast | June 18, 2012
description: Greek voters give a victory to a pro-euro party that supports the economic bailout. | Egyptians elect an Islamist in their first competitive presidential election.

title: For Weddings and a Funeral
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Its a modern marriage. A puppet show tells the couples love story in verse: while a young man narrates, five custom-made marionettes  the bride, the groom and their three children  bob about. The two people weve come to honor have to pick each other out of two line-ups of a dozen potential grooms and brides draped in bed sheets. Then emerges a young bearded man wearing a red cloak and a TV remote control around his neck. Placing battery-operated Christmas-tree lights on the couples heads, he pronounces them husband and wife to the applause of the 60 or so guests in attendance.

title: John McCains Three Little Words
description: In his 2010 State of the Union address, President Obama roundly criticized the Supreme Courts Citizens United decision, arguing that it had reversed a century of law. That practically sounds like a hymn of praise compared to what Senator John McCain had to say on Meet the Press this weekend. He called Citizens United: arrogant, uninformed, nave.

title: Bieber Fever Comes to Macys
description: For hard-core Justin Bieber fans it was an opportunity not to be missed. The pop star put out the word over Twitter on Sunday that there were 500 tickets available for an unannounced show Monday night at the Apollo Theater. All one had to do to get two of them was to buy $168 (plus tax) worth of his new fragrance at Macys in Herald Square.

description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified investigations into whether 1.4 million Toyotas and almost 342,000 General Motors sport utility vehicles may have defective power-window switches that could lead to smoke and fire conditions.

description: The trillions of germs living in and around your body; the mysterious third voyage of a 15th-century explorer; and new findings on cardiac deaths among patients with H.I.V.

title: A Bet on the Sun
description: Out in the Mojave Desert in California, a power plant that could eventually generate enough electricity for 140,000 homes hopes to get its moment in the sun soon. When the $2.2 billion solar thermal plant known as Ivanpah is completed  sometime next year, if all goes according to plan  nearly 350,000 mirrors on 3,600 acres will reflect light onto boilers. Steam will power turbines, which will generate electricity that flows to California homes. It will be the largest such plant in the world. These solar workhorses of the desert, says V. John White, an analyst in Sacramento and an advocate for renewable energy, can produce a lot of high-quality energy in the way that other renewable energies cant do. And there are only a handful of places on the planet that have solar radiation that good. But some opponents have criticized the Obama administration for pushing solar projects that dont pan out. The solar-panel maker Solyndra declared bankruptcy last year despite receiving $528 million in federally guaranteed loans, while BrightSource Energy, one of Ivanpahs developers, has benefited from a similar $1.6 billion government loan. Its expensive harnessing the sun. And the costs go beyond construction. BrightSource says that it has spent more than $56 million relocating desert tortoises. JULIE BOSMAN

title: The Look of a Longhorn Dynasty at the U.S. Open
description: The University of Texas is becoming known for more than its football and basketball prowess, thanks to the recent success of its mens golf team. The Longhorns just won the N.C.A.A. title, and can count on having two up-and-coming talents as part of their team for the next few years.

title: Too Poor for Their Own Graduation
Statin Drugs Cause Fatigue in Some People
description: Many observational reports have suggested that statin drugs cause fatigue in some people, and now a randomized trial has found further evidence for the effect.

description: Drinking, smoking and using recreational drugs probably will not reduce a mans fertility, a new study suggests  but working on a road crew might.

title: Do Magnet Schools Still Matter?
description: As detailed in Sundays Metropolitan cover story, Integrating a School, One Child at a Time, four elementary schools in Brooklyns District 14 won a federal magnet grant in 2010 for approximately $1.5 million over three years to desegregate.

title: Facebook Acquires Israeli Facial Recognition Company
description: Facebook, the largest repository of pictures anywhere and at any time in history, has acquired an Israeli company, called face.com, that makes facial recognition technology. Neither company disclosed the sale price nor the other terms of the deal.

title: Women Are Still a Rarity in Building Service Jobs
description: Monique Catus stood at the entrance of an elegant Art Deco apartment building on East 51st Street one day this spring, with a smile on her face and pristine white gloves on her hands. A little girl trotted by, she later recounted, looked up at her, and then looked at her mother. She was confused.

title: Morgan Stanley Declares Victory
description: Morgan Stanley, with Facebook egg all over its face, has adopted the strategy memorably advocated by Senator George Aiken in 1966: Declare victory, and get out.

title: Defense Minister New Heir to Throne in Saudi Arabia
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabias Prince Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, who was governor of Riyadh for nearly 50 years until his recent promotion to Saudi Arabias defense minister, was officially named crown prince on Monday, making him the heir apparent to the 88-year-old King Abdullah.

title: An Agency Division Chronicles Its Own I.T. Overhaul
description: A division of a giant agency holding group that usually produces campaigns for clients is, in a change of pace, undertaking a campaign with itself as the subject.

title: The Bodys Protein Cleaning Machine
description: When Dr. Avram Hershko, 74, a biochemist at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa and a winner of the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, was recently asked to name the most important fact of his life, he answered: That I love my six grandchildren. For two, three days every week, I take them to dance class, sport and school. I am completely in their lives.

title: TimesCast | Egyptian Election Analysis
description: In Tahrir Square, celebrations began Monday after Egyptians elected an Islamist in their first competitive presidential election.

title: Omega-3s Dont Cut Diabetics Heart Risks
description: A large trial has found that supplements of omega-3 fatty acid do nothing to prevent cardiovascular problems or death in people with Type 2 diabetes.

description: In the third inning of the New York Gothams first game on Governors Island on Saturday, a batter hit a towering fly ball to shallow left field.

title: Sonos Gets Boost From Former Apple Executives and Other Investors
description: Sonos is a company that sometimes gets compared to Apple because it designs the hardware and software for its products, a line of home audio equipment for listening to digital music. Now the company is raising money from a group of investors that includes a couple of former Apple executives.

title: Predators, Prey and Lyme Disease
description: Deer ticks are aptly named, in a sense; a Northeastern deer can carry over 1,000 of these ticks on its body. But as far as humans are concerned, the ticks might be more relevantly called mouse ticks. Thats because white-footed mice and other small mammals, not deer, are now known by scientists to be major carriers of Lyme disease.

title: At Party, Bloomberg Tips Hand on Endorsement
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has remained coy about whether he plans to endorse a presidential candidate this year, even as Mitt Romney and President Obama aggressively court the billionaire media mogul.

title: Fraud Charges Threaten Burgundy's Vaunted Reputation
description: PARIS  Accusations of wine fraud, which have been swirling around the international trade in rare vintages, have now struck home at the source of some of the worlds most prized bottles, the cellars of Burgundy.

title: To Advance, Search for a Black Cat in a Dark Room
description: Many people think of science as a deliberate process that is driven by the gradual accumulation of facts. Legions of smart scientists labor to piece together the evidence supporting their discoveries, hypotheses, inventions and progress itself.

description: Or at least thats what the speech recognition software on my voice mail says.

description: Q. If long-ago victims of the bubonic plague are dug up, could the germs infect someone?

title: A Hormonal Remedy for Brain Injuries Is Explored
description: Late one evening last December, 18-year-old Michelle Vaquero was crossing a busy street in San Jose, Calif., when a car slammed into her. She landed more than 30 feet away. An ambulance rushed her to Santa Clara Valley Medical Center, where doctors diagnosed traumatic brain injury.

title: A Mythical Anniversary
description: Were coming up on the second anniversary of my piece Myths of Austerity, in which I tried to knock down the simply insane conventional wisdom then gelling among Very Serious People. Intellectually it was, I think I can say without false modesty, a huge win; I (and those of like mind) have been right about everything.

title: Transcripts of Conversations Between Zimmermans Are Released
description: In recorded conversations from jail, George Zimmerman and his wife, Shellie, discussed how to move tens of thousands of dollars from the money that flowed into an online defense fund he set up to credit union accounts under her name and into his sisters account, according to audio recordings of their conversations and court documents released in Florida on Monday.

title: London Theater Journal: Imagination From Despair in Edinburgh and Minsk

In addition to the usual clutter of bottles, boxes and stolen street signs that passes for interior decoration among university students, fat bags of trash occupy a wall by the stove. In the tenants defense, allow me to note that theyre not just making excuses when they say they cant do a thing about it.

title: Battersby Is Poised, for the New Brooklyn

Couples cleave to a wall; latecomers hunch at the bar. Outside it is Smith Street in Cobble Hill, a formerly insalubrious strip (werent they all?) that is now just a Marc Jacobs away from becoming Brooklyns Bleecker.

title: Environmental Protest Becomes Rallying Point in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR  When a planned 24-hour environmental protest gets under way this Saturday on the outskirts of the coastal Malaysian town of Kuantan, the roll call will include speakers from across the country.

title: Nelson Peltz Takes 5.1% Stake in Lazard

Her anxious, endless nattering reverberates like a constant klaxon horn amid the silence inhabited by her uncle, who has retreated from the world to live in solitude with nature.

title: Southern Baptist Convergence
description: The secular media usually ignores the thousands of pastors, missionaries and church volunteers who gather every summer for the annual meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention. This year is different. Everyone from PBS to the Huffington Post is buzzing with anticipation  and not because they are awaiting the tedious discussion of committee reports and budgets necessary to manage the countrys largest evangelical denomination. The reason for all the excitement is this: the 2012 convention, which opens Tuesday in New Orleans, will elect a black man as president for the first time in Southern Baptist history. This is no small thing for a denomination that separated in 1845 from its northern brethren in order to defend the right of Southern slaveholders to serve as missionaries.

title: 800,000 People Forced to Flee Across Borders in 2011, Report Says
description: Upheavals in Ivory Coast, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and elsewhere drove 800,000 people to flee their countries and become refugees in 2011, the highest number in 11 years, the United Nations said Monday in its annual report on the forcibly displaced. The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said that 4.3 million people in all were newly displaced last year, which includes those who stayed in their countries and those who fled. At the end of 2011, the report said, 42.5 million people were either refugees (15.2 million), internally displaced (26.4 million) or in the process of seeking asylum (895,000). The overall total was lower than the 2010 total of 43.7 million mainly because 3.2 million internally displaced people returned home, the report said. The number of people who fled their countries and became refugees last year was the highest in that category since 822,000 in 2000.

title: Iraq: Bomber Attacks Funeral
description: A man wearing an explosives belt detonated it amid a group of Shiite mourners at a funeral in Diyala Province on Monday, killing at least 15 people and wounding more than 40, according to security officials. The attack came after days of strikes against mostly Shiite targets in a stepped-up campaign of sectarian violence carried out by the Sunni insurgent group Al Qaeda in Iraq. Over the past week nearly 150 Iraqis have been killed in attacks. Violence, largely sectarian in nature, has substantially increased after a period of relative calm following the withdrawal of the American military in December. The rising violence coincides with a political struggle involving Iraqs three main factions  the Shiite majority, which controls the government, and the minority Kurds and Sunnis, who have called for a vote of no confidence against Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

title: China: Spacecraft Docks With Orbiting Module
description: A Chinese spacecraft carrying three astronauts docked with an orbiting module on Monday, another first for the country as it strives to match American and Russian exploits in space. The Shenzhou 9 capsule completed the maneuver with the Tiangong 1 module 213 miles above Earth. The astronauts will live and work in the module for several days as part of preparations for a permanent space station. The crew includes 33-year-old Liu Yang, an air force pilot and the first Chinese woman in space. The docking was a first for Chinese astronauts. In November 2011, the unmanned Shenzhou 8 successfully docked twice with Tiangong 1 by remote control. Mondays docking also was completed by remote control from a ground base in China. A manual docking, to be carried out by one of the crew members, is scheduled for later in the mission. (AP)

title: Kenneth Lonergans Thwarted Masterpiece
description: Think back on the last time you saw Kenneth Lonergans 2000 film, You Can Count On Me. Do you remember how good it was? The intellectual and emotional complexity of the script? Those remarkable performances by Mark Ruffalo and Laura Linney? That scene  to choose one among many  between Terry (Ruffalo) and his 8-year-old nephew, Rudy (Rory Culkin), in which the drunk Terry sits next to Rudys bed late at night, smoking a cigarette and telling Rudy why his dad is such a jerk and why the town he lives in sucks so much? (Fortunately for you, though, your mom is like, the greatest. So you had some bad luck, and you had some good luck.) It was a modest story of a brother and sister whose parents die when theyre kids and whose lives are blown in different directions and who, years later, come to some almost-peace about what they can and cant be for each other. But there was such intense realness about it, the way people really talk, the way lives are actually lived, that was unlike anything else on screen, radical almost, in its attention to the genuine messiness of human lives.

title: Florida: State Is Sued Again Over Voter Purge
description: A second lawsuit was filed in federal court in Miami on Tuesday against the State of Florida over its search of voter rolls for noncitizens. Several civil and voters rights groups joined in the suit, which says the search violates the National Voting Rights Act and the National Voter Registration Act. The groups said the review discriminates against minorities and is prohibited within 90 days of an election. Florida has a primary in August. The state is also being sued by the Department of Justice. Earlier this year, the state sent names of 2,700 possible noncitizens to county election supervisors, who were advised to write those people, asking them to offer proof of citizenship or risk being dropped from the rolls. But the list, compiled by comparing voter rolls to a drivers license databank and overwhelmingly singled out minorities, was found to be flawed. The state has asked the Department of Homeland Security to allow it to use an immigration database to verify the list, but the federal government has not done so. As a result, Florida is suing Homeland Security over access to the database. The civil rights groups say they hope their suit deters other states from conducting similar searches.

title: Wasting Warren Buffett

It would have been so clarifying to have an independent voice calling out Mitt Romney for running a campaign that consists of decrying the last three and a half years of the Obama presidency, while offering to reinstate the very same failed policies that made the eight years of George W. Bush a disaster that President Obama has spent most of his time cleaning up. And it would have been equally clarifying to have an independent challenger calling out Obama for failing to put a credible, specific economic plan on the table  at the scale of our problem  but relying instead on a campaign that amounts to a series of discrete appeals to each of the Democratic Party constituencies. It feels like a ground war with no air cover.

title: Samurai Shopper | Prize for the Eyes
description: The Samurai Shopper is particularly delighted this week with eye primers. What a difference they make in the general scheme of looking good. Eye primers are not pudding-y and slick like eye creams, nor are they powdery, dry, greasy or thick like concealers: theyre the intermediate step between those two. Some are tinted to match your skin color, some have a nacreous luster, one or two terrible ones are pasty and glittery. The better primers disappear but leave a film that acts like a two-sided piece of tape: the primer adheres to eyelids while keeping eye makeup on top from huddling in a corner or forming a wobbly line on your eyelid crease. A good eye primer can replace concealers entirely over the lid, evening out skin tone. The very, very good ones can even be swept under the eye, where the bags might be.

title: Trouble in Sinai

In her review, Michiko Kakutani wrote: Thanks to Mr. Eggerss uncommon ability to access his characters emotions and channel their every mood, we are instantly immersed in Alans story, rooting for him somehow to win an audience with the king and turn his life around. We dont have a blanket policy here, but we need to have people with good morals, who are compatible with the public that we bring in, said Mr. Dutra, who added that groups of schoolchildren often tour the factory. title: The Opening of the American Frontier

The following March, Congress barred the military from returning fugitive slaves to their masters, and began to pressure Lincoln to take more drastic action.

title: Beyond the Four-Stroke
description: A conventional piston-driven internal-combustion engine functions by performing a cycle with four main steps: Air intake, air compression, combustion and exhaust. An engine is referred to as a four-" or two-stroke model according to the number of movements the piston makes to perform one cycle. The Scuderi split-cycle engine and EcoMotor OPOC engine are both departures from the four-stroke engine most commonly found in automobiles. They ejected Remedy, my old quarter horse, from the herd. My neighbor put salve on his bites. The self-immolations occurred in the Yushu Prefecture of Qinghai, a Chinese province that is traditionally the northeastern Tibetan area of Amdo. The burnings occurred in the town of Dzatoe, known in Chinese as Zaduo. The report, which cited a monk in India who came from the Yushu area, said that Tenzin Khedup died at the scene and that Ngawang Norphel was badly burned.

description: There is a dreadful routine to chemotherapy. My life has been synched to a chemotherapy calendar ever since my leukemia diagnosis last year. I have become an expert at predicting when side effects and symptoms will set in. Its a ghoulish monthly party, and the guests always arrive on time: nausea, vomiting, chills, exhaustion, fever, mouth sores, pain, infections and emergency hospitalizations.

description: Police Chief Bill R. Lee Jr. of Sanford, who drew criticism for his departments handling of Trayvon Martins killing, lost his job on Wednesday. In a news release, City Manager Norton N. In April, he announced that the chief had agreed to resign, but the City Commission rejected the resignation. Mr. Lee has been on administrative leave.

title: Hawaii: Island of Lanai Sold to Chief Executive of Oracle
description: Lanai, the smallest publicly accessible inhabited island in Hawaii, has been sold, the governors office announced Wednesday. Castle & Cooke, the company that owned 98 percent of the 141-square-mile island, agreed to sell that land to Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of Oracle, the software giant. The price was not known, and neither Castle & Cooke nor Oracle responded to a request for comment.

description: At least 11 animals at the Lake Superior Zoo in Duluth drowned when severe storms caused major flooding in northeastern Minnesota on Wednesday. Much of the zoo was under water, and firefighters and police officers were dispatched to help round up a polar bear and two seals that escaped from their exhibits.

title: From Milk to Peas, a Chinese Food-Safety Mess

He had gone with a reporter, Tusha Mittal, into the forest-dense state of Chhattisgarh in central India in May. He had been unwell during the trip and felt uneasy upon his return but continued to work. (The pictures that he took during the trip appeared in the magazines May 12 issue.)

title: Talking About Why Women Cant Have It All
description: The cover story for the July/August issue of The Atlantic is one bound to stir conversation  as it was meant to. In Why Women Still Cant Have It All, Anne-Marie Slaughter, the director of policy planning at the State Department under Hillary Rodham Clinton from 2009 to 2011, writes from personal experience about the reasons women cant juggle both the demands of a high-powered job and being fully present as parents  at least not with the way Americas economy and society are structured today. After two years in Washington doing work she loved, she returned to academia at Princeton University, not because she didnt want to stay in public service, but because juggling high-level government work with the needs of two teenage boys was not possible.

title: Stone Links: The Ethics of Ignorance (and Humor)
description: What do Jenny McCarthy and Socrates have in common? According to a post by Massimo Pigliucci at his blog Rationally Speaking, they each exemplifie a certain understanding of ignorance. Inspired by Katja Vogt, Pigliucci uses the Platonic concept of transferred ignorance, to distinguish between a healthy Socratic, self-aware kind of ignorance, and the kind of willful ignorance that allows feelings to somehow trump actual scientific evidence, as in the case of McCarthys campaign against childhood vaccination. Pigliucci argues, after Plato, that this latter type of ignorance can be morally problematic, and that its recent prevelance has led our political discourse into never before achieved peaks (or, rather, valleys).

title: Shes 350 Pounds and Olympics-Bound
description: When youre a big, strong girl  a really big, strong girl  its easier to pull the table to your chair than to scoot your chair toward the table. Doorknobs need to be tightened, or you might pull them off. Holley Mangold, 22 and a superheavyweight Olympic weight lifter, is 5-foot-8 and weighs 350 pounds. When she squats, which she can do with 525 pounds on her shoulders, she looks almost wholly like an egg. I get a lot of Creepy McCreepersons interested in me because Im so big its not normal, its like a fetish, she told me one day in the gym. And I dont like to sit outside. Not because I dont like to be outside, but usually there are plastic chairs. Once you break a couple plastic chairs, youre afraid of them all.

Last fall, the building reopened as the Green Garage, a living laboratory and co-working space for the what its owners, Tom and Peggy Brennan, see as the future of Motown  triple-bottom-line sustainable enterprises that define success by social and environmental measures as well as by financial profit.

title: A Dozen Ways to Serve Stone Fruit
description: Stone fruit is summer in your hand. To me, there isnt a better unmessed-with food than a good, ripe peach. Still, stone fruit can be fun to play around with, and a recipe for one kind is a recipe for almost all. Peaches, nectarines, apricots, plums, mangoes and cherries all respond similarly to sauting, poaching, macerating, grilling, roasting and drying. And once cooked, stone fruit goes with just about everything.

title: The Possum Ate My Cable
description: Venezuelans are pretty jaded about the news these days, and for good reason. Newspapers often read like a magic-realist novel: the presidents daughter redesigns national symbols on a whim; the government might mess with the time on your watch and the remains of independence-era heroes. But the bizarreness reached a new height this week when the Venezuelan government announced that the major blackout Ciudad Guayana had suffered the day before was to be blamed, not on years of mismanagement and underinvestment, but on a wily possum that had chewed through cables at a local substation.

It appears we are about to exit a world in which LeBron James has become the most vaunted athlete who has not won anything and enter one in which he has. College football moved with more finality out of the hated Bowl Championship Series era and into one with something resembling a playoff. That this all happened on the summer solstice might either prove to you that higher powers are fiddling with our fun and games, or prompt you to say, "It's summer for goodness' sake, why is the N.B.A. still playing basketball?!"

Because the 14th Amendment prohibits any action that raises doubt about the public debt, the theory went, President Obama could declare the ceiling unconstitutional and simply ignore the Houses threat.

title: Who Needs a Prince When Funs Afoot?
description: The riotous mass of bouncy curls that crowns Merida, the free-to-be-me heroine of the new Pixar movie, Brave, is a marvel of computer imagineering. A rich orange-red the color of ripe persimmon, Meridas hair doesnt so much frame her pale, creamy face as incessantly threaten to engulf it, the thick tendrils and fuzzy whorls radiating outward like a sunburst. Theres so much beauty, so much untamed animation in this hair that it makes Merida look like a hothead, a rebel, the little princess who wouldnt and didnt. Then again, Rapunzel has a supernice head of hair too.

title: For Convicted Financier, a Farewell to Bugatti and Other Baubles
description: Timothy S. title: Photoville Comes to Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: When the Miser was younger and needed the money, guarding one of the worlds greatest art collections in a majestic Fifth Avenue fortress didnt seem like such a horrible prospect, even if the uniform sure wasnt anyones idea of sexy. Summer weekends were tough, though. Long stretches were spent gazing out of available windows, neglecting priceless artifacts. Our holdings of works from Africa, Oceania and the Americas, for example, could have been greatly reduced thanks to the more prosaic distractions of Central Park in summer. Think about that next time you read of some daring art heist somewhere.

title: A Jilted City Finds Itself Enjoying the Heat
description: SEATTLE  It was Wednesday, the day after the Miami Heat went up, three games to one, against the Oklahoma City Thunder in the N.B.A. finals. And all around this city, there was a good deal of satisfaction that the Thunder, the team that used to be known as the Seattle SuperSonics, was probably going to come up short in their quest to win a championship.

title: Sonny Rollins Is Big Winner at Jazz Awards
description: Sonny Rollins, the veteran saxophonist, was the big winner on Wednesday night at the annual Jazz Awards in New York, taking home three trophies. He was named musician of the year for the second year in a row and won for best record and best tenor saxophonist to boot.

description: As Tyler Cowen (and then I) wrote about earlier this week, trust in government is declining.

title: Theater Talkback: Boxers on Broadway
description: ArtsBeat once again is inviting members of the theater world to contribute over the summer to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. For the first guest post, Trav S. D., a historian of vaudeville, talks about the long bare-knuckles history shared between the boxing ring and the stage.

title: A Strong Finish Makes Up for a Strange Ride
description: While the Oklahoma City Thunder await their formal elimination from the postseason, the rest of us can only enjoy  and dread  the waning moments of another brilliant N.B.A. campaign. What began in a Christmas Day fervor has ended with a gift; an exhausting regular-season schedule was upstaged by riveting playoff theater, and has culminated in an unforgettable display of artistry and grandeur in the N.B.A. finals.
