title: Stolen Cultural Treasures on Display in Paris
description: PARIS  It is a most unusual and diverse art exhibition for Unesco, the United Nations arm dedicated to preserving and promoting the worlds culture. On Wednesday, 31 rare artifacts and works of art  all of them stolen or illegally exported, mostly in or from Italy  went on display at UNESCOs Paris headquarters, in an exhibition called Recovered Treasures.

description: The fuel is cheap and plentiful. But there is little infrastructure to deliver it to users, and so there is little demand for equipment to use it.

title: An Earth Summit Draws on Oil, Mining and Utility Largess
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The cups at the water coolers here at Rio+20, the global sustainability conference taking place Wednesday through Friday, are made of rough biodegradable corn fiber rather than plastic. Vans running on second-generation ethanol made from sugar cane bagasse take conference members, free of charge, from the hotels on the Copacabana beach to the conference center an hour away.

title: Prosecutors in Norway Seek Hospital for Gunman
description: OSLO  Norwegian prosecutors asked a trial court here on Thursday to order Anders Behring Breivik, who has admitted killing 77 people, confined for compulsory psychiatric treatment instead of sentencing him to prison.

title: Bird Flu Paper Is Published After Debate
description: The more controversial of two papers describing how the lethal H5N1 bird flu could be made easier to spread was published Thursday, six months after a scientific advisory board suggested that the papers most potentially dangerous data be censored.

description: The battle for Quest Software highlights a boards quandary when a chief executive makes a play for the company. Not only that, its also a fun takeover battle in the midst of a slow summer deal market featuring some novel deal-making.

title: Air France Plans to Cut 10 Percent of Its Work Force
description: PARIS  Air France said Thursday that it would eliminate more than 5,100 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, by the end of next year, part of its efforts to return the company to profitability at a time of deepening economic gloom across Europe.

title: Crystal Clear | Eyal Burstein for Swarovski
description: Its hard to believe that Swarovskis Crystal Palace program, in which contemporary designers imagine ever-newer uses for Swarovski crystals, is 10 years old. The years  and crystals, as interpreted by people like Toord Boontje, Zaha Hadid, Ron Arad and John Pawson  have flown by. But last week, Swarovski celebrated the programs anniversary at Design Miami/Basel with Beta, an installation by the designer Eyal Burstein, of the Berlin studio Beta Tank, in which the crystals were conceptual rather than literal. Beta featured three concrete and metal chairs and a plexiglass bench, all of which were influenced by the shape of Swarovskis classic Chaton-cut crystals.

title: Refuse Thy Neighbor
description: I recently resigned from my job as an engineer to be at home more with my young children. When news got around, I started receiving requests for favors from neighbors (for baby-sitting, dealing with garbage bins, walking dogs). I didnt mind at first, but now Im being asked several times a week, often at the last minute and for much longer than originally requested (one hour turns to five). I feel like a lousy neighbor when I refuse, but even that hasnt deterred the guilt-trippers. Any advice?J. C., Baltimore

title: Laurie Metcalf Coming to Broadway in The Other Place
description: The 2013 Tony Awards race for best actress in a play has begun. Starting in December the Emmy-winning actress Laurie Metcalf (Roseanne) will reprise her acclaimed performance as a drug-industry businesswoman who unravels emotionally in The Other Place, a psychological drama by Sharr White that ran off Broadway in 2011 and will be remounted on Broadway by Manhattan Theater Club, the organization confirmed on Thursday. Ms. Metcalf, who is currently drawing rave reviews in London playing Mary Tyrone in Long Days Journey Into Night, won an Obie Award and a Lucille Lortel Award last year for The Other Place; hers was the sort of performance that often draws Tony Awards attention but The Other Place wasnt eligible because only Broadway productions are considered for Tonys.

description: LUXEMBOURG  Euro area countries must share debt and use rescue funds to recapitalize troubled banks directly to ensure the survival of the currency union, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said late Thursday.

description: BATAVIA, Ohio  The tumor grew like a thick vine up the back of Eric Richters leg, reminding him every time he sat down that he was a man without insurance. In April, when it was close to bursting through his skin, he went to the emergency room. Doctors told him it was malignant and urged surgery.

description: My colleague loved performing surgery as much as anyone I had ever met. Every morning he bounded into the hospital, full of energy and cheerful anticipation of the days surgical schedule, his prominent mouth stretched into a broad grin.

title: Health Care Confusion
description: The Timess Abby Goodnough reported today that right-wing groups have spent $235 million on ads attacking President Obamas health-care law  and seem to have gotten their moneys worth. People hate the law, they dont understand it, they think its something that will hurt, oppress and bankrupt them  even when it wont.

title: Laughs From the Comics Perspective
description: While Seinfeld was famously about nothing, last season Louie often seemed to be about everything, whether it was grappling with our countrys history of racism or the inexplicable torture of unrequited love. Yet what makes this FX show the best comedy on television  and its third season, which has its premiere on Thursday, the cultural event I am most excited about this summer  is how it manages to tackle big, complicated issues through a very small prism. The specificity of the New York stand-up comedy world that Louis C. K. presents on this show lets him explore universal themes without becoming abstract, overly cerebral or ever less than intensely funny.

title: Big Banks Brace for Credit Rating Downgrades
description: Moodys Investors Service has begun notifying some big banks that their credit ratings may get cut as early as this afternoon.

title: Blunt Memories of Celluloid Life
description: The energy source for Laura Moriartys new novel, The Chaperone, is its secondary character: Louise Brooks, at the age of 15. This book is really about the older woman enlisted to accompany Louise to New York from Wichita, Kan., during the summer of 1922. Louise was going to study dance. The womans job was to keep Louise on the path of virtue. As if.

title: 36 Hours in Kiev, Ukraine
description: AFTER seven decades of Soviet dominance, Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, has emerged as one of Europes most vibrant 21st-century cities. With a thriving contemporary art scene, a new generation of chefs taking innovative approaches to Ukrainian cuisine, and a delirious dance-til-dawn night life, Kiev  currently a co-host of the 2012 European Soccer Championship  is a weekend magnet for European and Russian fashionistas. But new cuisine and clubs are only the latest cultural attributes of a city that has more than its share of ancient catacombs, churches and monuments. Dont let Kievs reputation as the birthplace of the Slavs conjure up stereotypes of Slavic dourness. For starters, the city looks as if it was painted like a Ukrainian Easter egg, with brightly colored buildings and gold domes glittering on the hills above the Dnieper River. And then there are the Kievans themselves  a resilient lot whose hearty sense of humor and a seemingly boundless hunger for fun are reflected in the citys bustling cafes, thronged beaches and bars that never close.

title: Lively Kiev, Ukraine
description: Discover the citys pulsing clubs, arresting architecture, skimpy urban beachwear and more.

title: Inspired Creation, Found in a Desert
description: If I had a camper, I would load it up with big bottles of water at the end of this summer and head to the Black Rock Desert in Nevada for the annual Burning Man festival, which runs from Aug. 27 through Sept. 3  that is, had I been smart enough to secure a ticket long ago. Attendance is capped at 60,900, and the event is sold out.

title: Fund-Raising Fairness Is Being Tested in Oregon, With Mixed Results
Vintage Pynchon Goes Electronic
description: Fifteen years after it was first published, Thomas Pynchons Mason & Dixon remains his most emotionally affecting novel and a dazzling, encyclopedic showcase for his talents: his ability to mix the philosophical with the slapstick, the playfully postmodern with the old-fashioned picaresque; his delight in language and narrative sleight of hand; his Swiftian knack for satire; and his storytellers ability to fuse history and science and fable with ardor and panache.

title: Dreaming Up Whole New Carbon Markets
description: Normally, when supporters of renewable energy talk about carbon markets, theyre referring to a system of traded credits that industries buy to compensate for their emissions of greenhouse gases, like the ones already sold in Europe and under development in California and Canada. But at the Renewable Energy Finance Forum-Wall Street, an annual conference organized by the American Council on Renewable Energy, the talk on Wednesday was of developing a different kind of carbon market where the gas would be bought and sold like a commodity to encourage carbon capture.

title: Dispatches from Rio: None from Obama?
description: I understand why President Obama is not going to the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development in Rio, which is a reprise of the 1992 Earth Summit there at which President George H. W. Bush and nearly all the worlds leaders appeared. (Hes skipping the conference despite taking direct heat in a YouTube message to Rio from Senator James Inhofe, the Republican of Oklahoma and steadfast ally of big coal, and indirect heat from Senator John Kerry, the Democrat of Massachusetts who gave a long floor speech on global warming and the Rio meeting yesterday, decrying the conspiracy of silence that now characterizes Washingtons handling of the climate issue.)

title: Radiohead Postpones European Shows
description: The stage collapse that killed a Radiohead crew member last Saturday in Toronto also destroyed the bands sophisticated light show, forcing the British group to postpone seven concerts in Europe over the next two weeks while repairs are made, the band said on Thursday in a statement. That means Radiohead will skip a swing through the Italian cities of Rome, Florence, Bologna and Codroipo, a two-night stand in Berlin and a stop at Canton de Vaud in Switzerland.It will resume the tour in Nimes, France, on July 10.

title: Banner Days
description: His dashing ascot billowing, his flat cap perched just so (to hide his bald spot), the cleft-chinned Harry Hay had some impressive head shots. As a student at Stanford in the early 1930s, he had come out to his classmates as temperamental, code for homosexual. In 1934, having dropped out of Stanford and moved to Los Angeles to try a career in pictures  and having already begun to hone his identity as sensualist and agitator  he joined the Communist Party. Around 1936, he turned up at a Halloween party dressed as the demise of fascism. The other homosexual bons vivants were stumped: none were terribly turned on to politics, so none knew what Harrys costume meant. These men, and others like them across America, had no core ideology, no political groups to join, no leaders. Hay changed that. In 1950, he helped create the Mattachine Society, the countrys first gay rights organization, and demanded that the people it represented be respected for our differences, not for our sameness to heterosexuals.

description: Mitt Romney spoke on President Obama's most recent changes to immigration policy in an interview with Bob Schieffer.

title: How Can a Big Gulp Look So Small?
description: This column appears in the June 24 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Preview: Germany vs. Greece
description: One of the most famous Monty Python sketches, featured on the Goal blog earlier this week is a simple soccer match between Germany and Greece entitled International Philosophy. The twist in this timeless gag is that the two squads are built with classical thinkers from both nations illustrious cultural past, as they do their best to not only beat each other in the game, but to outwit and out think their opponents.

title: Ultra-Orthodox Men Charged With Trying to Silence Accuser
description: The Brooklyn district attorney, facing a wave of public criticism about his handling of sexual abuse allegations in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, on Thursday charged four men with attempting to silence an accuser by offering her and her boyfriend a $500,000 bribe, and threatening her boyfriends business.

title: A Darkening Jobs Picture
description: The jobs picture is darkening. The latest batch of economic data has been fairly weak, especially surveys from the manufacturing sector. As a result, The Timess weekly jobs tracker, based on forecasts from Moodys Analytics, now shows a projected employment gain of only 125,000 in June, down from a projection of 150,000 last week.

title: New Faces for a Familiar Festival
description: My last visit to the Newport Folk Festival was 10 years ago, when Bob Dylan made his long-awaited return, bringing a heavy dose of mystique and a fainter trace of closure. He hadnt played Newport since 1965  the year Dylan Went Electric, as lore would have it, raising the stakes for rock n roll artistry and planting a stake in the heart of the folk revival. Of course the rift was never really that simple, and the reunion was no act of penitence. In 2002 Mr. Dylan showed up in a fake beard and a cowboy suit and, backed by his whip-smart band, played a proud, locomotive set.

title: Google Aims to Smooth the Path for Android Developers
description: Android is the top operating system in mobile, but Android app developers dont seem to be making much money compared to Apple iOS developers. New statistics reinforce this trend.

description: High temperatures marked the second day of summer in New York City.

title: Yopparai
description: Inside the modest sake bar located in a repurposed Lower East Side railroad apartment.

title: Sizzling Hybrid of Rhythms
description: Arty and wild-eyed impulses are both part of any bohemia worth its creative juice, and in Brooklyn they regularly connect in music. The Afro-Punk Festival, which reaches its 10th year this summer (after Tropical Storm Irene canceled what would have been a ninth appearance last year), loudly celebrates both sides of its hyphen, among other subcultural hybrids. Along with music, there are skateboarding and BMX biking competitions.

title: Portrait of Bacon-Freud Back Up for Auction
description: LONDON  The e-mail blast was sent late last month. An exciting new discovery at Christies, read a statement from Francis Outred, the head of the postwar and contemporary art department in Europe for Christies. Mr. Outred was describing a 1964 painting by Francis Bacon, Study for Self-Portrait, which he said was the only full-length self-portrait to combine Bacons face with the body of his friend the painter Lucian Freud.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Gaza, Indonesia and Greece.

title: A Sake Bar Best Taken in Small Sips
description: IT feels illicit, to be hovering here on the crumbly stoop of a Lower East Side tenement. Press the buzzer, and a voice, garbled, exacts your name. The doorknob clicks, and you blink a moment in the bright foyer, until a pocket door skids open and a figure in black, behind a curtain of ropes, beckons.

title: In Magazine Interview, Curry Talks of Future on Today
description: Little more than a month ago, Ann Curry told a magazine interviewer that she saw herself spending the next five years on the Today show, where she was a news anchor for 14 years before becoming a co-host last year.

title: The Truth Is Out There, but Maybe Not in Here
description: The novelist Edmund White has called biography the most middle class of all forms, the judgment of little people avenging themselves on the great.

title: Cures for Blockbusteritis, Even in the Land of Hollywood
description: Each summer Hollywood swamps the countrys movie theaters with its biggest, often most blockheaded blockbusters, flooding thousands of screens with the usual loud bangs, broad laughs, high concepts, low returns, remakes, reboots and foolishly resurrected bad ideas. The summer can feel especially endless in Los Angeles, where I live, because the entire city and its environs  from car-clogged street to street, from looming billboard to billboard  transform into one continuous advertisement for new releases that youre not sure you want to see but probably will (even if you dont make a living watching them).

title: Can Come Back
description: The German experimental-rock group Can has never been obscure. Though not quite a household name here in the States, Can recorded several European hits in the years they were together, 1968 to 1979. They have also had an impact on a diverse group of musicians, from David Bowie to Brian Eno to Radiohead, and pioneered whole styles of music that their followers later expanded upon. This week, Mute Records releases The Lost Tapes, a three-CD box set containing over 180 minutes of previously unissued material. More than a great listen, the set solidifies both Cans oeuvre and their approach to music making as far-reaching influences.

title: Romeos and Juliets
description: Three ballerinas are playing Juliet in Kenneth MacMillans Romeo and Juliet.

title: Street Hustlers, in All Their Glamour and Grit
description: In Paris in the mid-1950s the Swedish photographer Christer Strmholm (1918-2002) gravitated to the red-light district around the Place Blanche, where he was drawn to a subculture of cross-dressing young men, many of whom worked as prostitutes to earn enough money for sex-change operations. The stocky, middle-aged photographer with a beard and military haircut hung out with them for more than a decade and photographed them on the street at night and in bars and hotel rooms with a coolly affectionate eye.

title: A Tool for Selecting the Best Cash-Back Credit Card
description: There are lots of cash-back credit cards out there, but its often difficult to know which one may work best for you, based on your personal spending patterns. Some cards offer initial bonuses, as well as rotating categories of purchases that can earn more cash back. So its hard to compare them without doing a lot of number-crunching.

title: Chinese Dissident Artist Ends Yearlong Probation
description: BEIJING  Ai Weiwei, the Chinese rebel artist, said Thursday that his one-year probation had ended but that the police had told him he could not leave China because of continuing investigations.

title: Leaving the Figure Behind
description: Approaching Abstraction, at the Rubin Museum, tries to put an Eastern phenomenon in a Western box. It doesnt always work, but theres much to be learned from the effort. It helps to let go of the Euro-American idea that abstraction is purely a formal phenomenon; in Indian modernism it can also be a rupture in narrative.

title: Long-Missing Proposal Found Close to Home
description: A 1940s proposal for a childrens picture book turned up a few months ago in forgotten files in London, after scholars had spent decades hunting for it as far away as Iceland. The illustrator Eric Ravilious was finishing the images when he was killed in a Royal Air Force plane crash in 1942, at 39.

title: The Times Co. Names 2 Directors, Including Joi Ito, Internet Entrepreneur
description: The New York Times Company, continuing its efforts to move forward in a more digitally focused news media industry, has added two members with extensive technology backgrounds to its board.

title: The Shard and the NYT Tower
description: When the Olympic Games are off and running on TV next month, viewers are sure to see lots of shots of the Shard, which topped out recently. Thats the new London tower above, in a picture taken by the photographer Chris Levine for the magazine earlier this year. (In that same London issue the novelist China Miville provided a word-picture equivalent: The spine of the Shard soars over South London accumulating glass as if its in solution, growing crystals.) When, as the BBC notes, youve got the tallest building in Western Europe  somewhere in Eastern Europe something looms taller, I guess  you can expect it to be the focus of much attention.

title: At Seasons End, a Flourish and a Glimpse of Whats to Come
description: The last subscription program of the New York Philharmonics current season began Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, but it would be understandable if you had failed to notice it. Not to sell the program short  Alan Gilbert led as majestic a Mozart performance as anyone might want, with the kind of guests that would make cognoscenti sit up and take notice.

title: Cellulite and 2nd Chances as the Stuff of a Revue
description: Step aside, all you apple-cheeked newspaper boys and American idiots, you little mermaids and littler orphans. The grown-ups have something to say. You may want to take some notes  and not just because youll be one of them soon enough.

title: In Men in Black 3, Court Street Is Dismissed
description: In May of last year, Court Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was transported back in time for a few days.

title: So Sayeth the Anchorman
description: Its not enough to be right; everyone else must be wrong.

title: Look Up to the Heavens and Listen
description: As throngs of musicians and listeners, professional and amateur, looked forward to Make Music New York  an annual daylong, citywide celebration of the summer solstice on Thursday  the Hayden Planetarium, with its proprietary interest in the phenomenon, stole a march on Wednesday evening. Part of the American Museum of Natural History, the planetarium presented Summer Solstice, a collaboration between the Cassatt String Quartet and Carter Emmart, the museums director of astrovisualization and the wizard behind the curtain of the Digital Universe, the museums compilation of data gathered from astronomical catalogs and other sources.

title: Kimmel Is Lifted to Late-Night Victory by N.B.A. Tie-Ins
description: ABCs all-out commitment to pushing Jimmy Kimmels late-night show during its coverage of the N.B.A. finals paid off last week with the best ratings for the show in five years, and a first: Mr. Kimmel topped both Jay Leno and David Letterman in the most important late-night ratings category.

title: On Vacation and Sick? A Court Says Take Another
description: BRUSSELS  For most Europeans, almost nothing is more prized than their four to six weeks of guaranteed annual vacation leave. But it was not clear just how sacrosanct that time off was until Thursday, when Europes highest court ruled that workers who happened to get sick on vacation were legally entitled to take another vacation.

title: Late-Night Drinks With a Pianist
description: A Little Night Music is the apt title for the Mostly Mozart Festivals popular series of late-night programs in the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. The success of this seemingly modest venture shows that it does not take much to freshen up the protocols of classical music and entice audiences. People sit at small round tables with complimentary wine, taking in starry views of the city. The programs begin at 10:30 and last about an hour. Audiences have relished the chance to hear a string quartet or a singer, a Baroque vocal group or a contemporary music ensemble, in this intimate, relaxed setting.

title: Submerging in an Ocean of Sound
description: In a way, the New York Philharmonics Philharmonic 360 program at the Park Avenue Armory is a classical music critics summer escapist fantasy: The orchestra, freed from the formal atmosphere and mediocre acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall, moves across town to the cavernous armory to present a program far quirkier and more adventurous than anything it does during the regular season.

title: Song and Dance, and Gender, in Dido
description: The revival of Henry Purcells opera Dido and Aeneas at the Mostly Mozart Festival promises to be an arresting event, even for the blind: While the Mark Morris production occurs onstage, the extraordinary mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe, placed with the musicians, will sing the Sorceress, as well as Dido, with her large, dramatic, dark but mobile voice, which can sound like molten lava.

title: Respectful Heirs Together Invoking Playful Spirits
description: When K T Sullivan swept onto the stage of the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesday evening with mischief in her eyes and a swivel in her hips, the image of Mae West flashed in my mind. Like West, Ms. Sullivan is voluptuous, blond and funny  and ageless. But Ms. Sullivan has a softer edge. Overt carnality is smothered in soap bubbles. Widening her saucer eyes and wearing a half-smile, a zany hat tilted just so, she projected an ebullient va-va-voom that camouflaged the vigilance of a performer on whom nothing is lost.

title: Slaying With Silver in 19th-Century South
description: Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter is such a smashing title its too bad someone had to spoil things by making a movie to go with it. Then again, a big-screen version of Seth Grahame-Smiths comic novel was doubtless inevitable, given the delectable absurdity of the 16th president of the United States going all Buffy on a vamp army, splitting heads like rails. That sounds funny, and for a while it plays like head-exploding gangbusters on screen, particularly when the young Mr. Lincoln (a solid Benjamin Walker), in his grasshopper stage, begins learning how to swing a silver-tipped ax like a kung fu master. (As the great man said: Whatever you are, be a good one.)

title: In Kampala, Classics Have Their Day in the Sun
description: Julia Mayersohn bravely and graciously attended numerous collector-car shows with Norman Mayersohn, her father and the deputy editor of the Automobiles section, while growing up in New Jersey. She lives and works in Kampala, Uganda.

title: A Teams Never-Ending Olympic Trials
description: Roman Catholics are supposed to hate the sin but love the sinner. Viewers can love sports and still hate the Olympics.

title: Visions of the 80s Storming Back
description: Nostalgia for the 1990s supplanted nostalgia for the 80s a couple of years ago, but lately the tides been shifting back: Reagan in political discourse, shimmery dance music on the radio, the crack plotline on Girls.

title: Q & A
description: Sponsor Withholds Maintenance

title: Romney on Immigration at NALEO
description: Mitt Romney spoke on immigration at the NALEO conference in Florida.

title: Increased Interest in Expanded HARP
description: MORE homeowners who are underwater, or owe more on their homes than they are worth, have been taking advantage of an expanded Home Affordable Refinance Program to refinance their loans and obtain lower interest rates, according to a recent government report.

title: Krzyzewski Wouldnt Mind if Finals Ended Tonight
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Count Mike Krzyzewski among the more interested observers in the remainder of the N.B.A. finals, which could end Thursday night, which would be just fine with Krzyzewski, the Duke coach. His rooting interest lies with neither Miami nor Oklahoma City, but more with time  time off, time to heal and time to prepare.

title: Mitt Romneys Positions on Immigration
description: A video feature examines how Mitt Romney has had to finesse his position on illegal immigration as he pivots towards the general election.

title: Spare Times  For Children for June 22-29
description: FAMILY DAY

title: For Teenage Heroes, Morphin Time Again
description: Every five years or so, a fad comes along that separates parents from their children but that, a decade or two later, those parents come to understand. What is a Monkee, and why are you and your friends endlessly debating which one is coolest? mothers and fathers all over the land were asking back in 1966. Yet before long, Monkees songs were turning up as elevator music.

title: Excerpt: As You Like It
description: Lily Rabe and David Furr in a scene from the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: Moodys Cuts Credit Ratings of 15 Big Banks
description: 10:33 p.m. | Updated Already grappling with weak profits and global economic turmoil, 15 major banks were hit with credit downgrades on Thursday that could do more damage to their bottom lines and further unsettle equity markets.

title: Whisk Opens Another Cookware Shop
description: When creativity hits, cooking often provides release. Take Natasha Amott, who decided four years ago that working with finance in the nonprofit sector did not inspire her. So she opened Whisk, a cookware store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. On Friday, shell add a larger outlet in the Flatiron district that goes somewhat beyond the offerings in Brooklyn.

title: Back Onstage, and Showing No Mercy
description: Hamminess, sloppiness, fatuity, inanity and, if were lucky, all-out insanity: such are the attributes that make a bad Broadway show so satisfying for people with a taste for turkey. In recent years mainstream New York theater certainly hasnt been lacking in productions that embody those essential traits. And disaster cultists who train their sights on Broadway thank the New York theater for continuing to deliver such abundance.

title: Time Machines, Always Cool
description: Fans of the modern Doctor Who  the fast-paced, high-tech, hyper-verbal science-fiction series that will begin its seventh season later this year  most likely know that the show has a long, storied and intensely codified history, stretching back 49 years and nearly 800 episodes. But if theyre American, the odds are good that theyve never seen the shows earlier incarnation, which ran on the BBC from 1963 to 1989.

title: From 20 Critics, a Ticket to Summer
description: SUMMER sauntered in this week and it wants to play. What will make its desultory heart race, its toes tap, its synapses fire in the steamy idle hours that stretch ahead? What movie, what concert, what play, what book, what TV show, what dance, what high art or low comedy? We asked 20 arts critics for The New York Times to share the one thing on, or inspired by, the cultural calendar that they most looked forward to. Their answers  your guide to a summer of entertainment  are below.

title: Lincoln Center Turns Dramatically Irish
description: The Lincoln Center Festivals rich roster of theater offerings this year includes a couple of promising star turns: a one-man Macbeth starring Alan Cumming, and Cate Blanchett portraying the languid, dissatisfied Yelena in Uncle Vanya. But the production Im most looking forward to is DruidMurphy, a cycle of three plays by the contemporary Irish writer Tom Murphy, presented by the Druid Theater Company of Galway.

title: Its Secretariat, Faster Today Than in 1973
description: Secretariat, the racehorse synonymous in most peoples minds with thoroughbred greatness, broke many records in his career. The latest fell only this week.

title: 33 Acres of Privacy for $65 Million
description: WHAT could be better than a sprawling home in one of the Hamptons most exclusive enclaves on the banks of the tranquil Sagg Pond, with sweeping views of the ocean? What if that home sat on one of the largest parcels of privately owned land in the area  33 acres to be exact  and was bordered by dozens of acres of protected land, ensuring privacy and pristine conditions in perpetuity?

title: Artwork That Runs Like Clockwork
description: This summer the city that never sleeps will have another glimpse of an artwork that doesnt relent much either: The Clock, a spellbinding, time-telling 24-hour wonder of film and sound montage by Christian Marclay, the polymath composer, collagist, video artist and pioneer turntablist.

title: A Tenuous Coalition Government Takes Reins in Greece
description: ATHENS  Greeces new coalition government, sworn in on Thursday, declared that its chief goals were to tackle the crisis, pave the way for growth and revise the terms of the loan agreement without endangering the countrys European course and its position in the euro zone.

title: Online Sale Picks for June 21
description: Give your wallet a break this week and get ready to beat the Web shopping sharks for some great markdowns. Review our online and sample sale picks of the week.

title: Politics as Performance, an Evolving Art
description: Artists have always blurred the lines among art, life and politics. Joseph Beuys planted thousands of trees as ecological sculpture. Gordon Matta-Clark stockpiled useless slivers of Manhattan real estate to illustrate the absurdity of property ownership. The tradition continues in the work of the Cuban-born artist Tania Bruguera, who has created the equivalent of a full-time performance piece called the Immigrant Movement International in Corona, Queens.

title: Where Holograms Are Hopping Again
description: Holograms havent been cool for a long time. Im old enough to remember when they were, at least to a 1980s kid raised on Star Wars and Jem and the Holograms. Somehow theyve been left out of the great 3-D revival, confined to credit cards, scanners and other useful but dull items.

title: Spare Times for June 22-29
description: LUMEN 2012 (Saturday) It wasnt until February that Christopher Eamon, the curator of Lumen festival on Staten Island, knew that the mountains of salt werent going anywhere. This free festival, dedicated to video, interactive and performance art, is being held from 6 p.m. until midnight at the Atlantic Salt Company, which provides New York with road salt. This years mild winter meant the mounds didnt budge. So Mr. Eamon and Melanie Cohn, executive director of the Council on the Arts and Humanities for Staten Island, the festivals sponsor, decided to use the 150,000 tons of salt as a canvas. The biggest mound will serve as a screen for projections  Marco Brambillas re-creation of the lunar landing, and a neon salt digger courtesy of a Brooklyn artist, Jeanne Verdoux, who made the cut in a local open call. The others will be surrounded by performances and site-specific installations. Were going to shape the salt in various formations and do something like a salt Zen garden, Mr. Eamon said via Skype on Tuesday.

title: When Graphic Novelists Go Where Photographers Cant
description: Sometimes circumstance dictates how we treat our articles visually. Often, for example, photography is not practicable for reasons of danger or an inability to capture past events. Were then forced to find a solution that not only depicts a sense of place but also helps tell the story.

title: Five Romeos and Five Juliets: Sweet Sorrow and Star Turns
description: Star quality: I dont know what it is, but Ive got it. The words are Nol Cowards and Star Quality is the title of the marvelous Coward show at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It is also epitomized by three international ballerinas performing next door at Lincoln Center as part of American Ballet Theaters current season.

description: Derek Eller Gallery

description: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

description: A day after George Zimmerman killed Trayvon Martin, he was interviewed on video by a detective.

description: A group of retired N.F.L. players has asked that the players association be expelled from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for failing to represent the retirees interests.

description: Jazz

description: Pop

title: Developer to Revive a Project in Brooklyn
description: A planned $1.4 billion residential development at the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn that was given up for dead last year took on new life on Thursday when a new developer signed a contract to buy the property.

description: Movies

title: Putin Seeks to Reassure Foreign Investors
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  After a series of hard-line moves and statements after his re-election this spring, President Vladimir V. Putin softened his approach during a speech to foreign investors on Thursday.

title: Theater Listings for June 22-29
description: Theater

title: U.S. to Play at Mexico in August
description: It is called a friendly, but usually it is everything but when the United States and Mexico take up occupancy on the same soccer field.

title: For Some Who Served, an Awful Betrayal of Trust
description: The documentary filmmaker Kirby Dick has become one of the indispensable muckrakers of American cinema, zeroing in on frequently painful stories about how power functions in the absence or failure of accountability. Twist of Faith (2004) was about a young man seeking some measure of justice after being sexually abused, as a child, by a priest. This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006) focused on the secretive, often inexplicable workings of the Motion Picture Association of Americas ratings board. Outrage (2009) pointed a finger at the sexual hypocrisy of the political class.

title: Designing a Synagogue for a Gay Congregation, With Acoustics in Mind
description: Since 1973, Congregation Beit Simchat Torah has tried to reconcile traditions transmitted across the millenniums with traditions that its members  gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Jews  have often had to make up on the fly, battling hostility, indifference and the AIDS epidemic at the same time.

title: Romneys Immigration Speech
description: Mitt Romney gave his big speech on immigration policy today and announced his big idea: He said the U.S. should offer a path to legal status for undocumented immigrants who were brought here as children by their parents.

title: Different Ways of Looking at Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Steak and Pie From the Automat, Back Then
description: To the Editor:

title: 47 Pit Bulls, Bred for Fighting, Are Rescued in the Bronx
description: Forty-seven pit bulls, bred for fighting, lived crammed in a basement-level apartment in the Bronx, the police said. They stayed in cages, some two to a cage, and, the police said, some of them might never have seen the sun before Thursday afternoon.

title: Reading and Guilty Pleasure
description: As we move into the summer season of beach and hammock reading, many of us reach for books that we describe as guilty pleasures. This notion has become an important category in our thinking about literature. Two prominent examples are NPRs regular feature My Guilty Pleasure and Arthur Krystals recent New Yorker essay, Easy Writers: Guilty pleasures without guilt.

title: What Kind of Church?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stop-and-Frisk, Through the Prisms of Race and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: The Risk of Concussions in Young Football Players
description: To the Editor:

title: This Neck of the Woods, Please
description: FOR Nelson Aspen, only one neighborhood would do. His new place had to lie within a certain chunk of the Upper West Side  the West 60s or the low West 70s.

title: Apocalypse? Road Trip!
description: If you are seeking a movie about the end of the world, you have a lot of choices. There are the sturdy, old, large-scale disaster epics, of course, but lately the trend has been toward more intimate studies of apocalypse, Lars von Triers Melancholia and Abel Ferraras 4:44 Last Day on Earth being two notable recent examples.

title: A Battle Over Faculty Housing
description: Princeton

title: Deed Mutes Protest in Ridgefield
description: RIDGEFIELD

title: Old Neighborhood, New Life
description: EMILY De NICOLO has lived in Manhattan for the last 14 years. But as she and her husband, Jay Della Monica, prepare for the arrival of their first child, in August, city life is looking more and more like a thing of the past. In fact, the couple are anticipating a future in Port Washington, Ms. De Nicolos childhood home.

title: As Roomy as a Town House
description: ABOVE a side entrance to the Abingdon, a newly converted condominium building at 320 West 12th Street in the West Village, are carved the words Laura Spelman Hall, a reminder of the 1905 structures early life as a home for working women. It was later a nursing home, with beds for 200 residents.

title: Changing the World, a Picture at a Time
description: A great passion fired up the Photo League, a group of mostly young New York photographers who, beginning in the 1930s and right up until the groups abrupt end in 1951, believed that they could change the world with their cameras and the righteousness of their own beliefs. The groups story  shaped by art and politics, some unexpected heroes and the periods usual lineup of red-baiting villains  is the subject of Ordinary Miracles: The Photo Leagues New York, an alternately stirring and stolid documentary directed by Daniel Allentuck and Nina Rosenblum, and narrated by Campbell Scott.

title: As You Like It
description: Scenes from the Shakespeare in the Park production.

title: A Delightfully Oddball Block
description: NOT all great New York blocks are end-to-end mansions. A case in point is the short stretch of West 75th between Broadway and West End Avenue, a curious mix of bedraggled row houses and spiffed-up town houses, of Tudor prewars and white brick apartment houses. If you need a big, fancy street, this isnt it; in fact, its just the opposite.

title: Les Amies de Place Blanche
description: Christer Strmholms photographs are the subject of a new show at the International Center of Photography.

title: Ronaldos Latest Masterpiece Puts Portugal in Semifinals
description: WARSAW

title: Hank Williamss Swan Song
description: The urge to romanticize popular artists who die young is a powerful one, and movies about their all-too-brief lives are often buffered by their subjects lingering charisma and ardent fan bases. Such is the case with The Last Ride, Harry Thomasons dreary imagining of the final days in the troubled life of Hank Williams, the music legend whose death on New Years Day 1953, at 29, has reverberated for more than half a century.

title: New MSNBC Show Will Feature a Panel of Political Pundits
description: MSNBCs plan for a new 3 p.m. program is illustrative of a cable news trend. Its an ensemble show with a cast of four fresh-faced political pundits.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Seafood Shop
description: For 40 years, this Wainscott standby has offered some of the freshest fish on the East End. The Hamptons have changed  fewer fishing boats, more yachts  but the shop hasnt much.

title: Transgender Athlete Fails to Qualify
description: BEAVERTON, Ore.  Keelin Godsey, a 28-year-old from Massachusetts who was seeking to become the first openly transgender athlete to represent the United States at the Olympics, failed to qualify for the London Games in the womens hammer throw competition held here Thursday.

title: Taliban Attack Lakeside Resort Hotel Near Kabul, Taking Families Hostage
description: QARGHA LAKE, Afghanistan  As families ate a late dinner at a popular lakeside resort hotel here on a warm summer night, at least three Taliban shot their way into the compound, entered the dining room and took an unknown number of hostages, Afghan officials said early Friday.

title: Shes Not His Mother
description: A damaged loner and a romantically hopeful virgin enjoy an unlikely bond in Nate & Margaret, Nathan Adloffs tart-sweet tale of cross-generational friendship.

title: The First Picture Show in a Tipperary Town
description: Stella Days opens with the last rites and closes with a first for a tiny rural parish in Tipperary, Ireland: a movie theater. In between boil all sorts of shenanigans, most of them in the vicinity of Father Daniel Barry (Martin Sheen), a well-traveled priest on loan from the Vatican. More progressive than his bishop or parishioners would like, the good father soon learns that electricity and enlightenment are to be equally distrusted.

title: Should Air-Conditioning Go Global, or Be Rationed Away?
Where Fishermen See Stars
description: WHERE, on the endless drive from New York City to the Hamptons, does the weekend really begin?

title: Can You Say That on TV? Broadcasters Arent Sure
description: WASHINGTON  Imagine a world where it would be O.K. to use particularly foul language in an e-mail sent from your smartphone, but where you would be fined if you uttered the same words during a phone call.

title: A.I.G. Installs New Chairman at Plane-Leasing Unit
description: The American International Group said on Thursday that it had named a new executive chairman of its plane-leasing unit, the International Lease Finance Corporation, following an investigation into a relationship between the divisions chief executive and another employee.

title: Good News From Down Under
description: It will soon be much safer to be a fish in Australia, now that the country is planning to turn nearly one-third of its coastal waters into the worlds largest network of marine preserves. The plan would restrict fishing and oil and gas drilling in a patchwork totaling 1.2 million square miles, including the Coral Sea and the Great Barrier Reef.

title: Spains Chief Justice Quits Over Claims of Misusing Public Money
description: MADRID  Spains image suffered another blow on Thursday when the chief justice of the Supreme Court resigned after being accused by a fellow judge of claiming vacations as business expenses.

title: Imprisoned Over 20 Years, Brooklyn Man Gets Retrial
description: After spending more than two decades in prison saying he was not guilty of murder, a Brooklyn man won a new trial this week after an appellate court vacated his conviction based on evidence that another man might have committed the crime and that a key trial witness had recanted her testimony.

title: Ex-Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Rape Charges
description: A former New York City police officer who was convicted in March of sexually attacking a schoolteacher at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan pleaded guilty on Thursday to rape counts that were left unresolved by a jury.

title: To Settle Lawsuit, Facebook Alters Policy for Its Like Button
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Complicating its efforts to accelerate advertising revenue, Facebook has agreed to make it clear to users that when they click to like a product on Facebook, their names and photos can be used to plug the product. They will also be given a chance to decline the opportunity to be unpaid endorsers.

title: Drug Kingpins Son Is Arrested in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A man believed to be the son of Mexicos most-wanted drug trafficker has been detained by the Mexican Navy, one of a series of recent moves aimed at toppling the elusive kingpin, Mexican officials said Thursday.

title: A Walking Course in Tel Avivs Graffiti
description: Guy Sharett teaches Hebrew on the streets and alleys of the Florentin neighborhood of Tel Aviv, along the way deciphering a new vocabulary of politics, art and subculture scrawled on the walls.

title: As Growth Ebbs, Brazil Powers Up Its Bulldozers
description: IPOJUCA, Brazil  More than 40,000 laborers swarm the port complex here in northeast Brazil, building a refinery for the state oil company. Five thousand others toil at a shipyard, another government-led project. Real estate prices are soaring and unemployment is falling in this region along the Atlantic coast, once known for its festering poverty.

title: Learning Hebrew on the Streets, With Walls as Assigned Reading
description: TEL AVIV  The texts, written on metal grates, stone walls and neon signs, sometimes disappear from one class to the next. The themes are pluralism, economic justice and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict  and grammar, always a little grammar thrown in.

title: Chief Justice Offers Hint at New Timing for Health Care Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday indicated that it is likely to go into overtime next week, as the nation awaits its decisions in challenges to President Obamas health care law and a tough Arizona immigration law.

title: Google Maps Where Your Workers Are
description: Workplace hooky, a hallowed tradition that put so many salesmen into movie matinees between customer calls, is so Web 1.0.

title: Britain: A Historic Address
description: Myanmars opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, urged British leaders to support moves toward openness in her country as she became the first person who was not a head of state to address Parliament on Thursday. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyis visit to Britain, where she once lived with her husband and children, was her first in more than two decades. She endured long periods of house arrest in Myanmar, or Burma, but refused to leave when she had the chance, fearing that she would be denied re-entry. I am here in part to ask for practical help, she said, addressing a hall packed with Britains political elite, in support of the reforms which can bring better lives, greater opportunities, to the people of Burma who have been for so long deprived of their rights and their place in the world. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel laureate and now a lawmaker, also met with Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: With a Four-Under 66, Simpson Keeps Smiling
description: CROMWELL, Conn.  The sound of cheers reverberated Thursday from the first tee at T.P.C. River Highlands, where they greeted the marquee group of Keegan Bradley, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson as they began the first round of the Travelers Championship.

title: Billions of Dollars Are in Play Over Health Care Law
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.  In this small city about an hour from Manhattan, pregnant teenagers, laid-off professionals and day laborers without insurance receive care at a community health center that has been part of the social fabric here for nearly four decades.

title: At Googles Annual Meeting, Silence From Larry Page
description: Larry Page was missing in action Thursday at Googles annual meeting because he had lost his voice. Eric Schmidt, the companys former chief executive and now executive chairman, pinch-hit. Mr. Schmidt did not explain what happened but made clear it was serious enough that Mr. Page had already canceled his appearance at a major Google event for developers next week as well as on the companys quarterly earnings conference call next month.

title: Rangel Seeks to Minimize Any Concern About Age
description: Congressman Charles B. Rangel was celebrating his 82nd birthday, but he appeared eager not to look like an old man.

title: Call Me, Pay Fee
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Sanctions Against Iran
description: It is disappointing but not surprising that two days of negotiations this week failed to produce any real progress toward curbing Irans nuclear program. Iran, always playing the angles, is still trying to figure out how much economic pain it is willing to accept to maintain its nuclear ambitions and what, if anything, it is willing to give up.

title: Normal as Folk
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Customers Do the Selling for Travel Firms
description: PERHAPS not coincidentally in an era of interpersonal, often electronic communication, three travel brands have introduced campaigns based on the concept of a travel diary.

title: Times Names 2 With Broad Technology Experience to Its Board
description: The New York Times Company, continuing its efforts to move forward in a more digitally focused news media industry, has added two members with extensive technology backgrounds to its board.

title: Ratings Downgrade Cuts Deeply at Morgan Stanley
description: As Moodys Investors Service prepared to cut the ratings of some of the worlds biggest financial firms on Thursday, Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James P. Gorman, was in St. Petersburg, Russia. He spoke to a group of business and economic leaders about how banks would have rethink their roles in an environment characterized by more regulation and falling profits.

title: The Schadenfreude Sports Fan
description: Tough week. Blistering heat. Europe on the brink. The activist Supreme Court just days from possibly taking health care away from millions. And then, those diversions of lasting consequence on the court and on the pitch.

title: Level of Music Label Power Is Debated in Senate Hearing
description: Is the music industry like other businesses, and thus subject to concerns about market concentration, or is it an anomaly in which nothing matters but hits?

title: Death in the Desert
description: Watertown, Mass.

title: Californias Trust Act
description: A bill moving through the California Legislature, aptly named the Trust Act, seeks to counter the damage done to community policing and public safety by the Obama administrations Secure Communities program. The program conducts mandatory immigration checks of everyone booked into local jails and has led to the deportations of many thousands of people with no criminal records, while impeding law enforcement.

title: Lottery Numbers
20 Years Later, a New World for the N.B.A.
description: MIAMI

title: For Gatlin, Brash Talk and Renewed Confidence
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Much was made of the recent back-and-forth between the United States sprinter Justin Gatlin and the Jamaican star Usain Bolt. Their brief exchange of trash talk essentially boiled down to Gatlin saying he would happily take charge of bringing a challenge to Bolt, and Bolt saying: I dont want to sound rude or anything, but I think Gatlin had his chance. Thats a funny thing he said. Bolt added that Gatlin has a few guys to get past before he worries about me.

title: As Facebook Seeks Answers, S.E.C. Investigates Exchanges
description: Nasdaq has blamed Facebooks botched debut last month on flawed computers and technical errors.

title: Six-Year Sentence in Theft of Millions in Union Funds
description: By any measure, Melissa G. King lived an extraordinary life, one that far eclipsed her position administering benefit funds for the sandhogs union. She spent millions of dollars on herself, hiring a personal staff, buying expensive clothes and jewelry, and running up about $5 million in equestrian-related expenses, prosecutors have said.

title: Fire Threat Up as Vintage Air Arsenal Shrinks
description: BROOMFIELD, Colo.  With a low roar, the 1954-vintage warplane barreled down the runway and heaved itself into the air, wobbling for a moment as its engines toiled to pull skyward. Theyre not exactly leaping off the runway, said Paul Buxton-Carr, a Canadian pilot, as he watched the potbellied plane, designed to hunt submarines, climb toward its latest mission: dousing wildfires in the American West.

title: Online Outrage Over Bullying of School Bus Monitor
description: Update | 11:55 a.m. Friday, June 22 More than $500,000 has now been raised online for a 68-year-old school bus monitor from Rochester, N.Y., after a cellphone video went viral this week, showing a group of seventh-grade boys on the school bus brutally mocking and taunting her.

title: Democrats Seek New Reports on New Jersey Halfway Houses
description: Democrats in New Jerseys Legislature called for stricter oversight of the states troubled system of halfway houses on Thursday, saying new disclosure requirements would lead to better safety for our communities and the halfway house residents.

title: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President
description: LOS ANGELES  Nearly 3,000 delegates from the nations largest union of state and local government employees gathered here this week. Judging from the talk on the convention floor, one would hardly know that they had experienced a huge defeat this month in their effort to recall Wisconsins governor, or that they faced lawmakers and voters across the country who have grown increasingly unsympathetic to public sector workers.

title: U.S.O.C. Knits a Controversy

title: NBC News Faces Shift in Television Dominance

title: Void for Vagueness

title: To Tackle an Invasive Weed, Bringing In the Hooved Pros
description: On a sweltering afternoon on Staten Island, the New York City parks department unveiled its latest weapon in the war on phragmites, an invasive weed that chokes the shoreline: goats. Twenty Anglo-Nubians, to be exact. With names like Mozart, Haydn and Van Goat, and with floppy ears and plaintive bleats, they did not seem fearsome. But on Thursday they were already munching inexorably through the long pale leaves in the first phase of a wetland restoration at what will soon be Freshkills Park.

title: New Mexico Commission Limits Drug Use in Horse Racing
description: The New Mexico Racing Commission voted unanimously Thursday to limit the use of drugs in the states horse racing industry and to impose tougher penalties on those who run afoul of its drug rules.

title: Romney Exhibits a Change in Tone on Immigration
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants on Thursday than he took during the Republican primary season, but he backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters as he confronted one of the trickiest issues in his efforts to build a broad general election coalition.

The series is a model of investigative reporting, which everyone should read. But it should also be seen in context. The horrors described are part of a broader pattern in which essential functions of government are being both privatized and degraded.

title: Racial Tensions Flare Anew in a Texas Town

Months after the brutal murder here of James Byrd Jr., a black man chained to a pickup truck and dragged to death by three white men on June 7, 1998, the fence was torn down by residents as a sign of unity and reconciliation.

The prosecutor general announced that the satellites were being seized temporarily as part of an investigation into Global Contact Consulting Ltd., a satellite television company in which Mr. Ivanishvilis brother holds a majority stake. The dishes, the statement said, were being handed out to bribe voters; their seizure was approved by the Tbilisi City Court. Mr. Ivanishvili, whose net worth Forbes estimated at $6.2 billion, announced last October that he would finance an opposition movement against President Mikheil Saakashvili.

title: Paris Does Brooklyn
description: Growing up in the Paris suburbs, David Obadia, 23, was obsessed with Nike Air Jordans and the American street-wear brands Supreme and Stussy. Meanwhile, his best friend, Nelson Hassan, 22, was more drawn to the avant-garde looks of Comme des Garons and Raf Simons. No wonder, then, that upon graduation from business school and fashion school, respectively, the duo started their own label, Brooklyn We Go Hard, named for the Jay-Z song. We like everything about Brooklyn, including Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Dr. Browns soda and the Nets, Obadia explains. (He assures that theyve both been there several times.) Brooklyn brings together the mainstream and the underground, which is what we want to do with the clothes. They started in 2010 selling simple white T-shirts embossed with gritty images of New York taken by a handful of Paris photographers, but they gained steam last year when they introduced an elbow-padded sweatshirt (about $140), soft cotton on the inside and nubby wool on the outside, with the motto Brooklyn Parle Franais embroidered across the chest. The sweatshirt got picked up by Colette in Paris, Antonioli in Milan, Urban Research in Tokyo and Opening Ceremony in the United States, and has been worn by the likes of Kid Cudi, who sported it at the Hunger Games premiere, as well as Olivier Nakache, the director of the recent French box-office record-breaker Les Intouchables. (Can you help us get the sweatshirt on Jay-Z or anyone from the Nets? Hassan asks.) Later this month, theyll show their first full collection at the Paris mens Capsule show; the collection includes pieces that would look right at home on the lazily fashionable young men of Bedford Avenue, including chambray shirts with baseball stripes ($100) and reversible cotton knit sweaters that droop on a skinny torso as raffishly as a cigarette from the lips of a Marais bobo ($164). The guys are making the clothes in conjunction with a magazine they publish that, in charmingly bad English, helps foreigners understand such Brooklyn characters as boricuas and Lubavitchers. People in Paris want to be in New York and Tokyo, and vice versa and vice versa, Obadia says. Everybody doesnt want to be where they are.

title: Having It All

The important truth is that there really is more than our society could do to help women (and men) balance their careers and their family lives. Both our workplaces and our public policy arrangements have not kept up with the decline of the single-breadwinner household, and an era of massive female labor force participation requires greater accommodations and adjustments to the reality of childbearing than American society has yet made.

Savoring Human Nature in Random Flux
description: ANDR TCHIN, who turns 70 next year, makes impossibly elegant movies about very messy lives. All the people in his films are in one way or another wanderers, existential transients drifting from relationship to relationship, identity to identity, unable somehow to settle into themselves, and thats just the way Mr. Tchin likes them. Movies like Wild Reeds (1994), Thieves (1996), The Girl on the Train (2009) and the new Unforgivable  his 19th feature, opening Friday  are filled with characters who seem not to have been created but simply found, strays picked up off the street. He offers them a place to rest while they, and he, try to figure out who they are and where theyre going: the house is rambling but beautifully appointed, and the host is gracious, tolerant, tactful. At this point Mr. Tchin has been putting up lost souls for nearly 40 years; he knows what hes doing.
