description: People in New York State will be notified within hours if sewage has been discharged into a waterway under a bill approved on Thursday that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to sign into law.

title: Traitor, Martyr, Liberator
description: Joseph Conrad wasnt the only literary European who traveled through the Congo basin during the 19th-century rush to harvest the regions ivory, animal hides, minerals and especially its black gold  the liquid latex that welled in its rubber trees. While journeying by caravan to Lopoldville in 1890 to take charge of the merchant ship Le Roi des Belges, Conrad met Roger Casement, a handsome 25-year-old Irish do-gooder who had lived and worked in the Congo Free State for the past few years. Like Conrad, Casement had come to Africa buoyed by the conviction that European colonization would bring moral and social progress to the continent and free its inhabitants from slavery, paganism and other barbarities. Each man would soon learn the gravity of his error.

title: Members of the Wedding
description: Seating Arrangements, Maggie Shipsteads smart and frothy debut novel, is set on a perfect John Cheever island  the kind where old-money families gather to drink gin and nurture loyalties. Beneath the surface of this summery romp, however, lie animosities, well-paced sexual suspense and a clash between appearances and authenticity.

title: Seeking Susan
description: When she was 13, Susan Sontag made a rule: No daydreaming. The habit of idle reflection, to most writers part of the job, seemed to her not so much a waste of time as a threat to stability: Being intelligent isnt, for me, like doing something better,  she confided to her journal in 1973. Its the only way I exist. If Im not [being] intelligent, I hover near being catatonic.

title: You Cant Say That
description: The United States is almost alone among Western liberal democracies in not punishing what is called hate speech  oral or written messages that incite hatred against a person or group on the basis of their race, religion, sex, ethnicity or sexual orientation. Canada, Britain, Denmark, Germany and New Zealand have such laws, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights purports to require signatory nations to pass them. In the American constitutional tradition, by contrast, even detestable speech is permitted so long as the speaker does not threaten violence or incite others to it. The Supreme Courts recent decision upholding the right of the Westboro Baptist Church to engage in hateful picketing of military funerals in opposition to toleration of homosexuality (God Hates Fags, one sign said) is a ready example. That case would almost certainly have come out differently in other liberal democracies.

title: Boiler Rooms
description: Robert J. Shiller made his name in 2000 with Irrational Exuberance, a book that drew on behavioral economics to explain why financial markets overshoot. Shiller concentrated on the boom-bust cycle in technology stocks, but a later edition published while real estate was taking off correctly anticipated the popping of that bubble, too. With his latest volume, Finance and the Good Society, Shiller is coming at us from the opposite direction. Quoting Walt Whitman, who found the eternal meanings in muscular commerce, he celebrates finances genuine beauty and exhorts idealistic young students to pursue careers in derivatives, insurance and related fields.

title: Were We All People?
description: One man volunteered for Auschwitz, and now we have his story. In September 1940 the 39-year-old Polish cavalry officer Witold Pilecki deliberately walked into a German roundup in Warsaw, and was sent by train to the new German camp. His astounding choice was made within, and for, Polands anti-Nazi underground.

title: Talking Head
description: How to Build an Android is the honest title of an earnest book, the first by David F. Dufty, a senior research officer at the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It explains how a team of researchers at the University of Memphis collaborated in 2005 with an artist and robotics expert, David Hanson, to create what was then the most sophisticated android anywhere, a replica of the science-fiction writer Philip K. Dick.

title: Egypts Quantum Entanglement
description: CAIRO  In the famous thought experiment by the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrodinger, a cat that is placed in a box, alongside a radioactive element whose decay will trigger the release of a deadly poison, is said to be at once alive and dead. According to the laws of quantum physics there is an equal chance that the radioactive element will decay and that it wont. Thus Schrodinger posited that until the box is opened and the cats state observed, the animal is theoretically in a state where both possibilities co-exist.

title: The Great Mediocrity
description: Slender volumes on hefty topics have a natural appeal. Who would not like to master a complex subject in the space of a single afternoon? Yet small books on big things can also have their built-in hazards, as they run the risks of neglecting nuance and precision and ignoring valuable details. While it certainly offers numerous insights into Adolf Hitler and the wider context that made his monstrous career possible, A. N. Wilsons Hitler ultimately falls short as a satisfactory substitute for something more substantial.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: WHEN CAPTAIN FLINT WAS STILL A GOOD MAN  By Nick Dybek.  Riverhead, $26.95.

title: The Dependents
description: While visiting the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, England, two Pakistani immigrants happen upon the Meridian Line. Harris, the central character in Rosie Dastgirs first novel, points it out excitedly to his date. Look! he exclaims. I have one foot in the Eastern Hemisphere and one in the West  at the same time. This is us, Farrah, isnt it? Eastern Westerners.

title: Child of God
description: There is a world in my room, says Judith McPherson, the motherless 10-year-old narrator of Grace McCleens first novel, The Land of Decoration. It is made from things no one else wanted and it is made with things that were my mothers, that she left to me. The world is Judiths miniature recreation of the land of milk and honey that she believes will come after Armageddon. Touchingly, it is just a cleaned-up version of her working-class neighborhood, comprising tiny gardens and snowmen and clay model figures on which she eventually enacts a shameful voodoo. Its no wonder Judith spends all day in her room. She is abnormally isolated  constrained by her fathers religious fundamentalism, which dictates that she sit out school assemblies and accept as her social circle the motley members of her church group, with whom she wanders through town trying to evangelize. Judith considers all of this within the range of normal. Only when she becomes the target of the class bully does the imminence of the End seem personal, and acute.

title: Up Front
description: My relationship to the gay rights movement has been decidedly mixed, said Rich Benjamin, who this week reviews Linda Hirshmans Victory, a history of the movement. Im not an activist by nature. Ive never been totally in the closet, but until recently Id never been out. Im a fan of secrets. The less people know about me the better I can maneuver. Theres a beauty to mystery, to conversation, to discovery, to the exquisite pastimes through which people do a tango of distance and intimacy. And secrets are power.

title: Inside the List
description: GUEST BOOK: Dorothea Benton Franks homey novels about family life in South Carolinas Lowcountry  her latest, Porch Lights, hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 5  are the kind youre apt to discover on the bookshelf of a rented beach house, their swollen pages foxed and mildewed and maybe marked with a ring of vegetable oil, since Franks Web site provides recipes for her characters meals. (Grilled chicken, fried bananas, lots of seafood.)

title: A French Jester Who Trades in Hate
description: PARIS

title: Editors Choice
description: BARACK OBAMA: The Story,  by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $32.50.) This huge and absorbing new biography, full of previously unexplored detail, shows that Obamas saga is more surprising and gripping than the version were familiar with.

title: Paperback Row
description: TRAIN DREAMS,  by Denis Johnson. (Picador, $12.) The taming of the American West is encompassed in Johnsons novella. Sent by train into the woods of the Idaho panhandle in the 1890s, his orphaned hero, Robert Grainier, works on logging gangs, falls in love and loses his wife and daughter to a devastating wildfire. What Johnson builds from the ashes of Grainiers life is a tender, lonesome and riveting story, Anthony Doerr wrote here.

title: From This Day Forward
description: When gay people everywhere can marry, will that mean the end of gay literature? I was regularly asked this question last spring while on tour for my most recent book, an account of how novels and plays in the years after World War II shook up sexual attitudes. This was months before President Obama announced his support for gay marriage; the subject was already very much out there.

title: Polls Shift Into the Swings of Summer
description: With summer here, accompanied by the heat, fireflies and the aromas of food on the grill, we can also expect volatility in the polls.

title: The Scarlet Diary
description: On Nov. 15, 1850, 37-year-old Isabella Robinson went to a party in Edinburgh where she was introduced to Edward Lane. Later she noted in her diary that he was handsome and fascinating, the first of many entries describing her feelings for Lane, a married medical student 10 years her junior.

title: Business Day Live | June 22, 2012
description: Ratings agency deals a blow to 15 major banks. | The Georgia town that took its public services private. | Colorado's governor on the economic toll of battling wildfires.

title: Mike Trout, the Angels Prodigy, Is Enjoying the Ride
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Mike Trout is a humble, clean-shaven baseball prodigy from a small town in southern New Jersey. He works at Angel Stadium, three and a half miles from places called Fantasyland, Tomorrowland and Main Street, U.S.A. His story springs from all of them.

title: 50 Shades of Mad Men
description: You can have one girlfriend or three, my divorced father once told me, offering advice, as usual, that only applied to him. But never two. When two girlfriends find out about each other, youve got trouble. Presumably two girlfriends would gouge each others eyes out, whereas three girlfriends might unpack a picnic lunch of tea sandwiches and cherry wine, lovingly braid one anothers hair and then fall asleep in the sun.

title: To Tell or Not to Tell
description: My mother has been having memory issues for a number of years. Her neurologist has been telling her it is mild dementia. Her cognitive impairment and memory loss have worsened, and I recently met the neurologist without her. He told me that she has Alzheimers. He felt we should not yet tell my mother, as that diagnosis has been her greatest fear and it would be too devastating. He felt we could not tell my father unless we told my mother. I am uncomfortable keeping this terrible secret. Is it better to tell a loved one of the prognosis they fear, or is it more ethical to let them live in hopes that they have escaped it? NAME WITHHELD

title: Who Made That Cubicle?
description: Imagine yourself in a typing pool in the early 1960s, amid the clack-clack-clack-PING of dozens of Smith-Coronas. Youre out in the open, like a factory worker, with nowhere to hide from the raking gaze of the boss.

title: The 6.10.12 Issue
description: PREP-SCHOOL PREDATORS

title: Our Lady of Contraception
description: After you testified before House Democrats in February about the limited contraceptive coverage in Georgetown Universitys insurance plan, Rush Limbaugh referred to you as a slut on his radio show. He said you were having so much sex that you couldnt afford all the birth-control pills you needed. Do you suppose he doesnt understand how the pill works?  It does seem to make a case for comprehensive sex education, doesnt it? Actually, what Ive learned has less to do with Mr. Limbaugh specifically and more to do with a part of our population that has this view. Because frankly, you dont go on national radio and talk for several days about something that no one wants to hear. Theres an audience for this type of sexist vitriol. There is real hate and sexism within our society that we have to do something about.

title: Looted for Love
description: I grew up in the East Village, in New York City, surrounded by art. Most of it was contemporary, but there was one piece that was old  really old. It was a fragment of an ancient marble column, and we used it as a doorstop. Id never seen marble like that outside of the Metropolitan Museum  marble that changed color with the time of day, almost as if it were blushing. After looking at the marble for 30 years, I finally asked where it was from.

title: Sweets and Studios in Kyoto
description: Artists and artisans are spurring a revival in a neighborhood thats fallen off the tourist maps.

title: Horace Mann Abuse Article Plays Loose
description: The New York Times Sunday Magazine article on abuse by teachers at Horace Mann School (Prep-School Predators, June 10, 2012) was a highly unusual artifact of journalism, a journey into a black hole of a kind.

title: France, and the World, Drinks More Pink
description: PARISHigh-end Bordeaux and Burgundy may be all the rage in the new wine-drinking markets of Asia, especially China. Back home in France, the star of the wine scene is ros.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Linda Hirshman talks about Victory, her history of the gay rights movement; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Lawrence Downes discusses the android Philip K. Dick; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: 3 Orchestras With a Sound To Fit the Space
description: FOR the planners and builders of the Park Avenue Armory, the landmark structure that consumes a city block, bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues and 66th and 67th Streets, music was surely not among the chief concerns. Completed in 1881, the armory was intended to serve as a military installation and social club for the Seventh Regiment of the New York National Guard.

title: Cuteness: Another Word for Evil
description: With Ted coming to theaters, a look at some other twisted walking, talking plushies on the screen.

title: Its All Over Now. Or Is It?
description: Perhaps, in the end, the Heat's N.B.A. championship will bring greater relief to everyone else than even to LeBron James himself. Because while yes, even James's superteam shortcut of sorts to the championship that would make his nickname sound fitting instead of ridiculous was harder than he expected, it was taxing for all sides. For the anti-James camp, it took energy to maintain a proper level of antipathy, when every missed fourth-quarter free throw or highlight-quality dunk qualifies as news in the James-obsessed N.B.A. Meanwhile, his defenders shouted themselves hoarse trying to drown out the detractors, especially with the Heat's tendency -- until the finals at least -- to make everything more difficult than it probably needed to be. And even those who sat back and considered "As LeBron Turns" to be a mostly fascinating nightly pschyodrama, it got rather exhausting. We worked overtime playing the role of his therapist and now we need a vacation.

title: Dispatches from Rio and Nepal: Knife Fights Over Firewood
description: In the final hours of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development in Rio de Janeiro, a reverberating theme has been sustainable energy for all  a push catalyzed by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon in a stump speech on energy poverty that he has delivered many times over the past year. The most effective lines in these speeches draw on his personal experience growing up with no electricity in post-war South Korea:

title: Weekend Fare: Mermaids and Gay Pride
description: In conjunction with the 30th annual Mermaid Parade, the Coney Island Brewing Company, 12th Street and Surf Avenue, in Coney Island, Brooklyn, will offer tastings on Saturday starting at 2 p.m. of four new beers. One is Shmaltz Brewings Mermaid Pilsner.

title: Notes From the Underground | Trixie Whitley
description: I had been warned to brace myself for the power of Trixie Whitleys voice, but nothing could have prepared me for what came spilling out of the mouth of this diminutive blonde. Whitleys vocals are nothing less than soaring, and the soul that pours forth from her is heart wrenching. Even in the stuffy reality that is an Art Forum/D.A.P. cocktail party at the top of the Standard Hotel, Whitleys boot stamping, guitar strumming and deep wails brought the schmoozing to a grinding, and welcome, halt.

title: How My View on Gay Marriage Changed
description: IN my 2007 book, The Future of Marriage, and in my 2010 court testimony concerning Proposition 8, the California ballot initiative that defined marriage as between a man and a woman, I took a stand against gay marriage. But as a marriage advocate, the time has come for me to accept gay marriage and emphasize the good that it can do. Id like to explain why.

title: Hearing the World, While Staying At Home
description: Honolulu

title: Hugh Bonneville, Star of the Olympics Comedy Twenty Twelve
description: TWO years ago Hugh Bonneville was just another hard-working British actor whose plummy vowels and cherubic cheeks lent themselves to characters good (Bernie, the stockbroker who never gets the girl in Notting Hill) and not so good (Henleigh Grandcourt, the aristocrat who sends the girl fleeing in Daniel Deronda).

title: Taliban Attack a Resort Hotel
description: Taliban militants shot their way into a lakeside resort near Kabul, killing 20 and taking scores of hostages during an 11-hour siege.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding The Upgrade Maze (June 10), I read that at the beginning of the fare games one of the major airlines believed its loyal customers would appreciate better service and amenities, even if they came at slightly higher fares. It lost customers in droves. As a traveler on a budget, I almost always choose the lowest fare, so I recognize that Ive helped create this mess today.

title: Going to the Fat Farm With Dad
description: My dad was a brilliant ad man in the Mad Men era, responsible for such iconic slogans as Coke Is It, Leggo My Eggo, and Fly the Friendly Skies of United. He also was extremely overweight.

title: Putting a Spin on Touring
description: ANDY HAMPSTEN, 50, may be best remembered by cycling fans for overcoming a blizzard on a steep climb in the 1988 Giro dItalia.

title: Restaurant Report: Restaurante da Dona Liceia in Arape, Brazil
description: The wealthiest guests travel to Liceia Franklin de Oliveiras farmhouse restaurant by helicopter, landing amid the green hills outside Arape, Brazil, about 20 miles as the chopper flies from the resort town of Angra dos Reis. But you dont need to be rich to afford the 70-real prix fixe lunch: thats only $35 at 1.98 reais to the dollar. Plebeians will, however, need some time. By car its a two-hour, 110-mile drive from Rio de Janeiro, the last three miles of which are down a dirt road barely wide enough for a compact rental. (Ask for directions if you dont see signs in town for the restaurant.)

title: Hotel Review: Brick in Mexico City
description: THE UPSHOT

title: An Old Mexico City Colonia on an Upswing
description: BESIDE the small, open courtyard on the roof of a former mansion, Anuar Maauad had a cigarette in one hand, a beer in the other and a ringing  constantly ringing  cellphone in front of him on his long kitchen table. He sat, flanked by friends, as the Mexico City sky exploded with thunder so powerful it shook the 123-year-old building.

title: Seeking Japanese Calm, Closer to Home
description: YEARS ago, while traveling through Japan, I booked a last-minute room through the tourist office at Kyotos train station and ended up at a traditional guesthouse without knowing what I was getting into.

title: Tracking the Bieb and the Bard in Stratford
description: ON a sweltering afternoon recently I stood in a dusty skateboard park in Stratford, Ontario, surrounded by about a dozen sullen-looking boys, all around 17. I mentioned someone they might know, someone who a few years ago used to hang out there, too, and a couple of them said he was a jerk. They could have been jealous, of course: We were discussing Justin Bieber, who not long ago was a local kid busking on the street a few blocks from this park and is now a pop star estimated by Forbes magazine to have earned $55 million, even before last weeks release of his third full-length album, Believe.

title: Hiking Through Biblical Backcountry
description: AROUND the corner from Nazareths Old City market, in the shadow of 200-year-old Ottoman mansions, theres a cobblestone street so narrow you can almost touch the houses on either side. An arrow pointing up some stairs is painted on one rough wall, along with the words Jesus Trail. Its the de facto trailhead for a 40-mile hike through the Galilee region of Israel in the footsteps, more or less, of the man who made Galilee famous.

title: Wall-Breaking Moves, Fit for a Screen
description: IN a new dance the choreographer Jonah Bokaer, dressed in black, moves inside of a sleek box that stands an arms reach taller than his six-foot frame. Transferring his body weight with exacting control, he maintains a profile stance as his arms and legs  extending straight like rods  create a world of lines within lines.

title: Chasing a Prairie Tale
description: One of the most adrenaline-fueled vacations in American history took place in August 1872, when a young New Yorker named George Bird Grinnell boarded a train at Grand Central Depot for the eras hot new travel destination  Nebraska.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Solar Power
description: When photovoltaic cells make electricity from sunlight, they collect a lot of heat along the way. And they dont work as well warm as they do cold.

title: Crisscrossing the Plains
description: Violent history, modern rebirth and an occasional curiosity on a trip through Kansas and Nebraska.

title: Image of the Day: June 22
Friday Flashback: For Federer, the Olympics Have Been About Family
description: Most athletes come away from the Olympics with a cherished lifetime memory of representing their country. A select few will get to be flagbearers for the opening ceremony. The really lucky and talented ones return home with a medal or two.

title: Blogging to Build Your Business
description: Blogging for business is not a new concept, but for many small businesses, especially service businesses, it can be an extremely effective tool to build your social media footprint, establish your brand, or position yourself in your area of expertise. The ultimate benefit of blogging is the opportunity to communicate your expertise and establish your business as a resource.

title: June 24  30
description: AN early oratorio version of Paola Prestinis multimedia opera, OCEANIC VERSES, was performed at New York City Operas Vox readings in 2011, and it left a mixed impression. But since then Ms. Prestini  an inventive composer whose style mixes the ancient and the up-to-date, the folk inspired and the artfully polished  has revamped the work, expanding it into a full opera, with a libretto by Donna Di Novelli and film by Ali Hossaini. The nonlinear story follows four characters  the Sailor, the Soldier, the Scholar and the Peasant  whose individual quests are linked by a search for a common past in the disappearing traditions of southern Italy. The characters have alter egos of sorts, film versions meant to represent their inner selves. The expanded work is having its New York premiere as part of the River to River Festival. The production is directed by Kevin Newbury, and Claudio Prima, Christopher Burchett, Helga Davis and Nancy Allen Lundy sing the principal roles, with Julian Wachner conducting Novus NY (the contemporary music ensemble of Trinity Wall Street), the Washington Chorus and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus. 7:30 p.m. Monday, Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 219-9401, rivertorivernyc.com; free.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Triumphs of the Gay Rights Movement
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Rich Benjamin reviews Linda Hirshmans Victory, a history of the gay rights movement. Mr. Benjamin writes:

title: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Investigations Into the Chrysler 200 and Ford Explorer
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened investigations into possible stalling problems on 87,000 Chrysler 200 sedans and a loss of power-steering assist on 83,000 Ford Explorers.

title: To Give or Not to Give, Up to $5.12 Million
description: TIME may  or may not  be running out for one of the biggest tax breaks for wealthy Americans: the chance to give up to $5.12 million to heirs tax-free and then pay a comparatively low 35 percent rate on any gift above that. The break is scheduled to expire in six months, but no one will hazard a guess about its fate because it is just one of many tax and spending measures expiring at the same time.

title: Braving the Klondike on a Shoe Diet
description: AS The Artist arrives on home video this week with its five Oscars in tow, perhaps this mock-silent movie from Michel Hazanavicius will motivate viewers to check out some of the many authentic examples of silent-film art that are currently available on DVD and Blu-ray. The air of amused condescension that Mr. Hazanaviciuss film expresses toward an imaginary era of lost innocence quickly dissipates when exposed to the emotional complexities and stylistic refinements of a film like Charles Chaplins 1925 classic The Gold Rush, recently issued by the Criterion Collection in a digitally restored version that puts all previous editions of this great film to shame.

title: Sanding Down the Grit on Rap and Metal
description: SpaceGhostPurrp

title: Former Busker Is Now Back as a Solo
description: THE audience at Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in SoHo might well have expected Glen Hansard to open his recent show there with a song from Once, the Broadway show built around his songs that had won eight Tonys just two days earlier. Or maybe something from his first solo album, Rhythm and Repose, which was about to be released.

title: Man Is Sentenced for Threats Against Creators of South Park
description: A man involved with a Web site that posted threatening messages about the creators of the Comedy Central series South Park was sentenced to 11 years in prison on Friday, The Associated Press reported.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 22, 2012
description: The New York Times film critics on Brave, To Rome With Love, and Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter.

title: Look of The Moment | The Angelina Effect
description: When Angelina Jolies leg stole the Academy Awards show this past February, the fashion police raged. Shocked and bemused, no one would have predicted at the time that the thigh-high slit in that Atelier Versace dress combined with Jolies deliberate, look-at-my-leg pose would start a red-carpet trend. But alas, the Angelina Effect has taken hold of red carpets everywhere, from New York to Hollywood and Antibes. A repeat offender, the model Anja Rubik took the look to new heights in an Anthony Vaccarello dress slit on the right for the Met Ball, and then in Roberto Cavalli at the Cannes Film Festival. There is something so seductive about the movement of a dress with a high slit, said Jason Wu, who designed the racy lace dress worn by the model Jessica Stam to the CFDA Awards earlier this month. It definitely makes you look twice. Also spotted at the CFDA Awards was the model Hilary Rhoda, in modernist Rebecca Minkoff. Adding a slit to a long dress makes it feel less formal, Minkoff said. Its a modern bombshell look. Thats got legs, no doubt.

title: Morning Walkabout  6/22: Techie-Friendly Ads and a T.S.A. Gadget That Doesnt Work
description: Ads and Apps Two techie-friendly ad campaigns: Crystal Cruises will let owners of iPhones with the Aurasma-augmented reality app use it to view videos that use the print ads as a jumping-off point. Air France has introduced a free iPhone app that lets passengers create personalized, location-based photo albums on their trips that can be shared on Facebook with friends and also with a network of Air Frances Travel Bookers. (The New York Times)

title: Pakistans Mnage  Trois
description: London  For as long as I can remember, the politics of Pakistan have been discussed in binary terms: civil vs. military, democracy vs. dictatorship, good vs. evil. The ouster this week of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on an order of the Supreme Court changes all that. Thanks to this judicial coup, as many in Pakistan are calling the move, the country is now in effect being run by a mnage--trois.

title: Whatever Happens, I Will Have Reacted Already
description: When a politician responds to something another politician has not yet said, we call that a prebuttal. Its a variant is the presponse, in which networks air the opposition partys response to a State of the Union Address that was taped prior to delivery.

title: This Weeks Movies: June 22
description: In todays edition of This Weeks Movies, Manhola Dargis reviews the horror fantasy Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter  a film with such smashing title, its too bad someone had to spoil things by making a movie to go with it  and Brave, the animated fairy tale that features Pixars first female protagonist. A. O. Scott weighs in on Woody Allens latest, To Rome With Love. Full reviews can be found here.

title: The TV Watch: Haiti
description: Alessandra Stanley, the Timess chief television critic, looks at several cultures from around the world through the prism of their television programming.

title: The TV Watch: Haiti
description: Alessandra Stanley, the Times's chief television critic, looks at several cultures from around the world through the prism of their television programming.

title: The TV Watch: Haiti
description: Alessandra Stanley, the Times's chief television critic, looks at several cultures from around the world through the prism of their television programming.

title: After Dominating Run to Finals, Thunder Must Absorb Loss
description: MIAMI  The Oklahoma City Thunder did not look interested in waiting their turn to become N.B.A. champions.

title: The TV Watch: Haiti
description: Alessandra Stanley, the Timess chief television critic, looks at several cultures from around the world through the prism of their television programming.

title: A Loophole Big Enough to Lose a Billion
description: If nothing else, the collapse of MF Global has made one thing clear: The notion that customer assets were safe was a sham.

title: New York Wrecks Inspire Aquarium Design
description: Scientists from the Wildlife Conservation Society are exploring shipwrecks off the coast of New York to help architects accurately design a new facility at the New York Aquarium.

title: Switzerlands Battle to Suppress the Franc Exacts a Price
description: IN the middle of the chaos and fear that is Europe today sits a country seemingly apart from it all.

title: The Swiss Dilemma
description: Switzerland is trying to keep its currency from becoming too strong, which is causing problems.

title: Syria Shoots Down Turkish Warplane, Fraying Ties Further
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey announced Friday that Syrian forces had shot down a Turkish warplane with two crew members over the Mediterranean, a potentially ominous turn for the worse in relations already frayed because of Turkeys support for Syrian rebels fighting to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.

title: As Sandusky Jurors Deliberate, Lawyer Acknowledges His Doubts
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  With the jury in the Jerry Sandusky sex-abuse case deep into its second day of deliberation, Sanduskys lawyer said Friday evening he would be shocked if his client was acquitted on all of the nearly 50 counts of abusing young boys he faced.

title: Business Day Live | Wildfire's Toll
description: June 22, 2012  Colorados governor talks about the economic impact of battling wildfires.

title: Should You Bribe Children to Behave in the Car?
description: Last weeks parental quandary was mine, or, at least, mine and a whole lot of other peoples. The problem? Children squabbling madly away in the car. I offered my solution in the video when I first posted it last week: I will give a Tic Tac to any child who can get through a car ride without poking, prodding or otherwise antagonizing a sibling.

title: The Sweet Spot | Dancing the Night Away
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about summer rock festivals and The Electric Daisy Carnival.

title: The Sweet Spot: June 22
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the increasing number of electronic dance music festivals and talk with Ben Sisario and Jon Pareles about the trend.

title: The First Family: A New Glimpse of Michelle Obamas White Ancestors
description: When we invited readers to pose questions about an article on Mrs. Obamas white ancestors, we never imagined that one would provide us with the first glimpse of two key figures in the first ladys family tree.

title: In Effort to Remove Tarnish, a Heat Title Helps
description: MIAMI  When the party crashed the locker room, made the floor a sticky mess and packed it with revelers wall to wall, Micky Arison stood in the middle and referenced the last time he picked up the check for a wild Miami Heat bash.

title: The Euro Is Flat
description: Still limited blogging. But I thought Id post about something that sort of surprised me.

title: Downsized, With Penthouse
description: JAMES FREUND grew up in a two-bedroom apartment on East 72nd Street, where his mother, Marcy Freund, a fiercely independent 104, still lives. But in many respects his heart was on the West Side.

title: The Soccer Chronicles: Inspiration in Sweden
description: Heather OReilly, a midfielder on the U.S. womens soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her second post.

title: On Our Radar: Limping Toward the End in Rio
description: Although serious policy discussions have unfolded at the Rio+20 environmental conference in Brazil  along with plenty of theatrics  it will wrap up today without committing nations to any binding targets on sustainability. [The Washington Post]

title: Iceland Plans to Join European Bloc Despite Economic Turmoil
description: BRUSSELS  Despite a sovereign debt crisis that threatens to tear the European Union apart, Iceland is speeding ahead on its bid to join the bloc and even delivered a pep talk Friday to those struggling to hold it together.

title: Tip of the Week: Texting a Caller Back
description: Ever been in a meeting or other quiet occasion where answering an incoming phone call is not an option? Smartphones running the Android 4.0 software (also known as Ice Cream Sandwich in Googles dessert-themed nickname scheme) offer a convenient feature that lets you respond to the caller with a text message.

title: Condo Boards Take a Stand on Delinquencies
description: A SUCCESSFUL condominium depends, in large part, on owners paying their monthly fees promptly and in full. Delinquencies can mean less money for maintenance and amenities  and draw the ill will of fellow residents. While the sheer size of larger buildings can often blunt their impact on the budget, small buildings with a high number of delinquencies can be toxic for buyers and a millstone for sellers.

title: Souped-Up Summer Vegetables
description: For a light, healthful meal, nothing beats soup, even in the summertime. This week Martha Rose Shulman offers soup recipes that put the spotlight on summer vegetables. She writes:

title: A Bicycle Headset Doubles as a Walkie-Talkie
description: If you like talking, bicycling and a project, then youll like the Cardo BK-1, a walkie-talkie, Bluetooth music player and hands-free phone headset in one.

title: Making Sense With Me Me Me
description: OK, actually its Making Sense With Paul Solman, but currently its a lot of me me me; videos galore. Also some of Robin.

title: Down Memory Lane With the National Book Awards (and Not Just the Winners)
description: The National Book Foundation has created an online exhibit to highlight notable American authors like Cynthia Propper Seton, Earl Thompson and Alan Saperstein. Oh, and Hemingway, Faulkner and Flannery OConnor, too. Theyre all among the 373 finalists for the National Book Award for Fiction since the honor was first issued in 1950.

title: Letty Brown and Jan Novak
description: WHEN Letty Brown and Jan Novak were introduced by a mutual friend at a Japanese restaurant in Sacramento in 2008, her course seemed set. Dr. Brown, a botanist, was planning to depart for eastern Brazil, where she was to map an uncharted corner of the Atlantic Forest on a Fulbright scholarship.

title: A Shipwreck as a Portal for an Aquarium Exhibit
description: On the evening of Feb. 10, 1939, the oil tanker Lightburne ran aground in dense fog on a shoal off Block Island, R.I. In lashing winds and pounding surf, the Coast Guard raced to the site and performed what The New York Times called one of the most spectacular ship rescues in recent years, saving all 35 crew members.

title: Euro 2012 Highlights: Germany (4) vs. Greece (2)
description: Germany Coach Joachim Lw made a number of changes to his starting lineup. Lukas Podolski, Lars Bender, Thomas Mller and Mario Gomez were out; Miroslav Klose, Marko Reus and Mesut zil are in. Boateng returned to the defense, And theres more. Perhaps only a team with the depth, and confidence of Germany could and would dare to make such wholesale changes.

title: Chris Bosh, the Second-Most Maligned N.B.A. Champion
description: This N.B.A. title  and all that comes with it  belongs to LeBron James, the player of unspeakable talent, unbelievable growth and the target of unprecedented criticism. But while his personal journey has become the narrative of an entire league, he shares the Heats scene with so many others. Dwyane Wade tabled injury and personal trial to compete for another title. Erik Spoelstra pushed the Heat into the future with his adaptive rotation. And Chris Bosh  the unbelievably strange target of a raging publics remaining bile  thrived for Miami in a more crucial capacity than ever.

title: Leaders Vow to Defend Euro, but Hint at Rifts on How
description: ROME  The leaders of the euro zones four largest economies vowed Friday to defend the common currency with all means necessary, trying to reassure jittery financial markets before yet another summit meeting of the European Union next week in Brussels. But clear disagreements remained on what those mechanisms ought to be.

title: Living With P.T.S.D. and Allowing Myself to Get Help
description: An alarm clock chimes across a pitch-black room. I slowly rise. Standing in my bathroom, I brush my teeth and shave away yesterdays stubble  part of every Marines mandatory morning routine. The person in the mirror seems somehow unfamiliar. Downstairs, the morning pot of coffee brews. I finally begin to wake. Leaving home, the roads are lined with beautiful farmland, backlit by a rising sun. Morning dew glinting off the fields gives way to a kaleidoscope of neon signs as I reach town. Pulling into the parking lot, I take a deep breath and step out of my truck.

title: Bain Capital Buys Half of TV Shopping Company in Japan
description: Bain Capital agreed on Friday to buy 50 percent of one of Japans biggest television shopping companies, in the latest move by the private equity firm in that country.

title: Shelf Life | Summer at Karma
description: From its seashell-encrusted vessels and faux aged terra cotta flower pots to the hand-painted driftwood key chains and dip dyed towels, Summer is exactly the kind of home dcor shop that you might expect to find on main street Sag Harbor or Amagansett. Only this three-week retail operation is in the West Village, in the storefront of Karma, Brendan Dugans design office/gallery/bookstore, and its proprietors, Aaron Aujla and Dylan Bailey, are not out-of-work Domino editors but the gainfully employed assistants to the artists Nate Lowman and Dan Colen, respectively. Aujla and Bailey, whose personal studio practices trade in mimicry and appropriation, spent untold hours studying and documenting virtually every home dcor shop within about 100 miles, meticulously cataloging the tropes and tricks of visual branding and retail display  Have you ever noticed that the dog bowl outside of the Thom Browne store up the street has a lemon wedge in it? Aujla asks  and then set out to set up a shop of their own.

title: When Zealots Attack
description: So far this year Ive only been called an idiot on two occasions.

title: Ex-Officer Gets 9-Month Term in Racially Tainted False Arrest
description: A former New York police officer who used a racial slur while bragging about falsely arresting a black man last year was sentenced on Friday to nine months in prison for violating the mans civil rights.

title: On Radio, Mayor Signs Taxi Sex-Trafficking Bill
description: For the New York City government, it was almost certainly a first: a sitting mayor signing a bill into law in the midst of a live radio interview, applying his signature from the unglamorous confines of a Lower Manhattan studio.

title: Lin Granted Early-Bird Rights
description: A dispute between the N.B.A. and the players union over Jeremy Lins so-called Bird rights could spill into July, clouding the Knicks free-agency agenda and creating potential chaos for all parties.

title: Rubio Denounces Partisanship on Immigration
description: An hour before President Obama was to speak to Latino officials on Friday, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida lamented how the immigration issue has become hostage to politics  on both the left and right.

title: After 62-Year Absence, Le Monstre Will Stalk Le Mans Again
description: Briggs Swift Cunningham, a wealthy sportsman who raced yachts as well as cars, never achieved his dream of winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in France. But he came fairly close, placing as high as third over all and first in class in both 1953 and 1954, with C4R and C5R cars of his own companys design.

title: Conventions, or Hallelujah Parties?
description: The quadrennial Republican and Democratic nominating conventions stopped being actual parts of the nominating process in the 1970s. But they retained aspects of their original purpose  the ritual vote and the speeches by each partys big shots and nominees. A convention can set the tone for the fall campaign  for good (Barack Obamas wildly successful convention in Denver in 2008) or ill (John Kerrys cringe-inducing convention in Boston in 2004.)

title: Cardinals Aide Is Found Guilty in Abuse Case
description: PHILADELPHIA  Msgr. William J. Lynn, a former cardinals aide, was found guilty Friday of endangering children, becoming the first senior official of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States convicted of covering up sexual abuses by priests under his supervision.

title: U.S. Military Hunts for Safe Smartphones for Soldiers
description: The military has long needed computers that are tough enough on the outside to withstand the rough and tumble of the battlefield. Now, with the proliferation of smartphones and tablets in the hands of soldiers, those devices also have to be strong on the inside. They are loaded with contacts, location information and all kinds of military-grade applications, so it can be deadly for a soldier to lose a mobile device or have its data leak out unwittingly.

title: How Is the Monthly Jobs Report Actually Calculated?
description: In this weeks magazine, Adam Davidson writes about the jobs report, the governments monthly estimate of the employment situation in the United States. The Bureau of Labor Statistics releases the report on the first Friday of every month, at exactly 8:30 in the morning. In an instant, reporters and analysts decide whether it spells doom or salvation for the economy. But how are the numbers calculated in the first place?

title: A Practiced Nonchalance
description: Sean MacPherson, 47, proprietor of the Bowery, Jane and Maritime hotels and an owner of the Waverly Inn restaurant, is revamping the Crows Nest Inn in Montauk, N.Y. His wife is Rachelle Hruska, a founder of the night-life blog GuestofaGuest.com. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Oregon Study Shows Benefits, and Price, for Newly Insured
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  When Wendy Parris shattered her ankle, the emergency room put it in an air cast and sent her on her way. Because she had no insurance, doctors did not operate to fix it. A mother of six, Ms. Parris hobbled around for four years, pained by the foot, becoming less mobile and gaining weight.

title: A Look at the Top N.H.L. Draft Prospects
description: The folks at Bleacher Report have produced a series of videos about a dozen of the prospects likely to be among the top selections in the N.H.L. draft on Friday night. Above, the video about probable No. 1 pick Nail Yakupov. The other videos can be found here.

description: Like the Biblical place that inspired its name, Goshen is the proverbial land of plenty, at least to many of those who live here.

title: Biblical Name, Utopian Quality
description: LIKE the biblical place that inspired its name, Goshen is the proverbial land of plenty, at least to many of those who live here: 5,500 people in the historic 3.2-square-mile village center, the Orange County seat; and 8,200, many of them farmers, in the countryside that makes up the surrounding town, renowned for its exceptionally fertile black soil.

description: David Gruber and Vincent Pieribone make their first dive at the Solomon Islands site.

description: Though the weather may not affect your road trip as dramatically as it would have in tornado-ravaged Hampton, Va., this month, it still can dramatically alter your drive.

description: American Airlines and the union representing its pilots are close to reaching a deal on a new contract, a significant milestone in the ailing carriers seven-month-old bankruptcy, although one that still leaves the door open for a possible merger with US Airways.

title: Gazprom Reaches Deal With EDF to Invest in European Power Plants
description: ST. PETERSBURG  Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, reached a deal Friday with EDF of France to jointly invest in gas-fired power plants in Europe, gaining an important toehold for its exports at a time when competition from shale gas and liquefied natural gas is disrupting its main business.

title: The Ascent
description: Part art installation, part adventure ride, part spiritual journey, The Ascent claims to let users harness their brains own electrical impulses to levitate themselves.

title: Ensemble Intercontemporain Names Music Director
description: The graying but still spry grandfather of new-music groups, the Ensemble Intercontemporain, said on Friday that the composer and conductor Matthias Pintscher would become its next music director, starting in 2013. Mr. Pintscher, 41, who has an increasingly busy conducting career along with his work as a composer, will succeed Susanna Mlkki.

title: Artifacts | Chris Crockers Zoo Story
description: Its Pride week in New York, when gay, lesbian and transgendered people can celebrate themselves in the streets. In Bristol, Tenn., however, the flamboyant Chis Crocker will have to parade at home on his computer screen. Not that hell be alone, exactly.

title: Brain Waves Lift Me Higher
description: YOU could drive past the hulking warehouse on the rough patch of waterfront in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, several times without ever figuring it for the latest frontier of neurological thrill-seeking. But thats where Yehuda Duenyas, 38, who calls himself a creator of innovative experiences, was camped out last week, along with his team of scrappy young technical wizards and a quarter-million dollars worth of circuitry, theatrical lighting and optimism called The Ascent.

title: The Science of Illusion
description: PINCH a coin at its edge between the thumb and first fingers of your right hand and begin to place it in your left palm, without letting go. Begin to close the fingers of the left hand. The instant the coin is out of sight, extend the last three digits of your right hand and secretly retract the coin. Make a fist with your left  as if holding the coin  as your right hand palms the coin and drops to the side.

title: Digital Notes: @KimDotcom Jokes of Money Laundering and Tennis Racketeering
description: For Hollywood and the music industry, the criminal case against Megaupload is critical in their fight against piracy, and the scale of it is the stuff of symbolism: A federal indictment accuses the file-sharing site and seven of its operators, including the founder, Kim Dotcom, of abetting $500 million in damages.

Theres the client who was billed almost $11,000 for an 11-minute hand surgery. The cancer patient who was charged $9,550.40 for a round of chemotherapy he never received.

title: A Summer Salad the French Might Recognize

I want more of a meal: savory, garlicky, shot through with anchovy and capers and herbs, and topped with skinny green beans and hard-cooked eggs.

description: This weeks City Kitchen column features a potato and green bean salad with inspiration from the south of France. Whether or not it qualifies as a true salade Nioise, or a simplified version of the real thing, is debatable.

description: Subjects include Nik Wallendas tightrope walk across Niagara Falls, the first hot spell of summer and a rock slide in the Palisades.

title: Richards-Ross Aims for Her Olympic Moment (or Two)
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Its overcast and drizzly on the campus of the University of Oregon, as the United States track and field Olympic trials prepare to begin in earnest at Hayward Field at 1 p.m. Pacific time. Fridays program features, among other events, half of the decathlon as well as preliminary rounds in several of the sprints. The only finals contested Friday will come in the evening, when the mens 10,000 meters starts at 6:45 p.m. and the womens 10,000 follows at 7:20 p.m.

title: Missing the Boat: A Case for Marriage
description: HE proposed a year after we started dating. I was 24, nave and ambitious. I had been plotting my career since I was 13, never giving much thought to marriage.

title: A Split Decision Over the 63 Sting Ray
description: THE 1963 Corvette Sting Ray coupe, with its sharklike styling details and boattail roofline, is acknowledged as one of the most desirable of all Corvettes. Its defining feature is a two-piece fastback rear window, the stylish conclusion of a windsplit that runs unbroken from the nose of the car to its tail.

title: Ralph Wenzel, Whose Dementia Helped Start a Debate, Dies at 69
description: Ralph Wenzel, a former National Football League lineman whose early-onset dementia helped draw attention to recent debates about the safety of football, died on June 18 in Annapolis, Md. He was 69.

description: THERE is no debate about this fact: The first year that American teenagers have their drivers licenses will be among the most dangerous of their lives. Nothing kills more of them than car crashes.

description: ON a late afternoon in May, Martin Amis gestured toward the tall, sun-filled parlor windows of his Brooklyn brownstone.

description: COST, duration and convenience are typical concerns when selecting a driver education program, but those are distant seconds to the main issue of quality, said William E. Van Tassel, manager of driver training programs at AAA.

title: Kevin Tucker Is Dead at 71; Led Philadelphia Police
description: Kevin M. Tucker, a former Philadelphia police commissioner who was credited with turning around a department riddled with corruption and beset by criticism over its bombing of a radical group called Move in 1985, died on Tuesday at a hospice in Mount Holly, N.J. He would have turned 72 on June 21.

description: Moscow

title: Worlds Within Worlds, Both Real and Imagined

Deganit Shemy, the choreographer of Hungry Kite, a new dance that opened at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday night, likes to keep things ambiguous. Her choreographic strokes leave behind blurry lines, so that linear meaning is cast aside for an atmosphere better suited to dreams.

And for those who find themselves in remote locations, a solar charger can keep phones ready, whether to report a bear sighting or just to call home.

No other production looks more beautiful on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House. The set and costumes, designed by David Walker, create a completely satisfying world, with space, air and depth around the dancing.

title: Stripping the Big Top to Sublime, Nail-Biting Essentials
description: BECKET, Mass.  Contemporary circus shows are often dissatisfying affairs. Having stripped out many of the traditional elements that make a trip to the big top so pleasurable, they suffer from something of an identity crisis, padding their offerings instead with tedious emotional clichs and boilerplate design elements. Spectacle becomes schmaltz.

title: A Nonvote in Albany: Tough Luck, Sharks

On Thursday, the New York State Senate did not act on a bill that would have banned the distribution, sales and possession of the fins before it adjourned.

title: Bloomberg Suggests Shame as a Punishment for Speeding

Not to steal the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festivals thunder on the opening night of its 80th-anniversary season, but as the Pillow presented its first concert, by Mimulus Dance Company of Brazil, on Wednesday, I kept thinking of its slightly younger counterpart, the American Dance Festival in North Carolina. title: Response from Bain Capital
description: Bain Capital does not make money on investments when our investors lose money. Any suggestion to the contrary is based on a misleading analysis that examines the income of a business without taking account of expenses. This selective accounting excludes the clawback of profits from other investments, and large expenses associated with running the business and exploring the hundreds of transactions we review and choose not to do every year.

title: Walcott: Don't Penalize Parents Who Raise Money for Their Schools
Devils to Host Next Years Draft
description: PITTSBURGH  The Devils will host to the 2013 entry draft, the N.H.L. announced Friday. It will be the first time the league has held the draft in the New York area.

title: Bill Cunningham | Sizzle
description: With exquisite timing, a heat wave arrived on the first day of summer, and stylish New Yorkers didnt miss a beat.

title: Achieving Fame Without a Legacy
description: When I was in graduate school in the mid-70s, trying to learn how to paint, a useful, shorthand criticism for a certain kind of creation was, It looks like a LeRoy Neiman. A reasonably sophisticated art student knew what that meant, and it was not a compliment. It referred to the splashy, garish, instantly recognizable style of illustration, a formulaic mix of impressionism, expressionism and realism, that Mr. Neiman used to make himself one of the most famous artists in America.

title: Robert J. Kelleher, Judge and Tennis Official, Dies at 99
description: Robert J. Kelleher, a federal judge and former tennis champion who helped transform tennis in the United States by spearheading an effort to admit professionals into major tournaments, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 99.

title: Greek Tragedy at the Soccer Bar
description: The winds whipped up, the thunder cracked and lightning bolts slashed the sky as I walked in the rain to my local soccer bar Friday afternoon to watch the match between Germany and Greece in the European Cup quarterfinals. A friend texted me, implying that Zeus had orchestrated the weather, suggesting that Greece  the underdog  would prevail.

title: The Trouble With Halfway Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Is Evolving
description: To the Editor:

title: Chevrolet Recalls 413,000 Cruzes for Engine-Fire Hazard
description: General Motors is recalling every Chevrolet Cruze it has produced at its plant in Lordstown, Ohio.

title: Innovations, Both Raw and Cooked
description: JUST when I thought I had experienced almost everything the restaurant scene had to offer, I walked into a renovated pizzeria in Jersey City and ordered a spicy barbecued squid salad. The pickled pearl onions, jalapeo peppers and fresh, bright cilantro seemed to pop in my mouth, to set off intensifying waves of flavor. Here was a kind of cuisine I had never tasted in New Jersey.

title: Korean Fare, on Tables Made by the Owners
description: KOREAN barbecue is a refreshing change of pace from the big slabs of smoked or slow-cooked meat featured in American styles. At Ssambap Korean B.B.Q. in Stony Brook, for instance, diners cook thin slices of raw meat on gas grills at their tables, then take the cooked morsels of meat and enfold them in a romaine leaf, possibly adding some bean paste, scallions and sliced radishes from among the condiments on the table. The resulting lettuce-wrapped package is a ssam; add rice to the mix and you have a ssambap.

description: Washington

description: To the Editor:
