description: To the Editor:

title: For Bullied Bus Monitor, a Windfall to Ease the Pain
description: About $600,000 has been raised online this week for a 68-year-old school bus monitor from upstate New York after a cellphone video showing a group of boys on the bus brutally taunting her spread quickly on the Internet.

title: Photos of Childbirth
description: To the Editor:

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,001 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Our Shared DNA
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobs in Restaurants
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Sentenced for Punching Woman in Fight for Parking Space
description: It began as the sort of tense dispute that is a regular part of Manhattans rattle and hum: two people, a man and a woman, arguing over who had the rightful claim to a parking space.

title: Even a Martini Has Prosciutto in It
description: My first pilgrimage to West Hartfords newest gastronomic shrine came one Tuesday evening when a friend and I managed to snag the last two seats at the bar. Across the marble counter, we found ourselves facing hanging cured meats and a gleaming Berkel slicer. All around, patrons enjoying cocktails and prosecco were dangling bits of prosciutto into their mouths.

title: Flower Power Sags in London
description: LONDON  The calendar kept by the theater here is as unforgiving as time itself. This season it is confirming, with withering wit and sociological specificity, that youth is never evergreen. Winter, you see, has finally arrived for the flower children of the 1960s.

title: G.M. Recalls 475,000 Chevy Cruzes to Fix a Potential Engine Fire Hazard
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Friday that it was recalling 475,000 of its popular Chevrolet Cruze compact cars in the United States and Canada to modify parts that could cause fires in the engine compartment.

title: Blues and Soul, Vintage Blend
description: Bonnie Raitt began her show at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night the same way she begins her new album, Slipstream: with a brittle funk tune called Used to Rule the World. Written by Randall Bramblett, it rolls out a catalog of comeuppance, its point aimed at anyone who ever claimed immunity against the passage of time.

title: Family-Owned, and Perfect for Families
description: It wasnt clear, at first, what the relationships were. Three handsome guys in their 20s were sitting at one of Cedar Street Grills prime window tables, talking and trading hats and goofing around. Friends? Roommates? But as the meal proceeded, it was revealed by the diners body language: The middle-age man and woman sitting with them were their parents, and the three were brothers, probably just back from college.

title: Far From a Shooting in Florida, an Increase in Block Watchers
description: Walking home in Astoria, Queens, one night this month, Daniel Rutkowski, 52, noticed a darkened stretch of sidewalk and looked up to see that the streetlight was out. He pulled out his cellphone and dialed, and said to the person on the other end, by way of introduction, Here is my number, rattling off a confidential identification code.

title: So Articulate, Yet Crazed by Loss
description: When I first read Joan Didions book The Year of Magical Thinking, in 2005, the observation I remembered best was about shoes. Ms. Didion, newly widowed, reasoned that she could not give away her husbands shoes because he would need them when he came back. After seeing the Westport Country Playhouses moving, elegiac production of the play that Ms. Didion adapted from that book, the line that echoes in my head is Youre safe. Im here.

title: We Have Met the Solution and It Is Us
description: RIO DE JANEIRO

title: Showdown at the Trailer Park
description: The New Jersey Repertory Company valiantly strains its modest stage capabilities to present the world premiere of American Stare, a new play by Tony Glazer that demands six actors and a realistic setting for a contemporary story that takes place in a trailer park in South Florida.

title: Something We Can All Agree On
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  From the start, the organizers of the London 2012 Festival wanted this celebration to take place all over Britain. As if to emphasize that goal, none of the major events that officially opened the festival on Thursday night took place in London.

title: In Banks Downgrade, Not Much to Worry Consumers
description: Now that several of the big banks credit ratings have been downgraded, they may have to pay more to borrow money. And while the banks are hardly shy about passing higher costs on to their customers, many experts said they expected that the downgrade would have little effect  at least in the near term  on consumers.

title: Hairston Embraces His Bigger, If Still Limited, Role
description: Ronny Cedeno, in his first game since May 26 after going on the diabled list with a strained left calf, was starting and batting second Friday night aganst the Yankees. Kirk Nieuwenhuis, the starting center fielder and usual leadoff man, was on the bench, as was the regular starting catcher, Josh Thole, and second baseman Daniel Murphy, who badly needed at-bats to shake a 2-for-21 slump. Manager Terry Collins felt he had no choice. A left-handed pitcher was on the mound.

title: For Pole-Vaulters, Clearing the Bar Is the Easy Part
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Mark Hollis often finds it hard not to scoff at vacation travelers who complain about having to fit sandals, bathing suits and tanning oil into a suitcase while still keeping its weight less than 50 pounds.

title: Light-Rock Concerts With a Cause
description: THE Two River Theater in Red Bank, best known for its dramatic offerings, is the setting for an Intimate Evening series of concerts this summer featuring artists like Rickie Lee Jones and Pure Prairie League. The shows will appeal to light-rock listeners, the organizers said.

title: Giants and Jets Sue to Block Mall in Meadowlands
description: The Giants and the Jets filed a lawsuit on Friday to block the proposed American Dream shopping and entertainment mall in the Meadowlands, which they contend will threaten their ability to successfully hold games at the nearby MetLife Stadium.

title: An Increase in Barriers to Trade Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON  Argentina tweaked import regulations on bottle caps and water balloons. India banned exports of cotton. South Africa instituted a tariff on artificial turf. Those recent policy changes sound minute. But they, and scores more like them, have stoked fears about trade protectionism rising as the global economy cools.

title: A Sober New Reality in Credit Downgrades for Banks
description: When a consumers credit score drops, it is hard to recover financially. Wall Street firms could face the same fate.

title: Maritime Rites
description: Central Park Lake

title: Cuomo Backs Rangels Re-election Bid
description: Four days before the states Congressional primary elections, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Friday endorsed Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and two other Democrats who are in tight races in New York City.

title: Vexations
description: Wall and Broad Streets

title: Musik im Bauch
description: Naumburg Bandshell

title: A Daylight Theft of a Drawing by Dal, Incongruous in Simplicity and Ease
description: He did not wear gloves, nor did he don a ski mask. He staged no elaborate diversion. He did not even hide under the cover of night.

title: The New Rule
description: Father Duffy Square

title: Arkansas Court Upends Death Penalty
description: The Arkansas Supreme Court struck down the states death penalty law on Friday, faulting a provision that permitted the Corrections Department to select the fatal drugs used in an execution.

title: Germany Progresses, Greece is Out. A Metaphor? An Omen?
description: In the end, the Germans won.

title: For Young Olympic Hopefuls, Table Tennis Is All Business
description: In Fridays editions of The New York Times, Somini Sengupta told the story of an unlikely incubator of Olympic talent: a nondescript warehouse in Milpitas, Calif., known as the India Community Center Table Tennis Center.

title: Basketball Star Sues Club Over Brawl; Liquor Agency Files Charges
description: Tony Parker, a point guard for the San Antonio Spurs, has filed a $20 million lawsuit against the W.i.P. nightclub in New York and its operators, saying his left eye was damaged during a brawl at the club last week involving the R&B singer Chris Brown, the rapper Drake and their entourages.

title: In Karaoke, Lawmakers Find a Catalyst for Collegiality
description: ALBANY  After several minutes of swaying side-to-side and fiddling with the microphones cord in his left hand, Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol stiffened his body. His torso inflated.

title: Snapshots of a Presidential Tour: Seized Silverware and a Stumble
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It was a quirky day on the road for President Obama. He headed to Florida for a couple of events: a speech to a Latino group in Lake Buena Vista outside Orlando, then a campaign rally in Tampa.

title: Game 5 Receives High TV Ratings
description: The Miami Heat won the N.B.A. title Thursday but even after being blown out in Game 5, the Oklahoma City Thunder proved emphatically that their small-market status did not hurt viewership.

title: Killings Curb Reporting of Mexican Crime Wave
description: XALAPA, Mexico  Throwing his burly frame to the ground, the photojournalist Alberto Morales click, click, clicked away on Tuesday as police officers and soldiers in body armor barked into radios, hoisted their rifles and crouched into position on word of a suspicious vehicle moving in.

title: In Valencia, Another Spin of the Wheel
description: VALENCIA, Spain  There have been seven different winners in the first seven races this season, and we may find it impossible to know who will win next; but these days it is even more difficult to figure out from the series practice sessions on Fridays who is most likely to take the pole position on Saturday.

title: New Union Leader Vows Tougher Fight for Rights
description: LOS ANGELES  For Lee Saunders, the newly elected president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, defeat does not mean retreat.

title: Companies Ills Did Not Harm Romneys Firm
description: Cambridge Industries, an automotive plastics supplier whose losses had been building for three consecutive years, finally filed for bankruptcy in May 2000 under a mountain of debt that had ballooned to more than $300 million.

title: Gay Marriage Gains Backer as Major Foe Revises Views
description: David Blankenhorn, a national figure in the movement against same-sex marriage, has recanted his opposition, saying the time has come for me to accept gay marriage and emphasize the good that it can do.

title: Chinese Data Mask Depth of Slowdown, Executives Say
description: HONG KONG  As the Chinese economy continues to sputter, prominent corporate executives in China and Western economists say there is evidence that local and provincial officials are falsifying economic statistics to disguise the true depth of the troubles.

title: Obama Draws Contrast With Romney in His Turn Before Hispanics
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  President Obama on Friday sought to capitalize on his newly announced reprieve for young illegal immigrants with a broad attack on Mitt Romney and Congressional Republicans as obstacles to a comprehensive overhaul of the nations immigration system.

title: Bill Is Passed to Make Kindergarten Mandatory for 5-Year-Olds
description: State lawmakers in Albany voted this week to make kindergarten mandatory for all 5-year-olds in New York City, lowering the required age for schooling by one year.

title: Why Vincent Chin Matters
description: San Francisco

title: Shaken by Sandusky Scandal, a Changed Penn State Is Moving On
description: With Penn States campus tucked away in a remote section of central Pennsylvania, one of its charms has always been its isolation and simplicity. The destination restaurant is The Tavern. The most popular hotel is still called an inn. And the primary administration building is simply known as Old Main.

title: The (Sort of) New Mitt
description: Today: Mitt Romney and immigration.

title: Bike-Share Program May Mean More Accident Suits Against the City, Liu Warns
description: The New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, is warning that the citys ambitious bike-share program, which is to begin next month, could face lawsuits from accidents involving those bikes.

title: Dolan Begins Religious Freedom Campaign
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan on Friday helped kick off a national campaign opposing President Obamas health care mandates and other government policies that Roman Catholic leaders say threaten their religious freedom.

title: Senates Vote Ousts Leader of Paraguay After a Clash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Paraguays Senate voted on Friday to remove President Fernando Lugo from office, plunging the country into a political crisis. Mr. Lugo said he accepted the results of the hastily arranged vote, despite describing the efforts to remove him as an express coup dtat.

title: 6 Charged in Murder of Rapper 50 Cents Associate
description: They called him Jimmy Henchman  the man with the Teflon reputation, tied for years to the feud that led to the murders of two legends of the hip-hop world.

title: Velzquez and Opponents in House Race Debate Influences
description: During the only debate of the campaign, Representative Nydia M. Velzquez and her best-known opponent, Councilman Erik M. Dilan, fought back on Friday against accusations that they were controlled by others, describing themselves as unbossed and unbought.

title: Finding in Sunlight a Sound and a Taste
description: Mountainville, N.Y.  A sparkling melody dances through the air on a hilltop in the south fields of Storm King Art Center, a sculpture park that spans 500 verdant acres here. Emanating from four bullhorn speakers mounted on a lone pole, the jazzy keyboard notes fill what is normally a silence broken only by birdsong and the occasional whoosh of the wind. Peter Coffin, the artist who created this sound installation, called it a soundtrack to the sunshine, an answer to the question: What does sunlight sound like?

title: Berkshire Hathaway Buys a Newspaper in Texas
description: Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald to expand in Texas. Berkshire is buying the newspaper, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, from the Robinson family, the company said. Terms were not disclosed. Warren E. Buffett, Berkshires chief, has said that newspapers must rethink whether to offer free content on the Internet, and that publications with a community focus can thrive where there is little competition.

title: Runaway Masters
description: The Arago, a mail steamer, was scheduled to head north at dawn from the Union outpost on South Carolinas Sea Islands. Any letters that missed the outgoing ships departure would wait for another 10 days. So it was that Maj. Gen. David Hunter stayed up all night on June 22, 1862, amid a violent thunderstorm, writing incessantly, assisted by his young aide, Maj. Charles Graham Halpine. Hunter, a West Pointer from the class of 1822, commanded The Department of the South  in Halpines words the tortuous and broken sea-coast of Georgia, South Carolina, and Florida that had proven vulnerable to Union naval probes.

title: Where Was Stonewall?
description: In the early spring of 1862, the Confederate general Thomas J. Stonewall Jackson won dazzling victories in Virginias Shenandoah Valley that made him the hero of the South. Combining incredible energy and audacity with a mastery of terrain and tactics, Jacksons Valley Campaign is internationally famous and still studied today.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mississippis Only Abortion Clinic at Risk as Law Nears
description: JACKSON, Miss.  It was only recently that Dr. Willie Parker began flying down here from Washington, heading to work at a vaultlike building that sits unassumingly on a busy thoroughfare. On his way in, he may pass Prof. Matt Friedeman, standing on the sidewalk with a Bible and a handful of pamphlets, having made the four-minute drive from his home as he has done once a week for years.

title: Burger King, the Cash Cow
description: Earlier this week, a well-known company went public in a complicated transaction that involved a handful of Wall Street sharpies and a mysterious investment vehicle called a SPAC. The company was Burger King.

title: Armstrong Could Lose More Than Titles if Guilty of Doping
description: Lance Armstrong should be ready to repay a $5 million performance bonus he earned by winning the 2004 Tour de France if the latest doping accusations against him lead to his losing that title, a lawyer for the company that paid that bonus said Friday.

title: The Anti-Union Roberts Court
description: The Supreme Courts ruling this week in Knox v. Service Employees International Union is one of the most brazen of the Roberts court. It shows how defiantly the five justices act in advancing the aggressive conservatism of their majority on the court.

title: A Skewed Take on Love in the 60s
description: Soon after Luv became a huge hit on Broadway in 1964, Murray Schisgal, its author, was asked in an interview to explain the title. The emotion of love has been perverted and misused to such an extent that it can only be defined by using another word, he answered in part. L-u-v is the perversion of l-o-v-e.

title: Video Adds to Honduran Drug Raid Mystery
description: WASHINGTON  Aerial surveillance video of a fatal shootout during a counternarcotics mission in Honduras last month shows a long, dugout-style boat ramming a smaller canoe carrying Honduran and American agents  and a seized cocaine shipment  followed by a brief but furious round of gunfire.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Nik Wallendas tightrope walk across Niagara Falls, the first hot spell of summer and a rock slide in the Palisades.

title: A Small Stimulus for Europe
description: At the conclusion of the meeting of leaders from the Group of 20 largest economies early this week, participants said they were united in their efforts to promote growth and jobs. But no one was sure whether Angela Merkel, Germanys chancellor and a champion of budget austerity, was ready to drop her opposition to more government spending to ease Europes debt crisis. Her agreement on Friday to a stimulus package worth up to 130 billion euros is a welcome sign that she might come around after all.

title: For Duquesne Professors, a Union Fight That Transcends Religion
description: Union busting is a mortal sin, the Catholic Scholars for Worker Justice said in a 2010 statement on the indispensable role of unions. And while the church hierarchy has never quite put it that way, workers right to unionize is an issue on which church teachings are pretty clear.

title: A New Generation Keeps Up With Bruce Jenner
description: EUGENE, Ore.  For the first time since the 1976 Olympic trials, Bruce Jenner returned to Hayward Field on Friday as almost surely a bigger star now than he was then.

title: Whats Missing From This Picture?
description: New York lawmakers had little reason to celebrate the conclusion of this years legislative session on Thursday. Gov. Andrew Cuomo praised the Legislature effusively for its work, but he failed to mention how he and lawmakers created corrupt legislative districts that will remain for a decade  the worst political act of the session.

title: Realized in the End
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  This puzzle almost made me weep with frustration, but I loved it. Its the same as all the Saturday puzzles youve done, yet its not.

title: Alan Turings Legacy
description: Alan Turing, born a century ago Saturday, was only 41 when he committed suicide. But into that short life, he crowded several lives. His essential insights into mathematics and the nature of computability dealt with the limits of what can be calculated by machines. One way to describe his achievement is to say that he was a genius of coded-ness, whether the code was mathematical, cryptological or biological.

title: A Debate Goes Behind Closed Doors
description: In the long war over Wall Street regulation, a little-noticed clash erupted this week over a plan to rein in risky trading overseas.

title: Sandusky Guilty of Sexual Abuse of 10 Young Boys
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, was convicted Friday of sexually abusing young boys, completing the downfall of a onetime local hero in a scandal that shook a proud Pennsylvania community, a prominent American university and the world of major college football.

title: Seeking Some Revenge, Greece Comes Up Empty
description: RETHYMNO, Greece  Poor Greece. Condemned in the court of world opinion after an economic crisis spread around Europe, Greek fans had to swallow a humiliating 4-2 thrashing on Friday night in Gdansk, Poland, at the hands of Germany as the delighted German chancellor, Angela Merkel, looked on in the stands.

title: Rodriguez, Having Been Down Similar Path, Is Happy to See James Win a Title
description: Alex Rodriguez watched his hometown Miami Heat win the N.B.A. championship on Thursday night, and immediately knew the exhilaration and relief that LeBron James was experiencing. Rodriguez said he felt the same way three years ago when he won his first World Series and eliminated one source of ammunition from his critics.

title: Florida Struggles to Overcome Threats to Freshwater Springs
description: SILVER SPRINGS, Fla.  Of Floridas 700 artesian springs, Silver Springs shimmered the brightest. Its fresh water was so translucent that the white sand and tiny shells at the bottom glistened, giving the river and springs a beautiful blue tint from above.

title: Bullies on the Bus
description: Making the Bus Monitor Cry.

title: A Digital Art Space
description: APP MoMA Art Lab

title: Cost of Minnesota Flood Estimated at $100 Million
description: The waters in Duluth are receding, but the damage is done: the northeastern Minnesota city estimates more than $100 million will be required to repair utilities, streets, parks and trails in the city and surrounding county of St. Louis, said Pakou Ly, a spokeswoman for Duluth. The State Department of Transportation estimates its roads have sustained $20 million worth of damage.

title: Searching for a New Economy
description: Given persistent debt troubles, the deep divisions between haves and have nots, and wear and tear on the planets living systems, theres much talk these days of new ways to define, gauge and nurture economic progress.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Jamie Dimon testified again about JPMorgan Chases huge trading loss, the Federal Reserve outlined more steps to help the economy and Ann Currys negotiations to leave the Today show signaled greater problems at NBC.

title: Mike Miller Shows How Heats System Can Work
description: In 12 N.B.A. seasons, Mike Miller earned a reputation as a reliable sharpshooting veteran. Though hes received accolades like Rookie of the Year (2001) and Sixth Man of the Year (2006), an N.B.A. championship eluded him.

title: Delighting in Sea Mail
description: HARVEY BENNETT, 61, has lived his entire life in Amagansett, on the East End of Long Island, but every few months since childhood, he has cast his fortunes out on the high seas by putting a note in a bottle and throwing it into the ocean.

title: The Third Intifada Is Inevitable
description: Jerusalem

title: Friends, Nostalgia and a Mountain of Seafood
description: Summer on the shore evokes soft breezes, cold beer, mini-golf, fried clams and lobsters the color of sunset. This year, that vision becomes reality amid the warehouses and cobblestone streets of Red Hook, Brooklyn, right across the street from the Fairway parking lot. In just two weeks, Brooklyn Crab has become the hot new vacation spot  for an evening. Its beach-town kitsch a long block from the New York Harbor.

title: Mets Closer Stirs Pot, Then Shuts Door
description: Hours before thousands of fans watched Frank Francisco dance around the Yankees in the rain, the Mets closer walked into the clubhouse Friday either unaware or ambivalent about the weight of his words, serenaded by the Chicken Dance song and surprised with a copy of The New York Post at his locker.

title: The Pepsi Septuagenarian
description: The breakout star of this years N.B.A. finals was not a member of the Miami Heat or the Oklahoma City Thunder, but instead a man appearing to be well into his 70s who had supernatural basketball gifts and referred to himself simply as Uncle Drew.

title: Emerson College Makes Splash in N.B.A.
description: BOSTON  Situated in the heart of the citys theater district, Emerson College boasts a list of notable alumni that includes the longtime Hollywood figures Jay Leno, Norman Lear and Henry Winkler.

title: Game 5 Draws Highest Average Audience of Series
description: The Miami Heat won the N.B.A. title Thursday night, but even after being blown out in Game 5, the Oklahoma City Thunder proved emphatically that their small-market status did not hurt viewership.

title: Pittsburgh-Carolina Trade Reunites Staal Brothers
description: PITTSBURGH  On Tuesday, Stefan Matteau, son of the former Ranger Stephane Matteau, whose famous overtime goal beat the Devils in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals, said it would be a bit ironic if he wound up being drafted by the Devils rather than the Rangers later in the week.

title: California: Cigarette Tax Defeated
description: Voters narrowly rejected a proposed $1-a-pack tax increase on cigarettes. On Friday, trailing by about 28,000 votes with just over 100,000 ballots left to count, proponents of the statewide tax conceded defeat. The vote had remained too close to call since polls closed on June 5. California has not raised the tax since 1998, and proceeds from the tax would have financed cancer research. Opponents of the tax spent nearly $50 million, largely from the tobacco industry, to defeat the measure.

title: I.R.A. Ex-Commander to Shake Hands With Queen
description: DUBLIN  In one of the most anticipated gestures in recent Irish history, a former commander of the Irish Republican Army will shake hands next week in Belfast with Queen Elizabeth II, once a prime target of I.R.A. attacks, the groups onetime political wing announced Friday.

title: 10K Runners Are First to Make Olympic Team
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Running through rain that was at times torrential, Galen Rupp, Matt Tegenkamp and Dathan Ritzenhein became the first runners to officially make the United States Olympic team Friday night when they qualified in the 10,000 meters.

title: Virginia: Governor Threatens University Board With Removal
description: The University of Virginia must decide on Tuesday whether to keep its president, Gov. Robert F. McDonnell said Friday, or he will ask the entire governing board to step down. The president, Teresa Sullivan, resigned two weeks ago after being told the Board of Visitors wanted her out. But protests from faculty members and students prompted the board to call next Tuesdays meeting on her status. I want final action by the board on Tuesday, Governor McDonnell wrote in a letter to the board. If you fail to do so, I will call for the resignation of the entire board on Wednesday.

title: For 40-Year-Old Rookie, Leader Board Is Long Way From Selling Knives
description: CROMWELL, Conn.  Kimberly Christian could not help but chuckle earlier this week when she noticed that the PGA Tour Web site had divided the Travelers Championship field by age and listed her husband, Gary, under the category of grizzled veterans.

title: Hiding Out, With Books and Food
description: As an editor at Simon & Schuster, Karen Thompson Walker used to spend her days polishing the prose of her roster of authors. But nearly every morning for more than three years, she was also rising at 7 to squeeze in an hour or two of writing before going to her day job in Midtown Manhattan. The product of that quiet endeavor is her debut novel, an apocalyptic tale titled The Age of Miracles, which will be published by Random House on Tuesday. Now a full-time writer, Ms. Walker, 32, lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with her husband, Casey, 32, who recently earned a Ph.D. in English literature from Princeton and has enrolled in the Iowa Writers Workshop in the fall. Until the couple pick up and move to Iowa City in August, they can be found wandering Brooklyn on Sundays.

title: Mets Make Opening Statement Hold Up
description: Because of an ill-considered comment by Frank Francisco, the Mets shaky closer, there was a heightened sense of drama in the ninth inning at Citi Field on Friday. Would the Yankees make Francisco pay for his remark, or would he back up his brash statement?

title: Oars Fly in Rumble on the River
description: AMANDA KRAUS stood in her favorite spot on the second-floor deck of the Peter Jay Sharp Boathouse, which floats in a cove on the Harlem River where Dyckman Street meets the Harlem River Drive. She watched as a pair of $45,000 shells, each propelled by a gaggle of high school students, eight to a squad, rushed past. When done right, its poetry in motion, she said of rowing crew.

title: Lee Is Doing Everything for Phillies but Winning
description: PHILADELPHIA  Cliff Lee was scheduled to start Friday nights game for the Phillies before it was rained out, and his basic season statistics read this way: 0-3, 3.48. That record would generate scrutiny for a past Cy Young Award winner in the seasons first month. But the season is in its third month, and Lee is still winless.

title: The Road to the Ironman
description: GUY ADAMI has experienced the thrill of trading millions of dollars in precious metals in a matter of seconds on Wall Street in the 1990s, and analyzing the financial crisis each afternoon as a panelist on the live CNBC program Fast Money.

title: Ill Have Another Will Stand Stud in Japan
description: Ill Have Another, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes last month, will head to Japan to stand at stud.

title: Offspring Who Cling to the Nest
description: Not too long ago, I asked a friend, the mother of two daughters who are 9 and 13, whether she had ever taken her children to Disney World  a contractual obligation of parenthood, I assumed. The girls attend a progressive school in New York, and their tastes and proclivities run accordingly. The older might be found on a Saturday cooking ground ostrich in spices, in deference to ancient Roman cuisine. The younger can solve elaborate cubic puzzles in the time it takes to turn on a faucet.

Twenty years and some 2,000 miles removed from the most memorable duel (and startling stumble) in United States decathlon history, a serendipitous twist of timing appeared to have left the sport on the cusp of another American renaissance. The Olympic trials here were supposed to be the send-off. There was the veteran Bryan Clay, 32, hoping to defend his gold medal from Beijing; there was the defending world champion, Trey Hardee, 28, squarely in his prime; and there was the phenom Ashton Eaton, who at 24 may already be the best of the group. American dominance in London seemed almost assured.

Chowhounds from Chico to Chula Vista have been opening their wallets for restaurants foie gras menus, gorging themselves like birds before the winter migration. The laws purpose is to end gavage, the ancient practice of forcing grain down the throat of a goose or duck until its liver is grossly enlarged. The laws critics say gavage is hardly more stress-inducing than the many other things humans do to the animals they eat. The corporate operations that grow and slaughter pigs, poultry and cattle represent animal cruelty on an immense scale, they say, about which the foie gras ban does nothing.

The big question is whether Congress has the power to require that individuals buy or obtain health insurance as part of a comprehensive reform. Other issues are whether Congress can broaden Medicaid coverage of the poor and taxpayers can even challenge the individual mandate before it takes effect in 2014. The outcome  aside from determining whether millions of Americans will get health coverage  will show whether the Roberts court recognizes that constitutional law requires that it defer to Congress on matters affecting the national economy.

description: OMAHA  In the individual medley events, the swimmer Tyler Clary has spent the past four years playing Andy Murray to Michael Phelpss Rafael Nadal and Ryan Lochtes Novak Djokovic.

title: Reader Comments on Iran
description: My Sunday column is my last from my Iran road trip, and its accompanied by a terrific video made by a Times video journalist, Adam Ellick, who accompanied me. I am still somewhat surprised and awed that Iran not only gave us visas but also allowed us to travel across the country unescorted. After all, Bahrain  our ally!  doesnt even give me a visa, because of my human rights reporting.

title: Supporters Slow to Grasp Health Laws Legal Risks
description: WASHINGTON  With the Supreme Court likely to render judgment on President Obamas health care law this week, the White House and Congress find themselves in a position that many advocates of the legislation once considered almost unimaginable.

title: My Iranian Road Trip
description: A short documentary follows the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof as he travels across the country talking to ordinary citizens about their lives and the effectiveness of American sanctions.

title: Juror Says Panel Had Little Doubt on Sanduskys Guilt
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa.  Joshua Harper watched Jerry Sandusky listen to one guilty verdict after another  45 in all  and was more certain than ever that Sandusky, the former Penn State football assistant, had sexually abused those young boys. Sandusky never flinched. No sign of regret creased his face.

title: In a Secret Ballot, Pole-Vaulters Have Their Say
description: EUGENE, Ore.  How is it determined that an Olympic trials competition should be postponed because of weather? Sometimes, apparently, the process resembles a student council election.

title: Critics See Flaws in Spains Art
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A consensus has formed at Euro 2012. Germany is the team to beat. Spain cannot decide on a lineup. It seems unsettled, if hardly unnerved. This is what happens when people are no longer content with beauty and now expect perfection.

title: For Wealthy Romney Donors, Up Close and Personal Access
description: PARK CITY, Utah They schmoozed with Mitt Romney at a barbecue cookout at the Olympic Park, pressing him on labor regulations and the threat of a nuclear Iran as downhill skiers performed midair flips behind them.

title: Mets Try to See Win Column as Half Full
description: Terry Collins and Miguel Batista started their major league careers in the same week, with the same team, in the same bullpen. Collins was a rookie bullpen coach for the 1992 Pittsburgh Pirates. Batista was a Rule 5 draft pick who made the team as a reliever. On the first Saturday of the regular season, he logged two innings at the end of a loss in Philadelphia. He did not resurface in the majors for more than four years.

title: Despite Slam Dearth, Federer Looms as a Wimbledon Favorite
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The Grand Slam drought grows longer for Roger Federer. He has remained a serial winner elsewhere, but he has not won one of the four titles that matter most since January 2010 and has not reached a final at a Grand Slam event for more than a year.

title: The Sandusky Verdict: Who Would Believe a Kid?
description: The former assistant Penn State football coach Jerry Sandusky was convicted late Friday of sexually abusing 10 boys, the verdict coming after two days of deliberation by a jury of seven women and five men, more than half with ties to Penn State.

title: In Omaha, a Hotels Guest List Will Include a Baseball Champion
description: OMAHA  Next year, every team that qualifies for the College World Series will demand to stay at the Hilton Omaha, one block south of TD Ameritrade Park.

title: Ex-Governor of New York Reluctantly Accepts Portrait
description: For years, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has refused to sit for his official portrait, leaving a void in the likenesses of former governors that line a corridor in the New York State Capitol.

title: I.O.C. Adopts Policy for Deciding Whether an Athlete Can Compete as a Woman
description: Three years after international sports officials drew widespread criticism over the handling of the case of a female athlete who was accused of being unfairly masculine, the International Olympic Committee has adopted new regulations for determining whether someone should not be allowed to compete as a woman if her gender is questioned under those rules.

title: Mets Bay Feeling Much Better
description: The Mets clubhouse was all laughs before Saturdays game against the Yankees. That was chiefly because of Little Jerry Seinfeld, a chicken that Tim Byrdak let loose inside as a gag a day earlier, which players say has brought good luck and humor to Citi Field. Left out of the shenanigans was Jason Bay, who addressed the serious subject matter of the concussion that landed him on the disabled list.

title: After Bad Start, N.B.A. Season Finishes with Inspiring Vision
description: As the music blared and the confetti spilled Thursday night in Miami, two transcendent figures met at midcourt, shared an embrace and some parting words  a poetic coda to a season that almost wasnt, an inspiring vision for the future.

title: Move to a New (Old) Park Helped Arizona on Road to College World Series
description: OMAHA  Baseball fans in Tucson revere Hi Corbett Field nearly as much as Bostonians do Fenway Park. The memories transcend generations. The Hall of Famers Bob Feller, Willie Mays and Ted Williams played at Hi Corbett during its 46 years as the spring training home of the Cleveland Indians, and part of the 1989 film Major League was filmed there.

title: Worlds No. 1 Needs Help to Prevail in Moscow
description: The Tal Memorial tournament in Moscow was a nail-biter: five of the 10 players were tied for the lead with two rounds to go.

title: Libya Democracy Clashes With Fervor for Jihad
description: DARNAH, Libya  Abdul-Hakim al-Hasadi first took up arms nearly 20 years ago to try to bring Islamic law to Libya. He studied under the Taliban in Afghanistan, and during last years uprising he led a local militia council here in a city famous as a cradle of Islamic jihad.

title: Flyers Acquire Defenseman Schenn From the Maple Leafs
description: The Philadelphia Flyers acquired defenseman Luke Schenn from the Toronto Maple Leafs for forward James van Riemsdyk. Schenn, 22, who has 14 goals and 61 assists in four seasons, should help replace the void created by the loss of Chris Pronger, who is unlikely to return because of postconcussion symptoms. Van Riemsdyk, also 22, has 47 goals and 52 assists for 99 points in three seasons.

title: Staying Patient, Yankees Bash Two Homers to Top Mets

Chavez was pacing in the tunnel between the dugout and the visiting clubhouse, keeping his surgically repaired back loose, when Raul Ibanez hit a three-run homer in the seventh, tying the game, 3-3.

The three runners talked excitedly about having made the United States Olympic team, with Tarmoh saying, Im so thankful for everything. Allyson Felix, who was said to have finished fourth, was despondent. Fourth is the worst, she said.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Outlook magazine in its recent issue weighs in on the debate about having a single entrance examination for all engineering colleges in India. The federal minister for human resource development, Kapil Sibal, is of the opinion that a single entrance examination will aid in creating uniformity in the system and reduce the applicants burden of stress, preparation time and money spent on examination fees. However, this proposal has not been well received. The piece delves into the negative reactions this announcement has engendered among the management of the prestigious Indian Institute of Technology (I.I.T.), which has several campuses in India, alumni of the institution and students aspiring to seek admission in the premier engineering institution.

Hes not a boy wizard like Harry, but he works magic just the same.

title: With Opposition to Runoff, Decision on Final Olympic Spot Could Be Delayed

As it turns out, the discussions may drag on even longer.

title: In Sleazy Era, Writer Found His Subjects
description: Don Winslow, whose book The Kings of Cool just came out, is a rarity among writers of crime fiction: He doesnt just make it up. For years he was a private investigator, and he used to read writers like Chandler, Hammett and Elmore Leonard while sitting in his car on stakeouts. Eventually he worked his way up to high-profile arson cases in California (the background for his 1999 novel California Fire and Life), but he got his start in Times Square in the late 70s, when, he likes to say, the whole place was a glittering river of theft.

title: Man Is Killed by U.S. Agent in Drug Raid in Honduras

title: A Festival With Classical Roots and Fanciful Surroundings
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  The Caramoor International Music Festival has a stranger back story than most summer music destinations, and its quirkiness remains a strong draw. It takes place on a 90-acre estate of Italianate gardens, picnic grounds, winding paths, outdoor theaters and an architecturally disparate country villa. The deals  like one being considered in Baltimore to allow advertisements on fire trucks  seemingly serve a need for each side. Cash-strapped cities averse to raising taxes can help pay the bills with the revenue from sponsorship deals. (By renaming its Bus Rapid Transit system the HealthLine, Cleveland received $6.25 million over 25 years.) And, Mr. Cooper writes, advertisers can try to reach consumers who have grown more adept at tuning out commercials, whether with remote controls or digital video recorders.

A riot of colors, ideas and symbols, the work is are arranged in three sections: the Hoovers (The New), the Banality sculptures, each of them according to Mr. Koons, a metaphor for the viewers cultural guilt and shame, and Celebration, a mix of paintings and balloon sculptures (dog, tulips, a heart). title: No Way to Run an Olympic Trial
description: The easiest old joke among the five-ring set is that the only amateurs left in the Olympics are the people running them. This theme pops up reliably at every Games, so we have to hand it to USA Track and Field for getting a jump on things and accomplishing this a month before the Olympics even start. In the first weekend of its Olympic trials, a dead heat for third place in the women's 100 means one of the marquee spots in the Olympics might be decided by a coin flip, or Allyson Felix or Jeneba Tarmoh could gracefully bow out for the good of making this seeming like less of a circus. The fact that those are two of the top three options hanging over the scenario two days after the race tells you pretty much everything you need to know about this enterprise. And these options were stumbled upon by USA Track and Field about a day and a half ago.

title: Stolen Bust of Rodin by Camille Claudel Recovered in France

The bust, one of about 50 sculptures made by Claudel, is estimated to be worth between about $600,000 and $1.2 million, according to Agence France-Presse.

title: As You Were

They have watched as hundreds of millions of special-interest dollars flowed into super PACs, and into secretive advocacy groups that violate the courts own preference for disclosure.

title: In Kashmir, Killing Ebbs, but Killers Roam Free
description: BONIYAR, India  After decades of war, Kashmir is blooming again. Hotels are bursting, roads are being fixed and offices rebuilt. But with the guns silenced, India must soon decide whether justice will be as welcome as the tourists.

description: Scientists have located the cells in the cervix that give rise to cancer when attacked by the human papillomavirus, a discovery that may lead to new methods of preventing and treating the disease.

title: Vollmers Fast Early Swim Has Her Thinking Higher
description: OMAHA  Dana Vollmer pulled off her goggles and read her time on the overhead scoreboard Monday morning with a mix of surprise and relief. Surprise, in that she nearly broke her American record in 100-meter butterfly in a preliminary at the Olympic swimming trials. And relief, in that a swim that fast felt so smooth and easy.

title: Tesla Model S Offers a Lesson in Electric-Vehicle Economics

The luxury sedans were fitted with the most powerful battery pack available from the start-up automaker, rated at 85 kilowatt-hours. In combination with the vehicles electric motor and other running gear, those reserves of energy are capable of generating 416 horsepower, Tesla claims.

title: Goodbye to Mountain Forests?
description: When the smoke finally clears and new plant life pokes up from the scorched earth after the wildfires raging in the southern Rockies, what emerges will look radically different than what was there just a few weeks ago. According to Craig Allen, a research ecologist with the United States Geological Survey in Los Alamos, N.M., forests in the region have not been regenerating after the vast wildfires that have been raging for the last decade and a half.

title: Powerhouse Fare for High-Powered Bidders

For an offering of Japanese contemporary art, potential bidders were plied with freshly sliced sushi. And for a preview before the sale of The Screamby Edvard Munch, who grew up in Oslo, there was a lavish smorgasbord of Norwegian specialties.

title: How Wider Coverage Affects Health Spending
description: In an article over the weekend, I took a close look at a continuing health study relevant to the Supreme Court ruling due Thursday on the federal health care law, the Affordable Care Act.

title: A Tale of Post-Traumatic Success Disorder
description: Halfway through this intense but ungainly memoir Anthony Swofford describes being enraged at his father and taking his fury out in his driving, as he guns his BMW M3 down an upstate New York highway, ripping through its gears, an angry man in a sick-fast car, doing twice the 45 m.p.h. speed limit. In front of me was about two miles of mostly straight road, he writes, and I killed it, I chewed it up, the speedo climbed to 90, and then 105, and then 120, and then 130, and then it hovered and ticked at 133; the world flew by, seasons changed, my heart hung at the edge of the world. I could die, I could kill myself with a flick of my wrist and it would look like a mistake, a daredevil young writer, war veteran, pushing all the limits at once and doing a header into a tree with his $65,000 car.

title: Traffic Noise May Raise Heart Attack Risk

title: A Town That Backed a Failed Project Refuses to Pay

title: New Troupe Chooses Bronx Zoo for a Debut
description: Now and then you witness a debut so happy and so rich with potential that you cant wait to share the news. In the case of On Site Opera, a fledgling company that mounted its inaugural production on Saturday afternoon, it seems especially vital to spread the word, since few cognoscenti were on hand to witness its opening splash. True to the troupes mission of presenting operas in unconventional settings, the performance took place on the Asia Plaza Stage at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Wandering and Waiting for the Unknown
description: In the two works presented by Dagmar Spain and her company, Dance Imprints, at Danspace Project from Thursday through Saturday, the best performance was given by Alec Dana. For the first few minutes of the first piece, Mr. Dana, an elegant older gentleman, sat silent and dignified as he was berated by the actor Iorgo Papoutsas. After that Mr. Dana left, never to appear again.

title: Rooms Where Norman Bates Would Feel at Home
description: Functional is all Im looking for. So announces the hustling copier salesman, Mark (Mike Shapiro), about his modest expectations for overnight accommodations. Its a low bar, but sorry, mister, youve checked into the wrong establishment.

title: How Gulbis Defeated Berdych: His Second Serve
description: Ernests Gulbis edged sixth-seeded Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic in three straight tiebreakers at Wimbledon on Monday, in a clash of two of the biggest hitters on the tour. Gulbis played boldly, hitting an astonishing 62 winners while committing only 33 unforced errors. The talented Latvian kept Berdych off balance with big serving and returning. Berdych, normally a power player who dominates points with his serve and forehand, was in the unusual position of having to react to Gulbis throughout the match. He managed only 30 winners (13 of which were aces) and had 27 unforced errors.

title: Math Prodigy, Too Smart by Half, Stuck in High-Strung Adolescence
description: Scott C. Emblers production of 7th Monarch, playing at the Acorn Theater, is directed with skill and capably acted by a smart if not always ideally cast ensemble. But while the story is absorbing, this odd mystery by Jim Henry has a whiff of stale psychodrama that overloads on sorrowful revelations with inadequate foreshadowing.

title: Computer Scientists Break Security Token Key in Record Time
description: For years private companies and government agencies have given their employees a card or token that produces a constantly changing set of numbers. Those devices became the preferred method of securing confidential communications online. No one could have access to the data without a secret key generated by the device.

title: Before The Newsroom, There Was The Newsroom

Its intended, in large part, as a critique of the news industry its venality, its superficiality and its overall intellectual laziness. All of which is exposed by Will McAvoy (played by Jeff Daniels), a mad-as-hell-and-not-taking-it-anymore news anchor who decides he can do better and an example of a stock Sorkin character type that The New Yorkers TV critic Emily Nussbaum calls The Great Man, a character who is theoretically flawed, but really a primal truth-teller whom everyone should follow (or date).

title: Two Days Contain a Multitude of Mood Swings

It was also divided by style. Saturday was devoted to electronics-loving, D.J.-rooted, dance-centered pop, headlined by the band Passion Pit and the rapper Kid Cudi. Sunday featured hand-played, guitar-centered rock from seasoned performers, headlined by Beck, Modest Mouse and Fiona Apple. But the festivals two-day passes were sold out; marketers and radio stations notwithstanding, concertgoers dont confine themselves to categories.

title: Britain: Security Chief Offers Assessment About Olympics
description: A month before the start of the Olympic Games, the chief of Britains domestic security service, MI5, offered a guarded reassurance on Monday about the risk of terrorist attacks during the 17-day spectacle in Britain. No doubt some terrorists have thought about whether they could pull off an attack, Jonathan Evans, MI5s director general, told an audience in London. But the Games are not an easy target, and the fact that we have disrupted multiple terrorist plots here and abroad in recent years demonstrates that the United Kingdom as a whole is not an easy target. British officials will deploy a security force of more than 25,000 for the Games, and Mr. Evans cited the extremely generous security assistance given by friendly countries, an allusion to an Olympic security unit run by F.B.I. and C.I.A. officials. He said security officials had assessed the current threat of a terrorist strike in Britain as substantial, meaning that an attack is a strong possibility. But he noted that the threat assessment was one notch lower than it had been for most of the period since the 2001 attacks in the United States. There is no such thing as guaranteed security, he said. But I think we shall see a successful and memorable Games.

title: California: Bankruptcy Looms for City at End of Mediation
description: State-mandated mediation between the City of Stockton and its creditors was set to expire at midnight on Monday, moving the Central Valley community one step closer to becoming the largest city in the country to go bankrupt. If the 90-day mediation fails, the City Council is set to vote Tuesday evening on a new budget to cover a $26 million deficit in case of bankruptcy. City officials would then have until July 1 to officially file for bankruptcy protection. Once a booming bedroom community for San Francisco Bay Area commuters, the city was hard hit by falling housing prices, enduring one of the highest foreclosure rates in the country. Since 2009, the city has cut some $90 million from its budget, including deep cutbacks to municipal staff, police and fire departments.

title: Massachusetts: Bulger Trial Delayed
description: Lawyers for James (Whitey) Bulger on Monday won a four-month delay in his trial and told a judge that a deal between their client and the government renders him immune from prosecution, and that they will seek to have charges against Mr. Bulger dropped. Mr. Bulger, who prosecutors said acted as an F.B.I. informer while playing a leading role in Bostons crime underworld, faces charges including 19 murders at a trial now scheduled to begin March 4, 2013. His lawyers said they need more time to prepare his defense. Mr. Bulger was captured last summer in Santa Monica, Calif., after spending 16 years in hiding with his girlfriend, Catherine Greig, who was recently sentenced to eight years in prison on charges of harboring a fugitive.

title: Florida: Zimmerman Seeks Another Chance at Freedom on Bond

In a motion filed with the Seminole County Circuit Court, the lawyer, Mark OMara, said his client is not a flight risk and takes responsibility for his role in not alerting the judge about tens of thousands of dollars in donations made to an online fund that he had set up before his first bond hearing in April. Bail was revoked for Mr. Zimmerman on June 1 after prosecutors told the court that he and his wife, Shellie Zimmerman, 25, had misled the court about their finances and had spoken to each other in code about the estimated $125,000 in donations. The second bond hearing is scheduled for Friday.

title: 5 Percent of Job Programs Fail Test on Graduates Success

Starting next fall, schools that fail all three tests for three of four consecutive years will lose their access to federal aid.

title: The Mediterranean Sea, Singing Along in Italy
description: Paola Prestini has been at work on Oceanic Verses, a multimedia folk opera, since Carnegie Hall commissioned part of it for a composers and singers workshop in 2009. She presented a section of it at New York City Operas Vox readings last year, and offered the New York premiere of the finished piece on Monday evening at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University, as part of the adventurous River to River Festival.

title: Three Dishes at Pok Pok Ny
description: Andy Ricker has been traveling to Thailand since 1987, and at some point he started to fall for the cuisine of the countrys north in a way that knocked his life and his career in new directions. Back home in Portland, Ore., he began grilling chickens stuffed with lemon grass in his driveway; customers would carry it over to his picnic table and sit down. This unconventional set-up evolved into Pok Pok, Mr. Rickers acclaimed Thai restaurant, which he has attempted to recreate on Columbia Street in south Brooklyn. That restaurant, Pok Pok Ny, is the subject of my restaurant review this week; a few days ago, I interviewed Mr. Ricker by phone to get some background on three of the restaurants best dishes.

title: In Dimitrov, Winning Echoes of Federer
description: The rapidly improving Bulgarian Grigor Dimitrov, nicknamed Baby Fed by tennis observers, made a telling comment in his news conference after his upset win over 32nd-seeded Kevin Anderson. When asked about comparisons between his game and Roger Federers, Dimitrov, while acknowledging the great compliment, gave an honest assessment of his game: Ive not got to the second week of a Grand Slam yet and have not won an ATP event or reached the top 20  I need to progress a lot and cant cut any corners.

title: Sothebys Contemporary Sale Makes $108 Million

The auction house had packed the sale with 79 paintings, sculptures, drawings and prints, mostly by artists who have brought top prices in recent seasons. But while the salesroom was filled with an international crowd of dealers and collectors, the evening could best be described as more solid than exciting.

title: Jesus Christ Superstar and Memphis Closing
description: Another major Broadway musical is closing in what is shaping up to be a summer of housecleaning at New York theaters. Memphis, which won the Tony Award for best musical in 2010, will close at the Shubert Theater on Aug. 5 after 30 previews and 1,166 performances, the shows producers announced on Tuesday. The musical will have had a fairly long run by todays standards, but ticket sales have been uneven, with the show grossing a relatively modest $541,602 last week (or 44 percent of the maximum possible amount). Separately on Tuesday, a spokeswoman for the Broadway revival of Jesus Christ Superstar confirmed that that show would close on Sunday after a run of 24 previews and 116 performances. The musical opened in March to mixed reviews and never caught on at the box office.

title: Columbia Unveils Med School Building
description: The architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro has designed a 14-story tower of study and social spaces that will be Columbia University Medical Centers new medical and graduate education building in Washington Heights. The design, to be released on Wednesday, is unorthodox for a medical school not only in its verticality and sculptural treatment of exposed interiors but also, according to the architects, in its reflection of a more collaborative, team-based mode of teaching. Gensler is the architectural firm of record for the building, working with the Diller team on technical aspects of the project, including construction documents. Construction  to begin in early 2013 and take about three and a half years  will be supported by a previously announced lead gift of $50 million from Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, an alumnus of Columbias medical school, and his wife, Diana Vagelos. The design incorporates an auditorium; event areas; student lounges; cafes; and outdoor spaces, including a terrace with views of the Hudson River. The building is to be the central hub for the students pursuing medical and doctoral degrees at Columbias College of Physicians and Surgeons and will also serve Columbias three other medical schools and the biomedical departments of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

title: Children in Prison for Life
description: The Supreme Courts ruling this week prohibiting mandatory sentences of life without parole for juveniles convicted of murder is a measured and important step in a trend in juvenile justice begun more than two decades ago. The court left open the possibility that minors under age 18 could be sentenced to life without parole  but only if the sentencing judge has made an individualized finding that such a penalty is appropriate, weighing the defendants characteristics and the details of the crime.

title: The Old Neighborhood
description: If youve lived for long in New York City, chances are youve lived in several different places. On the map of where we dwell now is also where we used to dwell, just across the park, a borough away, a few subway stops farther north or south. That is one of the peculiarities of this city  the proximity of our geographical past. Some people move from Ohio to Oregon. We move from 93rd to 13th, from Alphabet City to Carroll Gardens, all over town.

title: Inquiry Looks Into a Shield for Donors in Elections

Schneiderman of New York has begun investigating contributions to tax-exempt groups that are heavily involved in political campaigns, focusing on a case involving the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which has been one of the largest outside groups seeking to influence recent elections but is not required to disclose its donors.

title: Investigation Finds No Violations by Nuclear Head
description: A report by the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, released Tuesday, has found that the commissions chairman did not exceed his authority in directing his agencys response to the Fukushima Daiichi meltdown last year in Japan, despite his colleagues complaints over his management. The chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, has said he will resign as soon as a successor is sworn in, probably next week. The inspector general has investigated a variety of actions, but the new report does not find any clear violations. It said Dr. Jaczko had broken with past practice by seeking to change the recommendations of the commission staff, and that he limited staff communications with the other four commissioners in a way that was inconsistent with the commissioners expectations. His behavior was not supportive of an open and collaborative work environment, the report said. Dr. Jaczko denied any wrongdoing.

title: Rangel Fends Off Challengers to Win a Congressional Primary

No other quadruped or biped comes close. Galloping quarter horses top out around 47 miles per hour, while sluggish humans, in the person of the world record 100-meter sprinter Usain Bolt, have attained a top speed of less than 28 miles per hour. Even the bullet-trainlike greyhound, similar in build and running style to the cheetah, doesnt surpass 40 miles per hour.

title: Stone Links: A Constellation of Philosophers
description: Here is an intriguing map of philosophical space at the statistics blog Drunks and Lampposts, drawn in terms of the fields leading lights. The map looks much like a chart of the heavens, but lines of influence are what define the size and position of each node. The raw data was culled from the influenced by section for the pages of all the philosophers listed in Wikipedia  using an algorithm. The images are startling, and the map does seem to give many of the big thinkers what seems to be intuitively the right size and location (though one does notice Descartes star must be too small relative to his influence). But it is unclear how effective the algorithm is at saying something meaningful about the history of philosophy and, correlatively, the history of ideas. One also wonders what a similar map drawing on the data in, say, The Stanford Encylopedia of Philosophy, would look like.

title: Cooper-Hewitt Picks Design Team to Help With Its Expansion

Local Projects, a design firm, will also be part of the team and responsible for the museums digital offerings. The renovations of the museums Carnegie Mansion are part of a $64-million capital campaign. This project gives Cooper-Hewitt the opportunity to re-invent itself, to rethink museum conventions and the entire museum visit, said Caroline Baumann, associate director of the museum. Were delighted to be working with DS+R and Local Projects in creating a distinctly contemporary vision that will serve as a model for a new type of museum. While the renovations are underway, Cooper-Hewitt, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution, is offering exhibitions and educational programs at the Cooper-Hewitt Design Center in Harlem, the Enid and Lester Morse Historic Design Lecture Series at the University Club, and elsewhere. The museum on East 91st Street at Fifth Avenue is scheduled to re-open in 2014.

Marvels The Avengers which opened on May 4, reached $300 million in domestic ticket revenue faster than any other movie in history and tied the record for fastest $1 billion worldwide gross. On Tuesday, Sony will unleash the newest version of another venerable Marvel property, The Amazing Spider-Man, followed later in the month by The Dark Knight Rises, a Warner Brothers release and the third (and possibly the last) of Christopher Nolans Batman movies. The summer of 2012 is hardly unusual. The current superhero boom dates to the dawn of the century  Bryan Singers X-Men came out in 2000, Sam Raimis Spider-Man in 2002  and shows no sign of abating. Scientists were surprised to find that these hominins apparently lived almost exclusively on a diet of leaves, fruits, wood and bark.

title: Finding Childhood Independence in the Sabbath
description: Wherever I move, I always know which neighborhood I want to live in. I dont aim for proximity to organic freshly roasted coffee, a Whole Foods or Trader Joes, or even a park and green space, but to a synagogue. One day a week my family forgoes modern methods of transit and reverts to the primal ways of our ancestors by walking wherever it is we want to go, which makes it necessary for us to live in walking distance to our place of worship.

title: Andy Murrays Osmolarity Is Looking Good So Far
description: Andy Murrays demeanor has been dogging him lately. Yesterday, before Nikolay Davydenko took the court for his first-round match at Wimbledon against Murray, the British press was full of Davydenkos comments about Murrays on-court affect and his tendency to put his hurt on display. We just laugh sometimes, The Sun (among others) quoted Davydenko as saying. Sometimes he walks on court, he looks tired, like he doesnt want to run anymore, and then he runs like an animal. He has done that all his career. He just walks and hes like, Ah, I dont want to play any more. Then he starts returning and running, and you see his condition is very good. Maybe it is a special Scottish thing.

title: Alec Baldwin Returning to Broadway in Spring 2013
description: After seven seasons playing the charismatic, controlling network executive  Jack Donaghy on the NBC comedy 30 Rock, Alec Baldwin will return to Broadway in spring 2013 in a much darker show  but in a role that is no less charismatic or controlling. Mr. Baldwin will portray Harold, a mobster who is kidnapped and held by two troubled brothers in Lyle Kesslers 1983 drama Orphans, the shows producers said on Wednesday. The play will be directed by the Tony Award winner Daniel Sullivan (The Columnist, Proof), who is also staging a Broadway revival of Glengarry Glen Ross this fall.

title: For a Blonde Like That, Why Not Be Someone Else?
description: As his uproarious 1983 play Noises Off so nimbly demonstrated, Michael Frayn is a master of that most frantic of genres: the door-slamming, coincidence-splattered, slapstick-studded genre of farce. With his latest novel, Skios, Mr. Frayn tries to translate farce from the theater to the page  with somewhat mixed results. The novel is immensely entertaining, sometimes laugh-out-loud funny, but its also a pretty flimsy production, with an unsatisfying and jerry-built conclusion.

The room was packed tight, and the air thick with anticipation: this would be Mr. Ribots first engagement as a leader at the Vanguard, which is still a coveted milestone for almost any jazz musician. And his trio, with the bassist Henry Grimes and the drummer Chad Taylor, suggested both a convulsive departure from the clubs center-lane programming and the reverent ennobling of a chapter in its history.

Browsing Rights | Ommu in Athens
description: Its difficult, says Marina Legaki, summing up the current climate in Athens where she and her partner, Tasos Gaintatzis, run Ommu, a bookstore and arts space. Established in 2009 as a temporary shop in the corner of the Athens gallery AMP, Ommu now operates out of a newly renovated 1950s-era building all its own, specializing in hard-to-find (in Athens) international magazines like Kaleidoscope and Apartamento; monographs on artists like Dan Colen, Esther Tielemans and Fia Backstrom; and lesser-known publications like Movie List, a black and white facsimile of an original maquette by the late artist Dash Snow, released in zine form by Snows estate. Legaki, who studied psychology before moving into publishing, and Gaintitzis, a former photographer, first worked together in 2002, on the now-defunct Dynasty zine. Ommu also trades in limited-edition artworks and contemporary furniture  surrounding piles of books are psychedelic sculptures by the Greek artist Antonis Vathis and clever, modular benches by the German designer Manuel Raeder, all of which are for sale. Quick-fire exhibitions, the most recent of which featured works by the London design office Zak Group, take over any remaining white space on the walls.

title: Barbie, Not Ken, Does Repairs Here

The women were frustrated by the gender imbalance in their classes, Ms. Brooks said, and realized we could trace the initial spark for our interest in math and science to the toys that we played with. title: California: Stockton Readies for Bankruptcy

When officials file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, which could happen this week, Stockton will be countrys largest city to go bankrupt. The budget, approved Tuesday night, will suspend debt payments, cut employee pay and reduce retiree benefits, allowing the city of about 292,000 residents to continue providing essential services through the bankruptcy process. After nearby Vallejo, Calif., filed for bankruptcy in 2008, state lawmakers passed legislation requiring cities to hire a third-party mediator to negotiate with creditors before filing for bankruptcy. Stockton officials had hoped to avoid bankruptcy when the city entered into 90 days of mediation in March. But on Monday, the city and its creditors failed to meet a deadline for a deal.

title: Image of the Day: June 28
An Armchair Revolution, and Barbie, Too
description: IT was the video that went viral before there was such a thing as viral video. Todd Hayness Superstar, released in 1987, was a darkly campy and experimental biopic about Karen Carpenter, who rose to fame with her brother, Richard, in the 70s pop group the Carpenters, and who fought a protracted battle with anorexia nervosa before her death at 32 in 1983. In the film characters were portrayed by plastic dolls, including Barbies, that looked as if theyd been plucked from a garage-sale free bin. Running 43 minutes, Superstar was a phenomenon, but not at the multiplex. It was shown primarily in galleries, museums and clubs, though it had a theatrical life at some repertory houses. Eventually it was copied and widely traded on bootleg VHS tapes, available for rent at alternative video stores across the country.

Which park will build the fastest, tallest, scariest, weirdest or most-talked-about coaster of the summer? Park officials plug away at research, and engineers tinker with formulas to come up with rides they hope will turn heads and raise arms.

title: Romney Campaign Unleashes Coordinated Response to Court Ruling
description: Moments after the Supreme Court ruled on President Obamas health care law, Lanhee Chen, the policy director for Mitt Romney, sent an e-mail to about three dozen senior Republicans on Capitol Hill and in state attorneys generals offices.

title: Aid Workers Detained in Myanmar
description: GENEVA  The United Nations and several humanitarian agencies that operate in Myanmar said Thursday that a number of their staff members had been detained by the government in a part of the country where sectarian violence erupted this month, and that they were trying to secure their release.

title: A Vindication, With a Legacy Still Unwritten
description: WASHINGTON  For Barack Obama, who staked his presidency on a once-in-a-generation reshaping of the social welfare system, the Supreme Courts health care ruling is not just political vindication. It is a personal reprieve, leaving intact his hopes of joining the ranks of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan as presidents who fundamentally altered the course of the country.

title: Two Couples Collide, With a Roman Beauty as Muse and Catalyst
description: Not long after Philippe Garrels languid, emotionally raw film A Burning Hot Summer opens, its lonely beauty, Frdric (Louis Garrel, the directors son), dies. Hes first seen standing next to his BMW at a gas station, taking pulls from a flask, his hair and clothes disheveled. He looks more distracted than disturbed, but a few beats later, when hes speeding behind the wheel down a dark highway, you see that his eyes are glassy.

title: With Style, Balotelli Sends Italy to Final
description: WARSAW  The Germans have never beaten the Italians in a major soccer tournament, and after what happened here in Polands new National Stadium on Thursday night, they must wonder whether they ever will.

description: BRUSSELS  Working through the night in the face of pressure from the embattled euro zone countries Italy and Spain, European leaders agreed early Friday to use the Continents bailout funds to recapitalize struggling banks directly, according to the European Council president, Herman Van Rompuy.

title: Old Man of Rock Takes a Road Trip
Picking the Right College, Even if Youve Never Heard of It
description: Ariha Setalvad, who is studying journalism and psychology as an undergraduate at New York University, was raised in India and graduated from B.D. Somani International School in Mumbai. She is a summer intern on The Choice blog.

title: Spying on a Half-Sister Right Under Her Nose
description: The jittery opening scenes of People Like Us capture the high anxiety that is epidemic in the modern workplace with the clattering velocity of an action film. Sam Harper (Chris Pine), a motormouthed New York salesman of remaindered merchandise, is called on the carpet for a costly mistake in the transportation of a shipment of canned soup. Amid the brouhaha, a bigger screw-up comes to light, and for the rest of the movie he is hounded by telephone threats from the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Photo Replay: June 28
description: A view of the day in sports, with track-and-field action in Helsinki and tennis in England.

title: With Venice as Backdrop, Players Glide Among Their Relationships
description: The characters on the constant move in Unforgivable, the latest from the French director Andr Tchin, often seem to be heading toward one another, yet for all their movement forward, it can be hard for them to connect. They go in and out of homes, boats and beds, a rhythmic to-ing and fro-ing matched by the ebbing and flowing of the surrounding water. Set in a less touristy if still impressively lovely Venice than often appears onscreen, the film can seem as if its as unmoored as with all these people coming and going, as if Mr. Tchin had no particular destination in mind for these restless souls.

title: American Wrestler Kicked Off Team
description: The American wrestler Stephany Lee, who celebrated her Olympic trials victory in Iowa two months ago by marrying her longtime girlfriend, has been bumped from the team for testing positive for marijuana.

title: 10-Year Sentence for Lawyer in Terrorism Case Is Upheld
description: A panel of federal judges in Manhattan upheld the 10-year prison sentence imposed on Lynne F. Stewart, the disbarred lawyer convicted in a terrorism case who had been resentenced to that term after boasting that she could do a much shorter sentence standing on my head.

title: Assad, in Taped TV Interview, Calls Iran a Wise Friend
description: TEHRAN  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria thanked Iran as one of the wise governments seeking to protect Syrian stability in the face of the uprising against him, he said in a taped interview broadcast Thursday on Iranian state television.

title: Roberts Shows Deft Hand as Swing Vote on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has a favorite quotation from one of the giants who preceded him on the Supreme Court. Assessing the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. once wrote, is the gravest and most delicate duty that this court is called on to perform.

title: Brooklyn Prosecutors Role in Abuse Case Is Examined
description: For years, Avrohom Mondrowitz counseled children out of his home in the Borough Park neighborhood of Brooklyn. He was host of a call-in radio show popular among ultra-Orthodox Jewish listeners, claiming to be a rabbi and psychologist. But law enforcement officials say Mr. Mondrowitz, who fled to Israel in 1984 to avoid arrest, was also something else: a compulsive pedophile.

title: Seven Consequences of the Health Care Ruling
description: I have had some bitter disappointments as president,Harry S. Truman wrote in his memoirs, but the one that has troubled me most, in a personal way, has been the failure to defeat the organized opposition to a national compulsory health insurance program. He was just the first in a long line of presidents stymied by health reform. NowBarack Obama has succeeded where his predecessors failed. Or has he?

title: A Growing Black Market for Body Parts
description: With Europe roiled by financial upheaval, experts say the black market for selling human organs is expanding as vulnerable, desperately poor people seek to sell their body parts.

title: Black Market for Body Parts Spreads Among the Poor in Europe
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Pavle Mircov and his partner, Daniella, nervously scan their e-mail in-box every 15 minutes, desperate for economic salvation: a buyer willing to pay nearly $40,000 for one of their kidneys.

title: Will Googles Personal Assistant Be Creepy or Cool?
description: One day, people wont have to type queries into a box to search for information. Itll be delivered to them, via their various screens, based on where they are, who is nearby and what they might like and need to know.

title: Live Music, Hot Food, Hot Sauce
description: ITS a warm June night on Liberty Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens, a flat half-mile past the last stop on the A train. Inside what looks like a low, neon-lighted diner, a West Indian band has just taken its set break, and a tassa drum ensemble assembles in an alcove, four men loosely circled, between mirrored walls and beneath pinpoints of green and red light.

title: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds
description: An anonymous survey of nearly 2,000 retired officers found that the manipulation of crime reports  downgrading crimes to lesser offenses and discouraging victims from filing complaints to make crime statistics look better  has long been part of the culture of the New York Police Department.
